course_title: How to be a Tool: Storytelling Across Disciplines 001
best_comment: Zack and Davone and Julia were phenomenal!!! One of the best classes I've taken at Harvard, and created such a good community/group for thinking about what it truly means to produce art/creative content. Loved it, strongly strongly recommend!

course_title: How to be a Tool: Storytelling Across Disciplines 001
best_comment: Zack and Davone and Julia were phenomenal!!! One of the best classes I've taken at Harvard, and created such a good community/group for thinking about what it truly means to produce art/creative content. Loved it, strongly strongly recommend!

course_title: Introduction to African American Studies LEC
best_comment: This is a great intro course. The materials is super interesting, the professors and tfs are super nice and the course is not stressful and doesn't take up a lot of time outside of class. Everyone at Harvard should take this class.
worse_comment: you will learn so many disturbing things, be prepared to be outraged and upset, do not pass up on this class!
best_gem_comment: Please take this class; It is a gem and very laidback.
subject: African & African Amer Studies

course_title: Introduction to African American Studies LEC
best_comment: This is a great intro course. The materials is super interesting, the professors and tfs are super nice and the course is not stressful and doesn't take up a lot of time outside of class. Everyone at Harvard should take this class.
worse_comment: you will learn so many disturbing things, be prepared to be outraged and upset, do not pass up on this class!
best_gem_comment: Please take this class; It is a gem and very laidback.
subject: African & African Amer Studies

course_title: Social Justice and the Documentary Film LEC
best_comment: It's very interesting and lowkey until the last couple of weeks, which get really crazy as you're trying to put your own short film together. Very participatory and the professor is super cool

course_title: Black Womens Voices in the #MeToo Era LEC
best_comment: I'm so glad I was able to take this class now as this is Dr. Chaver's last year teaching because this class is truly everything. Dr. Chavers cares so deeply, not just about what her students have to say but how they feel. I've never had a space to talk about what it means to be a Black woman or how powerful blackness is and Dr. Chavers offered me that space in the most comforting way. she is very conscious of current events and takes the time to weave modern–day life into each and every discussion. the one book a week requirement seemed daunting but all the books were relevant and not difficult to get through. weekly discussion posts, as well as one class discussion presentation, made the overall semester feel more focused on what we actually had to say rather than arbitrary grades. I was never worried about my grades but rather focused on what my classmates had to say about topics such as survival and resistance, afro–futurism, and race in politics. in the end, the final essay was made optional but reflecting on the growth of my discussion posts showed me just how much this class taught me. if this class is ever offered again I cannot stress how much you should take it. if you're remotely interested in intersectionality, black feminism, and African American history, this is the class for you. loved every second of it.
worse_comment: Absolutely take this class if you can. No reservations.

best_comment: This is a great class to take if you are looking for an introduction into hip hop history and culture. The course looks at scholarship that connects hip hop to criminalization/mass incarceration, feminism, globalization, capitalism, and other interesting related topics. While the lectures could be somewhat improved in structure, the in–class student presentations, guest speakers, and discussion sections were highlights of the class.
best_gem_comment: This class is definitely a gem––you get to talk about music (for Black people its a space to just talk about your culture which is always nice) and learn about how hiphop is interpreted/felt by intellectuals.

best_comment: Professor Carpio is a brilliant reader and teacher. The syllabus is great, and she connects all the texts to each other & places them in U.S. history, showing their influence not only on the world of literature but the on the world in general. She shows how the writers of these works are not just authors, but theologians and politicians and comedians as well. Most of the course work is reading with a few short responses, which can be creative so they can actually be pretty enjoyable! Even if you've read some of the stuff on the syllabus, it's definitely worth it to read through them again with Professor Carpio– she will definitely open your eyes to some things you've never noticed before.
worse_comment: Take this course!! I cannot recommend it highly enough.

best_comment: Try and listen as best you can to the class. It’s interesting and you can learn a lot.
subject: African & African Amer Studies

course_title: Africa Rising? New African Economies/Cultures and Their Global Implications 001
best_comment: It is a fun class to take, Discussions are really good and it is a low time commitment. Professor and TF know what they are doing and they do their best to make the class engaging.
This class is not hard, but it wasn't taught this best way so take it with reservations
worse_comment: Do NOT take this course. It is not worth the stress and frustration dealing with an unorganized instructor.
subject: Igbo

best_comment: Learning a new language is never easy, but the close, small community and personable way that Swahili is taught in this class makes it such a rewarding, great experience. Professor Mugane is amazing and so funny and really brings the class together (sometimes over food :) ) so you enjoy coming to class each time. You will be amazed at the progress you can make over just one short year! Highly recommend!
subject: Swahili

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Taiwo is an amazing instructor who will put your needs as a student above all else. The class is fascinating and is equally about the culture of West Africa (which I had very little knowledge of prior to the class) as it is about West African pidgin itself. The assignments are fun and not overly difficult, but also useful. I recommend taking this class with a friend or two as it makes the group assignments/projects really enjoyable. Overall, taking West African Pidgin (more affectionately known as WAP) was the best decision of my freshman year, hands down.
subject: West African Pidgin

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Taiwo is an amazing instructor who will put your needs as a student above all else. The class is fascinating and is equally about the culture of West Africa (which I had very little knowledge of prior to the class) as it is about West African pidgin itself. The assignments are fun and not overly difficult, but also useful. I recommend taking this class with a friend or two as it makes the group assignments/projects really enjoyable. Overall, taking West African Pidgin (more affectionately known as WAP) was the best decision of my freshman year, hands down.
subject: West African Pidgin

best_comment: In this course, you have a teacher that is actually concerned with you learning and your progress. There are different parts to learning a language: reading, writing, grammar, and speaking, and while these things can be overwhelming in a language, Professor Taiwo goes at a good pace, and really adapts the class to student needs. You will learn a lot, outside of the language, and about language in general, but make sure to do the work and stay on top of things so you can benefit and won't have to stress a lot when it comes to exams.
subject: Yoruba

best_comment: Ensure you don't fall behind as it will be challenging in the end
subject: Zulu

course_title: Sophomore Tutorial: Anthropology as Social Theory and the Social Theory of Anthropology 001
best_comment: This class is really amazing. Mala is an absolutely incredible professor. She is so caring and thoughtful in designing the course. Theory seems really daunting and it is not always the most fun, and can be a lot of reading, but Mala makes it really interactive, interesting, and relevant.
subject: Anthropology
course_title_2023: Sophomore Tutorial: Anthropology as Social Theory and the Social Theory of Anthropology

course_title: Junior Tutorial for Thesis Writers in Anthropology 001
best_comment: Great way to fulfill an archaeology elective requirement! Very helpful for your thesis and tailored to you.
subject: Anthropology
course_title_2023: Junior Tutorial for Thesis Writers in Anthropology

course_title: Thesis Tutorial in Anthropology - Senior Year 001
best_comment: This class provides a great community while you're going through the thesis–writing process. Take advantage of your connections with your peers. I found it really helpful to meet with a fellow student also writing in medical anthropology ~5 days before the thesis was due. We spent a couple of hours sitting together reading each other's full drafts, and then we provided each other comments. This was so helpful, it it shaped how I devoted my energy in the final 5 days of revisions. Also, your course head and section leader are fantastic resources who will provide indispensable feedback on your draft chapters if you simply reach out to them. Don't wait until the last month to seek feedback from the course head! Just because he/she won't be commenting on your submissions to Canvas, you can still reach out to him/her to seek feedback.
subject: Anthropology
course_title_2023: Thesis Tutorial in Anthropology - Senior Year

course_title: Game of Stones: The Archaeology of Europe from Handaxes to Stonehenge 001
best_comment: I took this class for the great pun, but stayed because prehistory from the Paleolithic to the Bronze Age is really interesting, at least when professor Clark tells it. The assignments are really fun (although not entirely easy) and the small class size really helps to encourage interesting discussions about course topics. You won't regret taking this class!

course_title: Archaeology of Harvard Yard II: Laboratory Methods and Analysis 001
best_comment: As a senior, I can say that this is the best class I have ever taken at Harvard. Along with its Fall counterpart, you learn so much in the classroom and you look forward to both class and section! The teaching staff genuinely cares about you and wants you to succeed and by the time the class is over, you actually make an impact in the field of archaeology through your interpretations of what you excavated. Truly such a unique opportunity and one of my favorite times at Harvard!!

course_title: American Invasions: Archaeological Tales of Encounter, Exploration, and Colonization, 1492-1830 001
best_comment: This class is WONDERFUL! If you are curious at all about early American history, first contact history in the American continent, or Indigenous Studies, this class is for you! No experience needed, interesting lectures and readings, amazing professor! Section with our TF, Jess, was also AMAZING but she will not be teaching at Harvard next year. This class is really so great, my one piece of advice is to make sure to take notes!! When exam time comes around you have to study broadly, and there will not be any content notes on the lecture slideshows (only images/data/etc.) This class will not be your most intensive of the semester, but it will be interesting and fun! Highly recommend!

Take this class! It was definitely one of my favorite courses that I have taken at Harvard. A lot of studying is needed to do well, but you are somewhat forced to space this out due to the quizes. The studying is not so bad as long as you have an interest in osteology and develop good study habits early on (highly recommend Anki or some other way of doing flashcards). The practical component of this course was super interesting because we applied knowledge from lecture directly to real bones and/or casts of real bones. Harvard can be very draining academically, but this course has genuinely reinvigorated my academic spirit. Overall, super highly recommend!!!
worse_comment: While there are some sections of the course that is feel very fast, it does get broken down in the hands–on components very well. The lecture slides are posted, so you can use time in class just to absorb information.

course_title: Religious Dimensions in Human Experience: Apocalypse, Home, Medicine, Music, Sports, Sacrifice 001
best_comment: This course is perfect for people curious about how religion works in life and society. The readings are very interesting, but long. I struggled to finish them, but skimmed the best I could. Even so, I was still able to contribute what I knew and make connections. Work hard on the midterm! Pedro is a great resource for making sure that your understanding of course concepts is accurate. I enjoyed doing my creative project and would highly recommend that instead of the final since I was able to talk about the course topics that were most interesting to me, the ones that I paid the most attention to over the semester.
subject: Anthropology
course_title_2023: Religious Dimensions in Human Experience: Apocalypse, Sports, Music, Home, Sacrifice, Medicine

best_comment: Absolutely take this class if you're at all interested in the subject!! Professor Williams is brilliant and a wonderful teacher, and Assistant Professor Jubilee is the best canine co–teacher I've ever met.

course_title: The Anthropology of Power: Sovereignty, Hegemony, and Resistance 001
best_comment: Take this class if you have the opportunity to do so. If social anthropology or politics interest you in anyway whatsoever, you will enjoy this course. Professor Fierman is a joy to learn from and you will have the opportunity to blossom academically in this class.
subject: Anthropology
course_title_2023: The Anthropology of Power: Sovereignty, Hegemony, and Resistance

course_title: Neoliberalism: Empire, Extraction, and the Making of the Global Social Order 001
best_comment: I gained a really good understanding of neoliberalism m its history and how it shows up in all aspects of society. fantastic discussion and i learnt a lot from my peers. this course definitely challenged me but I think I am a better student for it – I was probably under prepared going into the course but I didn't drown and was able to takeaway A LOT. The professors are amazing and I would love to take another course by Salmaan Keshavjee, he is one of my two favourite professors at Harvard.  Reading a book a week was difficult but also a nice challenge and the books were all very interesting – especially the ones which demonstrated neoliberalism in different ways (technology, race, public health, pharmaceuticals)
worse_comment: You will leave questioning everything that you thought you knew (or didn't realize you needed to question) about the modern social, political, and economic order –– exactly what a transformative education ought to do.

course_title: Neoliberalism: Empire, Extraction, and the Making of the Global Social Order 001
best_comment: I gained a really good understanding of neoliberalism m its history and how it shows up in all aspects of society. fantastic discussion and i learnt a lot from my peers. this course definitely challenged me but I think I am a better student for it – I was probably under prepared going into the course but I didn't drown and was able to takeaway A LOT. best_comment: The course readings were super interesting, and I loved having some of the authors come as guest speakers. However, this felt more like a lecture than a seminar, which is what I was expecting. While I appreciate that Dr. Garza didn't assume any prior knowledge, it felt like that held us back from really engaging with the texts together.
subject: Anthropology

course_title: Anthropology of Mental Health, Mental Illness and Mental Health Care 001
best_comment: Please, please take this class. Professor Kleinman is a foundational figure in medical anthropology, and it is such a privilege to learn from him and the other members of the teaching team, who are fantastic. The anecdotes/kernels of wisdom that Professor Kleinman imparts makes the class feel like an education in life. There aren't many professors left at Harvard who have been around long enough to observe the transformation of American society, higher education, anthropology, and psychiatry. He holds so much wisdom, and I feel so privileged to have been able to learn from him. Additionally, the course readings are fantastic; I never found it burdensome to read a book a week because the books were so fascinating and enjoyable. Michael is the most wonderful TF I've encountered in the social sciences at Harvard.
subject: Anthropology

course_title: Anthropology of Mental Health, Mental Illness and Mental Health Care 001
best_comment: Please, please take this class. Professor Kleinman is a foundational figure in medical anthropology, and it is such a privilege to learn from him and the other members of the teaching team, who are fantastic. Michael is the most wonderful TF I've encountered in the social sciences at Harvard.
subject: Anthropology

course_title: Where Science Meets Society: Introduction to STS 001
best_comment: This class was very interesting in that it really brought how social factors influence the facts that we learn in school and in academia in general. Great conversations and workload. Readings can sometimes be pretty dense but as long as you get the gist from each one that is enough to be able to actively participate. Got a little repetitive and boring in the second half of the semester but overall really enjoyed this class! Anna is amazing and a great facilitator of conversation.
subject: Anthropology
course_title_2023: Where Science Meets Society: Introduction to STS

best_comment: This is a wonderful class and great introduction to Anthropology. Dr. Choi is a fantastic instructor: the class was well–organized and operated at a predictable pace. I would recommend it to students from across departments who are interested in developing a more critical perspective towards how people engage with the future, and how our ideas about the future inform the present. In general, it offers a fun and intriguing survey of "futurist" trends, which will expand your imagination.

This is a really great course if you are interested in spaitail analysis and learning new software. You don't need to be a computer person to understand and take this course. The professors are really terrific and understanding. You do need to have a good sense of time management and it is definitley helpful if you come into the class with a research question already in mind that you can work on throughout the semester. Overall this course is fun and different and I recommend it.

I would suggest everyone with an interest in kinship, gender and sexuality to sign up for this course. Prof. Jabloner is a fantastic instructor and is great to work with to develop research ideas – she even held regular office hours throughout the semester.
subject: Anthropology

best_comment: a unique and enjoyable course!

course_title: Ethnographic and Critical Media Studies Approaches to Digital Media 001
best_comment: Take this class!!! You will learn so much not only about the material, but also about how to write and think about writing, how to craft an argument, and how to engage in research and this kind of work that is also about building a kind of toolkit for the kinds of worlds we aspire for and hope to build/subvert/etc. The vibe of the class is really wonderful and, in large part because of the tone Gabriella set, I felt like I was able to learn so much from my classmates and the kinds of disciplinary and personal insights they brought into their writings and discussions.

I would highly, highly recommend this class for anyone who wants to have space to critically reflect on research methods as a whole (not solely in anthropology, but relevant to a range of disciplines). The class offers structure (i.e. weekly reading responses, practical activities) if you want that, and also offers a lot of space/openness/fluidity in the discussions and in your way of going about the activities and assignments (there are specific prompts if you find that helpful, but also a broader orienting question that you can approach how you like). The readings are amazing!!! And Kaya is wonderful and really makes space for curiosity and genuine conversation in the class.

course_title: Data Science 2: Advanced Topics in Data Science 001
best_comment: Honestly, this is a fantastic course. I know people may have qualms about the last few problem sets, but the topics were extremely topical and relevant to modern machine learning/data science literature. Topics like GANs, Word2Vec, BERT (transformers),  and hierarchical linear models are invaluable in my repertoire of skills and tools. While the psets could definitely be strengthened, I can't be mad at one of the few courses at Harvard that actually touch the edge of state of the art techniques. This class was a much needed breather from the vast amount of tiring classes that still cover support vector machines (and call it modern machine learning) and require pages of mathematical proofs. CS109b/AC209b gave me a ton of practice in just programming machine learning algorithms in Tensorflow and Pymc3, reading documentation, and doing cool projects on topics that are still being actively researched. After this class, I can go to any job or task and feel confident in applying these skills, while learning more on the way.
worse_comment: This class was quite a mess. The questions/ instructions on the assignments are incredibly unclear, so you usually waste so much time trying to figure out what you're supposed to do. This would be somewhat okay if the course staff would clarify questions quickly, but they were very nonresponsive on Ed and would not respond to any questions over the weekend. They were also incredibly selective in which Ed posts they would answer, which made me feel like members of the course staff didn't even know what was going on. It felt like the students were shouting at a brick wall when trying to get help.Several of the homework assignment toward the end of the class were ridiculously difficult and in some cases impossible –– I wasted ~20 hours once because the code the course staff provided to us was literally impossible to run and would not work. I often feel like students complain too much, but I think it was very warranted for this class. It was incredibly frustrating to spend over 40 hours on a homework assignment simply because students didn't know what the problem was actually asking them to do. Not to mention, there were so many typos in the homeworks. The undergrad TFs didn't seem super familiar with the assignments, but they did try to help when they could.Poor Chris Gumb needs a raise because he carried the class, and whoever wrote the assignments that made the experience so difficult for him should take him out to lunch
subject: Applied Computation
course_title_2023: Data Science 2: Advanced Topics in Data Science

course_title_2023: Data Science 2: Advanced Topics in Data Science

best_comment: The class material is great, but the grading scheme is like playing Russian Roulette. Pray you won't get a merciless TF!
worse_comment: Overall it's a good data science ethics course, but some of the lectures are hit–or–miss because students don't always engage. The in–class discussions, problem sets, and readings are all valuable.
subject: Applied Computation

course_title: Computational Science and Engineering Capstone Project 001
best_comment: Establish a good rapport with your team. When the project felt overwhelming, it was nice to know I had support from the people I was working with. Also, keep your expectations low for what you'll actually be able to accomplish in the time, since it's truly a very short amount of time.
This class is incredibly chill! But it's much more interesting when people contribute. It's good to come in with one comment or question about the material (even if you didn't understand it).
subject: Applied Computation

best_comment: I liked this course and think it's a really good alternative to the other math classes at this level (Math 21b, 22b, etc.). Fewer people take the applied math track, so the class is smaller, everyone knows each other, and you're more accountable for things like attendance. I thought the workload was really reasonable, but I'm still leaving with a good grasp of basic multivariable calculus. I do worry slightly that this course is a bit less rigorous –– not many proofs in the homework, for example –– so if you do want to get hardcore with math later in college, do consider taking a harder class. But especially if you're a freshman, this is a nice class that will challenge you and teach you what you need to know but not totally overwhelm you with impossible psets. I'd solidly recommend this and would take it again!
subject: Applied Mathematics

best_comment: This is a great introduction to applied math. It is not that hard of a class so you can easily coast by without really learning anything but if you engage in the material it can be quite fun and teach you a lot.
worse_comment: Work hard, you will get a lot out.
subject: Applied Mathematics

best_comment: This course was refreshing! I've always loved math prior to enrolling in college––taking this course reminded me of that, even as a non–math concentrator. This is my first applied math course at Harvard, and I could not be more excited to continue taking AM courses for my secondary. Professor Suo always came to lecture with great enthusiasm and passion for the subject, which I in turn felt while learning in class. I always looked forward to lecture. One of the things I loved most about this course was its particular pedagogy: it focused primarily on ensuring we learned and grew comfortable with applying mathematical relationships to real world examples. While we reviewed history and some theory, the problems and exams themselves emphasized application. Furthermore, I felt that all the quizzes were very representative of our understanding of the subject. Modeled closely after lecture and homework problems, the exams were never an unpleasant surprise and I felt that I not only could prepare well for them, but that I also learned a great deal while preparing for them. Overall, this course has one of the strongest teaching structures of all the courses I've taken thus far here at Harvard. I also really appreciated the Slack platform––it allowed for easy and quick communication with both the teach staff and with other students. Highly recommend this course!
worse_comment: This course is incredibly disorganized and poorly taught. For the first 2/3 of the course the material is generally easy but there's intermittently a homework question which involves content we have barely reviewed. The teaching staff often doesn't understand these types of questions. The end of the semester is very chaotic as the final was completely on content taught in the last two weeks of the course. Additionally, the lectures do a poor job preparing students for new questions and don't help to build a conceptual understanding of the content.
subject: Applied Mathematics

best_comment: This course is not for everyone. But if it is for you, it is extremely rewarding. You have to go to lecture. If you think that you are the type of student who might end up not attending lecture, don't take the course. The PSets are hard and take a while; they are always 5 problems, many of which are proof–based. (If you haven't done proofs before, this is not the class to learn how to do them.) The professor is very good, in a weird way. If you knew nothing about math and just listened to him, you would think the class is boring and slow. But really, lectures are fantastic if you are sufficiently engaged. His pace is perfect; not too slow, but not so fast. Such that you have enough time to take notes and think about the material to ask questions. And the topics are interesting, if you like math even just a little. Everyone I know liked the class; it's more the details around it that we didn't like. Of course, waking up early (it was at 9 am this year) is hard. And there were not enough TFs to help with the PSets, given how hard they were. Also, it is definitely not Applied, so I don't know why it is categorized as an Applied Math class. The topics are theoretical, and the fact that we are proving stuff confirms that.
subject: Applied Mathematics

best_comment: This class has a lot of components that require time and effort outside class but are very rewarding. Sarah is super flexible and an amazing instructor and really focuses on your understanding of the knowledge. Definitely a good choice for satisfying the Differential Equations req for AM
worse_comment: I would steer future students away from this course. This course was arguably the most demanding course of my Harvard experience so far. There were far too many minor assignments (pre–class assignments due before each class, in–class skill checks before each class, weekly problem sets), which made the course very difficult to catch up in if you happened to fall behind one week. Sarah is a great professor, but almost every assignment felt very tedious and stressful rather than helping me actually learn the necessary concepts. While the idea behind deciding your own grade may seem attractive, the amount of work and stress that this class causes arguably makes it not worth the hassle.
subject: Applied Mathematics

best_comment: I originally took this course to get honors without a thesis, but it honestly turned into one of my favorite AM classes at Harvard. This course was by far the most applicable math course I have taken, and I actually wish I had taken it my junior year, as I think I may have been more confident in writing a thesis with the experiences from this class under my belt. There are so many interesting topics you learn in this class, and my favorite part is that if you don't like one, the material moves quickly, and you don't need to apply any one given concept to your final projects. This class honestly changed the way I think about how math interacts with the real world, and I understand why it's a critical class for AM concentrators.I will say, it's rather important to get a good group for your project. I had a very dedicated, strong group, but I think if my group was less hard–working and cohesive, I may have liked this class less so. Overall, the concepts are super engaging, the material is useful, the professor and TFs are really kind, and I couldn't recommend this class more.
worse_comment: Take this class if you want to learn how to quantify and model problems using mathematical tools.
subject: Applied Mathematics

course_title: Applied Linear Algebra and Big Data 001
best_comment: Take AM120. If you hated Math 21b, this course offers a revival for your interest in linear algebra. Instead of being knee–deep in useless material such as linear spaces from 21b, you will instead take a dive into the concepts essential to machine learning and big data. Topics ranging from singular value decomposition, principal component analysis, neural networks (feedforward, back propagation), decision trees, random forests, etc. The material is levels above that of 21b and actually holds usefulness to fields in data science.Beware of the first pset. It is VERY LONG, so please for the love of Larry Bacow start it early, because I guarantee that you will regret staying up until 4am the night before it's due solving eigen–problems. However, the psets afterwards definitely do get better, and the homework help sessions are great for getting them done. The last three psets on neural networks are the most code–heavy out of all the psets. Also, DO THE PSETS IN MATLAB, it will make your life so much more convenient. MatLab literally stands for matrix laboratory, so it's like it was made for this class?!Lastly, I want to talk about the star of the show: Professor Eli Tziperman. Eli is a genuinely kind person to get to know. He cares about his students and whether or not they are motivated by the course. He tries really hard to engage students during lectures with jokes about himself and his family and other amusing topics you will find out (especially during the ODEs part of the course). He really wants you to succeed and have fun with the course, and that is what I love about him. However, lecture can be slow at times, and it sometimes gets hard to understand him. Though, he makes up for it by adding some motivating concepts during class by showing application areas for the concepts being taught. Eli is an awesome person, so definitely GO TO HIS OFFICE HOURS and take him out to Classroom 2 Table. Most importantly, figure out how to pronounce his name early on!First lecture, I thought this class had many red flags, including how there was going to a pset over spring break (crazy right?). However, as the semester was winding down, I learned to appreciate the course and the professor plus the teaching staff. I genuinely took a TON out of this course, more than from 21b. This is a class that I definitely recommend! Now, you may be thinking "this guy might just be smart and overstating the course." But listen to me, I was definitely NOT one of the smartest students taking the course. I struggled with the psets and quizzes from time to time, and I usually took longer to understand the concepts than others, especially during neural networks. However, this course is great. I urge to you to take it, because like you have definitely heard before, this course is extremely rewarding. By the end of the semester, you will look back at everything and appreciate how useful and fun this course was. So, definitely go to Eli's office hours, get to know him more, and pour some time into understanding the concepts. The ride will be a long one, but it's one that will be "interesting, useful, and fun" (you will understand the reference once you take the course :) ).
worse_comment: The material was fine, but the exams and homeworks in this class were really annoying and unsatisfying. There is a lot of work (12 psets) and much of the work is annoying and doesn't feel necessary. This is advertised as a "big data" class, but the exams and psets make you do by–hand calculations of matrix multiplication, eigenvalue computations, recursive problems, and other things that a computer can do instantly. If you have to take this class as an AM requirement it is fine, but there are likely better classes.
best_gem_comment: this class is a great overview of some very applicable algorithms, but it's not such a perfect gem as previous years may have implied. the psets rely heavily on matlab starter code that you have to modify, and unless you're already a pro at matlab and can write these algorithms from scratch, the pset process often becomes trying to modify matlab code and random bugs. best resources are office hours and the textbook (literally every answer you'll ever need is in that book). love this class for the toolbox of algorithms and eli (an actual gem of a human being), but if you're more interested in the "math" of the applied math, may suggest going somewhere else. this class is definitely very applied, with a good portion being memorization. overall okay class, but I might decide to stay clear of the AM concentration after this.
subject: Applied Mathematics
course_title_2023: Applied Linear Algebra and Big Data

best_comment: You learn a lot in this class, but it's also really challenging, so it might be best to take it only if you're comfortable with proofs. Yiling Chen is very knowledgeable and a good lecturer. The textbook is really good and although the exercises are hard, they teach you a lot.

course_title: Inverse Problems in Science and Engineering 001
best_comment: Michael Brenner is seriously the best professor. He motivated the importance of developing robust methods for solving inverse problems very well in this class. We developed a pretty comprehensive toolset during the class for tackling these types of problems, and I think this is a really good class if you want to expand your knowledge of computational tools that can be useful in a research settings. If you have taken more than one ML class or done ML research before, a lot of time is spent on these methods, so you might not get so much out of the class if you already know a lot.
worse_comment: This class is  disorganized and responses do not come quickly if you have questions outside of class time.

best_comment: Knowledge in control theory is not necessary, but you should know something about RL. I only knew a few basic definitions of control before this course, and it does not affect my understanding, since Lina had several lectures introducing the basic models. As for RL part, I think it presumably requires students to be familiar with basic RL concepts. So one of my friends who knows almost nothing about this topic dropped the course... Overall, I think this course is perfect for: (i) grad students completing their course requirements (workload is light compared to other numerical courses) (ii) students who have read some RL papers or textbooks, and would like to know more state–of–the–art works.

course_title: Physics as a Foundation for Science and Engineering, Part II 001
best_comment: TLDR:  Be honest with yourself. Want an A and nothing else? Take AP50a and b. Want to be pushed very hard but learn a lot of physics (and possibly get an A first semester)? Take PS2 and PS3. Want something in between, where you’ll learn some physics and still have a shot an A each semester? Take PS2 and AP50b.This class was the worst class I’ve ever taken at Harvard. I’d rather take orgo again than take AP50a or b again. That’s how much I hated this class. I never really got a chance to learn physics in high school because the physics program at my school wasn’t very strong and I was too afraid to take the class. This class excited me because it felt like a low pressure way to learn physics. This was anything but that. The sheer number of assignments makes it imposible to slow down and learn anything. If you miss an assignment, your focus becomes catching up, not learning. I’m walking away from this class having learned next to nothing. Now, every time I hear the word “physics” I am filled with AP50–related dread instead of excitement. Don’t get me wrong — the course staff are super friendly, knowledgeable and understanding, and they genuinely love teaching physics. The course structure is just incredibly flawed. For that reason, I think that your experience in AP50 comes down to what you want out of the class. If you want an A and you truly have no other desire out of a physics class, AP50 is the class for you. It will be the most tedious A you’ve ever gotten, but do what they ask and you’ll get an A.If you have the desire to learn, that probably will not happen for you in AP50.  You spend hours each week reading the textbook (which most people do not do because it is incredibly dense) and that is how you’re supposed to learn multiple complex topics (by yourself). Then, they suddenly expect you to apply skills that you supposedly learned from the textbook to 3 different assignments and 3 assignment revisions EVERY WEEK (luckily, you don’t need to get the answers right the first time). The problem is that you have no idea what was going on in the textbook, so you can’t really understand what is happening on assignments. All you can do is just enough to get by until the next week, where you do it all over again.  You do this day after day, week after week, until you become so tired and overrun that you stop trying to learn and you just do whatever they tell you to until you get your A. I’m not the only one who feels this way either. Every project group I was in talked about how much they couldn’t wait to just be done with the class. At the beginning and end of each semester, the course staff sends out a survey asking us “If you had to choose between learning a lot and getting a good grade, which would you choose?” If your answer is “learn a lot” and you’re depending on one class to teach you physics, this isn’t the class for you. If your answer is “get a good grade,” then there’s a spot in AP50 with your name on it. Although my GPA is better off now than it was last fall, I wish I had actually learned something. If I could go back, I think I would have chosen a different physics class.
worse_comment: If you took AP Physics E&M in high school, I strongly advise you against this class.  The content is very similar, and with the way that this class is structured, you will be drowning in busy work without learning much new content. There are 6 different deliverables each week, several of which are group assignments you have to schedule more meeting time for, and several of which are multi–hour assignments if you actually put effort into them.If you're an engineering student, I do NOT recommend this class. Most of the students in this class are bio/premed and physics is ...not their focus. It feels nice at the beginning to know a lot, but you end up having to take a lot of the slack from group members who don't know how to build things in the lab and aren't willing to put in the extra time to attend the trainings. This class was one of my worst experiences at Harvard because the time spent to new things learned ratio for me was very low. Also, the amount of effort I was willing to put into projects was not matched at all by my team members, several of whom were just putting in the bare minimum. The learning–from–your–peers model works well for students who don't know the material, but it's exhausting for the students who know more than their peers because they're pressured to act as TFs and teach others without even getting paid for it. :/
subject: Applied Physics
course_title_2023: Physics as a Foundation for Science and Engineering, Part II

subject: Applied Physics
course_title_2023: Physics as a Foundation for Science and Engineering, Part II

course_title: Physics as a Foundation for Science and Engineering, Part II 002
best_comment: This class can be great, but it can also be  a lot more time consuming than you expect. It's definitely harder than AP50A, and you may not learn the  concepts as well as you might with a lecture, but having a good group can make the class really fun, as can an interesting project, and the lack of exams and the mostly completion–based grading system makes for a pretty low–stress class. Also, Eric is incredibly nice, and the teaching team is very helpful if you reach out to them
worse_comment: TAKE IT TAKE IT! APPHY50 is a clusterfuck – tons of busywork, learning a bit from readings and spinning that into bullshit for 3 tasks until the week comes. Getting a solid A has never been easier, and if you try, you'll learn just as much and be 1000x less stressed than the girlies who decided to take PS2/PS3 bc they wanted to learn more.
subject: Applied Physics
course_title_2023: Physics as a Foundation for Science and Engineering, Part II

course_title: Physics as a Foundation for Science and Engineering, Part II 002

subject: Applied Physics
course_title_2023: Physics as a Foundation for Science and Engineering, Part II

course_title: Quantum and Classical Electromagnetic Interaction with Matter 001
best_comment: great lectures, Donhee is passionate about the subject, and the lecture notes are comprehensive
subject: Applied Physics
course_title_2023: Quantum and Classical Electromagnetic Interaction with Matter

best_comment: This class is perfect for grad students who want to gain a new technical skillset and who want a class that won't be so time consuming that it's hard to do research in parallel. The course staff are all amazing as well.
subject: Applied Physics

best_comment: You can do anything which can be liberating or daunting and at times, even both. If you are interested in getting out of your comfort zone and creating with your hands, then this class is just for you. It provides the freedom and structure necessary to complete projects of your liking. 10/10 would recommend to everyone!

AFVS 40A is one of the best classes to take at Harvard. You learn so much about how to take photos and analyze photography. In addition, you become so much more observant of your surroundings, and you become a lot more creative and imaginative. I also loved how helpful class critiques were because you get amazing feedback from your peers and the instructors in the class. Elle is also a great professor and very engaging. This course is even better with Elle, and I highly recommend to take this course.

This class has truly been the most amazing time. It was an absolute blast. I loved getting to know everyone in the class, going on field trips, and talking about art. I feel like I grew not only as a photographer, but also as a person. Hands down the best class I've ever taken in my life. Helped me tap into a creativity in me that had been long lost to psets and labs. Also helped me slow down to notice and enjoy little moments in life more. Sharon and Claude are kind, supportive, and kind of just the best people ever.
worse_comment: Don't hesitate because 'it might not fit in your schedule' – just take it

best_comment: The AFVS 50a/b series opened up the world of filmmaking for me ~ it was an amazing class, but prepare for a lotttt of time in the Sever basement. Working with physical film and sound was tedious at times, so make sure you have time in your schedule to go shoot on location and then sync and edit throughout the semester. I can't wait to use the skills to make more projects in the future. Ross, Anna, and Alfred have made me much more confident in my capabilities as a filmmaker.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: If you have an interest in documentary filmmaking, even if you have no prior experience, please consider taking this class!! It is a really good introductory class, and a great introduction to the AFVS community too. I think it's also really important that you are willing to dedicate time to your film, be it traveling down regularly to get new footage, or sifting through footage to get what you want, or spending time to rewatch your film and edit it. Also, I personally found carrying the camera and tripod around to be a real workout so be prepared for that Haha.

This course will be exactly what you make it. The more time you put in, the more satisfied you will be with the work you produce. That time commitment can be quite intense (especially toward the end of the semester with the final project) but I cannot understate how amazing the end result will be. Ruth and Sarah are incredibly knowledgeable, flexible, helpful, and caring instructors. Highly highly recommend this course if you have the time to commit yourself to it.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: Take this class! It's a great way to dive into film production! We're so lucky to have access to such great film equipment, and it's so fun to get out there and work on creative projects. I really recommend taking this course!

I think that I'd let students know that it's a really interesting class if you're truly interested in learning more on the topic. I think a number of my peers took the class with a passive interest in film. In the first few weeks, with a focus on unfamiliar silent film movements and theories, I think some of them lost interest in the course, as it wasn't necessarily what they were looking for. Their loss of interest in the course, however, not only affected them but also negatively affected their classmates like me as their mood towards the class could easily rub off on me. In short, I think this class is really beneficial if you get into it, but I think it's important for students to try out the first couple weeks of the course to know if it would fit them or not.
worse_comment: Very interesting, but lots of work towards the end of the semester (much more than you would expect!) and grading is harsh
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: I was really dissatisfied with this course as the sophomore tutorial for AFVS. I thought too much of the emphasis was on lecture and theory and really dense readings that could be summed up by secondary sources instead of dense primary sources—I just want to learn more about art, not read and analyze text like an English or history class. The assignments were cool but super infrequent and super vague, and while some people did a really cool job when we shared, some people didn't buy in as much which was less enjoyable. I was also really dissatisfied that so much of this content was focused on studio art and essentially way less or even nothing on film and photography and the visual studies element of AFVS, and because of that I felt like my studies were less represented in the class. It also had way too much lecture and less discussion among smaller groups so I feel like I got to know other people in the class less than I would have liked as fellow concentrators. Professor Joselit was very nice but I thought his background as more of a historian and curator and not a maker showed a little too much in the content of the course.
worse_comment: you have to take it for department requirement. you will hate it, but it’s 2.5 hours a week of low effort pain.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: This is an excellent class with excellent professors. At times it may feel a bit inaccessible and conceptual, but just speaking with the instructors and trusting the process will get you a long way. the class allows you to do literally whatever you want, which may be a bit daunting but if you just trust your gut and keep producing art it'll all work out

I think that this course is a really exciting chance for people interested in collecting to explore that interest through an artistic lens. I think that there are a lot of opportunities to explore your own interests and to let personal collections guide the kind of work you make. This lack of structure can be exciting, but might also be a bit challenging if you are looking for something that has more internal direction or that takes you through a progression across different projects.
It can be a bit of a time commitment but it is super manageable and definitely worth it! One of the best courses I've taken at Harvard so far!
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

course_title: Letters to a Young Artist, Part 2 1
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. I really thought outside my own artistic box for, I think, the first time. I went with some painting skills, some photography skills, and the willingness to try new things. I didn't think I would be able to create a museum–worthy installation when I first walked into that room – but by the end of the semester – I did! I created a large installation that had meaning and made people think. I am really proud of the artwork I created in this class and might even submit to some galleries!
worse_comment: You might feel lost but that's part of the prosses

course_title: AFVS 146J: Where Are We Going?: The Photograph in Contemporary Art (Studio Course) 1
best_comment: I loved the course. I thought it was a very meaningful and engaging exploration of many aspects of photography, including its history, theoretical concepts regarding photography, and opportunity to engage in studio work. I thought the teaching staff with Prof. Edmonds and Allison were great. Feedback was very helpful and definitely pushed me to become a better photographer.

Apply for this class if you have any interest in animation!You’ll get to try out different animation styles, like hand–drawn, puppetry, digital 2D, and 3D. The last half of the semester will be dedicated to working on an animation project of your own, which is open–ended and exciting. You also get to watch interesting films you wouldn’t otherwise see. This class can fit into a busy course schedule since there aren’t many hard deadlines, but if you're properly ambitious you'll still have a significant amount of work.
worse_comment: It's never been more true to say you get out what you put in.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: Take this class!!!! Young is a wonderful instructor and our TA this year (Aubrey) was really helpful. Young is really insightful in critiques and her feedback really gave me great guidance when I was stuck on my project. I really loved the screenings and the guest lectures too, though I will say the course is slightly heavier on the guest lectures and lighter on actual workshop/studio time (except for the last three–ish weeks). Like all AFVS classes, this class will swell to fill up as much time as you can possibly dedicate to it. Unity/C#/Blender experience isn't *required*, but I found that having programming experience in the past REALLY helped me (both in terms of understanding online tutorials about how to do a certain thing and also adapting that tutorial to my project). There's great flexibility in how technically ambitious you want your project to be, though, because what's most important is just the cohesiveness of the vision. This class was definitely one of the more formative experiences of my academic life here and I would highly recommend it :)

course_title: Modernization in the Visual United States Environment, 1890-2035 001
best_comment: Professor Stilgoe is amazing and I encourage all students to take a class with him, for his engaging lectures, fascinating institutional knowledge, and kindness. Office hours are right after class and also in my opinion a great part of class that you really need to take advantage of. Awesome. I liked 107 in the fall a little bit better but this one is also great. Take it.
worse_comment: This course allowed me to see the world in a different way and has been my favorite class at Harvard in my 4 years here. You learn to apply critical thinking to your observation which is a skill that has been lost in many people in today’s generation
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies
course_title_2023: Modernization in the Visual United States Environment, 1890-2035

best_comment: This is one of the best courses you will ever take at Harvard. The content is interesting, the discussions engaging, the final paper brimming with creative potential. The most important facet about this course however, is Professor Stilgoe. He is such a unique and special professor, and it is a shame there are not more like him. the most important aspect of this course is the feedback. Like I told my public speaking course, I have always loved thinking and theorizing academically. I just never believed that A) I was ever any good at writing academically, and B) anyone cared what I had to say because I had often been criticized for "being too ambitious" in my assignments or "not doing what was asked of me" (even if I did more than what was asked). Professor Stilgoe has been one of the ONLY people at this university who not only let me write how and what I wanted, but found things to praise about my thinking. I am not saying this is "excellent" because he simply gave me positive feedback, but because the way he engages with every single student and paper shows so much caring and excitement on his part about what we the students are thinking about. His in–depth feedback was the only way I felt actually spoken to about my writing, and it is single–handedly because of his feedback that I am not only a much better writer and thinker today, but actually believe that I have ideas that are worth something. Take this course, and any other Stilgoe teaches. You will be a much better person for it.
worse_comment: Don't. Stilgoe needs to retire. Not only is he wasting students' time by denying them an educational experience, he instead uses his time to slander women, bemoan his love life, and complain how he, as a white man, is experiencing microaggressions because cashiers don't put change directly into his misogynistic hands.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

course_title: Remapping Latin American Cinema: Chilean Film/Video 1968-2022 001
best_comment: This class is a good class and not that much work. The films you get to watch are really interesting, but the discussions can be a little boring because they are so long. If you know you love cinema, this is a great class for you to take. If you're unsure, this can still be a good class, but expect to be constantly engaging with content and film rather than learning theory and gaining a general introduction.

course_title: Remapping Latin American Cinema: Chilean Film/Video 1968-2022 001
best_comment: This class is a good class and not that much work. The films you get to watch are really interesting, but the discussions can be a little boring because they are so long. If you know you love cinema, this is a great class for you to take. If you're unsure, this can still be a good class, but expect to be constantly engaging with content and film rather than learning theory and gaining a general introduction.

Take. This. Class. Dennis is an incredible professor: very kind and obviously very invested in the students. As someone with very little experience in queer theory and film analysis, this class just totally revolutionized my knowledge bank and introduced me to theorists and filmmakers who are just incredible and I will now think about forever. It felt like the perfect introduction to queer theory, and Dennis curates an incredible list of films (from different countries, all exploring queerness in different ways) that you get to watch on the big screen. The people in the class are great, and it's just a whole lot of fun.
You get out what you put in. It's incredibly rare to have access to this kind of space, freedom, budget, and teachers.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: It’s very self directed and provides good work space and crit with the instructors, but not much else. If you are looking for arts community, opt for Directed Research or an upper level undergrad course instead.
worse_comment: This course was basically an unstructured independent project.  We never really met as a group and it was up to me to reach out to my professors to seek help or guidance. It was great to get credit for all of the hours I spend at the studio, but in terms of this class I spent no time interacting with the other students and very limited time interacting with my professors.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: I would highly recommend this class! It's a great one to take to fulfill your science distribution requirement or for anyone just remotely interested and who wants a lighter workload! This class is the perfect balance of both an interesting topic AND a light workload. You will feel like you really get something out of the class, without having to go crazy. The assignments are how they should be –– thought–provoking, requiring effort, but never too much. The entire teaching team is so kind and supportive. They truly care about the topic and they make everyone else care! I also love the way the course is taught in a more interactive format –– picture simulations and debates instead of a ton of lecturing! There is a really good balance of different formats so that you never get bored. And sections are built in during class time which is AMAZING – a true time saver.
worse_comment: Overall the class is pretty chill and interesting for anyone with an interest in outer space. I had Mia as a TF who was solid but wasn't the best in terms of grading and getting back assignments in a timely manner.
subject: Astronomy

best_comment: If you are taking this course with Professor Öberg, you will definitely learn a lot of interesting content, but be prepared to work hard! Professor Öberg is a wonderful professor and lecturer, and I always found myself very engaged during classes with her. She is so incredibly knowledgeable and passionate, and she has a great sense of humor and gives good advice! I enjoyed going to her office hours and talking to her outside of class. If you are an astrophysics concentrator, she is definitely someone you want to get to know!The psets in this course are generally very reasonable and connected to the lectures, plus most of the time I was able to complete a good chunk of the pset during the Wednesday section with my group. The exams are difficult – you have to be prepared to put in a good amount of effort and time to study – but the course staff are fairly generous with partial credit. Start the lab reports early!! You will feel like you have a ton of time to do it, but it will definitely take longer than you think because there are a lot of requirements to fulfill (this comes from personal experience – I turned in both lab reports late and suffered for it). Also, office hours were pretty limited, so I highly recommend working in groups for the psets, lab reports, and Python notebooks so you can pool your knowledge (and your questions for the TFs).
worse_comment: Great class, very interesting, but grading is a little bit of a pain and lots of homework
subject: Astronomy

course_title: The Unity of Science: From the Big Bang to the Brontosaurus and Beyond 001
best_comment: Definitely take this class for your science divisional distribution requirement! I had very little science experience before this class, but found it accessible and interesting. Irwin is awesome and clearly teaches this class because he loves it and loves engaging with students. The assignments are light, but you definitely should study for the exams. But I think I learned a lot and came away with a positive experience from the class. We were on Zoom the entire time which was a little unfortunate, but I didn't mind too much and still enjoyed it. I imagine it's even better in person!
worse_comment: Do not take it if you are not well versed in math and science.
subject: Astronomy
course_title_2023: The Unity of Science: From the Big Bang to the Brontosaurus and Beyond

best_comment: You get to work really hands–on with the techniques and concepts that you learn in the lecture component of the course, and there's lots of opportunity for in–class practice and 1–on–1 help since it's a smaller class. The spring break observing is a fun time and it's really cool to be able to handle the telescope control and make your own observations! (hopefully future students will actually be able to go to the observatory if covid permits!) The course is definitely more focused on being able to walk you through the different processes and techniques of observational astronomy, so there's not a heavy pset workload and the project during the second half of the semester is definitely manageable if you use your time in class to work on it.
subject: Astronomy

best_comment: You get out of this course what you put into it, and if you put in hard work and an attitude for learning and dedication, you will get a lot of cool opportunities in the course. You get to work really closely with active researchers and work on projects that are currently relevant to the work they do, so it's a really cool chance to learn about research methods in an active research lab! The final presentations and research papers at the end of each project are challenging because your instructors encourage you to really practice the skills you need to give real research presentations and write real research papers of high caliber, so it is really worth the challenge, and if you put in the work to write a good paper and give a good presentation, you will have learned a lot in the process. The course schedule can be difficult because you have to be at the CfA often several times a week, so keep that in mind when planning courses for your semester. Overall I enjoyed the course, and feel like I am better prepared for research!
subject: Astronomy

best_comment: I had high expectation about detailed consideration for advanced topics like CMB anisotropies, which haven't been quite fulfilled. Although we spent a decent time on analytical and semi–analytical growth of structure. Very few about galaxies specifically.

Very excellent class.  Flexible teachers, extremely manageable workload, fair tests, fun low–stress learning environment.  If you are an undergraduate, know that the public school of health doesn't follow reading period/final period rules.  Highly recommend taking this course.  The instructors are amazing and accommodating.
subject: Biological Sci in Public Hlth

best_comment: Very excellent class.  Flexible teachers, extremely manageable workload, fair tests, fun low–stress learning environment.  If you are an undergraduate, know that the public school of health doesn't follow reading period/final period rules.  Highly recommend taking this course.  The instructors are amazing and accommodating.
subject: Biological Sci in Public Hlth

best_comment: Be timely and dedicated. Lab takes a lott of time but it is very rewarding. The lab TFs and course instructor are very receptive to feedback, give great feedback, provide lots of support, and are always encouraging even when things go wrong in your lab experiment. The weekly journals are simple assignments and don't take a lot of time. The work definitely picks up with time especially in lab, but there is solid support for it. The exams are fair and reviews for them are very helpful.

course_title: Introduction to Biomedical Imaging and Systems 001
best_comment: This class is amazing!! It's not a wash but if you work on psets with friends and just keep up with work you can end up with a good grade. VERY useful if you're premed or interested in going into this field and the labs/hands–on component are great! The final isn't worth too much of the grade and the final project is pretty easy to do well on if you plan in advance so a pretty great mid–level (in terms of time commitment) class

You should definitely have a strong electrical engineering background if you want to be able to understand everything that goes on in the course. You can still take it if you do not have such a strong background, but be prepared to not understand some things, especially in the middle/later parts of the semester. Professor Liu is generally happy to answer questions after class or during office hours, and the homework and lab assignments tend to be interesting and not overly difficult. Some things covered include Neuralink and optogenetics–both very cool topics. Would recommend for Bioengineering concentrators or EE concentrators with an interest in medical devices, electrophysiology, or basic neuroengineering.
worse_comment: This class is not a lot of work, but I also don't feel like I learned so much from it. If you want a chill class that fulfills an engineering requirement this can be it (but warning that lab starts halfway through the semester and is 3 hours a week), but I don't feel like it helped my understanding of engineering/bioelectronics. Coming into it with more electrical engineering background could be helpful for that
subject: Biomedical Engineering

best_comment: This class is interesting and very relaxed. We had 3 problem sets and a final presentation. It is very clear that Maurice cares a lot about the material and about teaching it (this is what he does in his research), and that comes across in how he teaches and in the lack of stress/assignments/caring about grades––it's really not about the work or the grades but more so just interesting discussions on the material. The material sometimes felt a little disjointed (like it was just a series of classes but not necessarily a cohesive whole), but it was kind of nice in the sense that it was some slides/info and some math/equations, so whenever you were getting tired of one you'd switch to the other. You don't learn specific engineering concepts or skills, but it is interesting to think about
worse_comment: The class is what you make of it! We only had 3 problem sets, so there wasn't a lot of work. There's a lot of interesting material, so if you pay attention and apply yourself, you will learn all about signal processing and how it relates to body movement.

best_comment: This class is a really great way to read literature in our field of research and get to know your cohort through vibrant research discussions.
worse_comment: I would emphasize to future prospective students that the papers read in the class are almost all method papers, not papers focused on new biological insights.
subject: Biophysics

best_comment: This class is a really great way to read literature in our field of research and get to know your cohort through vibrant research discussions.
worse_comment: I would emphasize to future prospective students that the papers read in the class are almost all method papers, not papers focused on new biological insights.
subject: Biophysics

best_comment: If you're enrolling, you probably have to take this course, but it wasn't a bad experience, at least this time around. You can get exposure to a variety of different fields within biophysics, as well as some of the theory common to all fields. The workload is pretty light.
subject: Biophysics

best_comment: If you're enrolling, you probably have to take this course, but it wasn't a bad experience, at least this time around. You can get exposure to a variety of different fields within biophysics, as well as some of the theory common to all fields. The workload is pretty light.
subject: Biophysics

best_comment: If you're enrolling, you probably have to take this course, but it wasn't a bad experience, at least this time around. You can get exposure to a variety of different fields within biophysics, as well as some of the theory common to all fields. The workload is pretty light.
subject: Biophysics

best_comment: If you're enrolling, you probably have to take this course, but it wasn't a bad experience, at least this time around. You can get exposure to a variety of different fields within biophysics, as well as some of the theory common to all fields. The workload is pretty light.
subject: Biophysics

best_comment: Rui is the best
subject: Biostatistics

course_title: Introduction to Data Structures and Algorithms 001
best_comment: A really good course, covering both fundamentals as well as more in–depth material regarding algorithms and data structures. Dr. Hahn is a really good lecturer, and is very flexible.
subject: Biostatistics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Data Structures and Algorithms

course_title: Principles and Advanced Topics in Clinical Trials 001
best_comment: Unless substantial changes are made to the course, I would advise potential students to consider other advanced core electives. As essential and wide–ranging of a subject that clinical trials is, the opportunity cost of forgoing another high quality advanced core course in order to take this one is not worth it in my opinion, given the current quality of the course. As it currently stands, students are not pushed very hard, the course is fairly disorganized, and the coverage of topics is too topical to leave the course with a strong grasp of many of the topics that are covered. I hope this changes in the future.
worse_comment: A chaotic course, but a reasonably light workload.
subject: Biostatistics
course_title_2023: Principles and Advanced Topics in Clinical Trials

best_comment: Only take this course if you are really interested in the theory of inference and enjoy proofs. I took this as someone interested in applications of statistics to real problems, thinking it would be good for me to understand more statistical theory and push myself. In the end, this course did not help me in any way for applied statistics, but made me better at doing theoretical proofs.
worse_comment: The course itself is not designed to be stressful, as Rajarshi is a very understanding instructor. Nonetheless you will be challenged, as you will see a lot of things you've never seen before and go through very thorough proofs. It's a good deep dive into statistical theory and concepts!
subject: Biostatistics

best_comment: Great course if you're interesting in survival analysis! The amount of work assigned is very light, and there's no exams involved. Of course, you can always spend more time reviewing some of the course slides, since some of the material covered (especially when covering martingales) can be pretty dense, so how much time you spend on this course is mostly just up to you.
subject: Biostatistics

best_comment: This is a really great course if you're interested in Bayesian statistics (which you should be). It's a good amount of work, but it's worth it. If you have the chance to take this with Jeff Miller, do it! He's one of the best profs in the BST department. He's a great lecturer and has great materials.
subject: Biostatistics

best_comment: the course is very informative and covers a wide range of data types with sufficient background. the assignments are very complementary to the lectures and fun to complete. You are given sufficient time and the teaching staff are very helpful. Eric and Kelsey are great teachers. There are a bunch of similar classes on data analysis but they are truly the most effective and skilled educators.
worse_comment: You need to spend a lot more time just participating in the class, including coming to the class in person.  People will feel frustrated when more than half of the class is not showing up.
subject: Biostatistics

best_comment: the course is very informative and covers a wide range of data types with sufficient background. the assignments are very complementary to the lectures and fun to complete. You are given sufficient time and the teaching staff are very helpful. Eric and Kelsey are great teachers. There are a bunch of similar classes on data analysis but they are truly the most effective and skilled educators.
