subject: Biostatistics

best_comment: Nagy is a cool professor, very accessible, kind, flexible.  He's obviously probably one of the most knowledgeable people around on the material.  Lectures can be dry, but if you do the reading, they can be very informative.  The department is small, and these classes are often quite small as well.  You get to know everyone well, so it's easy to get help if you want to make sure you're on track.
best_gem_comment: Absolute Gem of a course that is actually interesting. Professor Nagy and Nick were awesome and extremely accessible

best_comment: This is a good overview of how statistics and science can sometimes have a disconnect as well as a review of some key statistical concepts.
subject: Chemical Biology

best_comment: This is a good overview of how statistics and science can sometimes have a disconnect as well as a review of some key statistical concepts.
subject: Chemical Biology

course_title: Research for Credit in Chemical and Physical Biology 001
best_comment: Research for credit is a great way to spend more time on research during the term, and great for thesis research prep!
subject: Chemical and Physical Biology
course_title_2023: Research for Credit in Chemical and Physical Biology

best_comment: This course is a great opportunity to conduct and write about an independent research project, however, go into it with a good idea about what you are going to write and get as much feedback from professors/mentors as possible, and as early as possible.
subject: Chemical and Physical Biology

best_comment: This course is a great opportunity to conduct and write about an independent research project, however, go into it with a good idea about what you are going to write and get as much feedback from professors/mentors as possible, and as early as possible.
subject: Chemical and Physical Biology

best_comment: As a second semester sophomore, I would say this is the best class I've taken here.  Logan is an incredible teacher with a ton of energy, a great sense of humor, a tremendous knowledge of the material (no one ever asked a question he answered poorly), and a tremendous work ethic.  The course materials are excellent: this class had more practice problems than any course I've seen before, and the psets and exams were instructive and fair.  This course consistently attracts a very knowledgeable, dedicated, and friendly teaching staff, which makes learning considerably more enjoyable than in most STEM classes here.Thoughts on Chem 20 vs Chem 17:– Chem 20 was very well organized and the teaching was very coherent; I've heard the same is not true about Chem 17– Chem 20/30 is considerably more difficult than Chem 17/27: Chem 17 claims to cover the material in Chem 20/30 in one semester, but topics are taught much deeper in Chem 20, especially topics related to synthesis (which is practically all of organic chemistry).  This class also tends to attract the chemistry and chem/phys concentrators as well as people with previous chemistry olympiad backgrounds, while Chem 17 is mostly pre–meds– The grading for Chem 20 is less focused on exams than Chem 17 (where the only grades are from exams), but the grading in both is still very exam heavy (~70% vs ~100%)– The lab component of Chem 20 was not very enjoyable – lab write–ups were excessively long, pre–lab quizzes had almost no relationship to the readings, and the lab staff was much more disorganized than the teaching staff– All around, if you're looking for a difficult but very interesting and well–organized class with a great group of people and a great teaching staff, Chem 20 is the way to go.  If you're just trying to get organic chemistry out of the way, Chem 17 might be a better option
worse_comment: The course policies actively work against students. This should not be happening. Some students who missed an exam due to being in covid isolation got to take it in their dorm room with access to lecture notes, practice problems, and the internet which isn't fair for everyone taking it in the lecture hall and compromises the integrity of the exam. Other students with covid emailed the professor and the head lab TF about missing a lab and received no response for weeks until the makeup lab section was announced (with less than a week's notice) and they were expected to drop everything and attend even if they had other classes or exams during that time. The attitude towards the make up lab was preposterous; the Head Lab TF said they only offer a make up since it is university policy and if you are unable to do the 4 hour (or more if you missed multiple labs) make up then you get a 0 for that lab. There is also so much hypocrisy and a lack of understanding built into the course policy about dropping problem sets; you can't drop a problem set, you can "make up" the point of a problem set since every problem set gives you the opportunity to earn 11 points but they are graded out of 10. This policy is impractical since students can't be expected to get an 11/10 on every problem set or even most problem sets and the graduate student TFs are such hard graders that getting high marks is nearly impossible.  The professor emphasizes prioritizing mental health and yet tells students who struggled on Exam 1 to spend their spring break studying for Exam 2 and is unwavering when students ask for some lee–way when submitting late problem sets. Late problem sets receive 50% if they're late within 24 hours and 0% if they're late after, even if you are struggling due to external factors out of your control and notify your TF about these struggles. Additionally, I don't know if the PSLs receive an answer key for the problem sets or not, but they should, since I've received "help" from PSLs several times in the past which was later marked as blatantly incorrect on my problem sets. Either better PSLs need to be hired or they should receive an answer key for the problem sets in order to best assist students. I get that Orgo is supposed to be a weed out class, but it doesn't have to be, especially at Harvard. Professors that are supposedly so passionate about their field aren't supposed to try to weed students out of it, they're supposed to try and make students love it, a job that shouldn't be that difficult when you have a self–selecting group of students who already want to pursue science and/or chemistry in the future. Take this class if you think you'll like the chemical aspects of orgo, but get ready for this class to take up a lot of your time and mental energy.
subject: Chemistry

subject: Chemistry

best_comment: It feels weird to be saying this about organic chemistry since it has such a reputation, but this was honestly a very enjoyable course and it has changed the way I think about biological concepts. Professor Balskus is an extremely good lecturer, very articulate and cohesive. Tim's Friday review lectures are very helpful for digesting weekly course material. Section (shout out to Jonathan Wong) is very useful for learning to apply lecture concepts in problem solving situations. There are SO many resources provided and the team really does care about listening to and implementing your feedback. There is basically nothing to complain about, aside from the fact that organic chemistry itself is just a hard topic. But it's a very well taught and very fair course –– all it takes is to do well is to be proactive and be diligent! Personally, my main secret for success was to start on the problem set early by going to PSL Help Room on the weekends!
worse_comment: Have your primary way of studying be doing practice problems and not rewriting notes. This course is difficult so don't be surprised if exams are very stressful
best_gem_comment: This class is incredibly well–taught and also offers invaluable support resources (instructor OHs, TFs, PSLs, etc.). Likely the best chem class I have taken here. I think Chem27 enables you to explore the beauty of organic chemistry and biochemistry––including several cool metabolic pathways and enzymatic reactions––making the process challenging but motivating. The course material (printed lectures and section handouts!) is presented in clear and very engaging lectures by Professor Balskus, who very much emphasizes understanding concepts and knowing the 'why'/logic of certain components of a given mechanism. Her OH are a very helpful resource. Anne Marie is also a gem in terms of her clear explanations for content. Much of the content also highlights applications for the material, which is a really exciting way to see these concepts in action. Psets and exams are fair, and OH are great if you are ever confused on any topics. This is a course for which if you invest the time and practice diligently, you can do well.
subject: Chemistry

subject: Chemistry

best_comment: Chem40 was one of my two favorite classes of all time. Take this class with Jarad, he creates a welcoming and comforting environment, he is incredibly intelligent and helpful, and he's one of the sweetest professors around. I also learned so much more and appreciated the material so much more taking it with Jarad than my friends did taking it with someone else. If Joy Cho TF's this class again, try to attend her section and get to know her! She's the most joyful, relatable, kind, and helpful TF I've ever had. You should be willing to put in the effort for this class. I spent probably 15 hours a week on this course, which is a lot more than I expected coming in. But I can certainly say that every minute spent was worth it – learning and understanding the material was incredibly rewarding. (The 15 hours might be biased towards the long end though, as I came in with less pre–requisites than required).I can never say enough about how much I love this course, and I can never say enough about how much this course single–handedly changed my academic path. From gaining a deeper appreciation of chemistry itself, I finally decided to change my concentration to something more chemistry–oriented. And from watching Jarad lecture and Joy teach section and help at office hours, I finally realized that what I really want to do is to be like them, a teacher with all their amazing qualities :). Take this class! If you're willing to put in the effort, this class can be the best class you'll ever take :).
worse_comment: This class has a lot of potential, but this reiteration of Chem 40 was not it. Jarad is really nice, knowledgeable, and means well, but this class was so disorganized it was almost laughable at times. During the first week of this class, the course staff shared that they 1) didn't exactly know what they planned on teaching in the course, and 2) weren't even planning on holding office hours. The lack of organization was the biggest downfall of the class. And that doesn't even touch the material. Some of it makes sense at surface level and some doesn't, but you are expected to know and memorize literally every detail taught during lecture (and lecture is just 75 minutes of new material, twice a week for an entire semester). There is not enough time to actually sit down and work with the material until you actually understand it. All it was was a few pset problems (that usually had material on it taught on the day before it was due, or sometimes the following week??) and like two problems during section. Otherwise, you are all on your own. Some TFs are hit or miss, too, and would sometimes send me to the unreadable textbook to try and figure out something that could've been explained in 3 minutes. The exams can be impossible too, with questions that make no sense, or tested something that Jarad had mentioned once for like 5 seconds during lecture then never came up again in psets or practice problems. Not to mention, there were never enough practice problems for these tests. All in all, this class was so miserable when it did not need to be. Kids who took the class last year had a much easier time even though the content was still hard, if slightly different. I really wanted to enjoy the class, but I just couldn't. If you're a chem concentrator, there's no getting around it, but I cannot recommend this class at all until some serious changes are made.
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: This class is pretty fun if you take it with your friends. All the TFs are very friendly and knowledgeable. Heidi and the TFs are responsive and accommodating. They give a lot of thorough feedback on assignments and are quick to respond to emails/questions. The only down–side is that the class is 10 hours/week, and there are assignments that do require a decent amount of time outside of class. Be prepared to dedicate a good chunk of your week to this class. Heidi is also a pretty strict grader.
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: Chem 154 is a great class if you enjoyed Chem 40 and are looking to learn more about the *why* to everything you learned in Chem 40. The details aren't skipped and you learn the math behind everything. Prof. Nocera is a good lecturer, and you will definitely learn a lot in this class! Problem sets can be tricky but my TF was always willing to help and exams were pretty straight forward.  Definitely would recommend if you are interested in inorganic chem!
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: A little disorganized, but overall good material and interesting class. Really low commitment, and the grading is really generous.
worse_comment: Go to section and office hours, problem sets are very very hard without them.
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: This course takes a lot of time, but i actually found it to be very rewarding. If you put int the time you do learn a lot, but be prepared to spend a LOT of time on reports and in lab.
subject: Chemistry

course_title: Foundations and Frontiers of Modern Chemistry: A Molecular and Global Perspective 001
best_comment: PS11 is my least favorite course of the year. I'm saying this knowing that the course staff put a lot of effort into organizing the course and improving it over the years, and I appreciate their work. However, the biggest problem I have with PS11 is its underlying teaching philosophy, which is rigid, didactic and does not account for leaning differences. I'm writing this feedback as someone who took this course because I'm genuinely interested in the topics presented. I'm not a pre–med student, but I really wanted to learn about the underlying chemistry behind climate change, energy and batteries (for a potential concentration in MechE). However, the course managed to turn the materials that I'm genuinely interested in into something I dreaded throughout this semester. The reason is because of the absurd amount of requirements and rigidity of the course. Personally, I found the material quite easy. I essentially self–studied 3 weeks worth of course material in the 3 days before every exam and averaged at 97 (for the midterms). The conceptual basis of all the units is pretty intuitive to understand (as someone with an honors chem background in high school), and then the rest of the work is just plug and chug. HOWEVER, this course expects you to spend essentially 3–4 hours every week just doing plug and chug. Add onto this the 2 hour lab sessions, where you essentially transfer a few liquids, write down a few numbers and just wait around. Add onto this MANDATORY lectures and sections, in which I quickly learnt it was more useful to spend my time doing other work (since I could learn the same material in 1/10 of the time afterwards anyways).  The PSETS are long and annoying. You know that feeling when you spend 10+ hours solving a really difficult physics or CS pset and feel really accomplished afterwards? Don't expect to feel the same way about PS11 psets. The only skill you'll be honing is using your calculator. I understand that this is a personal perspective and that there are students who might have appreciated the extra practice and explanation. However, the course should make this extra practice OPTIONAL, and not make all students sit through the grueling sections that they might not need. Personally, I also don't learn well in large, in–person lecture halls, and it's ridiculous of the course to presume that this is the best learning method for all students. If lecture was not mandatory, the students who genuinely benefit from this style of learning can come, and the rest can learn the materials through other methods. As long as they LEARN THE MATERIALS, which should be what matters most. For the course instructors—once again, I really appreciate your work (special shout–out to Lu Wang, I essentially learnt most of the materials through the textbook + your problem solving sections, and the way. you explain things is great). The content is quite interesting, and the general progression of the course neatly links the topics together. However, please seriously consider my above feedback and have more faith in students' ability to decide for themselves how they learn best. If you want students to spend a lot of hours on the course regardless, maybe consider designing more conceptually challenging problems/bonus options, etc. for the intellectually curious rather than having a one–size–fit–all approach. For students considering the course, my two cents is: – If you're pre–med and looking for an easy grade boost (aka you have to put in hours of mind–numbing work but will probably get a good grade), sure, this is the course for you.– If you're genuinely interested in learning the material, just get the textbook and skip this course. There are probably more useful things you can do with your time.
worse_comment: This is the worst class I have taken at Harvard. I am sorry to everyone for whom this is a requirement. First of all, this class meets 5 times a week which is entirely too many. Lectures are mandatory, but perhaps the least helpful aspect of any class I have taken. Jim Anderson is apparently a renowned chemist; he should not, however, be a renowned lecturer. Disorganized and unclear, his classes somehow simultaneously assume you know nothing and are a PhD candidate in chemistry. He leaps from topic to topic either without properly explaining any concepts or by explaining the most useless information in minute detail. His style consists of namedropping Tesla a thousand times and underlining or drawing checkmarks next to random information on the prepared slides and never once does this class set out core concepts to understand, appropriately explain the relationships between anything in chemistry and physics, or ask you turn on your brain. Greg is a significant improvement, but his lectures too struggle from a lack of direction and no synthesis of material. The PSETs exist simply to occupy your time — please just find someone who is premed or chemistry and do the PSET with them so you can spend as little time on this class a possible. I never once had to think in this class, you must learn the types of questions they ask and know how to answer them and nothing else. Exams are horrendously scheduled and dull, only possible due to the presence of the cheat sheet. Labs are a good awful use of three hours of my time when I could be doing anything that remotely interests me. They tangentially relate to class material and don't teach you anything about actual lab work all while imposing even more arbitrary deadlines and busywork to turn in. Someone please tell the natural science departments to stop requiring this class and figure something else out. The only redeeming quality of this class is that I have heard that PS1 is somehow worse.
subject: Physical Sciences
course_title_2023: Foundations and Frontiers of Modern Chemistry: A Molecular and Global Perspective

course_title: Foundations and Frontiers of Modern Chemistry: A Molecular and Global Perspective 001
best_comment: PS11 is my least favorite course of the year. I'm saying this knowing that the course staff put a lot of effort into organizing the course and improving it over the years, and I appreciate their work. However, the biggest problem I have with PS11 is its underlying teaching philosophy, which is rigid, didactic and does not account for leaning differences. I'm writing this feedback as someone who took this course because I'm genuinely interested in the topics presented. I'm not a pre–med student, but I really wanted to learn about the underlying chemistry behind climate change, energy and batteries (for a potential concentration in MechE). However, the course managed to turn the materials that I'm genuinely interested in into something I dreaded throughout this semester. The reason is because of the absurd amount of requirements and rigidity of the course. Personally, I found the material quite easy. I essentially self–studied 3 weeks worth of course material in the 3 days before every exam and averaged at 97 (for the midterms). The conceptual basis of all the units is pretty intuitive to understand (as someone with an honors chem background in high school), and then the rest of the work is just plug and chug. HOWEVER, this course expects you to spend essentially 3–4 hours every week just doing plug and chug. Add onto this the 2 hour lab sessions, where you essentially transfer a few liquids, write down a few numbers and just wait around. Add onto this MANDATORY lectures and sections, in which I quickly learnt it was more useful to spend my time doing other work (since I could learn the same material in 1/10 of the time afterwards anyways).  The PSETS are long and annoying. You know that feeling when you spend 10+ hours solving a really difficult physics or CS pset and feel really accomplished afterwards? Don't expect to feel the same way about PS11 psets. The only skill you'll be honing is using your calculator. I understand that this is a personal perspective and that there are students who might have appreciated the extra practice and explanation. However, the course should make this extra practice OPTIONAL, and not make all students sit through the grueling sections that they might not need. Personally, I also don't learn well in large, in–person lecture halls, and it's ridiculous of the course to presume that this is the best learning method for all students. If lecture was not mandatory, the students who genuinely benefit from this style of learning can come, and the rest can learn the materials through other methods. As long as they LEARN THE MATERIALS, which should be what matters most. For the course instructors—once again, I really appreciate your work (special shout–out to Lu Wang, I essentially learnt most of the materials through the textbook + your problem solving sections, and the way. you explain things is great). The content is quite interesting, and the general progression of the course neatly links the topics together. However, please seriously consider my above feedback and have more faith in students' ability to decide for themselves how they learn best. If you want students to spend a lot of hours on the course regardless, maybe consider designing more conceptually challenging problems/bonus options, etc. for the intellectually curious rather than having a one–size–fit–all approach. For students considering the course, my two cents is: – If you're pre–med and looking for an easy grade boost (aka you have to put in hours of mind–numbing work but will probably get a good grade), sure, this is the course for you.– If you're genuinely interested in learning the material, just get the textbook and skip this course. There are probably more useful things you can do with your time.

Lectures are mandatory, but perhaps the least helpful aspect of any class I have taken. Jim Anderson is apparently a renowned chemist; he should not, however, be a renowned lecturer. Disorganized and unclear, his classes somehow simultaneously assume you know nothing and are a PhD candidate in chemistry. He leaps from topic to topic either without properly explaining any concepts or by explaining the most useless information in minute detail. His style consists of namedropping Tesla a thousand times and underlining or drawing checkmarks next to random information on the prepared slides and never once does this class set out core concepts to understand, appropriately explain the relationships between anything in chemistry and physics, or ask you turn on your brain. Someone please tell the natural science departments to stop requiring this class and figure something else out. The only redeeming quality of this class is that I have heard that PS1 is somehow worse.

subject: Physical Sciences
course_title_2023: Foundations and Frontiers of Modern Chemistry: A Molecular and Global Perspective

best_comment: Professor Stähli is a really kind and knowledgable professor and the material is super interesting! A lot of course time is devoted to student presentations and the reading load is pretty light if you are looking for a good intro to classical archaeology.
worse_comment: this class is very difficult. while there was no homework weekly other than some reading, the two assignments were upwards of 12 hours of research each and were hard to complete because there were no expectations set. definitely not a class to take if you're not interested in the subject

course_title: Introduction to the Ancient Roman World 001
best_comment: This class was amazing! I already decided to concentrate in Classics, but if I hadn't, this class would have convinced me. Dr. Morgan is really knowledgable, funny, and engaging in his lectures, and he and the TF Julia were very helpful and available even outside class or section. Though there was a midterm exam and paper along with a final exam and paper, this was a very manageable course that I actually felt like I learned a lot in. I highly recommend taking this class even if you have no background in Classics or Roman history whatsoever – knowledge of Latin is definitely not required, and it's a great and super organized course on a fascinating subject.
worse_comment: I would just go ahead and take the class, no matter what your concentration is. Modern society seems more explicable when you understand Roman history. It's not too hard and you don't need any background knowledge. You will cover a lot material.
subject: Classical Studies
course_title_2023: Introduction to the Ancient Roman World

best_comment: A well–taught, well–executed class. Prof. Andrews and Sarah did a great job with the course, and you will enjoy the experience immensely. Though the quizzes are a tad obnoxious, the rest of the assignments are fair and enjoyable. The trip is also a nice touch as well. Overall, though a required class for the concentration, CLS–STDY 112 will serve you well and will become one of your highlights of the semester.
subject: Classical Studies

best_comment: Classics, Race, and Power is one of my favorite courses that I've taken at Harvard over the past three years. The topic is relevant, engaging, and fascinating. The reading assignments are quite interesting and engaging, and the graded assignments are very manageable. The guest speakers (and lunch afterwards with them) were amazing and made the course that much better. Elmer is a legend, and everyone should ideally take a class with him at least once before you graduate. Highly recommend the course – you'll come to love it in the same way I did.

A really fun and relaxed way of practicing Greek translation skills and learning more about Euripides. Prof. Nagy has an encyclopedic grasp of the material but is also very excited to hear fresh readings of the plays and invites connections to topics outside of the Classics. Him and Elizabeth are both very kind and quick to respond to students' concerns.

I highly recommend this class. It is challenging in the best way possible and will open a new world of sources, texts, and methods by which you can study and appreciate the ancient and medieval worlds.

Latin I & II exceeded my expectations. I went in already wanting to learn Latin and thinking that I would give the courses a year to see if I wanted to continue––now, I certainly do. Ivy is one of the most dedicated instructors I have encountered and the course is constantly evolving to fit students' needs (though it retains a core rhythm that works brilliantly). Be warned, the course is not easy; however, it is well worthwhile and manageable. Further, if you have any hesitation about learning a dead language rest assured that learning Romance languages (as I have) will become much easier after Latin. And, unlike contemporary languages, learning Latin will give you a new view of the world from thousands of years ago! I cannot recommend this course enough if you are interested in learning Latin.
worse_comment: If you haven’t studied Latin before or if you’re not concentrating in Classics than there’s no reason to take this class. You will not understand it, you’ll get no support, and ultimately it’ll just drag your gpa into hell. I put so much time and energy into doing the work and studying for quizzes and exams with no payoff. DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE.
subject: Latin

best_comment: I actually really enjoyed this course! Learning Latin helps with your English, and it’s also very cool to be able to directly translate some common Latin phrases that show up in everyday life.
worse_comment: Stay on top of your work and assignments because it is difficult to catch back up once you're behind.
subject: Latin

best_comment: This course is really great if you are interested in philosophy (specifically Epicureanism) but if not it would be pretty boring. Don't take it if you're just looking to take any Latin course. However, I really do recommend it if you like ancient philosophy. It is a good amount of work, but not unreasonable.

This class is an engaging introduction to the second half of Latin literature.  It is still a substantial work commitment, but no longer as scary as 112 was rumored to be in the past.  Take this class if you want to grow in confidence as a Latin reader across a variety of genres (I really did!!), and don't be afraid to face all kinds of different texts: a highlight for me was falling in love with Tacitus.Professor Peirano Garrison is a thoughtful, unfailingly kind, and very engaging teacher.  Rebecca (the TA) was also fantastic.
worse_comment: This class is extremely difficult, and I do not recommend taking another language class simultaneously. However, you will learn a lot, and the class is rewarding in the end.

best_comment: If you're unsure about taking a class on Modern Greek because it sounds like it may be a difficult class/language, don't worry.  Both Modern Greek AA and AB are not stressful classes at all and are often very fun and something I look forward to. Professor Dourou is very kind and makes learning Greek very enjoyable through fun activities. Both classes also don't take up any exorbitant amount of time for homework, and were usually a 2–3hr time commitment per week for me.
subject: Modern Greek

course_title: Advanced Modern Greek: Introduction to Modern Greek Literature 001
best_comment: Amazing class! Calliope is wonderful and we had some great discussions.
subject: Modern Greek
course_title_2023: Advanced Modern Greek: Introduction to Modern Greek Literature

best_comment: Be ready to read a lot. This class is a testament to the possibility of a rigorous approach to humanities. But also, be ready to explore anything and everything you want. Students can compare anything they want. And we had huge diversity in topics of comparison across the class. Students looked at psychologists, social theorists, art pieces, films and much more. It's also a great chance to work on your languages. The instructors are incredible and really care about the students and their development and this created a really nice atmosphere in the class.
subject: Comparative Literature

best_comment: Translating World Literature is one of my favorite classes at Harvard. Luke is a wonderful professor and I always really looked forward to coming to class. The readings and discussions we had were super interesting and I got so much out of them. The assignments were very creative, fun, and challenging and I thoroughly enjoyed getting to write my own translations of poetry and literature that appealed to me. If you know another language, I highly recommend taking this class. Your view of language and translation will definitely change for the better!
subject: Comparative Literature

best_comment: Your only grade in the class is the final, which is a take home exam or research paper. The lectures are so interesting and you learn a lot from Professor Giron and your peers. To enjoy the class, you should be interested in the material.
Professor Shell is both brilliant and funny. Everyone should take a class with him.

I would definitely recommend this class to other students who are interested in this course and its subject matter. Professor Lienau is an incredibly knowledgeable and encouraging individual who is open to providing of a space of intellectual intrigue in her classrooms. It was a pleasure taking a course with her, especially given her own scholarship on Indonesian and Egyptian texts and their relationship to colonial and post–colonial realities.

course_title: Bargaining with the Devil: the Faust Legend 001
best_comment: This is one of the rare occasions where I enjoyed the course much more than I can express in words. The readings themselves were rich with wisdom and creativity. They were often the lifework of the authors and it's evident that the magnitude of each work goes beyond much of the literature we as students normally read. Each literary work and the connections to one another gave me a much more profound understanding of the world and especially of German culture. I did not expect to learn so much about music theory, religion, etymology, and history but it was a welcomed addition that always elevated our understanding of the texts. Before taking the course, I was only somewhat familiar with the Faust legend. I did not realize how deeply this legend is tied to German identity. It explains Germany's historical journey, and we specifically focus on its connection to WWI and WWII. Moreover, the Faust legend captures something so innately close to our humanity that the questions raised and the works based on it illuminate much about ourselves, our purpose, and how to make sense of humanity's trajectory. I have always loved literature, but this course took it to another level. I felt so transformed by this course and it left me thinking, this is one of those courses you dream of taking. This is a class is the epitome of what makes Harvard an untouchable academic experience. Professor Hamilton is an amazing lecturer –– very humble too –– who can keep you captivated for the two hours we meet each week. Every lecture is like an intricate story that ties together knowledge from all disciplines to explain and analyze the text at a foundational level. It's beautiful to see how literature and the decisions made by the authors evolve from one culture to another, across time periods. I still remember our first class, when Professor Hamilton began by explaining the difference between literature and philosophy. Literature is for you to interpret. It doesn't retain a concrete meaning. It is meant to evolve, and it will connect to each individual uniquely. I have taken philosophy classes before and he is exactly correct. This class embodies an openness to ideas, no matter how unusual or unpopular. Unlike philosophy, literature doesn't have rules nor does it tell you how you should think. The joy and curiosity I thought I would find in philosophy, I actually found in literature.  With every essay, you can feel free to write wherever your connection to the literature takes you and Professor Hamilton is always supportive and encouraging of your interpretations. Sometimes, it felt intimidating to have to write essays after hearing Professor Hamilton's lectures which expertly made connections you can only make with his breadth of knowledge and after spending years ruminating on the literature. I truly was in awe after every class because his revelations about the text and about themes would be things I've never heard or even considered before. Oftentimes, perspectives and interpretations on common motifs are repeated so you hear them in one class and then another. This was completely different, like studying literature for the first time again.Having said this, please view the lectures as an incredible educational experience that should only inspire you to reach to produce your best work in the course. I would encourage you to challenge yourself in finding new connections, still, or ones that weren't touched on much in class. It's not easy, but it will be rewarding when you prove to yourself that there is no ceiling to literature. No matter how much you think you have learned and understand, there's always more to discover. Interestingly, the course structure doesn't appear to be heavy on workload or reading, but the beauty of only assigning work that is necessary is that we have the time to discuss and reflect, reread and do our own research. I spent considerable time outside of class thinking, talking about what I read, and over time that relationship with the text allowed me to make the most of each essay I eventually wrote. The course also isn't a writing course –– it's not meant to nitpick on writing skill/style –– but I felt a natural progression in improving my writing style because the material we wrote about has such gravity to it. I'm left with a greater sense of awareness of who we are and why we do what we do in addition to a deeper connection to humanity of the past and present. This course ultimately made me decide to continue studying literature at Harvard and the lectures and readings are things I will be thinking about, fondly, for years to come. No matter what your background is, if you are curious about humanity, its relationship to nature, and the ever–present balances in life –– if you are willing to dedicate yourself to the readings with care and attention –– I recommend this course with the greatest enthusiasm.
worse_comment: Take this course. Total Gem––engaging and low work.

best_comment: This class will give you what you put in. It's very free form, but it has a great set of materials and Professor Roilos is amazing.
worse_comment: This class takes a very rigorous approach to a number of texts that examine notions of reality and "hyperreality." It is in a seminar format, so student participation and discussion is imperative.
best_gem_comment: Professor Roilos is a gem of an instructor who would make any class fantastic!

best_comment: Professor Leitner is awesome, it's a great intro to CS. Get started on the PSETS early (there aren't that many) and you'll be fine. More generous and gentle than CS50.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: Rebecca is amazing! This is a great class to take to get to know more people studying CS and gain confidence in your skills. It's a really kind class––Rebecca and the TFs are all really supportive and understanding and want you to succeed which makes the class so much better overall. I enjoyed it.
worse_comment: DONT TAKE THIS CLASS WITH CS51 – manageable load aside, its so frustrating trying to take 2 courses where you learn in table groups –– this class there are kids that don't need to take it and it's mad annoying when there are no sections and you are left to fill up the "holes" of your confusion with a class structure with table groups & you fill out worksheets type of beat.
best_gem_comment: This course was advertised as a gem, but don't take that for granted. You will have to spend a significant amount of time for the class, especially when midterms roll around because there is a hefty amount of material in the class, and it is easy to forget specific formulas or niche topics. The teaching staff is great and office hours are a great tool for getting help for pets/understanding the material.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: As the course is named, this is a beginner CS course that emphasizes a computational thinking approach. For those of you who are considering CS50 or CS32, I believe CS32 has a much more natural and supportive method of teaching a beginner how to code. I came into the class without any prior coding experience. For years, I've wanted to learn but there's always been this sense of intimidation in addition to feeling overwhelmed in navigating programming on my own. Your first introduction to coding can shape your entire perspective, so I wanted a course that focused on fundamentals and did them well. I can say that CS32 gave me a solid foundation in python, helped me develop a problem–solving mindset, and gave me a new sense of confidence in my capabilities. Each class focuses on a problem to solve for the day, and we follow along as our professor breaks down the problem and solves it with code. This is not a class that formally teaches syntax. You learn the syntax by doing, kind of like learning a language by living in the country. For me, and I believe for many of us, we really struggled with the first and second pset because there is so much that is new. For instance, downloading python, setting up your computer, and then of course doing the actual coding can be extremely intimidating at first. Please know that this is completely normal, and while it's not fun in the moment, that challenge and discomfort will pay off at the end of the course. Instead of a final test, we have a final project and I didn't see how we would be able to design and solve a problem on our own after 3 months of coding. You'll be surprised because all of your work over the semester comes together in amazing ways in this final project. The final project was a highlight of the course for me. Application is key in learning CS. You won't always understand what's going on in class. You can feel lost, but when you work on the psets, you start to make those connections and by the end of each assignment, you'll have learned so much. For that same reason, a final project directed and made by you is the best opportunity to apply your knowledge and it will be incredibly rewarding to see what you are able to accomplish. Most importantly, the manner in which we learn to dissect a problem is the essence of programming and establishing this mindset early on will put everything into context, no matter how dry or difficult, in the future. Professor Smith and the teaching staff were very considerate of the pacing and they truly tried to give us the time, resources, and encouragement to guide us in this journey. A huge reason why the course was done so intuitively and naturally was because Professor Smith and the teaching staff understood what the perspective of a beginner is like. They eased us into CS and the first pset in a supportive way, and it's sometimes overlooked how important the awareness and dedication to the student experience is. Doing CS for the first time can be scary, but the CS32 staff definitely has the right mindset and will care about adjusting the course to best suit its students. What may surprise you is how much confidence you gain by going through this course. Coding can be frustrating and even the smallest mistakes could cause you to be stuck for hours. When you force yourself to sit there, make yourself understand every line of code, brainstorm different approaches to solving a subtask –– ultimately, you learn to have patience, be resourceful, and you'll see that you are able to solve any problem. Sometimes, it's better to resist getting help immediately because when it's just you and the code, you know you are going to have to be the one to solve the problem. And yes, you actually will be able to solve every problem –– it will amaze you. I went from being intimidated by coding to creating a final project that solves a real world problem on my own. Not just with programming, but in all respects, I have a great sense of confidence in myself because this course pushed me to realize there's a solution to every problem. If you want to learn how to code in a natural, problem–solving approach, CS32 is a great choice. The staff cares about making this transition as painless as possible for you. Focusing on python instead of learning multiple languages eases off the intimidation as well. Overall, if you're a beginner and you want to understand the spirit of programming, this is class will be a great experience for you.
worse_comment: This class is a bit disorganized, though this may be because this was the first semester teaching it. You will be exposed to a lot of new concepts and will learn things but may not get super good at actually writing code on your own by the end of the course. The assignments are pretty low stakes so the course isn't too stressful.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: This course can be a lot at the outset, but it has a ton of helpful resources that you can utilize to master the basics and then take on the rest of the course with more confidence, so definitely take advantage of them!
worse_comment: This is a very difficult and challenging course. 20% of the time it is very unfair with its test and assignments with the problems being well above an entry–level program. You get penalized for struggling when the aim should be to teach.
subject: Computer Science
course_title_2023: Introduction to Computer Science (for students unable to take in the fall term)

best_comment: This course can be a lot at the outset, but it has a ton of helpful resources that you can utilize to master the basics and then take on the rest of the course with more confidence, so definitely take advantage of them!
worse_comment: This is a very difficult and challenging course. 20% of the time it is very unfair with its test and assignments with the problems being well above an entry–level program. You get penalized for struggling when the aim should be to teach.
subject: Computer Science
course_title_2023: Introduction to Computer Science (for students unable to take in the fall term)

best_comment: I would encourage them to fully use their resources for this class! This class is the most famous class at Harvard, and plenty of people often go in with high expectations that are often not met––I believe this is because, for beginners, CS50 is only rewarding if you put in the effort to talk to your TF at the end of section and attend tutorials/office hours.
worse_comment: CS50 is a very chaotic class, and while there is a lot of value in the concepts this can sometimes get lost in the sheer complexity of handling the range of assignments and commitments. Keep this in mind when choosing to enroll.

course_title_2023: Introduction to Computer Science (for students unable to take in the fall term)

best_comment: PLEASE TAKE CS51! at first i almost didn’t take this class because i was scared away by its reputation but it ended up being my favourite class of the semester. for context, the only cs class i had ever taken before this was cs50, and although cs51 was tough, the work was manageable and honestly fun to do. it was pretty social too because you make friends through office hours and shuttle rides haha. this not only improved how comfortable i felt when writing code but also made me more cognizant of aspects like design/style/efficiency and strengthened my logical reasoning skills. the tfs are so incredible too and v v helpful and funny ! please don’t be scared of this class. it’ll change your life for the better and be a highlight of the semester.
worse_comment: I know a lot of people pick between this class and CS61 for the CS Programming 2 tag requirement. Honestly, this class was awful. The material is NOT hard BUT there is no structure to the class. There is no lectures and no real learning. Sections are not really that helpful. The only way to survive in the class is to READ THE TEXT BOOK EACH WEEK. If you do this then you should be absolutely fine.
subject: Computer Science

subject: Computer Science

best_comment: This course is good. I appreciated the staff taking their time to hold labs – but making them mandatory labs with mandatory partners are a waste of time in my opinion.  Most of the people I talked to agreed that going to lab itself was not useful at all. The lab materials and problems were very good though but I mostly just learned it outside of lab. Section is enough and way more helpful. The OH and TF support is excellent and the assignments are very fun. The class does take a lot of your time though so try to take it with lighter classes. Overall, I do recommend this class and I am glad I took it and had a lot of fun with some of the PSETs and final project.
worse_comment: AVOID THIS CLASS AT ALL COSTS. CS51 is by far the most difficult class I've taken at this school. Problems I had with this class: 1. Lack of structureThis class only has 5 lectures, and none of them were useful. Literally all they talked about was how beautiful programming is. What does that even mean? Like please I just want to pass this class. Lectures in NO WAY prepared you for assignments or exams. The only time any useful information was given was during code review (section) which is led by TFs, who are literally sophomores. Instead of lectures you would go to lab, where you would be assigned a random partner (this partner changed every week). I do not think this was conducive to learning because a lot of times your partner was just as lost as you so you’re both just sitting there and can’t figure anything out. Then you try to call over a TF and they tell you you’re doing everything wrong. And then you’re like, “How would I have known that?” Guess what. There’s no way you would have known that because the professors don’t lecture.In addition, the textbook for this class is NOT well written. The majority of the exercises provided in the textbook have no answer key, so you have no way of knowing whether you’re on the right track or not. The textbook is also so theoretical. It is very confusing and hard to read. I would say reading 10 pages of that textbook takes around an hour and a half, if you actually want to understand. Thirdly, the grading system in this class was very arbitrary. If you completed the assignment exactly how you were asked to, you would get a 90%. The only way to receive 100% was to code so well that you were on the same level as the professors. Let me ask you, how would I get to that level without ANY real lectures from said professors??2. Impossible examsThere are two exams in this class and I failed both of them. I have never done so bad on an exam before in my life. The sad thing is, when I was taking the exams, I thought I was doing pretty good. However, the way the questions build on each other makes it very easy to get a low score if you mess up the first part of the question. Additionally, some of the exam questions were so vague that I just completely misunderstood what I was being asked to do and as a result received like 0/12 points for that part of the test, even though I was somewhat competent. They release all previous exams to students as study material, but NONE of the previous exams have answer keys because apparently the professor and TFs used to just grade them as they went WITH NO ANSWER KEY. I’m sorry can you literally do the bare minimum and make an answer key to your own test??? Ridiculous.3. No support for studentsAll office hours for this class are overly crowded. Office hours were run from saturday–wednesday, and PSETS were due on Wednesday night. I have major issues with the way CS51 office hours were set up. For starters, we all know the CS department is loaded. Why then, are there only TWO TFs are each office hour session? In LS1b, there are literally 20 TFs staffing one office hour session, and you hardly ever have to wait to ask a question. In CS51 office hours, I had my hand raised on their virtual platform for over an hour before a TF came to address my question, and by that time office hours were about to end. Please hire more TFs so office hours are not so busy. I truly felt bad for the TFs in office hours but at the same time I was so desperate for help that I had to be aggressive and literally beg them to continue answering my questions before moving onto the next person in the office hour line. When we asked course staff to add more office hours earlier in the week so we would have to rush to finish PSETs, they suggested that we simply work on it more individually. If I was capable of working on the pset individually, then yes, this would solve the problem. Unfortunately I was so lost that I actually had no idea how to begin each PSET. Like I’m not a bad student. This should not be happening.One of the more useful components of this class was the Ed platform that people asked questions on. That being said, the reason it was so useful was that there were two genius students in this class that would just answer everyone else’s questions. While I do love them, that should not be their job.

subject: Computer Science

course_title: System Design Projects: Machine Learning for Social Impact 001
best_comment: This has been hands down the best CS class I have taken so far here at Harvard and is the closest you can get to real–world experience in the classroom. It was super cool to work with a non profit on a single task throughout the whole semester and to use what we were discussing and practicing in workshops to try and solve these problems. I loved the freedom of the course to allow us to pursue what interested us in our research and to further flesh out what our client wanted to get out of our final product, and I really appreciated how the TFs helped to provide some structure in helping us set weekly goals and giving us periodic assignments to see how we were doing. If you have any interest in machine learning or artificial intelligence and want to see what applying those interests can look like, take this class!!
best_gem_comment: This course has the potential to be really fulfilling / enjoyable, but I think that since it was the first year it was being offered, some general kinks and organization still need to be ironed out. It is definitely a gem though, and your experience will depend a lot on the teammates that you have and the TF in charge of your project.
subject: Computer Science
course_title_2023: System Design Projects: Machine Learning for Social Impact

course_title: Data Science 2: Advanced Topics in Data Science 001
best_comment: Honestly, this is a fantastic course. I know people may have qualms about the last few problem sets, but the topics were extremely topical and relevant to modern machine learning/data science literature. Topics like GANs, Word2Vec, BERT (transformers),  and hierarchical linear models are invaluable in my repertoire of skills and tools. While the psets could definitely be strengthened, I can't be mad at one of the few courses at Harvard that actually touch the edge of state of the art techniques. This class was a much needed breather from the vast amount of tiring classes that still cover support vector machines (and call it modern machine learning) and require pages of mathematical proofs. CS109b/AC209b gave me a ton of practice in just programming machine learning algorithms in Tensorflow and Pymc3, reading documentation, and doing cool projects on topics that are still being actively researched. After this class, I can go to any job or task and feel confident in applying these skills, while learning more on the way.
worse_comment: This class was quite a mess. The questions/ instructions on the assignments are incredibly unclear, so you usually waste so much time trying to figure out what you're supposed to do. This would be somewhat okay if the course staff would clarify questions quickly, but they were very nonresponsive on Ed and would not respond to any questions over the weekend. They were also incredibly selective in which Ed posts they would answer, which made me feel like members of the course staff didn't even know what was going on. It felt like the students were shouting at a brick wall when trying to get help.Several of the homework assignment toward the end of the class were ridiculously difficult and in some cases impossible –– I wasted ~20 hours once because the code the course staff provided to us was literally impossible to run and would not work. I often feel like students complain too much, but I think it was very warranted for this class. It was incredibly frustrating to spend over 40 hours on a homework assignment simply because students didn't know what the problem was actually asking them to do. Not to mention, there were so many typos in the homeworks. The undergrad TFs didn't seem super familiar with the assignments, but they did try to help when they could.Poor Chris Gumb needs a raise because he carried the class, and whoever wrote the assignments that made the experience so difficult for him should take him out to lunch

best_comment: This class is exactly as bad as everyone says it is, it will haunt my dreams, and I fully expect to wake up in recurrent cold sweats with "dynamic programming" echoing in my mind for years to come. If you take it, having Stat110 under your belt makes a lot of the second half easier. The psets are hard and take a lot of time, but going in I didn't expect it to take quite as much time as it did, so be wary of false expectations. The exams are extremely difficult and stress–inducing so, again, keep that in mind when choosing your courses. Office hours and section are very much your friend, and the Tfs are super helpful and great; anyone who did this class without attending those is someone I truly believe has the potential to conquer the world. Regardless of my own personal experience with the course, Adam is super dedicated to the course and was a really great professor. The extra office hours he would hold before exams and the responsiveness on Ed was much appreciated, so if he is teaching this course again I would consider taking it for those reasons. If you are generally short on time, I found that lecture isn't as helpful as actually just reading the lecture and scribe notes which  are really great overviews of the material.
worse_comment: For a person with good Math and CS background who knew most of the ideas in the course (who also took Math 55) , CS 124 was still hell. DO NOT TAKE CS 124 AS AN ELECTIVE OR IF YOU CAN AVOID IT. You will learn a lot and it will feel rewarding but this in no way compensates for the painful grading in the class. The TFs do not try to make students' lives easier in any way and the marking schemes are just obscene.The class assignments consist of 7 problem sets and 3 programming assignments. Expect to lose 10% of the points on psets just because you "were not rigorous enough" which is alone extremely annoying. After the first pset, you will start including more and more detail into your explanation just to make sure you get the points you deserve but you will continue to consistently get at least 10% off on each pset, thus getting yourself into the absolute mind–numbing conundrum that this class is. The programming assignments are even worse. The coding portions are pretty cool but there is no actual final objective to the task. In the end, you have to "write a report to summarize your findings." And guess what—if on that particular day, your mind–reading capabilities are off, you will lose 10% of your grade because you did not correctly guess what was on the mind of the people who wrote the marking scheme. The brutal amount of work that these assignments are feels pointless in the end—not because it was hard and you could not do it, but because it was hard, you did it, and then you lost 10% of your points because the problem statement was inexplicably vague.Finally, exams. Those are really cool. If you feel like participating in the Hunger Games. Honestly, that was my favorite part of CS 124—because it was the only way in which actual understanding of the material reflected on your grade. However, be ready to be challenged. There is almost no time to complete everything, and most of the problems require some ingenuity. The median and mean for both the midterm and the final were 50%. It is a brutal class. Take it at your own risk or even better, don't.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: Definitely take this course if you are at all interested in or curious about computer hardware. The course offers an excellent introduction to hardware from essentially the ground up, from transistors to logic gates to ALUs, registers, and memory to full–on processors. It's very cool to better understand how basic electrical components can be abstracted into the incredibly complex machines we often take for granted. That being said, the course was somewhat disorganized this year, with assignments often being released late and grades being returned very long after submission, if ever. Nevertheless, the assignments were still pretty good, and the content of the course is quite interesting overall.
worse_comment: the labs are hard, system verilog is not fun
subject: Computer Science

course_title: Design of VLSI Circuits and Systems 001
best_comment: This class is great to take when you need something to lighten the load of a heavy semester. It pairs perfectly with CS141 so if you are an EE concentrator, I would definitely recommend taking them at the same time if you enjoy the device side of EE. The class has a great vibe and its a great way to meet grad students and understand what grad school is like.

This class can be difficult, but reading the notes and attending sections and office hours can definitely help with completing the assignments and learning the materials. Plus, the generous amount of late minutes are a lifesaver.
worse_comment: This course is a relatively low workload CS course, but still not low workload by any means. Lecture notes are great, though lectures are not particularly engaging or entertaining, and it is difficult to grasp concepts in lectures often as a result. Exams are all multiple choice, and pretty difficult. Although many topics discussed in the course  are not particularly difficult conceptually, be prepared for a lot of confusing notation that is hard to interpret and makes learning the concepts much more difficult. Overall, the course does need a change in teaching style, but otherwise, it is a relatively decent CS course for those who want to learn more about the semantics of programming languages, evaluation, evaluation methods, as well as a lot about lambda calculus.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: This course took a lot of time throughout the semester, but even so, everyone loves the class! 1. Mickens is an amazing professor2. TFs are really cool and enthusiastic3. You learn a lot of interesting low level concepts4. You gain a ton of confidence in your coding skills5. Ppl in the class are great.There are literally the smartest ppl I've ever met in this class. It has a good collaborative atmosphere where everyone is friendly and tries to help each other. Great friendships are made by debugging together.You don't need a partner before the class. The professor helps with matchmaking if you don't have a pset partner in mind. I got randomly assigned to one, and they were great.
best_gem_comment: If you really liked CS61, especially WeensyOS, take this class!!! Prof. Mickens is such a gem; you will laugh out loud (and possibly learn) in every single lecture, and the course staff are all so amazing and knowledgeable. Building out Chickadee has been one of the most educational and rewarding things I've done at Harvard. That being said, it is a lifestyle––you should be prepared to spend a lot of time on the course if you want to get a lot out of it and do well. Also make sure that you and your problem set partner work well together!! Having people to work with can make the class feel much more manageable.

best_comment: Start the PSETs early and make sure you come into the class with an attitude to learn. Show up to class. I know you’ll be tempted not too because it’S in the SEC, but it’s worth it because you get to interact with Professor Gortler firsthand and meet your classmates. Also, definitely come to office hours! I’ve learned so much from my TFs there and met cool students there! Most importantly, please follow up and dive into the lecture material after class if you want to excel. Many of these concepts are new and challenging, so you won’t be able to unpack everything in a single 75 minute lecture. Finally – do some computer graphics research outside of class! By this I mean, Google any topics that interest you related to computer graphics and ask professor about it! This will ensure you’re engaged in the course.
worse_comment: I think this class is a very outdated class (in terms of assignments, very hard to navigate for Mac users) and alot of the pset materials seemed to be from a long time ago that sometime the professor may seem confused. This class is definitely a whatever you put in, whatever you get class. If I had the option to go back to choose if I would take it again, I don't think I would because I don't think I learned that much from it. Rather it may have discouraged me from pursuing graphics in CS. I do think it on the lower end of stress when it comes to the different CS classes so if you want a relatively chill but not chill class, this might be the one for you.
subject: Computer Science

course_title: Design of Useful and Usable Interactive Systems 001
best_comment: This was a super cool class. The projects were sort of lengthy but they were fun. I wish there was some more opportunity in the first two projects to be more creative, but that's ok. I also wish the lectures were a bit more related to the assignments in the latter half of the course, because the material was actually really interesting, it was just harder to pay attention to. While this is a very tech–focused design class, there is no coding required, it's all front–end focused rather than backend, which is cool if you don't have that experience or don't want to take CS51 or 61. The TFs are really nice, Prof. Gajos is a cool guy who tries to give interesting lectures. Def recommend for the CS elective or secondary.
worse_comment: If you get stuck with a group that sucks, you're screwed. A lot of grading is biased towards who they like. The prof isn't very down–to–earth and is somewhat rude.

best_comment: CS181 is a great class, but it is not a CS class. It is really more of a STAT class, and if you have a good bit of stats maturity and a desire to learn more stats you will enjoy the class. If you're excited to learn about algorithms or code up super complicated ML models from scratch, this is not the class for you. But, Finale does a great job motivating the content from her own research and she is an AMAZING thoughtful resource. Gives a great overview of a TON of different areas of ML!!
worse_comment: Avoid at all costs. Horrible. Not even hard like 124. Just a really bad class.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: The GEM of the CS department. Literally no easier class than this. If you are looking for a class that is super chill, but gets a CS elective out of the way, CS191 is the class for you. Its more of a social class than anything else – my blockmates all took this together and I know a solid >30 other friends who also took this class around the same time. The course staff have been very stickler with many things though. I feel like they overexaggerate how hard the class is and how hard the video project is, when in reality everyone who puts the slightest bit of effort (aka showing up to class at 11:15) into the class will end up just fine. I also hope they don't ban sophomores from taking the class though for being too "underprepared", especially since I'm sure most of them are probably more prepared than all the upperclassmen trying to get last minute CS secondaries by taking this class after CS50. I know Harry was throwing around the idea, but I hope this doesn't happen!
worse_comment: DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. Taking it is my biggest regret of college. To the greatest possible extent, expectations are ambiguous, grading is inconsistent/subjective, and your needs are overlooked. The teaching staff is composed of a couple students, the professor, and the professor's elderly (and completely unqualified) buddies. The professor and his buddies incessantly belittle students, despite only knowing about pre–1980 computer science. They convey zero knowledge of pedagogy, and only seek to show off their experiences the course topics. I will never forget their countless and obnoxious interruptions during student discussions and class lectures.  Furthermore they are not at all accessible outside of class and act "put out" if you ever approach them. This was the worst class I have ever taken and I highly recommend avoiding it at all costs.
best_gem_comment: This class is an absolute gem, and super interesting if you're generally interested in the history of computer science and reading CS papers. It is a bit stressful that the entire grade comes down to the video project, though at least the course staff makes it pretty clear what the expectations for the video are and also there are two possible submission deadlines (so if you do bad on the first, you can submit another to bring your grade up potentially). Also, the quality of conversations can either be really good or just okay depending on the table group you get.
subject: Computer Science

course_title: High Performance Computing for Science and Engineering 001
best_comment: I’m not sure what this class will be like without Fabian but if he is still teaching this course next year, TAKE IT. As someone coming in without systems knowledge, this is a great course. If you have good systems knowledge, a lot might be an overview and the class might be on the easier side, still you will come out of it with a lot of practical knowledge on parallel computing. The class can get a little bit too technical sometimes and I wish some of it were abstracted away a bit more but Fabian is great, the course is not too hard but still involved enough to keep you motivated plus the final project is a great way to put everything you learned in practice.
subject: Computer Science
course_title_2023: High Performance Computing for Science and Engineering

best_comment: Take this course! I knew nothing about DP coming in, but it was a fantastic time. Salil is one of the best professors I’ve had at harvard and he really cares about his students. Wanrong and James are also amazing and contribute with new perspectives on the material. The psets are reasonable, but start early. The final project is also super fun, so think early about what you might ant to work on

Take this course! I knew nothing about DP coming in, but it was a fantastic time. Salil is one of the best professors I’ve had at harvard and he really cares about his students.
