course_title: Topics in Theory for Society: Fairness and Validity 001
best_comment: This class is definitely not easy, and not necessarily because the psets are insanely difficult or the proofs are super long or whatever, but because the concepts themselves are sometimes hard for you to wrap your head around.  Additionally, there isn't a lot of existing literature on some of the topics because differential privacy is just a very new field. Definitely focus within the first few weeks of the class and try to really understand the picture, otherwise you will find yourself very confused. The last portion of the class is honestly very, very interesting , and fairness is a very important topic. I do expect that there will likely be some level of vitriol over disorganization in the class, etc. and while I think that this class could use work in terms of being a bit better organized, a lot of people in the course honestly just seemed kind of bitter over things that are to be expected in a CS grad class (e.g. literally being asked to come to class). Also the TFs were great! I believe they're seniors so not sure who's going to do it next year, but office hours were so, so helpful. Also, Prof. Dwork is really, really passionate about a lot of these topics, and in the classes where we did discussions, I found it interesting to hear her questions, thoughts, and interpretations. This class is definitely you get out what you put in in terms of engagement with the material, and as someone who could have engaged more, know that now before you take it!
subject: Computer Science
course_title_2023: Topics in Theory for Society: Differential Privacy

best_comment: Lectures are very difficult to follow, probably because slides are just scanned copies of handwritten notes that are extremely difficult to read. There was not much flow between lectures and lessons and many times it was not clear how different lectures connected to each other. The problem sets were very long and had barely any connection with what we learn in lecture. Finishing the problem sets required going to office hours and reading the textbook (even then, we never learned the necessary strategies to solve such problems, or were given any examples to work through in class). The project had no concrete guidelines, leaving us guessing as to what is to be expected. Annie and Yash really did the most and were accessible and great. The class overall is pretty chill because there are very few assignments, but I found myself spending 20+ hours on each assignment. If you take this class you need to get started on psets early and go to office hours. I think there were 30ish students enrolled, but from the lecture recording it seemed only 5 people showed up. Take with caution, the material is honestly very cool and interesting, but this class did not generate any enthusiasm for the subject, and I don't think I actually learned much from this class
worse_comment: The teaching is not very good. I think he's too smart. Slides are hard to read. Hard to know exactly what's going on... not the math or any individual proof, but the big picture and how the concept he's talking about is important. The textbook is fine, but a little bit dense.  I cannot say I learned much, unfortunately, but that is perhaps just my own problem. The TFs were pretty good 👍.

best_comment: Honestly, I was on the fence about taking this class at the beginning of the semester, with this being a new class and having a new professor. I'm so glad I ended up taking it though because I actually really enjoyed this class. The time commitment was fairly chill and Anurag is a very kind professor and always trying to make sure that everyone is understanding the content as much as possible. I never really imagined myself taking a quantum computing class and made this decision on a whim, but the content was really cool and I can really say that I learned so much taking this class. My one issue with the class is probably that it felt like there were more underlying prereqs to the class than expected. While the only prereqs were CS124 and Stat110, it felt as if we zoomed through the physics background that you needed to learn about and I had to spend a bit of time outside class just trying to understand all the notation and all the other basics. Once I got past this part, it was fairly smooth sailing so I would still recommend this class to  anyone who has a strong linear algebra and CS background.

Definitely take this class! Especially if you are interested in EconCS and learning about how theory can be used to optimize social welfare in a myriad of settings, you will find the course material very fun and fascinating. The course is run extremely well and Ariel is a phenomenal professor. It's not too much work; the psets can be hard but would definitely encourage psetting with friends and going to office hours. Class project is very doable since Ariel is very responsive in giving feedback and helping you along the way. One of the best courses I have taken at Harvard, would def recommend!
worse_comment: Really hard problem sets
best_gem_comment: I am so, so glad this class exists and so glad I got to take it! Ariel is a gem of a human being and a great lecturer who introduces concepts clearly and concisely (it doesn't hurt that he's a Hamilton fan too LOL). I learned a ton about some very interesting topics in the CS–gov intersection, and honestly this is the most engaged I've been in a CS class in a while. The psets are definitely HARD like start those early and work together because you will seriously regret it if you don't, and the final project definitely isn't a joke either, but honestly this class is one of the best and most rewarding ones I've taken at Harvard. Take it if you can!
subject: Computer Science

course_title: Advanced Design of VLSI Circuits and Systems 001
best_comment: This class is great to take when you need something to lighten the load of a heavy semester. It pairs perfectly with CS141 so if you are an EE concentrator, I would definitely recommend taking them at the same time if you enjoy the device side of EE. The class has a great vibe and its a great way to meet grad students and understand what grad school is like.

course_title: Projects and Close Readings in Software Systems 001
best_comment: Be prepared to spend a lot of time reading research papers. It is time consuming, but you do get a lot out of it. It's very nice when you're able to participate in the discussion. It happened to me often times that I only got to truly understand a paper after someone else spoke about it in class. You are technically able to get away with skimming the papers, but then you might as well not take the class. Apart from the final project, we only had one other assignment, which was fun and relaxed. You have lots of opportunity to do whatever you want for the final project; please start early. It is nice when you are able to produce actual results by the deadline, and it feels like a very rewarding end to this course.
worse_comment: Overall a fun class – I would take it just to get to interact with Eddie more. You get to read a lot of foundational papers in the field of distributed computing and systems. You end up absorbing a lot of the high–level information regarding the field, but I'm not sure how well some of the details (i.e., the differences between systems and how they all interact) stuck. While the class is not very difficult, it's a bit more work than I expected (reading four papers, even if only skimming, can add up and the projects are non–trivial).

best_comment: CS271 is a great class if you are interested in working on a visualization research project. I did not take CS171 but I had research/work experience with visualization, and this was fine for the project. Johanna is an excellent and enthusiastic teacher who was respectful and helpful throughout the process. The workload was manageable, and everyone in the class was super nice, and it seemed like everyone wanted to be there.

course_title: Topics in Machine Learning: Advancements in Probabilistic ML, Programming Models for ML, Causality 001
best_comment: Take this class! It think that it is the best applied ML course at Harvard and I would argue the best ML course at Harvard as well. The instructors from Google are incredible – the provide a super cool perspective on the papers you read, really show you a lot of the inner workings of industry research, and are great project mentors. The course also has as really good topics list from applied deep Bayesian methods, to reinforcement learning, to causal ML, to cutting edge applications in bio and chem. Again, I would strongly recommend for anyone interested in ML at Harvard.

course_title: Topics in Machine Learning: Advancements in Probabilistic ML, Programming Models for ML, Causality 001
best_comment: Take this class! It think that it is the best applied ML course at Harvard and I would argue the best ML course at Harvard as well. The instructors from Google are incredible – the provide a super cool perspective on the papers you read, really show you a lot of the inner workings of industry research, and are great project mentors. course_title: Multi-Robot Systems: Control, Communication, and Security 001
best_comment: If you have any interest in robotics, you should absolutely take this course.  Dr. Gil is one of the best lecturers I have encountered at Harvard, she explains things super well and is super friendly with all the students, truly a gem amongst the Harvard faculty.  Give yourself plenty of time for the minihacks and psets.
worse_comment: Do not take this course, especially if the hardware component is still around. The hardware component was not well thought out, and I wasted countless hours trying to debug hardware issues that were simply not possible for students to debug. It is a waste of time to constantly be in the lab, and just be stuck on issues. Also, the course is poorly organized such that assignments are frequently overlapping, and it is very overwhelming.
best_gem_comment: If you have any interest in robotics, you should absolutely take this course.  Dr. Gil is one of the best lecturers I have encountered at Harvard, she explains things super well and is super friendly with all the students, truly a gem amongst the Harvard faculty.  Give yourself plenty of time for the minihacks and psets.

best_comment: This is a fantastic course, and I hope that it is implemented in other programs beyond CS. It teaches a variety of skills that are very helpful for succeeding in the PhD specifically (e.g. reading a paper, critiquing a paper, reading theory papers, communicating science) as well as skills that are helpful for doing well in grad school and life (e.g. mental health, imposter phenomenon, debugging unhealthy self–expectations). There are a variety of faculty visits throughout the course, and they can be very engaging, but I would say that the true gems are the student panels where students ranging from G2 to G6 weigh in on a variety of topics (e.g. how much do you work each day, how to talk to your advisor about vacation). These panels made me feel like I'm not alone in what I'm experiencing. Can't recommend this course enough!
subject: Computer Science
course_title_2023: Seminar on Effective Research Practices and Academic Culture

subject: Computer Science
course_title_2023: Seminar on Effective Research Practices and Academic Culture

course_title: Minerals and Rocks of the Earth and Planets 001
best_comment: This class is something that really changes person to person. Lectures aren't the most interesting. Bur lab can be fun, especially because of the interactive and collaborative settings it produces.  But if you're not that interested in minerals, or don't have a basic foundation in mineralogy, this course isn't really for you. There are a lot of minerals to go over, and crystal structures and other things to memorize. While the assignments are not bad, the tests can be really difficult and hard to prepare for (and you NEED to prepare for them). If you like minerals and have a passion for them, I would recommend this class. The field trip especially was interesting and fun. But if you don't, this isn't the class for you. I will say, the teaching staff are great. While it may not have been the best match for me, both JJ and Rebecca were a delight to get to know and made the class environment very positive!

course_title: Geobiology and the History of Life 001
best_comment: This class is incredible!!! Nadja, Dave, and Javier do a really good job alternating lectures based on their area of expertise and are able to teach these concepts so well that you don't necessarily need much background in either EPS/geology or biology to get a lot out of this class! The labs are where you get to look at a ton of cool rocks and fossils and talk about what we can learn from them, plus there's a really great field trip where you get to see real fossils and rock outcrops in the field! The only grades are from the labs (which you basically finish during the ~2hr lab each week) from a midterm and final exam, and from two ~3–4 page papers that aren't too difficult. This class is obviously perfect for people interested in the overlap between geology and biology, but it's also a great 50–level course for people interested more in either subject!
subject: Earth & Planetary Sciences
course_title_2023: The History and Evolution of Life on Earth

course_title: Geobiology and the History of Life 001

course_title_2023: The History and Evolution of Life on Earth

best_comment: Amazing class!! Professor Eli is a wonderful professor and the climate science topics were fascinating. I especially enjoyed classes on climate reporting when we talked about articles in mass media talking about climate, and on Climate Policy. I am much more aware of climate science, issues of uncertainty and the importance of good data representation. Favorite class at Harvard so far. Take it!
worse_comment: Don't take this class. The assignments are a combination of busywork and attempting to read the professor's mind. Don't be baited by the lack of exams. This is truly the worst class I have taken at Harvard. It's a pity that this class is so bad because the material is inherently interesting. As it is, I wouldn't wish this class upon my enemies.
best_gem_comment: THIS CLASS IS THE BEST CLASS YOU CAN TAKE AT HARVARD. BASICALLY A GEM, BECAUSE YOU LEARN SO MUCH, IT IS EXTREMELY DOABLE, AND THE GRADING IS FANTASTIC
subject: Earth & Planetary Sciences

course_title: Data Analysis and Statistical Inference in the Earth and Environmental Sciences 001
best_comment: The largest strength of this course is that every lesson is tied to specific applications. The result is that you will walk away with a toolbox of statistical methods for environmental sciences. I would recommend this course to anyone in the environmental sciences fields, especially ESPP concentrators who would like a more rigorous statistical introduction than say stat 102/104 but want to keep it more applied to the field than say stat 110. You learn a lot. The evaluative component of the course is fair and low stress (no exams really helps here). The course staff was very receptive to feedback, and provided additional help for students after a difficult problem set 1 really threw  us for a loop. Overall, Roger and the TF's did an excellent job listening to student input. One critique: the late day policy was pretty unintuitive – late days kicked in automatically for assignments worth a negligible part of the grade (BCAs), whereas students had to request late days on psets. The result was that you could inadvertently blow your late days on BCAs. The largest weakness of this course is that it isn't particularly engaging. I felt that the lectures were relatively dry, though I did appreciate whenever Roger tied the lectures to applications in his own research. Sections were more dry, and often it was unclear why exactly we were rehashing a certain topic or focusing in one area rather than others. The projects were pretty fun; I appreciated that students were given flexibility to research their specific interests.  The course gets a little funky and quirky at the end when we talk about ML and Bayesian Statistics, that was cool. If you need to knock out a stat requirement, this is a pretty good way to do it.

course_title: Introduction to Physical Oceanography and Climate 001
best_comment: This class is truly an amazing EPS course. You come away feeling like you understand so much about the ocean; Eli is a great professor and the TF (Camille) is also super accessible and great! The teaching staff has your best interest at heart. With all that being said, this course is definitely mathematically rigorous conceptually, even though psets are infrequently. If you are on top of your work, though, it is super doable.
worse_comment: It’s a good class but the material can get confusing sometimes. It requires a deep conceptual understanding and sometimes that’s more assumed than taught.

best_comment: Take this class! It was super interesting to learn about the atmosphere and the scientific basis of climate change and air pollution. I feel like I walked away with much deeper understanding of atmospheric chemistry. Daniel is one of the leaders in his field and it was so cool to get to learn from him. He is a very engaging and knowledgable professor. Ellie and Nadia were also great TFs and were very helpful with answering pset questions. The psets were not too long and generally the work load in this class was very manageable.
subject: Earth & Planetary Sciences

best_comment: This class was ok. I expected there to be more about the mechanisms of toxicology, but it was more about the physical dynamics of toxins in the environment. A lot of the assignments seemed disorganized. Many times we were given exercises to complete without being fully taught how to complete the exercises – they were just graded on effort, but I think it would have been more effective to be taught beforehand rather than try to figure it out ourselves. Additionally, the material covered on assignments and exams did not always accurately reflect the time spent on those topics in class. That being said, grading was always fair to generous. Elsie and the TFs were helpful and available outside of class.
worse_comment: Everyone should take this class. I learned so much about the chemicals in the environment and in products that will weigh on decisions I make everyday. It scares me how little I knew about toxicology and the fact that there may be others in my same boat that are making policy decisions that effect so many people.

best_comment: Biogeochemistry is a cool class, and Ann is a great professor. You will learn a lot and it will be really interesting. But it's also difficult – be prepared to be confused often and struggle with PSets. Office hours are really helpful, and forming a study group and asking questions in class is essential. Unless you need an EPS credit, I'd recommend auditing or taking this class Pass/Fail, since it has really interesting content but the assignments are really difficult and not all that helpful.
This was a great course. Robin engages with the class well when lecturing. Homework assignments are helpful but not overwhelming. The final project was rewarding.

This class is great. It teaches a lot of interesting details about the science of sea level change. Jerry and Marisa are both great, and create a really friendly class environment. The assignments are not very difficult, and the teaching staff is always willing to give a lot of help.

course_title: An Introduction to Computation for Contemporary Science 001
best_comment: This was Science 5's first year and it certainly has some work  before it becomes a truly successful course. I entered not knowing any coding and, while I cannot run off and code in Python anything I want, I do know how to import data, create graphs, and learn new coding techniques. This course is the least rigorous intro to coding course at Harvard, and I hope they make it more challenging. The foundations are all strong for a truly great course and I believe that the passionate instructors will successfully make this so in the next iteration.
worse_comment: I would not take this course unless it undergoes an immense remodel. I honestly don't think that I learned anything. Actually I must have learned a few things, but definitely not enough for a whole semester of material. Lecture was a waste of time, the assignments were difficult, TFs were frankly unhelpful (perhaps just because of the way the course is organized though... I think they were doing their best), and material was haphazard. This class was incredibly stressful, and I contemplated dropping many times. Beware.

course_title: An Introduction to Computation for Contemporary Science 001

best_comment: I learned so much Chinese – it's weird to literally gain the ability to communicate in another language. I recognize that that's the point of a language class, but I think this is the first one I've taken that succeeded in this goal. By the end of the class, I'd walk out of section chatting with my classmates still in Chinese. It's crazy. I often bragged to my friends about how my classmates and I can *literally* speak Chinese now, like hear questions and just answer them without needing to manually translate word by word. Anyway, I loved this class, actually looked forward to it and felt energized after. It is a lot of work, but very worth it to me.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: The teaching staff is really amazing and supportive, and they are all excellent teachers. Though the coursework is a lot, your Chinese will improve rapidly. The course encourages you to be consistent and intentional with your language learning, and it has been instrumental in helping me on a trajectory towards becoming fluent.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Chinese BB is an extraordinary class. If you took BA, you know what to expect, so there's not too much to say here. The laoshimen are all so kind and invested, the grading is fair and quick, the feedback is detailed, and the community is great. A wonderful, wonderful experience across the board.
best_gem_comment: Honestly pretty tough class even as a native speaker. A lot of time spent studying for dictations, assignments, quizzes, etc. Teaching staff are an absolute gem though and class can be incredibly fun and great way to meet new people and bond with your peers.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: IF YOU TOOK BA, TAKE THIS CLASS! I know it can seem a bit intimidating, but there is truly nothing to lose. Every single one of the instructors are incredible, your Chinese will continue to improve dramatically if you put the work in, and class is just really fun! You'll see the benefit to every assignment you do, from homework to dictations – there's no busy work, everything contributes to improving your overall Chinese fluency.  The teachers are the best part: they're amazing in every way.
worse_comment: Be prepared to stay on top of things in this course. There are days that are more dull and know that you will be answering some questions that you may not know how to articulate in the beginning, but this is all part of taking a language course.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: I really recommend this class. I took it as an elective because of my interest in the language, and found it really helpful in establishing a foundation level of Chinese. The teachers are so kind and supportive, and ready to help too.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Come to this course with a clear specific goal, put effort into the work and you will get more out of it than you expect
subject: Chinese

best_comment: The Chinese language program at Harvard is excellent; teachers are very nice and constantly give helpful feedback, assignments are relevant to class material, and quizzes and exams are truly testing concepts learned in class and not unnecessarily difficult.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: moves very quickly but is even more rewarding. teachers are super fun and understanding
worse_comment: It is organized more or less the same as previous Chinese classes with the exception that you no longer need to learn to write characters (you can use computer for exams/homework), so it is actually quite a bit less time–consuming.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: This class is set up very well and ran by a group of very passionate teachers. They push you to be your best and help in countless ways. I would 100% recommend this course.
subject: Chinese

course_title: Intermediate Modern Chinese for Advanced Beginners 001
best_comment: Taking Chinese was an AMAZING experience, and I'm so glad I took it for at least one semester during my time at Harvard. Take it with friends in the same section and class will always be fun, the teachers are incredible and I learned so much of the language! I appreciate that content is based around very applicable topics, so everything we learn feels very useful.
subject: Chinese
course_title_2023: Intermediate Modern Chinese for Advanced Beginners

course_title: Intermediate Modern Chinese for Advanced Beginners 002
best_comment: fantastic, fantastic course for people who are looking to improve their conversational Chinese — my parents have remarked on my improvement from our facetimes :) and the teachers are so lovely
subject: Chinese
course_title_2023: Intermediate Modern Chinese for Advanced Beginners

course_title: Intermediate Modern Chinese for Advanced Beginners 003
best_comment: Harvard's Chinese department is incredible, and this class further confirms that for me! The teachers make every class so much fun, and the community is amazing as well. You will quickly progress your Chinese speaking, reading, and writing level, and also gain a deeper cultural understanding.
subject: Chinese
course_title_2023: Intermediate Modern Chinese for Advanced Beginners

best_comment: Chinese has always been one of my favorite classes every semester, if not my favorite. It was incredibly engaging and provides so many opportunities to practice. The Chinese department is wonderful and always has new ideas to improve the class.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Please take chinese if you are considering it. The Chinese department is so amazing and you will not regret taking this class. You have the chance to talk about real–world problems with your peers and receive thorough feedback by the teaching staff. If you put in the work, you will see the results, FAST.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: I firmly believe the Chinese department is the best language department at Harvard. If you’ve taken other Chinese course at Harvard, then you know what to expect for this class: wonderful and enthusiastic  teachers, well structured and thought through lesson plans, and insight into Chinese culture, art, and politics! Of course the time commitment may be a lot with having class five days a week, but it is well worth it. I would not describe it as any more than previous levels. Take this class and watch your Chinese improve, while also meeting some of the best, nicest, and most committed teaching staff around!!
subject: Chinese

course_title: Pre-Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners 001
best_comment: Take this class!!! The teachers are great, content is pretty engaging, and everyone who picks this class is quite enthusiastic which makes for an even better experience :)
subject: Chinese
course_title_2023: Pre-Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners

course_title: Pre-Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners 002
best_comment: Chinese 130XB is a little tougher than the previous levels but definitely super interesting and very rewarding! The grammar structures are harder and are more focused on formal language, but the instructors still try their best to engage you with the course content. The lectures are centered around different social issues in China, so it's super interesting to be studying and talking about current events in the class too.
subject: Chinese
course_title_2023: Pre-Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners

best_comment: The teachers are great! Like all Chinese classes at Harvard, I really enjoyed my time in this class and learned a lot. However, the course structure is different from other Chinese classes and I felt like not having tests or dictations hampered my ability to remember all the vocabulary.
subject: Chinese

course_title: Life and Death in Late Imperial China: Social History of the 10th to 19th Centuries 01
best_comment: This was the best class I've ever taken at Harvard, hands down. As a cynical history concentrator I had grown tired of the standard way history classes are taught, but Professor Szonyi reinvigorated my love for history. His lecture style is very participatory, there was no class where he was just talking and students were just taking notes; in every single class, 90% of the students participated in the class discussion (which was intertwined with the lectures). My comments actually felt valued by Professor Szonyi and the TF (Chao); it was a nice feeling. Even if you don't think you would be interested in Imperial Chinese history (I get it), after taking this class you will feel so lucky to have learned more about it. Also, for the STEM people out there, you should consider this class too. There were multiple STEM concentrators in the class, and everyone was able to participate fully. Readings are well chosen, and never overwhelming. 10/10, 5 stars, etc. Essentially, just take this class!
subject: Chinese History
course_title_2023: Life and Death in Late Imperial China: Social History of the 10th to 19th Centuries

best_comment: This is a really worthwhile class.

course_title: Modern History of Rural China: Proseminar 01
best_comment: Prof Szonyi is the best instructor I have met at Harvard. He is very knowledgeable, smart, and humorous. I learn a lot from the way he teaches.
subject: Chinese History
course_title_2023: Modern History of Rural China: Proseminar

course_title: Shanghai and Beijing: A Tale of Two Cities: Seminar 01
best_comment: Definitely worth taking if you are interested in 20th–century China!

This course is an amazing course that truly makes you rethink your engagement with media. My own engagement with media completely changed from before I took this course––each week's topics and readings are remarkable and Professor Zahlten's lectures are always very rich with material, cohesive and interesting. I would highly recommend it to anyone––no background in Japanese language etc. I think is necessary as Professor Zahlten always contextualized everything thoroughly for everyone in the class.

course_title: Media Mix: Representations and Meaning Between Media in Japan: Seminar 01
best_comment: One of the best classes I have ever taken at Harvard. If you're interested in media, this class is a great introduction to so many areas of discussion. The selection of readings are super interesting and the class discussions were phenomenal. Definitely don't feel discouraged from taking this class just because of prior background with media studies/comfortability with the Japanese language..! Learned so, so much from this class that made me incredibly interested in media studies and also made me rethink my engagement with media in a completely different way.

course_title: Introduction to the Study of East Asia: Issues and Methods 001
best_comment: I thought this was a great sophomore tutorial. Not only did it challenge me with the subject matter, but also I felt equally well exposed to the variety of topics that intersected with EAS. I also thought the class gave students a great opportunity to learn about who is in the department, and I feel more at ease reaching out to a random EAS professor. Also, as an East Asian student in the class, I thought it did a pretty good job educating about other EA cultures. Although, I wish there was more information about non–Chinese, Korean, and Japanese cultures. Definitely recommend taking it if you are interested in EAS, or just want a class to provide you with alternative perspectives.
subject: East Asian Studies
course_title_2023: Introduction to the Study of East Asia: Issues and Methods

course_title: Major Religious Texts of East Asia 01
best_comment: This class is amazing. Professor Abe really cares about each student in the class. You get to read really interesting books every week and meet peers from a variety of disciplines. You learn about ways to prioritize happiness in your everyday life, and how to develop a healthier relationship to desires, expectations (whether from family or peers), and overall, grow as a person to be more compassionate for others.
If you are able to complete large amounts of reading, this course is for you. Its a very interesting subject, but may require more work than one would initially assume.
subject: East Asian Studies

course_title: Medicine and the Self in China and in the West 01
best_comment: I would recommend anyone who has the slightest interest in Chinese medicine and/or those who have yet to fulfill their arts and humanities requirement to take this course. You will not only learn about traditional Chinese and Western medicine, but you will also learn about new ways to view the world and to view the self. It is truly an enlightening and illuminating class. Additionally, Professor Kuriyama is such a great lecturer,  he makes sure that classes are engaging and his magic tricks are certainly a highlight! I also felt like the workload was pretty manageable and you get a good variety in the types of assignment you need to complete.
worse_comment: Taking this course was one of the most educational experiences i've had at Harvard. No matter your level of familiarity or interest in history you WILL learn something. Not just stories or facts, but methods and the fun/joy of being a historian. That manic Charlie Day energy finding weird connections, being called crazy, and making genuine historical arguments on fashionable fainting – for example.
best_gem_comment: Overall a really interesting class! Definitely learned about different perspectives about the history of medicine that I don't think any other classes on campus really offer. There is an assignment nearly every week (quizzes, synopsis essays, database activities, etc.) so it might be a little bit more work than I was hoping for from a gem, but its totally manageable

best_comment: A really important class to better understand China and stop treating it as a monolith. You will learn a great deal about the internal politics and geography of China and reevaluate the extent of control the CCP has on its citizens. Probably one of the classes I have learned the most from content–wise. Great in terms of building skills too, as you learn how to use map–making software (QGIS) and create an interesting final project. Prof. Koss is a good lecturer who always ties in his own experiences and shows actual pictures of what he's talking about in China. He's a bit of a "scattered" lecturer, but very passionate and the lessons are always clear.
worse_comment: This class is very educational but very very very very time demanding. You do not have much support and basically must fend for yourself. Professor Koss is nice and understanding but at the end of the day the material is brutal and the assignments are super difficult
hard work will pay off.
hard work will pay off.

best_comment: Take this class if you have any interest in Japanese/Japan whatsoever (even if it is just from anime) . It is an fantastic course with amazing course staff, and it's honestly really fun. Because you meet every day, you'll get to know a lot of cool people and be part of a great community.
subject: Japanese

best_comment: To enjoy the process. It is a very rewarding experience and can open up opportunities in the future.
subject: Japanese

best_comment: This class is simply amazing. Unlike most other classes at Harvard, I am never looking at the clock during Japanese class and wondering when the class will end. Kageyama Sensei, Nakazato Sensei, and Takehara Sensei keep all of us engaged throughout the entire class, and I always can pinpoint what exactly I learned or improved upon after class. My language skills have improved immensely. As someone who has only taken STEM classes at Harvard, Japanese BB allowed me to meet a diverse group of people who are all extremely passionate about Japanese and make a lot of friends. The instructors put a tremendous amount of effort into the class and exhibit a lot of passion for the material. As a result, you will find that your peers also put in a lot of effort and actually care about the class material. The workload is very manageable and spread out.  If you are on the fence about Japanese, please take it! You will not regret it, I promise.
worse_comment: There is no way that Harvard's JAPANBa & Bb courses are not the very best introductory Japanese courses in the nation (and probably the world). If you have any interest in the language, then I would say the best time to start learning would be now.
subject: Japanese

best_comment: This was a great course, as have all my experience with the Japanese language program has been. Through this course, you will learn how to effectively read, write, speak, and listen to Japanese, making you one step closer to achieving total fluency.
subject: Japanese

best_comment: Japan 120b is a small step up in difficulty, but will massively increase your Japanese ability and confidence relative to 120a. Well worth the significant time investment required. You will have to work a lot, but there is no studying required that felt gratuitous.
subject: Japanese

best_comment: Same as 130a, same structure etc etcYou'll get really advanced, more so than the jump from 120 to 130 imo (not in difficulty but in how much you know and how much you can say.)If you finish 130 you can certainly finish 130b so don't give up!!
worse_comment: Pace yourself, study hard, and remain organized.
subject: Japanese

best_comment: Definitely take this course if you're on the fence! It is incredibly rewarding and will allow your Japanese to advance leaps and bounds. Professors Asakura and Yagi are outstanding teachers, and I felt supported by them, as well as my peers in my class throughout.
subject: Japanese

course_title: Reading Scholarly Japanese for Students of Chinese and Korean 001
worse_comment: Useful for scholarly reading. No pain, no gains.
subject: Japanese
course_title_2023: Reading Scholarly Japanese for Students of Chinese and Korean

course_title: Traditional Japanese Literature: From Mythology to (Early) Modernity 01
best_comment: Take this class. It's absolutely remarkable. Prof. Atherton alone is enough of a reason to enroll because he is so knowledgeable, enthusiastic, funny, and warm. Each and every class is exciting and engaging, with tons of fascinating discussions. The reading list is incredible (get ready for some truly wild literature, in the best sense) and the assignments encourage so much creativity, which makes the work feel all the more satisfying personally. Prof. Atherton genuinely cares about his students (evident in his very thoughtful feedback on all assignments) and creates a wonderfully supportive classroom environment. Despite how much I'd encourage others to take this class, I only hope it remains somewhat small–natured in the future, because I think this course is so successful in large part thanks to the intimacy of knowing everyone in the room and being able to discuss things all together.
best_gem_comment: If you're at all interested in the subject matter, take this class!! Prof. Atherton is literally my favorite professor at Harvard––his enthusiasm for the course material is infectious, and he is the most compassionate, understanding, and accommodating professor I have ever taken a class from. Truly a gem!!!

course_title: Early Modern Japanese Literature and Culture 01
best_comment: This class is well worth the time as a crucial step towards autonomy in research.
It is quite a bit of work, but the teachers are great and sections are very interactive. My Korean (especially written and formal speech) improved  a lot!
best_gem_comment: This class is definitely a gem. But please be ready to be challenged and be ready for quite a heavy workload.
subject: Korean

best_comment: This class is worth taking! It's been one of the most rewarding classes I've taken. The staff will help you push through some of the challenging conjugations in such a fun and encouraging way. I've had so much fun laughing at the final projects you get to create in this course. I wish I had started taking Korean classes at Harvard sooner!
subject: Korean

best_comment: While the course can be hard at time, it is worth the effort since I could clearly see great improvements in my Korean skills. Professor Noh is honestly one of the best teachers. She can explain really complex grammar structures in such a simple manner all while speaking Korean. Also, she makes class so fun through her dynamic and engaging teaching style. I also really liked how this semester we learned more about Korean culture and how to talk about cultural differences. This is a must take class if you want to continue to improve your Korean.
subject: Korean

best_comment: Teaching:The teaching in this class was fantastic! Kim SSN is so funny and talented and makes every class equal parts informative and entertaining. I can confidently say that I had the most fun in Korean Bx + 123xb out of all the classes I took this year.Workload/assignments:The workload can get pretty heavy at times, so if you are interested in taking the class, be prepared for a lot of assignments. Based on my experience, most of the assignments did end up being worthwhile but it can definitely feel like a slog at times. A typical week of assignments consists of 2–3 chapters of grammar homework   (1–2 hrs depending on ur speed) and a couple short essays based on narration passages from the textbook (another 1–2 hours). However, three times a semester you will be required to write a 1.5 page essay and then memorize and give a 5–minute presentation based on that essay. On those weeks, I probably spent between 8–10 hours on Korean outside of class. As some consolation, there is no grammar + composition hw on presentation weeks.Community:I love the community that formed around this class! I found that it was easy to make friends since as Korean Americans we had many common experiences to bond over. It was also fun to have a group of people around the same level as me in Korean who I could converse with on a daily basis. Some of my favorite memories with my Korean chingus this semester were hanging out for an hour before most classes in NW basement and planning a group 노래방 trip together!Preparedness:I would say if you are trying to figure out if 123xb is the right class for you, taking the placement test is definitely the best option! After you get your initial placement, you can schedule a follow–up meeting with one of the Korean professors to get a better idea of where your specific reading, writing, and speaking skills fall relative to the classes. My one note for 123xb and the heritage track in general is that since most of the students speak Korean at home, they will be able to process and speak and process the language pretty quickly and comfortably even if their grammar isn't 100% correct.
subject: Korean

best_comment: 130b is a huge jump from 130xa in terms of amount of work, but not in terms of difficulty. I'm not sure how it will be next year, but this year the lesson homeworks were shorter than 130xa, but the textbook homeworks required more work and there were video speaking homeworks to go with each speaking session. There is also a reading presentation that is longer than the final presentation. Given all that, the homeworks all had a purpose and really made me practice Korean every day. The final essay topic options are also generally drier than 130a options as they are supposed to be more advanced topics. Lee and Kwark SSNs were really amazing as always and were a joy to be taught by. There were many opportunities to practice speaking and to hear others speak which I thought was great. After 130xa/a there is still a lot to learn in terms of grammar structures and vocab, so 130b is definitely worth it if you have the time.
subject: Korean

best_comment: I'm saddened and distraught to hear that Professor Binh Nhu Ngo will not be teaching anymore but he certainly made the class what it is at Havard. I think this class was a great way to start the day and to just have fun learning and speaking with your classmates.
worse_comment: Whether you are of Vietnamese heritage or not, you can succeed in this class with reasonable effort.
subject: Vietnamese

best_comment: The class with Anne LeBrun is rewarding if you put in the work. She doesn't do an incredible job teaching the material in lecture, but if you can go to office hours and get help then the class is great. Anne is super excited about teaching economics and it shows, you can tell she loves teaching Econ. Really light work load, so a gem if you get economics really easily.
worse_comment: Make sure to attend lecture in–person! You learn much more, and it saves time in the end (going back to the slides is not as helpful, and usually you end up worse–off when it comes to preparing for the exams).
best_gem_comment: The class with Anne LeBrun is rewarding if you put in the work. She doesn't do an incredible job teaching the material in lecture, but if you can go to office hours and get help then the class is great. Anne is super excited about teaching economics and it shows, you can tell she loves teaching Econ. Really light work load, so a gem if you get economics really easily.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This class is great and I personally think it's a class everyone should take regardless of major. I had basically no knowledge of economics before this course and it was a great introduction that made me realize just how important an understanding of basic economics and finance is for everyone. The professors are great and so passionate about the subject and it really makes you feel passionate about it as well. My TF was also amazing and cared so much about making sure everyone understood the material. The assignments are extremely manageable and are actually related to the material taught in class. The exams are also fair and there's no surprises. Overall, great and important class.
worse_comment: Take it!!! Take it pass/fail if you are afraid of its impact on your GPA. Do all of the URPs to avoid being stuck with a B+/A– as a result of bad test scores
subject: Economics

best_comment: This class is great and I personally think it's a class everyone should take regardless of major. I had basically no knowledge of economics before this course and it was a great introduction that made me realize just how important an understanding of basic economics and finance is for everyone. The professors are great and so passionate about the subject and it really makes you feel passionate about it as well. My TF was also amazing and cared so much about making sure everyone understood the material. The assignments are extremely manageable and are actually related to the material taught in class. The exams are also fair and there's no surprises. Overall, great and important class.
worse_comment: Take it!!! Take it pass/fail if you are afraid of its impact on your GPA. Do all of the URPs to avoid being stuck with a B+/A– as a result of bad test scores
subject: Economics

best_comment: This class is great and I personally think it's a class everyone should take regardless of major. I had basically no knowledge of economics before this course and it was a great introduction that made me realize just how important an understanding of basic economics and finance is for everyone. The professors are great and so passionate about the subject and it really makes you feel passionate about it as well. My TF was also amazing and cared so much about making sure everyone understood the material. The assignments are extremely manageable and are actually related to the material taught in class. The exams are also fair and there's no surprises. Overall, great and important class.
worse_comment: Take it!!! Take it pass/fail if you are afraid of its impact on your GPA. Do all of the URPs to avoid being stuck with a B+/A– as a result of bad test scores
subject: Economics

course_title: Using Big Data to Solve Economic and Social Problems 001
best_comment: Great course to satisfy the Social Studies stat credit. Lectures are more interesting than normal stat/ec lectures because they actually apply the concepts to reality. A lot of lecture is just Prof. Chetty talking about different people's research, so the connection to stat isn't always clear (basically the connection is just that they used stat to conduct their research). The lab component is where you do the most stat. I did lab in stata and it was pretty easy considering I had never coded before — you are given a lot of starter code so it's very beginner friendly. Not a ton of time is spent on explaining the stat components of the course — although they are gone over a bit in lab and you can always ask questions if you have them — so sometimes it felt like the elements of the class were a bit disjointed: lecture was applied economics, lab was coding, and the lab–prep videos were stat. The midterm was short and easy — just watch all of the lectures to prep and you'll do great because they pull directly from lecture. The empirical projects were a bit more time–consuming and complex than a normal lab but definitely nothing too bad and if you need help there are lots of office hours available. Overall, a good way to satisfy a stat credit with minimal math and not a very big time suck. Recommend.
worse_comment: This class has a lot of assignments and as non–ec major they became a bit burdensome.  Additionally, this course has such a large breadth and tries to cover so much cool stuff that its very hard to actually learn something before moving on to the next thing. Additionally, the exams are kinda stressful and nitpicky and cover very specific things from lectures/labs so its hard to study for them.
best_gem_comment: Easy class. Definite GEM! Interesting material and if you get a good section you basically are walked through the lab, which is the only homework component other than 2 Emperical projects throughout the semester. Honestly, the Emperical projects are basically the only work to do.
subject: Economics
course_title_2023: Using Big Data to Solve Economic and Social Problems

subject: Economics
course_title_2023: Using Big Data to Solve Economic and Social Problems

best_comment: Obviously this class is required but its definitely important to enroll in a subject you're interested in as you solely focus on those areas. STATA office hours were so helpful with the PSETs and final project.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This feedback is for the law and economics seminar specifically. This seminar is 100% worth the time and you should 100% take it. The readings, although a lot, are always really engaging. Class discussion flows naturally and each week is quite substantive. Professor Felter is so kind and accessible and truly does care about each student's success. He gives thorough feedback on all assignments and does a great job of encouraging the Socratic–style seminar. It's one of the only tutorials with a second class for a reason!
worse_comment: Applying Economic Theory to the Practice of Law is not easy, but you do end up learning a lot and Professor Felter is very thorough with his comments. A fair warning is that grading is pretty harsh, and you most likely won't get above an A– on most assignments or in the class.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This economics tutorial is phenomenal and is a gem within the sophomore tutorial selections. There are a lot of readings and writing assignments, but such is the case with most other tutorials. If you are on the fence about the law, or just want to take a class to learn a lot about economics and the law, I would highly recommend this class. Every reading was selected with care for the content. Professor Felter provides ample feedback to help you improve as a writer and critical thinker. The discussions every week were interesting. You do not need to be pre–law to take this class, and in my experience, most of the people were on the fence about the law. Professor Felter is an amazing professor, and if you take this class, you will leave the class knowing comprehensively what economics is and what the law is, and what an economic analysis of the law entails.
worse_comment: Professor Feldman is a great professor. He gives feedback that is very thorough and in–depth. There are a lot of readings but I feel I learned a lot from being in this class. While this class was difficult, I would consider it a gem.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Before taking Econ 970, I had heard that sophomore tutorials were time–consuming, difficult, and honestly unenjoyable. I'm surprised to say that it ended up being my favorite class of the semester and one of my favorite I've taken at Harvard. I took Economics of Cities with Andrés Maggi and couldn't recommend it more highly. Andrés cares so much about his students, makes you feel like he genuinely wants you to succeed, and is all around THE BEST. He fostered such a great class environment where everyone was encouraged to participate and we could all joke around together and have a good time as well. I'm truly not a hardo who usually loves difficult classes, but I was pleasantly surprised by this one, even though there was a decent (but definitely manageable) amount of work.TLDR: Take Economics of Cities with Andrés!! He's so knowledgable, understanding, and made this class so much better than I expected it to be.
worse_comment: My favorite class by far –– Economics of Cities with Andres Maggi (sometimes Q guide is weird about splitting up ) You will get a thorough understanding of both how to read and how to write economics research. Andres really takes you through the field of spatial economics with a planned mode of attack such that you understand the field at a high–level and understand some details. Take this one if you can!!!
subject: Economics

best_comment: Great course on development economics, state capacity, and taxation. Be sure to read papers beforehand to contribute in section.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Take this class, you would enjoy it. Have some understanding of statistics.
worse_comment: This class is not fun, a lot of busy work, reading, writing, and coding for not much benefit and upside (because this class has so much work and students are already so busy that students just BS all of the assignments), but you have to take this class because it is required. I think the Ec department should slowly move away from this class and no longer make it a requirement in the future.
subject: Economics

best_comment: The sophomore tutorial is a requirement for economics concentrators and it is definitely one of the harder courses in the concentration. Your experience in the class will largely be determined by the tutorial you get placed in. I think that Applied Health Economics is one of the more interesting classes and I would recommend it to anyone who is interested in medicine and healthcare. Brad is also super knowledgeable and all the case studies he introduces in class are a great addition to the course material. However, I do think that he does not give as much constructive feedback as one might like so grading can feel a little arbitrary at times.
subject: Economics

course_title: Behavioral Economics of Risk and Learning 001
best_comment: This is a fantastic class that spans almost all relevant topics in behavioral economics. Tomasz is a great professor who is easygoing in his lecture style and the class feels like more of a conversation than a high pressure tutorial. Awesome freedom to study what interestes you and develop your own unique final project while not getting bogged down by too much work. A great experience overall.

I loved this class. Amanda is wonderful – talented and articulate and passionate and kind. She makes everything completely accessible and is completely open to questions and clarifications. Francesca is also extremely accessible and knowledgeable. The content is not going to change your world but it might equip you more skills as you pursue a thesis or research. Nothing crazy, but given the more limited workload over the week, it is worth it. The large assignment of designing an experiment is fun and interesting. I'd take with no hesitation again. It would be great to balance out an extremely tough workload. One of my favorites.
If you write a thesis, I couldn't recommend taking Kiran's Ec 985 enough! She is brilliant, engaging, and deeply caring.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Definitely take it if you’re writing a thesis. Even though you may not be solid in a topic, getting started with a general idea early on is very helpful, and this class helps with that.
worse_comment: 985 in the spring isn't as helpful as in the fall – it's mostly presenting your work to the section. Take advantage of meeting with your section head for more detailed feedback.
subject: Economics

best_comment: melitz is a great lecturer/professor, and I really enjoyed taking 1010a in the spring. not sure what the fall version is like, but I like how the psets are in the form of Smartworks, where we get infinite tries + hints + explanations to the problems. overall, weekly psets/quizzes are very fair and great to learn from. i also like how the course is structured so lecture is for conceptual understanding and section is for problem–solving. i debated between taking this class and ec1011a in the fall, but as a math/cs–leaning person, taking this class in the spring just made a lot more sense for freeing up space for more math/cs classes in the fall.
worse_comment: This is the worst class that I have taken at Harvard so far. The content is bland and boring, and the course staff is not very helpful. Avoid it at all costs, unless you need to take it as a requirement. Either way, I would very much recommend taking it in the Fall.
subject: Economics

best_comment: I thought this course was better than what most classmates told me about. The lectures were pretty effective for doing well on the tests, and I found it helpful to rewatch the lectures before the tests. The Psets aren't graded and lecture attendance isn't required, so showing up is definitely a good way to begin doing well.The tests are all multiple choice which can sound difficult, but I actually liked it better than free response problems. The only tricky thing to keep in mind is that Professor Foote will test on small points (ex. what did this specific paper say about this topic that we briefly discussed for 5 minutes four weeks ago).I don't know if I would take this course as a non–ec concentrator but I definitely think it's a good course. I learned a lot about macro and feel like I better understand the world economy.
worse_comment: Despite excellent lectures from Professor Foote, Ec1010b is the single most frustrating course I've taken at Harvard.  The exams feel designed to deceive and trick you into picking the wrong answer rather than truly assessing your understanding of the material.  If that isn't bad enough, they make up 90% of your grade (really 100% when you consider that most students earn virtually all of their homework points). Overall, this course was incredibly disappointing and I would not recommend it to anyone unless required (or taking pass/fail).
subject: Economics

best_comment: I took this class my first–year spring, without having taken Ec 1011a in the fall. My relevant background includes Math 25a  in the fall and AP Econ in high school. First, I think that Ec 1011b is more of a math class than an econ class; most of the class focuses on manipulating mathematical models of the economy using algebra and taking derivatives. For the level of math required, Math 21a is recommended, but it should be doable without knowing any multivariable calculus because almost all of the calculus in this class is taking partial derivatives (I personally took Multivariable Calculus simultaneously with Ec 1011b, and was fine even though I used partial derivatives in econ before I learned about them in math). But math is a central component of this course, and expect to do a hefty level of math. However, the thing with the class being mathy is that you can get away with a good grade without having much of an economic intuition for the models; aka you can do fine without understanding why certain things are true about the models (ex. why is this investment function decreasing with interest rate?) I personally had this issue in the beginning, so if you find yourself being fine at the math but not really understanding why you're doing the math, I recommend reading the textbook and asking your TF/Prof for intuition. They are very helpful, and make sure to ask very basic questions even if you think you'll look stupid (because you won't look stupid, actually), especially if you didn't take Ec 10b (I asked a lot of these). Having a strong econ and math understanding of models will make you appreciate the things you learn in this class WAY MORE, and I think you'll find econ to be super cool :)
worse_comment: This was a really rough class; lecture was often confusing and chaotic, with several errors in slides. Section was helpful, but could also be extremely confusing if derailing questions were asked. Problem sets were not nearly as challenging as exams (the first exam was so hard that the grading distribution of the class had to be changed in the middle of the semester). Mathematically, I don't think it is that difficult, but the presentation of the content makes it seem much more confusing than it is. Coming from a 1010a background, I missed Boycko's clarity; you'll have to put in a ton of time outside of class just to understand what is going on in the models (but the math in the models is not too hard). Also, way too much time was spent with the head TF hating on the professor, and the professor hating on the head TF; the focus should be on the economics....
subject: Economics

best_comment: The most thought–provoking class I have taken at Harvard (though I am a Stat concentrator, so take that with a grain of salt). Some of the economics is breezed over, but the topics discussed and the discourse on race and inequality are very relevant and interesting. Prof Fryer is an engaging lecturer and encourages pushback on his ideas, which makes for some fun class discussions. Assignments are very chill which helped me fully enjoy the course content. Great class!
best_gem_comment: Take this class! It was my favorite class that I took this semester and Fryer is such a gem. You'll really enjoy the lectures and they're interactive which is cool.

course_title: The Psychology and Economics of Beliefs 001
best_comment: This is an excellent seminar. Matthew is a genius, he can think of economic models for almost everything you can imagine. If you can follow his toughts, it is a terrific experience to have a conversation with him. It is very hard to find professors so open to students as he is. Definetly I would recommend you to take this class.
worse_comment: Need stat background to do well and understand the slides. Professor Rabin is very approachable/nice but could be quite unorganized regarding posting slides, problem sets and so on; be prepared to face a lot of uncertainty.
subject: Economics
course_title_2023: The Psychology and Economics of Beliefs

best_comment: Econ 1050 gives a nice and simple overview of game theory. While it brings up a lot of interesting concepts, it does not go too in depth into the technical workings of them. As a math concentrator, the calculations and problem sets were not too difficult. There was not too much work outside of class, so it was nice to take as a light class along with some very difficult ones. Overall, the class was fun and interesting and I’m glad I took it.
worse_comment: This class is very hard and confusing, do not take this course.
subject: Economics

best_comment: it's a requirement, so you have to take it anyways if you're an econ concentrator. BUT try to take this course when Prof Bruich teaches it!! The class is so organized because of him—lecture slides are really helpful and easy to digest (great formatting), section notes are a godsend & lifesaver for studying for exams, and the problem sets are barely busy work (with the exception of lots of repetitive coding when it comes to generating output tables and running regressions). Make sure to choose a section leader that is effective for YOUR learning style, so switch to a diff section even if you were assigned to a certain one! Reading the textbook is useless for this class, because all that you possibly need to know is in the lecture slides / section notes. Exams are very fair, and resemble the practice exams, so make sure to do those. Overall, not as painful of a class as I'd expected, but putting in the work does take time.
worse_comment: This class will make you feel a lot more equipped to understand the methods used in economic papers and actually use them someday to answer questions that interest you. The lectures sometimes seem overwhelming with math, statistics, and code, but the problem sets and exams are generally restricted to only the most relevant material.  Also, lack of coding experience is not a barrier to taking this class at all; all problem sets include sample code, and the exams do not involve coding.
best_gem_comment: This is class is hard. Don't take this as an elective. Only if it's required. And if it's required, take it RIGHT after you do Stat 100 or 104 or Ec 50, and be prepared for this to be your hardest class. Don't take another pset class the same semester as this one unless you're built like that, and make sure you have at least 1 gem in rotation.
subject: Economics

course_title: Authoritarian Superpower: The Political Economy of Modern China 01
best_comment: An amazing, amazing course!!!! Please please take it, Yang is an amazing professor and a genius. He cares so much about the course content and his students. He has optional lunches with him––strongly recommend attending if you can! Super knowledgable, always available after class/in OH. Literally everything you would want in a professor. You also learn SO MUCH about China. Would recommend actually doing the readings, they are short and help you outside the material. Also, start early on the project, it's super helpful to do this and then attend OH as questions about data/econometrics/results come up.

course_title: The Economics of Development and Global Health 001
best_comment: It is really hard to describe what it was like. You kind of had to be there yourself. But Matt was a passionate, brilliant, caring lecturer who seemed to have unlimited knowledge and experience. But it was also fair to say he is still young and ambitious with some likely exaggerations and minor flaws – the slides could be confusing and the larger point sometimes muddled amidst constant, thought–provoking studies. Some days it felt like it was all coming together, a broad and holistic synthesis to equip us tools to solve pressing issues, others it all felt confusing. But I think the course is unlike any other and one 100% worth taking just to hear from Matt and to consider society's problems and potential solutions. Gl.
worse_comment: This class is unforgettable. You are taught to completely question all the economic and statistical models we are taught in the rest of our Economics coursework, rightfully so. You are taught to recognize your role in helping others. This class put a fire under all of us to do something about the people dying from stupid deaths and I don't think any other economics class has the same amount of impact this class has the potential of making.
subject: Economics
course_title_2023: The Economics of Development and Global Health

best_comment: SHLEIFER is AMAZING!!!! Cares SO much about his students and this class. I honestly learned a lot about political economy and am grateful to have taken this course. Super nice that it only meets once a week, and the readings are honestly not that bad/long. A lot of the papers are seminal works in econ, so worth actually reading them. The books are interesting as well––I would recommend that with weeks with memos, you start early, as the response papers can sneak up on you. Final project is fun, would also recommend starting early if you can, so you're not scrambling to write the 20 pages, which the first draft is due mid–April.
subject: Economics

best_comment: TAKE THIS ECON ELECTIVE!!! Robin is a fantastic and engaging lecturer, and this is genuinely the best econ class and among the most enjoyable Harvard courses I've ever taken. Psets are challenging but interesting, exams are fair, and you'll start to see traces of industrial org theory (which is fascinating, if you've ever wanted to learn how to win an auction or dip your toes in a manageable way in other concepts like market concentration and platforms) everywhere in life.
worse_comment: I think this is the most interesting/useful economics class I've ever taken! Very applicable to the real world. But make sure to do your readings and start your problem sets early!

course_title: Economics of Climate Change and Environmental Policy 001
best_comment: I would definitely recommend enrolling in this course, especially if you are looking for an interesting and relatively painless way to fulfill an economics elective requirement. The instructor is great, he has great anecdotes from his firsthand experience working in climate negotiations and policy, he is also dry and entertaining to listen to. The PSETs and exams are all very fair, and the course staff provide lots of practice materials and detailed answer keys to assist with studying. Be warned that the exams are a significant portion of your final grade (75%) if you do not like testing under pressure. Overall, very solid and tangible course in the department that genuinely only requires EC10a to succeed.
worse_comment: The course content and delivery is extremely old–fashioned in its dependence in economic theory to the point that it has clear holes in the realistic application in the policy sphere including the information on the treatment of poorer countries in international policy, the realistic implications of current carbon pricing policies and their actual impacts on mitigating climate change, and the treatment of scientific concepts and progression as concrete and unchanging. Further, student disagreement and questions are largely disregarded and dismissed because of the siloing of policies into the lens of classical economic theory.
subject: Economics
course_title_2023: Economics of Climate Change and Environmental Policy

best_comment: An amazing introduction to corporate finance in a way that is extremely applicable. This is hands down the most interesting and useful class I have taken at Harvard – if you are interested in IB/PE, the fundamental concepts will be extremely valuable and interesting. Professor Bergstresser is also such an awesome professor, tells great stories in class, and is super accessible/down to earth (definitely be sure to get burritos with him at Felipe's). Without a doubt this is my favorite class I have taken at Harvard!
worse_comment: If you have already prepped for banking interviews this class is all review and will be a little boring and slow. If not, it is a great way to prep for finance jobs.
best_gem_comment: This class is one that many people take as an easy econ elective that satisfies the intermediate prerequisite requirement. I would say that if you are not already in the finance field, this class is not as easy as people make it out to be. There are tons of people that do finance, are in finance clubs/have learned most of this material already taking this class as an easy gem, and they will screw up the curve for you. The people I knew that did not know finance coming in really struggled with the concepts.
subject: Economics

course_title: Financial Crises and Recessions of the 21st Century 01
best_comment: This class was terrific! I took it as a senior, having taking nothing but Ec10a and b my freshman year and I loved this class. It's an awesome mix of economics and history and Professor Dynan (my friends call her Queen Dynan) is so engaging, friendly, and knowledgeable. The assignment are not too challenging while also zooming out and providing a broader view of the topics covered in this class. A great class to take if you're curious about economics but don't necessarily have a robust background in the field. I highly recommend!!
worse_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS TO LEARN ABOUT 2008 FINANCIAL CRISIS and 2020 COVID–19 CRISIS!!!
subject: Economics
course_title_2023: Financial Crises and Recessions of the 21st Century

best_comment: The third quarter materials on GE and moral hazard appears to be useful for multiple subfields within economics, so it is probably a good idea to learn this material well if you want to do research involving applied theory. Jerry's part is enjoyable, and you should make the trek to HBS for his lectures and the tasty chocolate covered almonds in the faculty lounge!
subject: Economics

best_comment: The third quarter materials on GE and moral hazard appears to be useful for multiple subfields within economics, so it is probably a good idea to learn this material well if you want to do research involving applied theory. Jerry's part is enjoyable, and you should make the trek to HBS for his lectures and the tasty chocolate covered almonds in the faculty lounge!
subject: Economics

best_comment: This course is definitely accessible to an undergraduate (like me) with lots of math/stats background and Econ 1011A. It was certainly challenging, but I found it so interesting and rewarding to learn macro at this level. The work was worth it.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This course is definitely accessible to an undergraduate (like me) with lots of math/stats background and Econ 1011A. It was certainly challenging, but I found it so interesting and rewarding to learn macro at this level. The work was worth it.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This course is definitely accessible to an undergraduate (like me) with lots of math/stats background and Econ 1011A. It was certainly challenging, but I found it so interesting and rewarding to learn macro at this level. The work was worth it.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Try to have a study group to answer the assignments and study for the exams. My friends were brilliant, and they helped me understand much of the material we saw in class. The students have different backgrounds, and it's hard to have a class that makes everyone happy. Some students will feel it's too complicated, and others might feel the course was too easy. If you don't have a strong quantitative and economics background, reach out to the professor, and they will guide you to make the best of this course. If you have a strong quantitative and economics background, you should also reach out to the professor, and I'm sure they will provide you with more resources to learn more about the course topics.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This class is pretty good!  Read Kahneman's "Thinking, Fast and Slow" –– if that intrigues you, then you'll probably enjoy the class.  The class begins with Kahneman and Tversky (heuristics and biases, prospect theory) and quickly moves to more recent developments and applications.  Some of these are fascinating: modelling stereotyping using the representativeness heuristic, salience theory, the role of memory and attention, and quasi–hyperbolic discounting.  The class is also very chill –– there are psets due every other week, which are a bit long but oh well.  I cannot comment on the final (worth 2/3 of the grade) since I haven't taken it yet.  Shleifer (leads 2/3 of the lectures) is funny but speaks a bit slowly, which sometimes caused my attention to drift.  Laibson (1/3 of the lectures) is a great lecturer.  Both professors are very nice and approachable.
worse_comment: If you are an undergraduate thinking about taking this course, make sure you have a good group of friends to complete problem sets with. You do not need the recommended prerequisites; as long as you have some general intuition and comfort with math, you are fine. David's problem sets are very difficult, but he releases solutions before the deadline, so you can use those to guide you if you really have no idea. The final is hard to study for; work through the math on the problem sets slowly and make sure you really understand the psychology bits presented in lecture.
subject: Economics
