subject: Economics

course_title: A Computer Science Toolbox for Modern Economic Theory 001
best_comment: A fun course: this was Yannai's first time teaching it and it showed (some lectures ran over, there was some uncertainty about the assignments), but overall, it was an excellent class. The topics are fascinating, Yannai is passionate about the class, and assignments are very low–stress. Would recommend for other undergrads: it says that graduate micro is a prereq but I didn't struggle to understand what was going on even without taking it! Would just recomment some exposure to game theory + auctions/matching, and you can look up everything else along the way
subject: Economics
course_title_2023: A Computer Science Toolbox for Modern Economic Theory

best_comment: Take this course! It is definitely on the Harvard must do list! Scott is absolutely amazing (as a teacher and as a person), the guided discussions of papers are great, the topics are both rigorous and meaningful (with cool applications to current events such as the pandemic, and modern issues like inequality and cryptocurrency), and the project is a great opportunity to explore a topic that you care about with great mentorship from Scott. Definitely highly, highly, recommend.

For the first half of the semester, I rated this as an excellent class: I was learning about topics (IV, Matching, LATE, RD, etc.) that were frequently popping up in other areas of coursework and research. Time and reflection, though, cooled my stance. While this class certainly *covers* relevant topics, I don't really feel that I deeply *learned* them. I am going to have to supplement this course with significant amounts of outside reading to really feel qualified to engage with these topics as a researcher.The root cause of this, in my opinion, is the extreme heterogeneity of technical background in the course: some students have significant quantitative background (multivariable calculus, coding, probability and inference), some have a mix, and some have little to none. This is completely fine, and natural, to expect in a graduate school; the issue arises when everyone is required to take the same course. The result is a class that iterates through the material in fits and starts, never really diving deep enough into the concepts to develop a strong understanding. I thought that Econometrics I in the fall did a better job of applying graduate–level quantitative skills, perhaps to the ire of some participants, but it allowed me to walk away with a better understanding. This course often felt like an undergraduate course a la Econ 101: lots of handwaving, statements like 'trust that this works' and qualitative questions meant to trick you instead of truly testing your understanding. I know that the natural fix – splitting this into two tracks – is complicated, but I'm not sure how to improve the course otherwise. Ultimately, I would not take this class unless you are absolutely required to, which, unfortunately, you might be.
subject: Economics

worse_comment: Hard class, but more practical than 2120
subject: Economics

course_title: Empirical Research in Labor and Public Economics 001
best_comment: This is a great class! The material covered was very useful: state–of–the–art topics in applied econometrics relevant to labor and public economics. The professor teaches what she knows, which is a lot and at a great level of detail. I found this class to be one of the most relevant classes to my research, both in its content and structure. The assignment of putting together a research proposal and thinking about a research project practically (e.g. how to get data) was incredibly useful.

This is a great class if you're interested in development, behavioral economics, or both. The final project is an amazing opportunity to kickstart the idea generation process that will help you transition into your third year of your PhD.

This course is useful for gaining an understanding of the development of econometrics in macroeconomics. You learn a broad range of topics and get exposed to a variety of questions that could be addressed in the field of macroeconomics.

course_title: Public Economics and Fiscal Policy II 001
best_comment: Course is great intro to canonical topics and methods in public. Definitely emphasizes applied theory more than labor sequence. Nathan is really great at making this a PhD course because he really emphasizes discussion about how to identify and do good research—the kind of professional advice and mentorship I wish was more common in the department.
subject: Economics
course_title_2023: Public Economics and Fiscal Policy II

best_comment: I would highly recommend this course. Perfect course to learn about topics in health econ.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Prof. Rogoff and Prof. Stein gave us a diverse and engaging perspective on the field and it's very illuminating to hear their insightful comments and insights on the various topics in class. It exposed me to the pioneering research and helped clarified my research interests for my senior thesis. Would highly recommend for undergrads who are interested in a more "active research in the field" oriented perspective! Prof. Stein and Prof. Rogoff are also very kind and understanding in providing guidance and flexibility on the term paper.
subject: Economics

course_title: Labor Economics and Labor Market Institutions 001
best_comment: Definitely take! Instructor is very helpful and supportive of students.

course_title: Educational Outcomes in Cross-National and Cross-Cultural Perspectives 001
best_comment: Do not take this class. I took this class as an elective and was very excited about the class (I care deeply about education and was very interested in what this looks like from a cross–cultural perspective). I was disappointed. The readings were interesting but the discussion surrounding them was subpar. Professor Harris clearly cares a lot about this material, but he chose texts/questions that he had a pre–determined opinion about, which stifled discussion. I did not feel engaged in this class, and I did not feel like my classmates were engaged. However, if you are able to write clearly and lay out a solid argument in an essay, this is a very easy class with not much work (100% of your grade is essay–based). For me at least, that didn't make it worth it.
subject: Education Studies
course_title_2023: Educational Outcomes in Cross-National and Cross-Cultural Perspectives

best_comment: Definitely take this class if you can! It's really interesting, and Beth Simpson is a great professor with lots of wisdom!
subject: Education Studies

course_title: Flavor Molecules of Food Fermentation: Exploration and Inquiry 001
best_comment: Take this class!!! This is one of the most niche and AMAZING, unique classes you'll take, and you'll be greatly inspired to be more creative and confident in your scientific pursuits. There is so much opportunity to take this course as far and as deep as you would like to go, so there is less pressure to "meet" a certain structure and more emphasis on enjoying the scientific process of exploration and curiosity. This is a perfect capstone for science majors, especially, as it is one fo the only opportunities that you can be so free and explore other disciplines while still diving into the nitty gritty of fermentation if you want.
best_gem_comment: Take it! Gem Easy grading, very few assignments out of class, such an interesting subject, and yummy food :). Why not take a gem where you get to brew your own alcohol?????
subject: Engineering Sciences
course_title_2023: Flavor Molecules of Food Fermentation: Exploration and Inquiry

best_comment: This course definitely requires some background in electrical engineering. The first few lessons will be very challenging without any previous background.  Problem sets were very long and challenging, but they are doable if you know how to manage your time. The quizzes weren't as bad as I expected them to be, but they were definitely challenging and time–consuming (took me 6 hours without breaks to do each quiz). The course definitely covers a lot of things that may be of interest to some students, like Op–Amps, logic gates, circuit components, and breadboarding. However, the course doesn't go too in–depth in any of the topics, and they go over several topics very fast which can make it hard to learn.
worse_comment: It is not taught or assessed well. Take for the sake of learning, not enjoyment.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Great hands–on lab component with a fun design project robot battle!!  Lecture is pretty non–existent (at least it was after the midterm), needs to be improved, less the material and more the faculty delivering it, just not engaging when it could be having the students up at the boards each class so they learn during class and not on their own.  Overall, this course has great potential and the group work was a highlight of my semester, so I recommend with reservations.
worse_comment: Only take if Dr. Panahi is not the instructor. If he is, I would delay taking it until a proper instructor is put in place.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: ES91hfr (or I guess ES105hfr now) provides a fantastic opportunity to get real–world engineering experience and to improve teamwork skills.  Fantastic course, 11/10, would recommend. Honestly, more of a club than a class.
worse_comment: This is the class for you if you are looking for a hands–on project that is solving a real–world problem.

course_title: Entrepreneurship and Innovation: Practical and Academic Insights 001
best_comment: Take this class! This is one of the best courses that I have taken at Harvard by far. Lerner is such an engaging professors and will make you feel motivated. The cases are super interesting and honestly do not feel like work. The TFs are super experienced and it's very cool to be able to talk to an HBS student regularly. I think that even if you don't like entrepreneurship too much, you would still find this class interesting.
subject: Engineering Sciences
course_title_2023: Entrepreneurship and Innovation: Practical and Academic Insights

course_title: Entrepreneurship and Innovation: Practical and Academic Insights 002
best_comment: I would say to take this class. it was so fun and Josh is a great and enthusiastic lecturer. you learn a lot from the case studies and from your peers and it truly has that Harvard MBA class style written all over it. You meet some really cool people and just generally learn what it takes to be successful with your startup. I can say taking this class will directly lead me to making better decisions if I have a company. I think that the grading is pretty good too as 20% get As ,70% A–, and  10% get B+, so I think that most students should be alright. The only problem for me was that I never got my assignments back on time so I don't really know where I fall in the above grading. I think they Got to improve on that.
subject: Engineering Sciences
course_title_2023: Entrepreneurship and Innovation: Practical and Academic Insights

best_comment: This class is very much a “get out what you put in” kind of place. You could coast and baloney your way through a semester and end up with nothing to show for it at the end…OR you could invest in your cohort and take advantage of the awesome advice and resources and get a huge leap forward on your company. Treat it and give it time like you would that thesis or hard CS course and RAD will help your company in ways you wouldn’t expect and help develop you as a founder.
worse_comment: Take one of the other courses on startups offered either at the college, MIT or HBS. You will learn more and not have to undergo useless busy work assigned by a bully.  Simply useless.
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Engineering Problem Solving and Design Project 001
best_comment: If you're on here, you have to take this course for the SB, so I'll just give some advice on how to make this experience less painful for you. As stated in previous Q guides, I think the main factor that will determine your experience in ES 96 is your instructor. Depending on the instructor, you will receive more or less support throughout the project, more or less encouragement, and more or less work outside of class time. The last point is the most important because with a great instructor your section will be very efficient with doing work for the class DURING class, and you will not fall behind or need as much prep work outside of class. You will most likely not get to choose your section, but you will have a great experience if you're in Kelly's section because she's super nice, super sweet, very encouraging, and has taught the course so many times that she knows where the class is supposed to be at a specific point in time. That means that you won't fall behind in the project and class time is used very effectively to meet goals, compared to other sections that have had to meet multiple times a week outside of class to catch up with the syllabus. Also, hopefully you are able to get along with your teammates really well (or learn how to).
worse_comment: This is the single worst class I have ever taken in any school my entire life. Harvard should be ashamed of itself for allowing such a terrible course. You absolutely learn nothing at all. Every day we would come in working on a project with no solution that has no relation whatsoever to our major while our professors actively hold us back from making progress. The class became a game of guess and check where we would come up with a solution designed to solve youth homelessness (as engineers, how are we qualified to work on this???), we would find out the company we're working with is already doing that solution, and we would repeat the process. This class gave me depression and it made me significantly more nihilistic and pessimistic.
subject: Engineering Sciences
course_title_2023: Engineering Problem Solving and Design Project

course_title: Engineering Problem Solving and Design Project 002
best_comment: Please, please do not go into this believing it will be one of those hand–wavy no–test classes. Depending on the project and professor, it may well be the most time– and energy–intensive course you take at Harvard as an engineering student. However, the most intense projects tend to be the most rewarding and the most camaraderie–building. Don't take criticism personally, and be sure to organize yourselves into teams with clear team captains early on!!
worse_comment: Choose your path in the beginning. Either just don't care about the course, or make sure your teammates also care when you start work on the project.

best_comment: This course is incredibly personal and engaging. I highly recommend taking this class as an introduction to engineering. If you are studying the natural sciences this is a great engineering class to take to learn about technological implementation of natural sciences. Professor Martin is incredibly kind and made the classroom setting very comfortable and fun.You will gain a strong intuition and thermodynamic mentality towards the technological world, but it does not imbue very strong quantitative thermodynamic skills if that is what you are looking for.
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Introduction to Fluid Mechanics and Transport Processes 001
best_comment: If you're on here, you most likely have to take this course, so I won't spend time telling you whether or not to take it, but I'll focus on how to best prepare yourself for the course. (1) Go to section. Section really helped me clear up all confusions I had during lecture, and it was a really good resource to help me consolidate material from the past week. If you pick a section, try to choose a section earlier in the week so that you have the content fresh in your mind when you're doing your pset throughout the week (our psets were due on Fridays and I had section on Tuesday). (2) Collaborate with others. Working with others, whether it be during OH or outside of class, will help you clear up any misunderstandings of the material and will help strengthen your grasp of it. So really recommend. (3) Ask help of the TFs. The TFs really made the course not sucky, and they are there to have open conversations about the material, final projects, and performance in the course. If you need any help, reach out to them and it will be worth it. (4) Continue giving feedback. Although the course has a long ways to go to being a good course, Petros is really open to feedback, and if you keep on stressing important aspects in the feedback, the teaching staff and Petros will soon catch on and will adjust the course as necessary.
worse_comment: This class is a huge time suck, with lecture three times a week, section, and basically weekly lab. I found it to be extremely difficult and required a lot of prior knowledge of physics and multivariable calculus. Lecture had almost no correlation with homework and exams, and psets were very difficult, requiring you to go to at least two sets of office hours per week.
subject: Engineering Sciences
course_title_2023: Introduction to Fluid Mechanics and Transport Processes

best_comment: I definitely recommend this course! It is on the light side in terms of workload, but it definitely makes you think. This class certainly requires thought unless you already know advanced statistics; Yue does a great job at introducing the topics both for those with no prior background and for those who have taken statistics before like me. He also does a good job of keeping stuff interesting in lecture. He is good at giving lectures, and he gives lots of interesting examples about the topics we learn. He also gives fun bonus problems that encourage us to think more about the material. Also– the exams follow pretty directly from the homework and lectures. Na Li is also great if you are taking the class with her, although I think Yue usually teaches it.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: I very much enjoyed the class and found it interesting. But make no mistake– this is a math class and it is reasonably difficult. It is well grounded in engineering applications, especially towards the latter half of the course, but much of it is straight math, and spent on systems and Fourier analysis. I would recommend it because I appreciate the skills taught and I enjoy math for its own sake. (As of now, it is required for EE majors.) However I think people who don't like math will be less enthusiastic about the course from what I heard from my classmates. It is one of the less popular electrical engineering cores. Nonetheless, this class teaches a lot about systems and it is a good thing that EEs have to take it. Go to lecture and office hours and you'll be fine. The last thing I would add is that the exams are not just repeats of homework or lecture; you have to actually think on them.Todd is great and very happy to help, although a bit strict about deadlines. Didn't take it with Flavio, but he seems great as well.
worse_comment: This course is difficult and hard to follow at times. The real world connections aren't always visible and I found that made it hard for me to keep up at times. The course material also had some frustrating typos that took a while to figure out.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Prof. Hu is fantastic. We were able to take this course in CNS, which was also a privilege.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Prof. Hu is fantastic. We were able to take this course in CNS, which was also a privilege.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: This is a moderately easy class but you don’t fully understand a lot. The topic is dense and there’s a lot of textbook readings. Lecture you just watch as prof derives all of heat transfer without pause. Homework is easy and you can definitely get full credit if you go to OH. 3 labs in groups. Final project was fun
worse_comment: The lecture component of this course was very difficult to follow and not very useful. I would not recommend taking this course. That being said, there was only one pset every 2–3 weeks with just a few problems, so it was very reasonable course load. But if you would actually like to learn the material, I do not believe that the pedagogy is up to par. You end up having to learn on your own. Lecture is 90% derivations that are not really useful to actually solving heat transfer problems.
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Introduction to Materials Science and Engineering 001
best_comment: Section may be optional, but it is a great opportunity to get help on complex material and homework assignments.
subject: Engineering Sciences
course_title_2023: Introduction to Materials Science and Engineering

best_comment: Take this class!! Favorite class potentially ever! Prof Mitragotri is a leader in his field and his lectures are quite interesting. Lectures don't go too in depth, but you come out feeling like you have a pretty comprehensive overview of drug delivery concepts. I also recommend going to office hours just to ask questions to Prof Mitragotri for the sake of interest. You get out what you put in––it's easy to fall into the habit of skipping class, but then you won't get as much out of it. Also, stay on top of the grant proposal assignment because it's difficult to finish last minute, especially if you don't have grant proposal writing experience.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Be timely and dedicated. Lab takes a lott of time but it is very rewarding. The lab TFs and course instructor are very receptive to feedback, give great feedback, provide lots of support, and are always encouraging even when things go wrong in your lab experiment. The weekly journals are simple assignments and don't take a lot of time. The work definitely picks up with time especially in lab, but there is solid support for it. The exams are fair and reviews for them are very helpful.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: I would highly recomend taking this course as an engineering elective! The work was definitely more challenging and time consuming than some of the other elective classes out there but there is no course at Harvard that offers this much of a breath of the engery consumption and production industry. I learned an incredbile amount in such a short time and the course provided me a perspective of the energy world that I would have not gotten otherwise. I really enjoyed the open ended term paper at the end were I got to look into a research problem I enjoyed and eneded up writing a very cool and insightful paper (there are not many classes I can say that for). Definitely take if you are at all interested in the energy world.
worse_comment: Everyone at Harvard should take this class or another related to the climate crisis
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Getting to know and learn from Professor Yang is an amazing experience. This course will expose you to different ideas and give you a closer look of the larger contexts that revolve around innovation and entrepreneurship. It will also help you learn how to think about and analyze complicated systems and industries.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: You should definitely have a strong electrical engineering background if you want to be able to understand everything that goes on in the course. You can still take it if you do not have such a strong background, but be prepared to not understand some things, especially in the middle/later parts of the semester. Professor Liu is generally happy to answer questions after class or during office hours, and the homework and lab assignments tend to be interesting and not overly difficult. Some things covered include Neuralink and optogenetics–both very cool topics. Would recommend for Bioengineering concentrators or EE concentrators with an interest in medical devices, electrophysiology, or basic neuroengineering.
worse_comment: This class is not a lot of work, but I also don't feel like I learned so much from it. If you want a chill class that fulfills an engineering requirement this can be it (but warning that lab starts halfway through the semester and is 3 hours a week), but I don't feel like it helped my understanding of engineering/bioelectronics. Coming into it with more electrical engineering background could be helpful for that
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Prof. Hu is fantastic. We were able to take this course in CNS, which was also a privilege.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Prof. Hu is fantastic. We were able to take this course in CNS, which was also a privilege.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Amazing class, take it! Be adventurous, try anything. Best time to take risks.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Amazing class, take it! Be adventurous, try anything. Best time to take risks.
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers 001
best_comment: Honestly, I think this should be a required course for everyone. Learning how to write is so important in both academia and industry, and this course is a really great low stress way to learn how to write well. In particular Suzanne is really dedicated to the students and put together an amazing and diverse group of guest speakers and readings. I am so glad I got to take this course and only wish I had taken it earlier in my studies to produce better papers.
subject: Engineering Sciences
course_title_2023: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers

course_title: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers 001
best_comment: Honestly, I think this should be a required course for everyone. Learning how to write is so important in both academia and industry, and this course is a really great low stress way to learn how to write well. In particular Suzanne is really dedicated to the students and put together an amazing and diverse group of guest speakers and readings. I am so glad I got to take this course and only wish I had taken it earlier in my studies to produce better papers.
subject: Engineering Sciences
course_title_2023: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers

best_comment: Jill has a wealth of knowledge and is a great professional resource for any students considering a career in journalism — this class will offer real–world information about the industry and investigative techniques that you won't find elsewhere.
worse_comment: Take this class if you do not like structure and just like to write and research on your own –– this felt more like an independent study than a real class, very relaxed and high expectations because of that.

best_comment: Musa is incredibly supportive and created a chill, engaging, and fun class environment where I felt very comfortable sharing my writing. Everyone in the class was so nice and gave constructive, helpful feedback. It was nice to be held accountable for writing consistently without being pressured for the results to be "good". As Musa said once, it's a writing workshop, not done–shop. The class emphasizes the process and craft of writing rather than the result, which is super different in the best way possible from other Harvard classes. This was one of my favorite classes I have ever taken.
subject: English

best_comment: Take it! A very personalized course where you learn so much from your peers. Fabulous opportunity to grow as a writer.

Before taking this class, I hadn't really ever shown my poetry to other people. The same was true for many of my classmates. It was certainly scary at first to workshop my poems and have them be read by everyone in the class. However, it became easier over the course of the semester and it was soooo worth it! This was a really great class and I super highly recommend that others apply to take this class.
subject: English

course_title: Creative Nonfiction: Before and Beyond the (Imaginary White) Reader 001
best_comment: It's a really great class if you want to think more critically about your relationship to your work and its relationship to whiteness/dominant literary structures.

course_title: Found Poems, Erasures and Other Adventures in Documentary Poetry 001
best_comment: Wonderful workshop experience with Professor Smith. Her feedback and especially her takes on the excellent assigned readings are thoughtful, insightful and deeply socially conscious. Pretty busy semester as we wrote a poem every week, workshopped 6 people a week (you write a poem every week even if you’re not up for workshop, but Professor Smith writes comments on all of them every week), and wrote two primary reader letters for peers each week, plus keeping up with assigned readings, which we discussed for the first half of the 3 hour workshop. As a result you get a ton of experience reading and writing poetry but it can be a bit draining and the 15 minute slots for workshopping each person felt quick (I’m sure this could change in later years or even within a semester with student feedback). But because Professor Smith wrote feedback every week and you wrote and received two full feedback letters every week, you end up with like a dozen heavily feedbacked poems, half which were discussed in class, which is awesome. Overall a great course to explore documentary poetry, and the assignments are varied and you can write whatever you want (she doesn’t expect you to follow the assignment prompts exactly if you don’t want to). And of course such a pleasure just to hear Professor Smith talk about poetry and life, as with all these workshops, do be sure to read her work if you aren’t already familiar and to talk to her about her writing and experiences in office hours!
Josh gives insightful feedback, is kind and understanding, brings excellent vibes to class and with his gentleness helps bring out the best in our work. 100 / 10 !

The course isn't always clearly structured and classes can sometimes drag on, but Prof. Abramson is a pretty amazing resource. So many stories about journalism and her comments on your drafts are invaluable. The course gave me the opportunity to produce my favorite writing of the year and develop my skills at weaving narrative and factual reporting. I felt like I was also able to develop my personal journalistic voice.

Definitely take this class! You will read a lot of cool plays, you'll get to write every week, and you'll get invaluable feedback on your writing from both Sam and your peers. It's a very fun and very engaging class. If you have any interest in creative writing or theater, this is the class for you.

This class is really great. You learn a lot but it is really fun, engaging and low stakes. There is a really clear focus on your development as a screenwriter and you are not forced to write or think in a certain way. The community (the students and Musa) are all interesting and different and thoughtful and take your work to really great, new and exciting places. The assigned readings and films are all so different and really take an open–minded approach to short films as a genre. This open–mindedness is reflected n every element of the class.
subject: English

best_comment: If you get the opportunity to take this class, *take it*!!!! It was hands–down my favorite class and a consistent bright spot in my week all semester. Normally, I can barely sit through a two–hour seminar, but this three–hour class flew by every week. It's so wonderful to be able to sit with a small group of brilliant, amazing writers, all of whom care so much about the class, and just talk to them for an afternoon. The assigned readings are fantastic and introduced me to so many new authors I'll still be reading for years. I grew immensely as a writer myself over the course of the semester; it was so nice to have a low–pressure, built–in way to spend time with my writing. Also, Molly is just an amazing human being. She always made sure we took a break in the middle of class, had class outside when the weather was nice, and is just so kind, understanding, and supportive. It was a privilege to take a class with her.

Take this course!! If you are new to fiction or haven't written anything before at all, I would strongly recommend this course! You will learn so much from your peers, and the class is is a very supportive / non–judgmental setting to start sharing your writing drafts with other people to get feedback. Also, it's a pretty chill class where you can learn a lot in a low–stakes environment. There aren't that many assignments and Molly is very understanding with giving extensions if you can't make a deadline. Also, the most important thing is that you will be surrounded by a community of passionate individuals who are all trying to figure out their identities as writers! It's truly really inspiring and has pushed me to grow a lot as a writer ;)
worse_comment: Apply. Don’t hesitate because you don’t think you’re a writer. Hitting submit on this application is the first of many invaluable opportunities for self–growth and vulnerability that this course will offer you.

best_comment: Moments of resonant belonging are rare in life, but especially in adulthood. As I age and mature, I find myself a little less pliable, elasticity slowly bowing to rigidity. And yet, this class was a belonging space for me and a resounding one at that. In my PhD program my writing had been everything but handled tenderly. I’m under no delusion that my writing doesn’t need work; however, I’ve never been in a space where we are so strongly encouraged to find the good, the cors and to make a piece the best version of itself not your best version. Academia has largely severed my connection with writing although it was my lifeblood as an introverted child working through what I now recognize as trauma. I’ve gradually lost my connection to the sustaining power of this art, compounding my pain. This class has begun to mend that relationship. It’s forced me to see the good in my own work. It’s pushed me to offer myself the same tenderness that I seek to offer others.Within the first few classes, if not the first class, Meng was able to invite us into a space where not only were we affirmed, but so too was our writing. The writing exercises early on both excited and intimidated me. Watching the ink spread on my page gave form and life to my ideas. So many of them have gone untilled, unattended that it seemed impossible to ever watch them flower and fruit. Within the greenhouse of our classroom, as I released my cors into the atmosphere and so did my peers, our gifts collided, thickened, and nourished us all. I’ve learned so much from this class. Let the erotic lead you to the “I.” Continually asking myself, “what comes through the hole?,” diverging from tropes and detouring from the paths our minds try to take us for a more excellent way, and, of course, “tell, don’t show.” But even beyond these, the hardest lesson Meng has taught is the importance (and challenge) of writing the good. the beautiful. the delightful. I must admit, this is a lesson that I will be learning for the rest of my life, but it’s one of which I’m beginning to appreciate the value. I really needed this class. It has done more for me than I can adequately express. Thank you, Meng, for the invitation to join this class and thank you for bringing such an amazing course concept to life for each of us.
subject: English

best_comment: If it's Meng, take it – she's absolutely simply amazing (I think she's around for another year!). She is both really knowledgeable and also so kind/empathetic. She is simply the best and makes the class. Go to office hours! They're great :)

course_title: Advanced Fiction Workshop: What's So Western About the Western Story 001
best_comment: Incredible course. Loved the intimate nature of the class which provided us with opportunities to be vulnerable & test and develop our writing skills with the constant reinforcement of our peers. The workshop setting is absolutely vital to this sort of creative exploration, and my writing benefitted from being able to workshop my peers' stories in small groups with highly analytical, literary–minded peers (workshop is great at helping you to develop tough skin and the ability to be vulnerable with your writing). Take this class if you LOVE to write and are SERIOUS about improving your writing. Truly the light of my semester!

If you're hoping for a structured class where you can workshop something you've already written, this may not be it. But this course is a really rich, wonderful opportunity to listen to and learn from Professor Kincaid and classmates alike. I learned so much from and felt really inspired by my classmates' writing –––  Professor Kincaid invited us to engage with profound, personal topics, and everyone rose to the challenge.
subject: English

best_comment: I was so sad to learn that Russ is retiring after this year, because he's one of the best instructors I have ever had at Harvard and it's a shame no one else will be able to experience his teaching and mentorship going forward. I had a fantastic experience in this class – the content experience (Fiction By Other Means) is as promised, and Russ is such a lovely person with a wealth of knowledge and experience and a really natural teaching and mentorship style. While he wasn't the most critical or technically focused writing instructor, the amount of encouragement he offered and his listening ear (in contrast to some writing instructors, who let their own experience and expertise become the focus in one–on–one conversations, rather than giving the student space to talk about and ask question about their writing) helped me develop my confidence as a writer and the inspiration to write more postgrad. I plan to develop the short story I wrote over the course of this semester into a novel this upcoming year, and I have Russ to thank in large part for that.

course_title: The Art of Writing about Science and the Environment: Workshop 001
best_comment: This is a great class. It gets a bit drawn out at times and could benefit from more variety such that we aren't workshopping for 2 hours and 45 minutes at end. But creative writing is great, and you learn a lot.

course_title: Narrative Nonfiction. Writing Wrongs: Women, Gender and Journalism: Workshop 001
best_comment: This has the potential to be a great class if you don't slack off. Susan is so wise and gives amazing lectures, the readings are excellent, and feedback from peers and Susan is always thoughtful and nuanced. However, much of the quality of the class hinges on how engaged the students are in discussing readings, and how honest students are willing to be when giving other students feedback on their work. Please be engaged and don't be afraid to give useful feedback, beyond flattery, on other people's work! In any case, if you're an aspiring journalist or you just want an opportunity to improve your writing, this is an incredible class to take!

For English concentrators, this required course is definitely shaped by the instructor. But overall, the readings across forms are generally interesting and the assignments are not horribly difficult. Do not fear English 20, and try to enjoy the assortment of texts it has to offer you. For non–English concentrators, I'd recommend choosing an English course that speaks to your specific interests rather than this general topic course.
worse_comment: Take this class because it sets you up to understand literature from the bottom up—as a form of science, even. That is how much it is broken down.
subject: English

best_comment: Take eng20 if it is a requirement, skip it otherwise. It's a good class for basic exposure to lots of different forms, but I didn't feel like knowledge about really any specific form grew greatly as a lot of the class is just student–driven discussion so if you've never analyzed a form before you can feel a bit lost. While I really liked the teaching staff, it did feel pretty chaotic and disorganized most of the time. This class was the most "english" class I have taken so far — nearly every other sentence was a reference to a canonical piece that I had not read so I often felt pretty out of my wheelhouse. That being said, it was an environment very open to questions which was nice. The structure of the class was to bring a prepared question to class and that will be the jumping off point for discussion. So often class was just talking about random (although interesting) things that weren't always super central to the text. The assignments were pretty flexible though — up to two creative assignments out of four total. Overall, a perfectly fine class but not my favorite, especially since I often felt kind of ostracized from not having the same background knowledge as everybody else (but that could just be specific to the group I was with and not the class).
subject: English

best_comment: If you're interested in James or Baldwin or just gender, politics, American history, race or sexuality, this course could be really good for you. We got to explore big questions and themes particularly relevant to race, gender and sexuality in America while reading great fiction. The readings were very well picked: besides reading novels we also read non–fiction, which I thought was helpful in giving us insights with which to analyze the fiction. It was great to discuss the books with students who are interested in the same questions. Not only did the readings and class discussions help me understand American literature better but they also triggered personal reflections that helped me question some of my opinion and form new ones. The instructor, Jesse McCarthy is really great, super knowledgeable, and very available to meet students outside of class.

Great class! All of the readings were super interesting, the discussion was very organized which facilitated lots of participation and thoughtful insights, and the community engagement aspect was an unexpectedly powerful way to connect the readings to my own life. Highly recommend.

course_title: Theory Matters: Problems in Contemporary Literary and Cultural Theory 001
best_comment: Take this course if you can! The theoretical work you do is rigorous, and challenging, but Professor Bhabha, Paul, and your fellow students are working through the issues with you with a remarkable patience and grace. You will learn a lot of frameworks and ideas and ways of thinking which'll be applicable to other theoretical texts you pursue, and also to your growth as a philosophical and historical thinker, even though this is an English course.

James Wood is such a great instructor. The readings were really well selected and the instructor is so knowledgeable and passionate about the subject that class was always really fun and enlightening. The instructor does a great job at connecting materials such as religious texts, music, and other writings to the main course materials, showing us important connections we wouldn't have otherwise seen. The class has taught me what makes a piece of fiction great, and I now have a better understanding of the place of realism and of authors like Flaubert, Chekov and Wolf in English and Western literature. The class introduced me to really important works in world literature. Class discussions were always very well moderated and I feel like I've learned from my peers' observations. The course assignments offered me a great opportunity to reflect more deeply about topics such as feminism and anti–Semitism in fiction.
worse_comment: Take this class!! Learning from Professor Wood is an unmatched experience.
subject: English
course_title_2023: Consciousness in Fiction from Austen to Woolf

best_comment: As a graduating senior, this was my favorite course I took at Harvard. <3 Shop the class and see if you like the vibe of lectures; if you do, take it. It's a heavy reading load and the assignments always take more time than you think they will, but it's such a well–curated course and Professor Miller cares about it a lot. While I don't think a theater background is necessary, you'll enjoy the class much more if this is something you're really interested in and want to dive into. Professor Miller is one of my favorite people on campus, is extremely knowledgeable in the field, and is a wonderful lecturer — would highly recommend his courses!
best_gem_comment: Take this class! Professor Miller leads fascinating discussions and assigns some great plays to read. Gem of a class and one of my favorites at Harvard.

course_title: Women on Being, Belonging, and Constructing 001
best_comment: take this class!!! Very low stress and you will come out of it having read fantastic literature that is a extremely accessible. Even though the reading workload may seem like a lot (half a book per week), they are typically fairly quick reads. The more you put into this class (doing the readings, flagging things you want to talk about) the more enjoyable the class will be. The professor is also very kind, understanding, and flexible with assignments. There was always a creative option available!

Taking the Dracula version of this course where that's the only book is anecdotally very different to how it's normally taught with a range of books – it cuts down on some of the reading as we're only reading one book, but if you don't like Dracula then that may reduce your enjoyment of the course. It's a really great Sophomore Tutorial, and getting to know the different literary methods is really interesting and crucial for the rest of your time in English.
worse_comment: Honestly didn't like this course at all. It felt extremely white centered, from the course staff to the students to the course materials.  The few racial discussions was about the film Blacula which was rushed through at the end of the semester and one convo on Dracula being Eastern European as opposed to western. For a class that's supposed to teach us Literary methods, it just felt limiting that it was restricted to the one novel. Sure, a class on Dracula is cool, but don't make it a requirement for the sophomore tutorial because it does not fit the interests of most concentrators. I think this class would've been a decent  elective. Every day I dreaded going because ,honestly, I was extremely bored and felt invisible.
subject: English

course_title: Epic: From Homer to Star Wars 001
best_comment: I took this class without having read any of the texts previously; it is doable, but I imagine the readings took me a little longer because I had to do a pass for understanding and a pass for analysis. My writing skills certainly improved through the feedback I received on assignments, and I am a more critical reader now than I was at the beginning of the course. I'd recommend the class for anyone who wants to read some great texts under the guidance of excellent instructors.
worse_comment: The course itself made me far more interested in many of the works we read – classical works like Aeneid and Paradise Lost that I didn't think were interesting were spotlighted and taught in such wonderful depths by the two professors. That said, the grading in this class is very harsh + overall the course has a much higher workload than all other courses I've taken in the English department. Lastly, the course uses Star Wars in its title, but do know that the course does not talk about any contemporary epics until the very last lecture (Star Wars is mentioned for 10 minutes).

course_title: Epic: From Homer to Star Wars 001
best_comment: I took this class without having read any of the texts previously; it is doable, but I imagine the readings took me a little longer because I had to do a pass for understanding and a pass for analysis. My writing skills certainly improved through the feedback I received on assignments, and I am a more critical reader now than I was at the beginning of the course. I'd recommend the class for anyone who wants to read some great texts under the guidance of excellent instructors.
worse_comment: The course itself made me far more interested in many of the works we read – classical works like Aeneid and Paradise Lost that I didn't think were interesting were spotlighted and taught in such wonderful depths by the two professors. That said, the grading in this class is very harsh + overall the course has a much higher workload than all other courses I've taken in the English department. Lastly, the course uses Star Wars in its title, but do know that the course does not talk about any contemporary epics until the very last lecture (Star Wars is mentioned for 10 minutes).

course_title: Imagining the World in Medieval and Renaissance Literature 001
best_comment: This class provides the perfect introduction to Medieval and Renaissance Literature—it recognizes, then interrogates, the several threads that run through historical texts, and seeks to understand the ways in which writers and readers alike have imagined others, defined variously along colonial, religious, racial, gendered, and class lines, amongst others. Despite the fact that we are reading texts written hundreds of years ago, the class remains engaged with political issues that feel strikingly relevant, and whose effects and afterlives we are still seeing unfold today. This is a wonderful, engaging class—take it!

Take this class!!! Professor Niles is excellent. I wish I could take this class again. The lectures are really cool, and I also enjoyed the assignments (they aren't all typical analytical essays). I felt like I read such a wide breadth of Shakespeare's work (poems, sonnets, and plays) that I have a very good grasp of what it means to read Shakespeare. This class was not super stressful, you could really enjoy the material. I highly recommend this class

this is an amazing class!! take it!!! it's probably the best English class at harvard !! (I say after only having taken 6 English classes lol) –– no but seriously; the lectures are really engaging and exciting, the professor is extraordinary and the TF is also great; you will learn a lot and have fun! and you will probably get a good grade! the assignments are challenging, but they are spaced out nicely and the expectations are made clear. the reading is also really challenging but they're broken up into manageable chunks of like ~100 pages per class (I think). definitely make sure this is NOT your first English class at harvard. the material is difficult. but overall the class is really fun and definitely worthwhile. it is also nice to your mental health compared to other courses.

course_title: Broadway Bodies, or Representation on the Great White Way 001
best_comment: This class is an easy A but its also super fun. The assignments re pretty creative and I actually enjoyed doing them. A lot of readings but worth it in the end.

This is one of the BEST classes that I’ve taken at Harvard!!!! I’m such a huge fan of Stephanie — she’s so cool and knowledgeable and understanding and brilliant. I also adore the syllabus and there’s really something for everyone.  I was surprised because every week I’d come to class and find a new poet that I loved. I’ve taken other poetry classes at Harvard but this one is my favorite. The breadth of works and combination of modern and classical poetry is so refreshing. If you have any interest in English literature, you should DEFINITELY Take this class.

Amazingly rich and generous course on Black lyric poetry and art in the US, spanning a wide history of identities and artistic traditions. Professor Smith is a wonderful and necessary addition to the Harvard faculty and is brilliant and caring in lecture and discussion. One of the absolute best courses I took at Harvard, would recommend to anyone at all without reservations. Even if you’re not an English concentrator, this is a great course to take as an introduction to poetry and Black arts movements—and it resists the dominant structures of white, imperial, heteropatriarchal western canon that many other Harvard English courses are pretty tied up in or don’t work as hard to critique.

Emily Sun is the best! If she's TFing again, a huge plus — great at leading sections, really helpful and kind. Professor Kim is so brilliant and lectures excellently. The course material is a great selection, and teaching staff cares a lot about making the course accessible to students with any level of background in English.
worse_comment: This is a very well–taught course that approaches the history of American literature in an engaging and diverse way, and touches on themes –– fear, violence, marginalization, grief, loneliness –– that are useful for every person to think about, regardless of whether you are an English concentrator or not.

course_title: The American Novel: Dreiser to the Present 001
best_comment: Definitely recommend taking this course!! It's not an easy 4th class, because you go through essentially one book a week, and the books are incredible so you shouldn't just skim or definitely not worth just sparknoting. But Professor Fisher's lectures are super good, and the class is such a good way to think deeply about living in general, art and aesthetics, and consciousness/memory. Super interesting!
subject: English
course_title_2023: The American Novel: Dreiser to the Present

best_comment: Please take this class! It was great and you will enjoy it if you like scifi as a genre. The writing assignments may be a bit difficult if you are not accustomed to the style expected in English classes, but they are well explained and you could always ask Prof Serpell or the TF for extra clarification. If you are a histsci concentrator or getting and EMR secondary it will count for both of those! Overall a great class and I highly recommend.

Take this class! Professor Dimick is absolutely wonderful and cares so much about the student experience. You will read some great texts, think deeply about environmental justice, have meaningful discussions, and make good friends.

course_title: Images, Idolatry and Iconoclasm: Late Medieval to Early Modern 001
best_comment: If a similar version of this class is every offered again, I highly recommend taking it!
worse_comment: I wish you all could take this class, if it were offered again :(

best_comment: This is one of the greatest courses I have taken at Harvard. As an economics concentrator, I have never taken an English class (let alone one about the Harlem Renaissance!), and enrolled in this class last–minute on a whim. I am extremely glad I made this decision, as English 276LR taught me so much.The greatest strength of the course, without a doubt, is Professor Gates himself. He is not only a wonderful facilitator of every class (and has plenty of amazing stories to share from his illustrious career), but he is also very accessible to all his students (and gets to know them very well!).Georgia, the course's TF, is also an absolute gem. She is extremely helpful toward students' every need, and does an outstanding job guiding the class behind the scenes.A third strength of the course is its reading material. The articles, essays, books, and visuals we embrace not only allow us to embrace the African American literary tradition, they also shed light upon struggles and challenges endured by black America as early as the Harlem Renaissance, and as late as today.Perhaps the most underrated benefit of the class was its participants. Every Tuesday gathering in the Hutchins Center allowed for incredibly nuanced conversation among the diverse set of students hailing from different backgrounds, and left us feeling enriched with broadened perspectives. I cannot recommend this class highly enough!
subject: English

best_comment: Take the class. If you want to get the most from this experience, do not merely do the readings (and do them, by the way, judiciously, as opposed to giving each text a cursory read); you should also, as Prof. Bhabha often mentions in class, synthesize your most interesting findings or urgent questions in preparation to share them with the class. Doing so allows you to bring your thoughts to the table, and animates discussion.
subject: English

course_title: Introduction to Environmental Science and Engineering 001
best_comment: I would say that if you want to go into the clean tech space this is not the class for you. I wanted to go into clean tech with ESE in my degree but if you attend intern fairs for clean tech you'll realize that theres no civil or environmental engineers. The horrible thing is that this class did not show me this, it was my own initiative that showed me this.  This class does a horrible job of showing you concepts about the mechanisms for climate change and certain environmental issues, but it does show you how real research is conducted, and it does expose you to labs with really cool equipment. I dont know what the hell we used because they did a horrible job of explaining it, but all I know is that our lab was pretty legit and we got to use very rare equipment. I went into this class with no R experience, but an amazing conceptual understanding of environmental and atmospheric phenomenon. There's people who dont understand what I do but do know R. And this class does not help either of us if i am being honest, it does not fill either gap. I have friends who by the end of this class cannot explain radiative forcing, which is a simple concept that this class just can't seem to explain in an intelligible manner. I do know R now, but I was not taught R. Youtube and Mona taught me. Thank you mona, you are amazing. One specific TF (my TF, who is not mona) is brilliant, but extremely condescending. I would also say that because they do a horrible job of teaching R the tf's are soooo overwhelmed and usually have to stay overtime at their office hours. I came to this class to see if I wanted to do environmental science and engineering, and it turns out that I do not. I would say that wofsy is an amazing man who really makes people comfortable asking questions and who is very open to providing support for research positions and other stuff. Great man, not a great lecturer. I also would say that this class doesn't give you insight into careers for ESE concentrators. The truth is that the jobs are limited, you need an SB if you want to go into environmental consulting, which involves LOTS of oil and gas clients (I have been told this by many ESE graduates). This class focuses on the research aspect of environmental science. If you want to go into research take this class. If you  want to be in the clean tech space and are considering ESE, my recommendation is that another class will better prepare you to understand the concepts this class is supposed to teach you (specifically GENED  1094). I would say don't take this course, but personally I needed to take it to be comfortable in deciding that ESE is not for me. If you have 3 pset classes and expos maybe don't take this course it was tough. Its doable, im a FGLI student with no R background and I got through with an A–, but it was so freaking hard and did take a toll on my other classes (no low B's though).  I hope that provides enough insight. Overall you're not missing out from taking this class.
worse_comment: I was looking at both EPS and ESE as potential concentrations and this class made me realize that regardless of the material (which is similar in both). I would probably rather be in the EPS department environment. I liked the material covered in this class, but did not like the structure at all.
subject: Environ Science & Engineering
course_title_2023: Introduction to Environmental Science and Engineering

course_title: Introduction to Environmental Science and Engineering 001
