I would probably rather be in the EPS department environment. I liked the material covered in this class, but did not like the structure at all.
subject: Environ Science & Engineering
course_title_2023: Introduction to Environmental Science and Engineering

best_comment: Amazing class!! Professor Eli is a wonderful professor and the climate science topics were fascinating. I especially enjoyed classes on climate reporting when we talked about articles in mass media talking about climate, and on Climate Policy. I am much more aware of climate science, issues of uncertainty and the importance of good data representation. Favorite class at Harvard so far. Take it!
worse_comment: Don't take this class. The assignments are a combination of busywork and attempting to read the professor's mind. Don't be baited by the lack of exams. This is truly the worst class I have taken at Harvard. It's a pity that this class is so bad because the material is inherently interesting. As it is, I wouldn't wish this class upon my enemies.
best_gem_comment: THIS CLASS IS THE BEST CLASS YOU CAN TAKE AT HARVARD. BASICALLY A GEM, BECAUSE YOU LEARN SO MUCH, IT IS EXTREMELY DOABLE, AND THE GRADING IS FANTASTIC
subject: Environ Science & Engineering

course_title: Introduction to Physical Oceanography and Climate 001
best_comment: This class is truly an amazing EPS course. You come away feeling like you understand so much about the ocean; Eli is a great professor and the TF (Camille) is also super accessible and great! The teaching staff has your best interest at heart. With all that being said, this course is definitely mathematically rigorous conceptually, even though psets are infrequently. If you are on top of your work, though, it is super doable.
worse_comment: It’s a good class but the material can get confusing sometimes. It requires a deep conceptual understanding and sometimes that’s more assumed than taught.

best_comment: This class was ok. I expected there to be more about the mechanisms of toxicology, but it was more about the physical dynamics of toxins in the environment. A lot of the assignments seemed disorganized. Many times we were given exercises to complete without being fully taught how to complete the exercises – they were just graded on effort, but I think it would have been more effective to be taught beforehand rather than try to figure it out ourselves. Additionally, the material covered on assignments and exams did not always accurately reflect the time spent on those topics in class. That being said, grading was always fair to generous. Elsie and the TFs were helpful and available outside of class.
worse_comment: Everyone should take this class. I learned so much about the chemicals in the environment and in products that will weigh on decisions I make everyday. It scares me how little I knew about toxicology and the fact that there may be others in my same boat that are making policy decisions that effect so many people.

best_comment: I cannot recommend this course enough! This is one of the best courses I have taken at Harvard, with really cool assignments, a classroom environment that is simultaneously challenging and supportive when students ask questions or make mistakes, and a fantastic teaching team. I would encourage future students to start thinking about the black carbon project early on and to be really deliberate going into experimental design because there are a lot of unexpected complicating factors that can come up and ultimately make it hard to draw meaningful conclusions, but the process behind that project is incredibly educational and rewarding. This class is definitely graded fairly, and from a pedagogical perspective, I think it was taught beautifully. Frank is an amazing professor who really cares about his students and their understanding and appreciation of the curriculum. Take this course if you can!

ESPP 90E is a great class. You will learn a lot and find yourself in a classroom of students who care about the ocean and want to help. The discussions are really interesting and you'll get to hear a lot of different perspectives since students from a variety of backgrounds take this class. The three projects are interesting and manageable. I think that we could all learn more about marine conservation and recommend this class to all. I will mention that in my iteration of the class all of the work was due in the latter half of the semester and grading was sometimes unclear, so I encourage you to ask questions about that in advance. The class also tended to run overtime. Nonetheless, I'm very grateful I took this class.
worse_comment: The professor is a tough grader.

best_comment: If this topic is taught again, I would recommend the course if you truly want to learn about the tensions and abstract concepts within climate justice. If you already have extensive knowledge or passion about the topic, it may be alienating to have the uncomfortable conversations in class that challenge the validity of the framework. Regardless, it is crucial that this topic is at the forefront of the climate action conversation, and that as many student can engage with it as possible.

course_title: The Technology, Economics, and Public Policy of Renewable Energy SEM
best_comment: I would absolutely take this class, regardless of concentration. I concentrate in biology and had no reason to take this class other than wanting to know more about clean energy, and it ended up being one of the most engaging and interesting classes I've taken at Harvard. I particularly enjoyed that our discussions were centered around technology, economics and many other aspects of clean energy, as this provided a clear picture of the benefits and pitfalls of different clean energy solutions.
subject: Environmental Sci & Public Pol
course_title_2023: The Technology, Economics, and Public Policy of Renewable Energy

best_comment: Take this class!!!! It is a gem. One of my favorite classes I have taken at Harvard. It is a very interesting subject without being stressful. Professor Ken is incredibly kind, funny and supportive. You feel that the professor genuinely cares for you. The weekly homework assignments were very easy and the term project is super reasonable.
subject: Environmental Sci & Public Pol

best_comment: Take this class!! Any class with Americo is a gem. He is willing to hear your and everyone's input, especially about concepts surrounding Latinx and Indigenous studies. He really prioritizes participation and effort in assignments and during lectures. The class is meant to be in the style of a seminar, so feel free to jump in with an idea at any time. Personal anecdotes from your life, whether it be about your upbringing or about filling out the race question on surveys, are very much appreciated. This class makes you think about your own identity a lot, which is a great thing. The guest speakers are so nice and bring in so much knowledge, so make sure to ask questions.
subject: Ethnicity, Migration, Rights

course_title: Latinx Representation in Media, Films, and Pop Culture 001
best_comment: This course is extremely important for anyone interested in Latinidad, media, Latinx people, and culture in general to take. I'm grateful that it exists, and I deeply enjoyed absorbing its content and applying it to my assignments.  I felt very connected to it, and am ready to carry what I learned with me. The downside is the way that it was taught, as there is certainly room for improvement. The expectations for students of this course were sky high, which is acceptable only if they had told us about them. Once our first few assignment grades rolled in, we were hit with rubrics and expectations that hadn't existed a few weeks before. I felt lied to. This only continued as assignments that were not on the syllabus were popping up, sometimes just 24 hours before they were due. In a college course, clear communication, expectations, and following a syllabus at least somewhat closely is crucial for the well–being and learning experience of the students.
best_gem_comment: Definitely take this course! It teaches you very interesting things about Latinx media and what representation actually is. The assignments are few, and the class usually consists of videos, music, guest speakers, and conversation. Prof. Americo is also very kind and enthusiastic about the course. It's truly a gem.
subject: Ethnicity, Migration, Rights
course_title_2023: Latinx Representation in Media, Films, and Pop Culture

best_comment: Take this class!!! You will not regret it! It is such a laid–back and SUPER relevant class that will shape or re–shape your perception of how capitalism, racialization and the US empire come together and its effect on marginalized people within and outside the nation. The class discussions are amazing and the classroom space is very safe and open (also depends on your classmates). Prof Yalzadeh is such a sweetheart you will love her! Don't miss out

course_title: Topics in Asian American and Pacific Islander (AAPI) Studies 001
best_comment: If Eleanor is teaching this, and you are interested in AAPI studies (or even the vague idea of what that means), you should definitely take this course!The readings are really interesting, the discussions are vibrant, and Eleanor makes a point out of this class not being yet another stressor in our lives. It's very clear how much everyone cares about the material and I think it leads to some beautiful conversations. Moreover, even though I'm not an EMR (or EMR adjacent) concentrator (although I can't say I'm not slightly swayed), I think I learned far more about myself in this class than I have in all my years of middle and high school.  It's a wonderful platform to try and unpack your own experiences, if that's your thing, and it's quite cathartic in that regard!Finally, although I come from a STEM background, I never felt alienated by the class for it. There's lots of people here who had very different backgrounds, opinions, and worldviews, but it was very respectful and encouraging. (For those of you who took the course this year, thanks a lot for that!) If you take this class, I guarantee that you will find interesting things to contribute, and that they'll be things your peers will be glad to get to ponder!
subject: Ethnicity, Migration, Rights
course_title_2023: Topics in Asian American and Pacific Islander (AAPI) Studies

best_comment: This was a pleasant expos experience. I really liked working with my museum exhibit, and It is very nice to only have two essays.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class was great! The content was really interesting and Dr. Becker was a great preceptor. Not having to write a 3rd paper is definitely a huge advantage. Overall a great Expos course and I would definitely recommend it.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Overall not bad, but if you're looking for one of the more "fun" expos classes where you get to watch movies and write about rap songs etc., this isn't it. It's very straightforward and to the point, which isn't a bad thing if you wish to improve your academic reading/writing skills. I personally don't regret taking it, as a couple of friends and I took the class together and managed to have a good time and have interesting discussions during class, but I wouldn't necessarily recommend unless you're very interested in slave narratives in a literary sense or love reading through academic articles.
worse_comment: Listen to your predecessors. Becker is a hard grader. I thought my grades were low (B on the first paper) but then, after speaking to other stude. nts, I was not alone. The readings are tough when you have to go from one scene of tragedy to the next while expected to analyze them; I will always find this odd.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: It is a challenging class, but the knowledge you gain makes it worth it.
worse_comment: As a black student, I was apprehensive about taking a class on Slave Narratives taught by a non–black person, but Dr. Becker approaches the texts with such respect and genuine care for the authors of the narratives, the characters of the novels, and the students living with the repercussions of slavery. It never felt like he was explaining the black experience to me or anything like that.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Religious Pluralism was actually one of my favorite courses this semester. The play we read was amazing, and it was short so it was an easy read, but it had so many places for great analysis. Unit 2 was equally as fun, and even more applicable. We learned about the legal side of religion in America, and then were able You might find yourself agreeing with things you might not have thought you would, and then questioning what you really value, or at the very least you'll definietely get to hear a range of perspectives on pertinent issues. In general the themes we covered in class discussions were interesting, and they pushed people to think and disagree, and rethink, a process I really enjoyed being a part of. Religion is a vessel for larger themes in society and I think this is a great place to bridge those connections.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I would definitely recommend this as an expos course. You won't be totally overwhelmed by work (seems like its less stressful than other expos courses), you get to read cool short stories and watch documentaries, and you have tons of freedom for the final project to choose something you care about researching. Collier is a fantastic teacher and cares about the literature and his students a lot, and is quite an encouraging person. Overall, had a really good experience in this class!
worse_comment: I highly recommend taking this class, especially if you are a worried about expository writing being difficult or time–consuming.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Dr. Quigley is the absolute best, literally take this class just for her. She is so kind and compassionate and you will learn SO MUCH from her. She encourages you to step out of your comfort zone and is so inviting. Her class truly felt like a safe space to learn and grow. The class content itself was engaging, interesting, and intellectually challenging and stimulating. You will learn so much about gender and its intersection with psychology and mental health. I had a really heavy course load this semester and she was so understanding with deadline extensions and just in general. I was initially worried about not having any experience in psychology as I never took a psych class before, but I never felt like I couldn't express my opinions or share my thoughts on psych topics. It truly is a safe space for everyone.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is a great course and I'm really happy that I chose to take it. No previous knowledge or experience with 1984 is needed, and even if you have read the book before you will find it super interesting. The book is an absolute masterpiece, the discussions in class are always great, the professor is super nice and gives clear and helpful feedback. Assignments are clear but also very open, which means that you get to focus on and write about something that you personally find particularly interesting. I was worried that the class would be extremely difficult and complicated, but I had a really good experience. All expos classes are challenging but it becomes easier to handle when you find a course you enjoy and especially when the professor provides helpful advice and guidance throughout each step of the course.
worse_comment: I would tell them that they should only take the course if they are prepared to be scared about the reality of our world!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I would really encourage other students to take this class. I found the topic area to be very interesting and also very topical. 1984 was a great read, and I also enjoyed the opportunity to read some of Orwell's essays. Professor Cole is a great instructor who will do his very best to help you improve your written work. I took a lot out of this class and think that a good portion of next year's students would find the same.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Definitely consider taking this course if you're interested in the social sciences  (government, sociology, social studies, and econ especially) and their application to real–world problems! Readings may be more complex than other expos courses (would recommend looking at the syllabus before you decide for any course), but there's so much to gain from being able to analyze social theory to research–based arguments that will set you up well for the rest of your courses here. I actually enjoyed writing the papers because the subjects were interesting to me (colonialism, neoliberalism, environmental justice, race, inequality,  etc.) and I learned so much about them, helping me decide on my concentration for next year. If you struggle to understand something, feel free to reach out to the preceptor and read your peers' discussion posts for more support. Definitely recommend this course for anyone interested in these subjects!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is one of my favorite classes I've taken during my time here. I'm very much not pursuing a career/concentration in humanities/politics and actually considered ranking a more STEM–y expos section higher — but I'm super glad I ended up being placed in this course. Prof. Gilbert is super enthusiastic, passionate, and committed to having an open dialogue in the class; he's a really, really excellent teacher. I learned a lot; I challenged myself as a writer and as a person, as did a lot of my classmates. I've also been able to meet so many cool people through the class and had some interesting discussions outside of class since the material is that compelling. Would definitely recommend taking it :)
worse_comment: You'd be an idiot to not add this class to your lottery application.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: DR GOLD IS A GIFT PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE TAKE THIS COURSE TAKE THIS COURSE TAKE THIS COURSE. DO NOT BE A FOOL AND TAKE THIS COURSE PLEASE. As a dense stem major who thought that writing 2–page papers were nearly insufferable,  I came into expos resigned to the pain this class would cause me for the entirety of the spring semester. I accepted the hit to my GPA and that I was about to endure and just hoped for the best based on the topic and q guide scores. BOY WAS I WRONG. I left this course fully prepared to change my major to either English or comp lit because Dr. Gold is such an incredible teacher and will genuinely help your writing. Her comments on drafts are thoughtful and useful and she is SO supportive if you reach out for help. She wants you to succeed and to make you a better writer and IT SHOWS. The class itself is as enjoyable as it could be. Some classes are spent discussing readings and the people this class attracts (by nature of the topic) make the discussions insightful and inclusive and will make you want to participate. The classes when you go over the technical parts of writing are expectedly less interesting but Dr. Gold is such a wonderful person to be in a room with and does care about communicating the information so these classes are not that painful to sit through (and most of the time we did activities that allowed for social interaction which was maybe marginally useful for understanding the material but engage with the info in the Gold Guide (which is goated btw) if you tune out during lectures. The class is a fun experience even if you hate writing or struggle with it –– it was my favorite class this semester. Even if you aren't really sure if you have much to say on the issues of feminism and WGS, the research paper is super flexible and you can write about just about anything related to social justice or activism or social media or art –– not everything is about gender specifically in the class and it touches on broader topics of activism that are enlightening. I thought I hated writing (which I still lowkey do but I think everyone hates writing on some level) but this class has made me love it in a strange way and once again (because it can't be said enough) Dr. Gold is an incredible preceptor. Do not be stupid and do take this class. Take this class even if you are not a woman or don't feel you fully identify with the me too movement/experiences because the class is so much more than just social issues. If nothing else take it for Dr. Gold.  Obviously, your mileage may vary, but expos was a fundamentally (positive) life–changing experience for me (which is a sentence that I don't think gets said often). I have no idea what they pay Dr. Gold, but I guarantee it's not enough.
best_gem_comment: This class is truly a gem expos class. Not only are the course materials and texts engaging and interesting, but Dr. Gold is an incredible instructor who gives excellent feedback to help guide students' writing.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: By FAR the best Expos class out there!!! Dr. Gold is such an incredible teacher and overall a lovely person. The content you learn is important and timely, and makes the writing assignments feel useful and not at all burdensome.  Dr. Gold truly cares about making you a better writer and provides SO much helpful feedback throughout the writing process. I couldn't recommend this course highly enough!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is a very good class, at least as expos classes go. I think all expos classes have issues, but at least in this class, you will get interesting readings, engaging discussions, and a lovely teacher. Eliza was great to meet with outside of class. She is clearly a great writer, and she always has helpful feedback to give. Expos can be rough –– it's a lot of writing and it moves quickly. But, Eliza was always understanding and would easily grant extensions and be okay with soft deadlines. If you are interested in climate change, environmental justice, environmental studies, etc, I highly recommend this expos class.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: So many of my friends complained so heavy about their expos, but this course was very good! I enjoyed Eliza thoroughly as a teacher, while the content was always quite interesting to me. I also learned so much about how to write.
worse_comment: Expos 20 is a 20 vehicle flaming wreckage on the Massachusetts Turnpike. It is the worst course at Harvard, sustained only because it is a requirement, and no matter who you are you will almost certainly hate it. It is very possible that it will make you hate Harvard as a whole, and potentially hate yourself too. Expos teaches you nothing useful about writing, it only makes you jump through the arbitrary hoops that the writing program has laid out. The assignments bear no resemblance to any sort of academic writing that you might actually do, unless you are an English concentrator. The first two papers are literary analysis papers, while the third is a research paper in which you do no research, instead you simply compile other people's ideas into a trite synthesis of their research that you must then claim contains your own original contribution. This class in no way achieves its goal of improving people's writing.That being said, since you are forced to take it, this is among the less bad sections to be in. Eliza is a really nice person, and a fair grader. While Expos teaches you absolutely nothing useful about writing, some of the readings in this section are moderately interesting. If you are sufficiently skilled at compartmentalizing your pain,  might even momentarily enjoy some of the readings or discussions before returning to the untreated sewage waterboarding that is the Expos 20 material and assignment structure.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Obviously Expos is a required class, but I've enjoyed my time in this class quite a bit. There's definitely quite a lot of reading at times,  which can be tough. I also think the essays have a good balance of prompt/structure and independence.
worse_comment: Ricky is not a super easy grader. It took me a while to get an A, and my final grade will definitely not be an A. The first unit is very boring and about anthropology, the second unit is a paper about a film – either bewitched or Harry Potter, and the third paper is a research paper of your choice. I chose to investigate the Scarlet Witch, and my analysis was super fun. The last unit is hard but the least boring in my opinion. You should have some minimal interesting in witchcraft at the very least before taking this class. Ricky is very nice person, and easy to talk to if you need. His advice is often very vague, which can be difficult.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class, is by far the best course I have taken in my life. I am probably going to be a STEM major, and I did not know what to expect from this Expos course. I came out of the class as a stronger writer and a better thinker. The issues covered in class, especially around what personhood means, is one of the most fascinating topics I have ever encountered in my short academic life. The discussions in class are also particularly relevant today. The work in the class is by no means easy, but it is certainly the best class to take if you want to take your writing to the next level. Ross is one of the most intelligent, but most importantly, thoughtful and kindhearted professors at Harvard. He will make sure that you are successful in this class if you are willing to put effort into your writing.
worse_comment: Of course, certain discussions will be political. In general, we were able to have open discussions about difficult issues, though sometimes, because of the context within which the conversations were situated, entire segments of opinion were naturally shut out.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Unless for whatever reason you have a burning hatred/disgust for anything related to constitutional law, I would recomend this course to anyone. I noticed very few q reviews going into this when I signed up for the class, which I think is criminal because of how (in my opinion) this is a fantastic expos. I'll give a rundown of why you should take this course.For ppl interested in gov/law/sociology/anything related to this field: as someone who was interested in pre–law yet also severely lacking in knowledge about conlaw, this course was so engaging and interesting. Ross strikes the right balance between making sure the basics are covered about differing theories of interpretation, the general facts of landmark cases, etc. but also providing nuanced views/takes about cases. There are some in our class who clearly know a lot more about US law/conlaw than I do/most people, and Ross both speaks to their level of understanding but also by no mean forces the class to operate at their level of understanding. The course, I think, sparks interest in law at all levels.  I also appreciate that the law we learn is not insulated or theoretical, he also makes sure to tie it very closely to real–world events and current events. For ppl who don't care about law: despite the fact that we will reading exclusively written court opinions on cases, every discussion we have on a case is related quite explicitly and meaningfully to non–law topics (policy, race, sociology, history, gender, technology, science, etc.) . The final essay project gives you freedom to not be restricted to a legal or constitutional–history analysis of cases. It could be a gov/policy–type paper, it could be a paper about, it could be a sociology or philosophy type paper, etc. The cases are wide–reaching in their impacts, and if you want you can totally use them as gateways into less law–restricted papers.  The other papers we do before the final paper are not as generous in their scope, but they also definitely do not need to be law–analysis papers. (think more like an english/history paper where you analyze the author's biases or theories, etc.)For ppl who care more about writing skills: Ross is a preceptor who genuinely cares about your writing skills. He makes himself as open as possible to read theses/arguments you send him over email, to schedule extra conference/OHs, etc. He puts a lot of time into giving very specific and follow–able advice for your first draft, and he also ensures you get a conference with him after. Despite the intense focus on law, you also aren't restricted at all (or even encouraged) to learn to write like a legal analyst or gov concentrator. I think that because we aren't reading novels or essays that we are often more accustomed to from high school english classes and because we are given a new kind of writing (SC opinions/case writing) that is new to us, the course really pushes you and helps you find writing skills (analysis, communication, developing arguments, etc.) that help you in any kind of writing that involves convincing a reader. Ross cares more about understanding your audience, developing arguments that work and don't work, and understanding authorial/your own biases–––which are all applicable no matter where you write. I think it may be pedagogically better that we were forced to use different texts that we were used to so that we weren't limited to following formulaic, discipline–specific habits (like a high school English analysis paper) so that we could think more consciously about what we're writing and why we're writing. For your final paper, depending on what field you want to place your essay in (legal analysis, polisci, history, more literature–based, scientific, philosophical, etc.), Ross will help you craft your writing style/arguments to something that is more suitable for those fields too. I've learned a lot of specific skills and internalized specific goals that I've seen as problems in my writing for quite some time now and that I have seen myself improve on/can see myself further improving on in the future. For ppl who just want a gem/don't want to get grade–curved: this course is not grade–locked, so he does not limit the amount of As or Bs in the class. In terms of reading load, some cases can be definitely tough and dense, but compared to other courses I've heard about, it's not as much. it's 1–2 cases per week, no quizzes or anything like that, discussions to ensure that you know what's going on, etc. Honestly, the good thing about reading court cases is that there are tons of summaries about the cases you read which will help if you find the texts hard to read. The amount of non–essay assignments are limited, honestly (which I like). Ross isn't an easy grader per se (like he won't instantly give everyone As on your first assignments), but as long as you keep in communication with him you'll do fine. Despite your first impression of him, also, Ross is just an incredibly funny guy who makes sections a blast even if you find a certain class or discussion to be a drag in terms of content.

subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is the best expos professor possible. He is super chill and very helpful and accessible at all times. Take this one if you like sports or politics.
best_gem_comment: This class is a gem! Keating is the best professor and is very understanding. The topic of sports and politics is really interesting, especially if you have experience in it. Definitely take this class. The work load is not bad at all and Keating is very perceptive to students.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I LOVED More Than a Game. Every essay is so interesting and Keating is flexible about thesis directions. Keating is one of the best professors I’ve ever had the pleasure to learn from. He cares so much about each student and I bc eats in each students writing progress. Definitely take this class!!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I loved this course! TAKE THIS CLASS! Professor Rachel is the best and she will guide you through nailing down things like topic sentences, thesis, and question formation, and she will teach you a lot about sociology.  She is also very understanding and enthusiastic! Professor Rachel knows a lot about sociology and her field, it was really awesome learning from her.  Also, there are only 3 units, each one gets harder as the semester goes on. Read the sources right away do not wait until the last minute work on your drafts and put a lot of effort into them because it will help prepare you for the final paper!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is probably one of the best expos classes out there. Dr. Miller is really helpful and is always there to answer any questions. However, there were times when students would ask questions  in section about papers, and her answers wouldn't be clear enough. I think that maybe it was her way of allowing us to approach the papers/topics in our own way.  Her feedback on drafts is super useful, so I would recommend putting in effort into your drafts. This way, revising will be much easier/approachable.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Professor Miller is the best! She is very kind and genuinely wants to help her students grow without creating a stressful environment. If you are anxious about the requirement, take her course. Professor Miller is passionate about the plight of domestic workers and that enthusiasm will transfer to you if you don't already have it. This course was very helpful in making me a better writer.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this expos! Out of the many expos offerings, I've heard complaints about most of them –– this is one of the rare ones that no one complains about. The class isn't amazing –– you're not going to learn anything life–changing (the way the people in some of the engaged scholarship expos classes say they've been changed) or even particularly love the material (don't think you're suddenly going to learn a lot about ancestry, for example) –– but it's a writing class, so it's not even for that. However, the class is definitely very good –– I liked much of the material and rarely felt out of my depth. Prof. Nee is such a kind teacher, and he's always willing to meet with you to help you figure out how to improve your writing. He always gives very clear feedback and doesn't grade super harshly, so you generally know what you need to do to score well. The material was generally very approachable, and Prof. Nee generally spaces out the work so that you don't have to put in too much time until you have to write your essay draft. Above all, make sure to rank this class high on the lottery and hope you get it!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is a great Expos and I would highly recommend! David is a caring, thoughtful, and very professional preceptor, and runs an organized class with a professional, academic tone. However, he is still very easy to talk to and is obviously invested in our development as writers. In Unit 1, you read the Saga of Laxardal (an ancient Icelandic saga), which I quite enjoyed, but you must be prepared to actually read it and dive into it. It is definitely **old** (written in the 1200s) and can be a bit of a drag at times, but if you want a solid essay you must commit to reading it. However, the quantities of reading are very reasonable and if you're actually invested in the plot, then the essay and class discussions will be engaging and fun. Unit 2 is centered on the show Finding Your Roots (very fun to watch in my opinion) and lens theory. This unit generated some interesting discussion, and there wasn't really much work outside of class for it, but was definitely the least engaging of the three. In Unit 3, you pick your own research topic, so I would recommend finding a book or TV show that you really enjoy, and then the paper will be quite a breeze to write! If you've never done research or used Hollis before there are some in class sessions about it; though if you have, then it will feel very redundant. Overall, the workload for this class was quite low––outside of the essays, there was maybe 18–25 hrs (just a guess) of additional work for the whole semester (like writing response papers, reading, etc.). David gives great feedback on the essays, and I would definitely recommend meeting with him one–on–one to discuss your work. In my experience, he was very clear about what he wanted me to change, and it worked out well for me. The downsides of the course were few. There were times that I didn't feel discussion was that engaging; I think there was potential for us to have really interesting conversations and the vibe was often very academic and stiff. However, if you're considering an Expos, I would definitely recommend Family Sagas!
best_gem_comment: This expos is an highly underrated gem! Take it, I loved all the material that we had to read/watch for this class (Icelandic Saga, Minari, etc). Its very low–key and extremely interesting as the topic of "family trees" applies to each and every one of us.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you're reading the Q guides to find an easy/cool expos class I would leave this browser right now. To be fair the class was sometimes interesting and we could engage in intellectual conversations within class. BUT, the grading is absolutely awful. It's not because the points weren't being philosophical enough or because the writing was not intellectual enough. It's more because this teacher only accepts ONE style of how to write a paper and if it is not done in that way you're automatically marked off. I remember reading the Q guide and thinking this expos wouldn't be that bad but honestly I was bored 95% of the time (I also like philosophy so isn't that ironic)... and the teacher is so vague with the writing. After you get your first grade on that first paper your stuck in a hole if you didn't get an A. There's legit "always" something wrong with the paper no matter how many times the teacher allows you to speak to her. All do respect to the professor (Jen), she is a nice woman and very respectful but I personally did not have a good time in this class and would never tell someone to go through the pain that I went in doing the work in this class. After reading this and you still want to take this expos then best of luck to you !
worse_comment: Idk
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: The first thing a freshman needs to know about Expos is that it's not an intellectually fulfilling experience (and it isn't meant to be), so don't pick your section based on how interesting the title is. Even if you find yourself fascinated Jane Austen or con–law, you're likely going to find that the course really doesn't focus as much on the topic as you, the literary/legal obsessive, would like. And chances are you're going to be wasting time being taught how to write a topic sentence or a conclusion paragraph.This isn't meant to be cynical, it's just the way things are. And once you accept that, you can make a better decision. Yes, this class has the most boring title/description, but it is an absolute gem. The only participation grades are the daily reading checks. (4 multiple choice questions that are as straightforward as possible. As in, you can probably get away with not doing the reading some days—especially when you're reading, say, the plagiarism guide—and still get 100%.) This means you aren't pressured to contribute a nothing–opinion every 5 minutes to save the GPA. The essays are practically graded against a rubric, meaning once you figure out the key–phrases ("in this paper, I will..."), you're pretty much guaranteed an A. The trick is to assume your reader has a double–digit IQ.Tl;dr: When it comes to Expos, "Friendship" is the path of least resistance. (And to be clear, anyone will tell you that there is no point in choosing "resistance" for Expos, it's all just busy work.)
best_gem_comment: The first thing a freshman needs to know about Expos is that it's not an intellectually fulfilling experience (and it isn't meant to be), so don't pick your section based on how interesting the title is. (And to be clear, anyone will tell you that there is no point in choosing "resistance" for Expos, it's all just busy work.)
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I think I would tell them to take this class if the topic interests them. The readings in the class are really interesting and nice and the work load is not overbearing. The class is more writing focused than content focused though, so if you do not mind then, then this would be a good class for you.
worse_comment: It may seem tedious at first but for many, it is critical for developing a basis for a more complex thought process
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: We received good feedback on our essays and drafts, and there were opportunities for office hours. It felt like the most complicated part of this course was understanding what the assignment was; once we understood which types of arguments which essay structures were accessible, assignments were time–consuming, but simple. Know that this is first and foremost a writing course, and you will spend much more time discussing the best ways to incorporate sources into an essay than you will spend discussing the sources themselves. I think that might be true for any expos course, however.
worse_comment: Prepare for some really boring class sessions.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this class if you're interested in synthetic biology, its applications, and/or its ethics. The class is so interesting, and Emilie knows what she's talking about. In the beginning of units, readings can get dense and heavy but as long as you understand the main gists of the major readings, it's not too difficult and you can sometimes get away with not doing a few readings. Every assignment that isn't a paper or a presentation is ungraded, so that makes everything super low–stress (at least in my opinion) and assignments never take more than 30 minutes to an hour to do after class. Emilie is also super lenient with deadlines, for both assignments and papers, and she gives amazing feedback. Writing the papers themselves was honestly not bad, but that's only because I really enjoyed the class topic and what I was writing about. I honestly believe that as long as you pick an Expos class with a topic you like/a topic that GREATLY interests you, it'll be easy for you to do well.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Super interesting course with a very manageable workload – highly recommend if you're interest in bio. I originally didn't like writing very much, but actually enjoyed writing most of these essays – however, the caveat to this is that you must must must start early on your essay. Writing your entire essay the day before it's due is never going to be fun, no matter how good the course is. Other than that, Emilie is a joy to be in class with and is super helpful and accommodating to her students
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take American Money!! 2 out of the 3 essays that you write are based on movies (one is The Big Short and the other is a film of choice) so they are super enjoyable to analyze. The class is a bit more focused on developing writing skills than on talking about the content matter. Hannah is the sweetest person ever and will definitely be there to support you through it all. Not too intimidating of an Expos class!
worse_comment: I’d advise you against taking this course. Readings are quite boring, grading is unjustifiably harsh and subjective.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I had really mixed feelings going into this course, and my feelings about it were periodically rocky during the semester, but now that it's finished, I feel strongly hat it was a good decision. Not many people rank this section highly in their Expos ranking survey, I think because it's more rigorous than other sections, but I'm really glad I ended up in this course. First, the readings are awesome. My friend once asked me what we'd read so far in my expos, and I started saying "Plato, Gandhi, Kant, Rawls, Arendt, Thoreau, Malcolm X..." and another kid turned around and asked what class I was talking about, and I said "Expos," and he was like, "WHAT?  How is that an Expos class?" Seriously, the readings here are I think way more canonical and cool than those you'd do in most other Expos sections. Second, Ben is totally awesome. He's not exactly the person who's going to rally the troops for battle, or get you super excited about philosophy if you weren't already, but he's extremely smart and clear–thinking. His commentary is spot–on, he's a great discussion leader, and his comments on paper drafts are really thorough and useful. I never felt like anything he asked us to do was a waste of time. He's clearly thought a lot about good pedagogy, and that really shows in his course.Expos is something you simply have to take, and you can't get out of it. One way to deal with that fact is to put in as little effort as possible so that you can spend more time on things you want to do. But another way to deal with it is to accept that, if you have to do Expos, you might as well work hard on your papers and try to get a lot out of it, and if that's the approach you want to take, this section is for you. I feel like a much better and clearer writer thanks to this course, and especially Ben's guidance. I'd strongly recommend Civil and Uncivil Disobedience.
worse_comment: I would tell future students in this class to do all of your reading beforehand, and more than that, create a summary sheet where you note the main argument and premises of the text that you read for that class in an extremely structured and concise way. It will help you massively not only in the context of the discussion, but also when writing your response papers, as there is an expectation for you to be extremely rigorous in the way that you deconstruct the arguments you are critiquing/ extending. I would also recommend you discuss your paper ideas with the preceptor prior to writing them, perhaps in office hours, as he is extremely good with offering ideas, and making you question aspects of your argument. Don't be afraid to have slightly non–conventional contributions to the arguments made in class. This will be appreciated, so long as you are argumentatively solid!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you have the slightest interest in immigration and/or incarceration, you should DEFINITELY take this course. Based on what I've been hearing from my peers, this is actually one of the best expos you can take in terms of both content and workload. Readings are interesting and very light (graphic novels, podcasts, and videos a lot of the time!), and we always have good discussions on them. I'm usually a pretty quiet person when it comes to class discussions, but the environment was very comfortable and Erin is so friendly that I felt comfortable speaking up whenever! There's no "unnecessary" busywork, just the core assignments. Erin is very accessible, flexible, and simply the best!!! She feels more like a friend/mentor, and I loved having her as my preceptor!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! TRULY a gem of the expos classes; super relaxed, interesting and generative class discussions, and Erin is a FABULOUS preceptor. She prioritizes student mental health and is generous with extensions.
worse_comment: This class is engaging and fun, but don't expect to improve significantly as a writer.
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! TRULY a gem of the expos classes; super relaxed, interesting and generative class discussions, and Erin is a FABULOUS preceptor. She prioritizes student mental health and is generous with extensions.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I would ABSOLUTELY TAKE THIS EXPOS if you can!!! Rank it first! Sparsha is one of the most wonderful professors that I have had at Harvard and she moved with much flexibility for us, yet also made sure to ensure that we were really improving our writing. I feel like I came out of her class with more tools in my toolbox for writing and have even begun to implement some of her techniques in my other academic writing (for example, setting up a puzzle in our paper, this is something you'll come to learn if you take her class)! Sparsha is one of the kindest professors as well and genuinely cares about every single student and wants to see us all succeed. In addition, she is so obviously passionate about all of the work that she does and very obviously cares about the issues that she teaches in class. However, I do want to note that this is NOT some kind of class that is trying to turn everyone vegan, that is actually the last thing Sparsha wants to do. All she wants to do is educate us more so that we can make more informed decisions about our individual choices in life and give us better writing skills. Absolutely take this Expos, Sparsha is by far one of the best professors that Harvard has to offer and you will take away so incredibly much from this class.
best_gem_comment: This class is an absolute GEM! Animal rights are such an overlooked yet pressing issue, and Sparsha clearly cares deeply about the topic and each and every student in the class! She gives amazing feedback on every single assignment and the outside events, while numerous, are all incredibly engaging (especially the trip to the Arboretum). WOULD HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT!!!!!!!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Definitely take this section! The readings and class discussions are very fun and insightful. Adam is an amazing teacher. He is kind, thoughtful, and encouraging. You will learn a lot of great specific writing tips from him, and he will always respond to your writing in a very thoughtful and helpful way. I became a much stronger writer thanks to this class.
worse_comment: If you are even slightly interested in the idea of hell take this class.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This was an amazing Expos class. Although the topic is about the underworld, you spend a lot of time discussing interesting societal problems as well. The first unit can feel a bit dull as you're looking at older texts, but the second and third units are where the class really gets interesting. The readings are both engaging and varied; you go from religious sermons to intellectual analyses of how Hell is used in media to short horror stories. They also aren't too long, and if you enjoy them it doesn't feel like a chore to go through them. Adam is also an amazing preceptor. His comments on your writing really help you improve, and it's clear he wants to help you improve. If you like reading fiction and discussing their larger ideas, you should definitely take this class.
worse_comment: You just kind of have to push through it, we all have to take it, and as someone who HATES writing essays.. I'll just say this class did not make me love it more, but the discussions in class were fun, especially cause it was about hell, which brings in a lot of interesting other topics that are relevant to the real world.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Hard work, but fun environment, great instructor. Makes expos feel non–stuffy, fun questions at the beginning of every class (so you know everyone in your section), beret very interesting material, good criticism (you actually lesser from it), Ian has lots of good literary recs and is great fun to chat with outside of class.
worse_comment: Don't procrastinate and save yourself the stress.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I never expected EXPOS to be my favorite class, but here we are. I absolutely loved Art of the Con this year. I came in interested in startups and entrepreneurship, and I was curious how the syllabus focused frequently on fraudulent founders. But I ended up taking away so much more than that. Ian has crafted an absolute masterclass with his course. From sharing fun facts about ourselves at the start of class to watching documentaries on cons, I felt like I learned so much about my classmates and the world in general. We covered such a broad scope of themes, from ethics and morality to Silicon Valley and entrepreneurship to philosophy and psychology. Ian went above and beyond constantly, even with a surprise you need to wait for until you take the class (no spoilers!) But this course CHANGED. MY. LIFE. So thank you so much Ian and I highly recommend taking this class — you'll meet some of the most interesting people on campus and learn a lot about yourself in the process.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is definitely a solid section! Prof Sinnott is great and grades very fairly/gives helpful feedback on assignments, and is accessible & available for office hours or to talk about progress in the class. Course materials are also published on time, and there are very reasonable deadlines/extensions for assignments. One thing to keep in mind, though –– reading legal philosophy is basically the first unit of the course, so make sure that's interesting to you (or at least – interesting enough to write a paper about!)
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: It won't be your most exciting or interesting course, but as far as expos goes, if you are interested in privacy or surveillance or technology, this would be at least tangentially related and interesting. It generally gets the job done in teaching general improvements in writing and isn't particularly time intensive — mainly 0.5–1 hour of reading per class and essays.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is great if you have no writing experience and want to learn how to make your essays crystal clear and easy to communicate. If you already have your own preferred style of writing, it might be a bit difficult to adjust to the expectations that Julia has. That being said, she does make it clear that she does not grade based on the style of the essay, but rather how effective it is in communicating across the point of the essay. Julia is a great preceptor that puts in a lot of effort to help her students succeed and to answer their questions. At the same time, I get the feeling that she tends to reciprocate the amount of effort that you put in. In other words, if you don't put in effort into your work, she won't put in effort into helping you as well, which is completely fair.  For me at least, I came in with a very rigid writing style, and I had to put in a lot of effort to ensure my essays matched her expectations. But I would say it was quite worth it in the end, for I came out of the class having improved my writing style greatly. Definitely a good expos section to take but definitely not easy in my opinion.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Rank this expos as your first choice!!! You will not regret it. Hudson is what truly makes this class and is very understanding. He makes expos as bearable as possible but still pushes you to become a better writer. Regarding the work, all of the assignments build up to the major essays and is structured to make the writing process easier. Though, what you put into the course is what you get out. One thing that makes this expos different is the engaged portion built into the course which involves several guest speakers who are directly involved with the issue at hand. All of the speakers were great and I enjoyed listening to the work they've done to help solve the mass incarceration crisis in the country.  Overall, this was one of my favorite classes of the year because of the interesting topic and people.
worse_comment: TAKE IT! It's not much work and it's really interesting...but the grading is difficult.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is challenging but very rewarding. Hudson is an exceptionally kind, generous, and effective preceptor and is always willing to help. He does a create job of creating a sense of community by forming small research groups to provide feedback and having members of the community speak about what they're doing to end mass incarceration. If you are willing to put in time and effort, you will become a much stronger writer and learn to contribute original arguments to complex and important topics. I highly recommend this class, especially if you are even remotely interested in criminal justice, activism, and community–based work.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is a lot of work. But if you put the time into it, you will get so much out of it. Your writing will improve immensely, and you may develop arguments you never thought you could come up with. The most important part of the writing process is the response papers. Make sure you give them the time they require, and ask questions early on. It will make your draft much more effective, your conference much more helpful, and your revision much easier. And go to the writing center! I went for all of my papers, and I always got pointed advice. If nothing else, the writing center will give you peace of mind before you submit your essay. I definitely enjoyed this class, and while Expos may seem intimidating, it's very rewarding.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This course is one of the more demanding Expos courses: a lot more response papers and a lot of reading. But Wilson was a great teacher, the grading was pretty forgiving, and Shakespeare is a great Expos topic.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is very interesting, but if you're not too politically inclined then you might find the second unit hard to digest. Dr. Z is amazing and she's very lenient with things if you let her know in advance. She's very detailed in her feedback too, which helps a lot when it comes to revising your essays. Discussion–based participation isn't a requirement, which is great for students who are shyer than others, but participation is always encouraged and Dr. Z makes it a welcoming environment.
worse_comment: The more effort you put into the essays, the better writer you will become. If you complete assignments passively, you will not gain much from the course.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you're interested in public history, memorialization, or even just Boston in general, and you have the opportunity to take this course, take it. It was an amazing experience that I'm really grateful to have had. I think that humanities and social sciences people will probably gain a bit more from this class, but interest in the subject matter is really all that's required to have a rewarding and engaging expos experience.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: IF YOU ARE INTERESTED IN LITERATURE IN THE SLIGHTEST, TAKE THIS CLASS! Even if you are not, take it!Prof. Peterson is an amazing preceptor. Feedback is always extremely useful and she puts a lot of effort into understanding each individual argument. I would say it is a tiny bit more work than other expos classes (certainly more readings), but the assignments are so interesting that you will not even notice it. Building up to the draft of each long paper, we had to write a short response paper on a similar prompt, as well as a thesis paragraph. Prof. Peterson gave feedback on all of them, so one could easily see what arguments worked and what arguments did not for the longer paper. She is also just an amazing person in general, extremely passionate about the topic and wants to pass her passion on to all of her students. Before I took this class, I thought literature was extremely subjective, but she taught me that as long as my argument is well–proven, it creates the basis for a very good paper. Highly, highly encourage you to rank this first in the expos lottery.
worse_comment: Expos is a bad class across the board – it is unnecessary if you know how to write and you will find it incredibly tedious and redundant, especially if (like so many, myself included) you take it in the spring having already taken an essay class in the fall. Try to make discussions about the text rather than about your works cited or the MLA format, or you'll go insane.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is especially great for those who are considering concentrating in English because it really teaches you how to analyze literature in a thoughtful way. The material is very interesting and the class was overall relatively enjoyable.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Be prepared to write a lot, but also enjoy the readings given in the class. Also, you can write about just about any topic, as long as it somewhat relates to the readings.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: You should take an expos based on a fun topic. You are going to enjoy writing papers so much more on a topic you enjoy reading about, rather than feeling like you have to take a non–fiction based expos to learn something. My writing got so much better because I loved the short stories, books, and movies we absorbed in this class, whereas my friends had to trudge through a miserable paper because they took a different expos.
worse_comment: Take this course! Dr. Zecca is so sweet and caring. I went into this course as a fan of scary movies, but I soon learned that there is so much more to the genre than just horror films.  Also, start on your essay drafts early.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is definitely one of the best expos classes you can take the material is super interesting and it's a manageable workload. Also Dr. Zecca is great.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I would definitely recommend ranking this class high when choosing your Expos 20 section! Dr. Lane is so sweet and understanding, and she tries her best to make class engaging and a true community beyond just a classroom. The theme of the class is also super interesting since it is basically just all about technology, and technology is an inseparable part of our current society. I'm not the biggest fan of sci–fi, so I was worried that I would not vibe with the course materials, but I enjoyed pretty much everything we read / watched this semester, and not all of it was sci–fi. There is also not that much reading to do for the class (though there are some long movies to watch), so outside of papers, it is not a huge time commitment at all.
worse_comment: Take this class! The subject may seem niche and strange, but you will learn so much about your own writing and technology in both the literal and the abstract.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is a PHENOMENAL class! Given that it was the first semester this expos section was offered, I was not sure what to expect, but it was wonderful. The readings/viewings are fascinating, and I enjoyed the in class discussions. It is clear Dr. Lane cares about her students, and you will receive plenty of honest and incredibly useful feedback that will help you grow as a writer. TAKE IT!
worse_comment: The topic seems interesting at the beginning, but the preceptor is not very skilled and there is a lot of open–end discussion, which can be okay at class but doesn't help you much for the papers. So, if you know how to write take the course, but otherwise, you're not taught much, and Dr. Lane is not a very generous grader!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Please take this course. I absolutely recommend this course. The work is extremely manageable, and it is catered to every writer, whether you're a beginner or have taken writing classes before. Professor Strauss is incredibly sweet, understanding, passionate, and informative. The course material is also extremely interesting, and the amount of outside–of–class work is relatively light and relevant (not to mention fascinating). Again, I highly recommend this course!
worse_comment: don't take this class. it is not a safe space if you are part of a historically marginalized community.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I really enjoyed this course.  The materials were really interesting and felt very relevant, and it was really neat to be able to write about a topic that I genuinely cared about.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I would tell future students that this is an excellent choice of a class. Your experience in a course isn't only your investment and interest, but also the instructor's investment and interest. Getting to know your instructor is extremely helpful in making you and the instructor a living, breathing human to each other and helps the instructor know how to support you.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is by no means an easy class, but I personally found the topic to be really interesting which makes it easier to get through assignments and readings. Dr. Schwab is a pretty hard grader but still reasonable. She provides really useful feedback and pushes you to write your best.
worse_comment: The professor of this course grades very harshly and sometimes the grading does not make much sense.  I would recommend this course if you want some variety in the sources you analyze and the formats you can use (ie. you get to watch married at first sight and analyze the dynamics that occur there and do a podcast for the final project). This specific EXPOS class is not a lot of reading and is minimal work, but again, the grading is harsh.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Prior to taking this course, look over the assigned readings and ask yourself, "could I see myself writing and discussing this for a whole semester?" I wish I'd been smart enough to do that prior to placing this course on my list. It's not a bad course, I just think that finding the topics interesting makes a world a difference.
worse_comment: The topic is interesting but kind of restricting once you have to explore your own research question. The course involves conducting your own primary research and converting that research paper into a podcast project essentially, but there are only two essays.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you are not looking for something literary, this section is probably not the best fit, but the class is great for those interested in the subject (being Gothic fiction). Pat is a very thorough preceptor and clearly cares a lot about helping her students become better writers. I think my writing improved a lot this semester, but I also found the class to be fairly time–consuming.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is a wonderful course. The feedback is thorough and extremely helpful. I never felt lost in the writing process. Because it's a course that's in more of a niche area, the other individuals in the class seem to be very enthusiastic about the topic as well. This made the class so much fun to be in. The homework was never overwhelming, especially if you begin drafting more than a week in advance. it is very helpful to submit a solid draft the first time!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This course was fun, engaging, and I could not recommend it enough! Jane Austen may not seem relatable or interesting, but I promise there's so much humor and interesting comment that keeps her work relevant to this day. The second unit is focused on movies and the third on any Austen topic you like, so you don't even have to keep working with Austen's books if you don't want to. There's something for everyone, from politics to romance to literature to history (well, maybe not STEM). One of the great aspects of this course is that it actually does what Expos is supposed to do: it teaches you how to write! You will go over the fundamentals of writing a college essay beyond the 5 paragraph structure. Every assignment has a purpose and will help you hone skills in close reading, analysis, and research. If you invest time into the class, you will definitely progress as a writer regardless of your prior writing abilities. Plus, Dr. Napier is an amazing preceptor and truly cares about feedback and your progress in the class. He's funny, smart, engaging, and super accommodating. The seminar was always a fun experience, and you'll get to know all the other students in the classroom. Expos has a scary atmosphere around it, but I think this course is a great way to fulfill that requirement.
worse_comment: Take this class! Dr. Napier is a tough grader, but he gives incredible feedback and will really transform your writing to get it in ship shape
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you feel like your writing is not the best or you want to develop your writing skills, Expos Studio series (10/20) will help you with that because it focuses on each aspect of writing. You will focus a lot on stakes, have peer workshops, and check–ups with your preceptor for drafts which I thought was very helpful because they will truly guide you. Both preceptors I had were amazing and super sweet. Also a great perk on fulfilling pre–med English req.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you feel uncertain about your writing abilities Studio is great. While it is 2 semesters of writing instead of 1, you can see legitimate growth in your writing abilities
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I am so glad I took the Studio series over standard Expos 20. I was a bit hesitant at first, but I learned a lot from both courses and my writing greatly benefitted from them.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you want to improve your writing and have opportunities for 1 on 1 time with the teacher to go over your work take this class!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class has given me an appreciation of writing I didn't know I had.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you want to close the premed English requirement, take the studio series. I am not a native speaker, and I found this class super chill after taking Studio 10 in the fall (in comparison to my non–English speaking friends who struggled, taking Expos 20 in the spring).
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is super chill and perfect if writing is not your strength, but you want to improve in a supportive environment.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Dr. Starkowski is a great preceptor! Classes were as engaging as they could be and she's supportive, flexible, and cares. About the class, very similar to expos studio 10 but (quite) longer readings and more challenging essays (they are also longer and you have to include more sources...). If you're thinking about studio 20 vs regular 20, I'd say take studio unless you find a topic you're passionate about in regular 20, but don't expect studio 20 to be easier than regular 20 it's just different (in a good way I think)
worse_comment: Overall, it is not a challenging class, but what you get out of it depends on how much you put into it.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Expos Studio 20 is a course I would recommend taking if you don't quite feel that Expos 10 covered areas of writing that you still need to work on. Also, the topic is quite an effective topic (topic is successful life) in that it is interesting for most as it is what many of us hope to have a successful life in some shape or form. The class also teaches how to read articles more effectively and how to go about writing a research paper. I also found the class helped with navigating Harvard's library.
worse_comment: This class might be stressful but at the end you will see the change.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Have a lot of questions prepared during your meetings with your professor so you can get good feedback. While it is an extra step, future you will thank you when you're writing your essay.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: It's challenging but rewarding. Trust the process and you will come out a better writer!
worse_comment: This class is very difficult.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: It really helps you learn the writing process and you benefit a lot by the support from and working with your peers.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Do the readings since they can easily inspire a great topic for a paper.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Don't fear this class. People really talk down on this class, but it's not as bad as you may hear.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I would tell them this is a great class to take. You learn a lot about how to write effectively for all different types of writing.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Allocate a decent amount of time to this class. Writing takes up time and can't be done all at once. Be prepared to take a lot longer than you would expect.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Don't worry about the Studio 10 placement, it was one of the best decisions I have made staying in the studio series. I learned much more and had an easier work load
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Get ready to choose something you are passionate about and write an interesting prompt about it.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Your experience is very dependent on who your section leader is. In my case, my section spent the first month of the semester doing a lot of readings / TED talk reflections, and small verbal exercises and games in class – neither of which felt applicable to actually improving public speaking skills, and also may have prevented our class from growing comfortable with each other and bonding earlier.  (Based on what I've heard, other sections did a lot more impromptu speaking / speaking games early in the semester.) That being said, the actual experience of preparing and giving speeches was fantastic and well–supported throughout, and feedback from peers and from the instructor was invaluable. I had a very good experience overall and grew much more confident not only as a public speaker but as a speech writer, where I felt the most significant improvement was made.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class should 100% be required. You must take it if you can. Incredibly helpful, the atmosphere/community is GREAT and I have new friends coming out of it which is so rare!The class really supports speakers of all levels and you definitely shouldn't feel intimidated about your speaking ability going in because you will learn so much. It is amazing experience building and I can't recommend enough. You will feel so much more confident about participating in class and presenting after taking this course. It's just superb.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: SO MUCH FUN!! This class was definitely the highlight of my week. There were lots of opportunities to practice public speaking in both formal and informal settings, and I made so many new friends from this class :)I will say, though, that I didn't find this class to be as "life–changing" as I've heard people call it in the past. In terms of public speaking techniques, I don't think I learned too much that I didn't already know (like the importance of using logos, ethos, pathos, etc), but this class definitely provided a great environment to practice all these skills.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Please take this course!!!! This is by far the best course I have ever taken at Harvard. Every single thing you do in the class is so fun, engaged, and interactive and you come out of this course walking away with not only more confidence, but also a whole new group of wonderful friends. Kate Clarke is by far the best preceptor at Harvard. She is the most kind, patient, and thoughtful professor that I have ever encountered in my four years here. Would highly recommend taking this course – you would be missing out on Harvard if you did not.
best_gem_comment: Please take this course with Kate if you can. It is a must–take before you graduate, definitely a "transformative experience". You will learn a lot and Kate is simply the best, a gem!!!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Expos 40 is one of the best courses at Harvard. PERIOD. If you have Kate as your instructor, your experience will also be even better. You will learn so many ways in how to become a better speaker and you will gain many life skills from this course. Expos 40 also helps build confidence in yourself, and you will grow so much as not just as a speaker but also as a person after taking this course. I also love how this course actually makes learning fun. For instance, the improv exercises at the beginning are so fun but they are also great at building community. I only have good things to say about this course.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Everyone speaks about how it's great and a gem so I'll spare you those details. If you actually want to use this course to become better at public speaking (as you should), then know that this is just like any other skill. If you work hard and go beyond the demands of the assignments, you will improve a lot and gain a lot as a speaker. If you do what you need to do to get by you will not gain much from the course. I think that if you just want to take a gem, don't waste spots for other people who might take real advantage of this amazing opportunity and go for the Greek Hero or something :)Also, Lee Nishri–Howitt is an amazing instructor. He has fine–tuned senses to see where different issues are coming from and has some unique and helpful fixes to them. He also creates a welcoming class environment and is very non–judgmental. IDK about other instructors, but Lee is the bees knees. :)
best_gem_comment: Everyone speaks about how it's great and a gem so I'll spare you those details. If you actually want to use this course to become better at public speaking (as you should), then know that this is just like any other skill. If you work hard and go beyond the demands of the assignments, you will improve a lot and gain a lot as a speaker. If you do what you need to do to get by you will not gain much from the course. I think that if you just want to take a gem, don't waste spots for other people who might take real advantage of this amazing opportunity and go for the Greek Hero or something :)Also, Lee Nishri–Howitt is an amazing instructor. He has fine–tuned senses to see where different issues are coming from and has some unique and helpful fixes to them. He also creates a welcoming class environment and is very non–judgmental. IDK about other instructors, but Lee is the bees knees. :)
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I loved taking Expos 40!! I am so grateful that I got to take it during my last semester here at Harvard. This class is definitely what you put into it – if you try, you will get a lot more out of it and improve a lot more as a speaker. The environment was super conducive to learning and felt safe for me to take risks and be vulnerable. I loved this class so much, truly the highlight of my senior spring.
worse_comment: Take Expos 40! It is very low stress and will give you useful skills for life after Harvard
best_gem_comment: take this class regardless of ur familiarity with public speaking you are guaranteed to come out with skills and more confidence. also so easy and perfect gem
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: You've surely heard all about Expos 40, but I'm here to say that it really does live up to the hype. Having the opportunity to speak in front of your class is an invaluable experience, and the feedback you receive over the course of the semester really helps you rethink your tactics and approach. I feel so much more confident speaking, whether extemporaneously or with rehearsal, and better understand my own tendencies, strengths, and areas to improve upon. Also, it's just so fun to hear what everyone decides to speak on each week and spend time delving into topics of your choosing.
