subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Zach is literally the best. He brings so much fun, energy, personal anecdotes, jokes to the table and it is such a joy to be around him. It is so clear he wants the best for his students – giving them extensions, giving them helpful feedback, lifting them up. This class was honestly one of the best at Harvard due to the instructor, the workload, and the engagement of the class
subject: Expository Writing

course_title: Fieldwork and Ethnography in Folklore: A Tutorial in Cultural Documentation and Community Engagement 001
best_comment: Take this class. One of the best classes I've taken at Harvard and Lowell is literally the best. Super fun material and the assignments are actually fun to complete.
subject: Folklore & Mythology
course_title_2023: Fieldwork and Ethnography in Folklore: A Tutorial in Cultural Documentation and Community Engagement

course_title: Internet Folklore, Online Communities, and Digital Storytelling 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!!! It is SO fun and interesting! There are a lot of readings, but not gonna lie, you can easily get by with just going to class and listening to the lectures. Lowell is also just a SUPER nice person in general, like he is just SUCH an amazing teacher. You really can't go wrong with this class! I took it pass/fail so the pressure was even less for me, so I think I was really able to enjoy the class. Still, even if I hadn't taken the class pass/fail I think I would have ended with an A based on past assignment grades. One of the most interesting classes you will take, for sure, so don't miss out!!!
worse_comment: Easy A class for sure, but kind of boring and pointless. Take it if you want an A, but not very useful or engaging otherwise unless you're really into internet culture.
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. Awesome teaching staff, fun easy psets (no its true its true I actually enjoyed doing some of them), student presentations are so chill and you will be dying of laughter at least once per class. Will change how you use the internet. GEM ALERT!

best_comment: This class is really fun and worth taking. That being said, I think you get as much out of it as you put in. The readings, the discussions, and the hands–on work is all really fun, interesting, and educational, but some of it (especially your final project) will take a lot of time. I highly, highly recommend taking this class. You don't need to have any background in sewing, and Professor Lufkin is wonderful.
worse_comment: you don't reap the benefits of this class until the end, when you make your final quilt project and use all of the skills you learned. Most of the first 2 thirds of the class it was very boring and uninspiring. I enjoyed quiltlab meetings but wished they were longer and the quilt history meetings were shorter.
subject: Folklore & Mythology

best_comment: TAKE THIS SEMINAR!! Professor Wakeley is an amazing person, and he's super caring and understanding of the class. He's always there to give great advice and provide insights into all of the conversations! He fosters a very safe and welcoming environment in which we're all comfortable to speak and share new ideas! He becomes one with the students and is equally willing to listen to what we all have to say! The course itself has great material, and trust me, you'll have a great time learning about the intersection of all these different topics in the future!
best_gem_comment: TAKE IT it is so fun and fascinating. A “gem” of a freshman seminar for sure bc I loved it and the only requirement is the readings and the final paper

best_comment: This class is AMAZING! Brian is a wonderful teacher. If you have an interest in biology or music...this class if for you! Or even if you aren't...this class is still great. You don't need any previous experience in these topics. Every class we watch videos, listen to sounds, and discuss. The only real assignment is a presentation at the end of the year which is super laid back on a topic of your choice that relates to anything we have discussed. Honestly this class is a 10/10...I highly recommend it.

This course has been an absolute highlight of my semester! I've never found a course that better combines my interest in medicine and literature/writing. The readings were incredibly interesting and allowed me to see into the decisions and perspectives of physicians and patients. My favorite part of the class was Dr. G, who integrates his personal anecdotes with the lessons from these readings; his thought–provoking questions and insights always reminded me, in his own words, that "there is always more to learn." I came out of every class a better thinker as well as a better idea of what it means to be a good physician/person, and I would highly recommend anyone interested in medicine, literature, or anything in between to take this class! It's truly amazing!!
subject: Freshman Seminar

best_comment: This class is very interesting, and if you are interested in math and physics you really could not choose a better course. It was fun, the professor is a great orator, you get to solve puzzles in class, and you learn a lot of really cool concepts. Before this course, I hadn't heard a lot about what is going on in modern physics or anything about the history of physics really. Not only did we learn about that, but the delivery is so engaging that even for topics that seem way too advanced to comprehend you can learn a little something.

This seminar was extremely interesting if you’re motivated by questions of what it means to be human, cognitively, and how we come to be functional beings. I gained a fundamentally new POV on the role and functions of memory, and actually have a much deeper appreciation for its function despite examining “sins”. The subject matter inherently hits home sometimes but is very interesting for that reason. Schacter is SUPER knowledgeable and fun to talk with!
subject: Freshman Seminar

course_title: The Biology and Science of Cancer and Its Treatments: From Empiric to Scientific to Humanistic 001
best_comment: TAKE. THIS. SEMINAR. If you are remotely interested in cancer, medicine, science, pharmaceuticals and drug development, even business administration, or if you're just looking for a neat seminar that's outside of your usual fields of interest, take this seminar.  Dr. Demetri is a warm, kind, knowledgeable, passionate doctor and professor with a talent for giving engaging lectures.  This seminar was, to me, everything a freshman seminar should be: low commitment, high enrichment.  Every week I walked into class knowing I would spend two hours learning fascinating bits of information about all sorts of different topics in an accessible, entertaining fashion.  Outside of class, I never felt pressure or stress because of work for the class; in fact, there's barely any.  10/10, would recommend highly to anyone.
worse_comment: This class is a gem!! Dr. Demetri is such a passionate physician and professor. You will learn so much about cancer, from the basic science to the patient care to public policy and more.  We also went on fieldtrips to Dana Farber and a local biotech, which were incredible learning opportunities. The class is very low stress, and allows you to focus on learning rather than the grade. I cannot recommend this seminar enough!

best_comment: Only take this course if you are interested in art philosophy and history. This course is interesting and lets you explore broad questions about art in a low stakes context, which is fantastic if that is what you are looking for.

course_title: Trials from Classical Athens and Modern Legal Debates 001
best_comment: For anyone with an interest in law, like how it was conducted in the past or what debates are relevant in 2022, this course is the perfect way to satiate those thirsts for knowledge. Even if you are unsure about studying law or what that might look like, having Professor Lanni as a resource is incredibly valuable, as she is very generous with her availability and feedback on law school/law as a career. You get as much out of this seminar as you put in, so I would encourage those who take this course to close read and really think carefully about the material they absorb. It will be most impactful if you participate often and meaningfully, and have some fun in experiences like the trial of Socrates.

course_title: Food for Thought: Culinary Culture in Spain and Beyond 001
best_comment: If you're looking for a nice freshman seminar that is low stakes and very enjoyable this is the one. Get prepared to eat and to get very close to the amazing Dr Liander who fuels very interesting discussions on food and spanish history.

This is a GEM!! Don't even think but apply! This is one of the best experiences of my freshman year and you will love it! Professor Ofek is just a brilliant lecturer – every discussion is so engaging that time passes by so quickly. I did not miss a single class because each of them was so valuable! Assignments are manageable and creative! Most of them are readings on real–world business cases!
best_gem_comment: This is a GEM!! Don't even think but apply! This is one of the best experiences of my freshman year and you will love it! Professor Ofek is just a brilliant lecturer – every discussion is so engaging that time passes by so quickly. I did not miss a single class because each of them was so valuable! Assignments are manageable and creative! Most of them are readings on real–world business cases!
subject: Freshman Seminar

course_title: Law and Society through the Cinematic Frame 001
best_comment: This class is amazing and really gets you thinking in ways you might not have before. It is heavy on discussion which is perfect if you enjoy the topic and want to learn more or talk about legal theory and ideas related to law. Even if you may not think you like the topic, it can definitely surprise you and is just a low–stress class that is super fun and great to try.
subject: Freshman Seminar
course_title_2023: Law and Society through the Cinematic Frame

course_title: America's $4 Trillion Challenge: Boosting Health Care Productivity and Broadening Access 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS SEMINAR!! The lectures were amazing, engaging, there was lots of active participation encouraged, the topics were fascinating, incredible class–wide discussions, and Professor Garber overall is such a great teacher and has so much expertise! You will learn so much about health, economics, medicine, clinical research, the US health system and the class–wide discussions are phenomenal. I was always so excited to come to class each week. You will learn a lot if you do the readings, engage with lectures and discussions in class, and choose a final paper topic that really speaks to you. Loved the flexibility in what we could research, and the encouragement throughout.
worse_comment: You'd be an idiot to not apply for this course. I couldn't have taken a better freshman seminar.

course_title: When Bad Things Happen Early in Life: Effects of Early Adversity on Brain and Behavioral Development 001
best_comment: SUPER highly recommend the professor is amazing

course_title: The Economist's View of the World 001
best_comment: This was an AMAZINGLY fun course to take this semester. I don't think that it was as life–changing as some past q–guide reviews have indicated. You'll read books and discuss very relevant issues, but it probably won't change the course of your career. We read 7 books this semester, and you could honestly just read them on your own and learn most of the same material (I think the syllabus reading list is available online). I do recommend reading the books fully, but you could just skim them and be fine. However, if you genuinely enjoy thinking/arguing about economic issues from either a left or right perspective, you will really enjoy this class. Every Monday morning, I could look forward to two hours of enthusiastic, often humorous, discussion, and it was a really nice highlight of each week. Greg Mankiw is one of the sweetest, most knowledgeable people here at Harvard, and getting to know him in a group of 12 people is a really special opportunity that you may not get again. Also, if you tend to lean conservative, this is one of the only spaces on campus where you can actually have a respectful discussion about your opinions without fear of getting canceled, which is a nice bonus.

course_title: Political Legitimacy and Resistance: What Happened in Montaigne’s Library 001
best_comment: This is a wonderful class that takes dense texts and makes them digestible to students of all backgrounds. Arthur is a gem – super patient and funny. The workload is not insignificant, and you might get confused at times in the readings, but class discussions help to clarify the key points of the readings. Great class atmosphere with discussions.
worse_comment: This is a worthwhile class, but you must be willing to read. That's the biggest barrier to entry and it inhibited some of our discussions this year when people didn't read.
best_gem_comment: This is a wonderful class that takes dense texts and makes them digestible to students of all backgrounds. Arthur is a gem – super patient and funny. The workload is not insignificant, and you might get confused at times in the readings, but class discussions help to clarify the key points of the readings. Great class atmosphere with discussions.

course_title: Gut Reactions: Discovering Chemistry from the Human Microbiota 001
best_comment: This is a very rewarding course if you give it the time it deserves. It's not demanding in terms of coursework outside of class and it's very rich in discussion, mentorship, wetlab work, and research exposure. Great seminar for STEM majors or even non–STEM majors who would like to learn more about science and the chemistry of the gut microbiome.
Take this class! Professor Girguis is amazing; my favorite class I have taken thus far at Harvard. Fun, very interesting, and takes a great approach to learning about interesting topics.

course_title: The Story of the Alternating Sign Matrix Conjecture 001
best_comment: First and foremost, this is a math–heavy seminar.  You don't necessarily need a super strong math background, but be prepared to do a considerable amount of math during class.Given that you are looking for a math–heavy seminar, this class is amazing.  The content is super interesting, and covers a huge array of fields.  Professor Williams is a superb lecturer, and also a really nice person.  Get to know her; I highly, highly recommend going to office hours even if you don't have questions.  The amount of homework is also perfect; enough to be interesting, but not enough as to be overbearing.  The final presentation and paper are also pretty open, which is nice.

course_title: The Universe: Its Origin, Evolution, and Major Puzzles 001
best_comment: Definitely take this class. Relatively easy, but also very interesting and was a great break in my week.

course_title: Insurrection in a Little Kingdom—The Real Story of the Standard Model of Particle Physics 001
best_comment: This is a fun class. The book you read is very interesting and enjoyable, and the environment in a small class with just Professor Georgi and a few other students is very fun. The lectures are also very interesting and well–taught, though the subject matter is quite advanced so don't expect to be able to learn everything without paying full attention. Professor Georgi is a great teacher. He is funny, kind, and charismatic, and he responds to questions thoughtfully.
worse_comment: Georgi is a phenomenal personality and researcher, and he really makes this course what it is. But beware: this course may not have much work at all but the content is not presented in an accessible way. If you are actually interested in learning the ins and outs of particle physics, this is perhaps a good starting point but it may leave you frustrated as you are presented with dense slides of math you could not hope to understand.

course_title: Changing Perspectives: the Science of Optics in the Visual Arts 001
best_comment: I highly recommend this class to any prospective students. It is a very chill class where you get to play around with art, look at a bunch of art closely, and I just took away a greater appreciation of the art world. Prior to this course, I had a very poor understanding of art. My parents would bring me to art museums and I would just not understand anything other than "it looked pretty", and I could count the number of artists and paintings I could name on my hand, a far cry from where I am now. This class truly transformed my view on art by enticing me through a scientific thesis that we were trying to investigate. I appreciated that this course wasn't just about perspective paintings either, we got a general taste about what art is like, from contemporary to pointillism to silhouettes to portraiture to freehand sketches. Most importantly, I can look at a painting now and know how to look for details and techniques and just in general appreciate art to a much greater extent.

course_title: Science and Technology Primer for Future Leaders 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU CAN! This seminar was beyond a doubt one of my favorite ever learning experiences. The class environment is super chill, and Hongkun is absolutely amazing and phenomenal. I took the class because I was quite captivated by the title – the promise to give you a broad and comprehensive overview of science and technology – and it really did deliver on all of these promises. Hongkun is also just so great and so accomplished and it was an absolute delight to be taught by him. Cannot recommend this course highly enough, if you'd like a thorough and in–depth overview of several different areas within science without the pressure of psets and exams.
subject: Freshman Seminar
course_title_2023: Science and Technology Primer for Future Leaders

course_title: Misinformation, Disinformation, and BS in Science Communication 001
best_comment: This was the best class I've ever taken. Make sure to take it! Professor Hartl is awesome

course_title: Religion, Neuroscience, and the Human Mind 001
best_comment: Professor Lamberth's seminar is an interesting one, but definitely one that will be more rewarding if you really commit to putting the time into doing the readings. The reading load is relatively heavy, and can be quite dense at times, but it is always interesting and thought provoking by the end. The professor really cares and is very passionate in explaining topics in the class, and will offer lots of insights from his study of the readings presented by the class. Class discussions really make or break the seminar, and the discussions that we had in our class were usually interesting. It's necessary to make an effort to contribute to discussions in order to make the class worthwhile
subject: Freshman Seminar
course_title_2023: Religion, Neuroscience, and the Human Mind

best_comment: ABSOLUTELY AMAZING! If this is ever offered again, PLEASE take it. The highlight of my first year at Harvard. You will leave this course with a more profound understanding of important drawings and artists throughout history. You'll also be super well–versed in identifying varying mediums that drawings are made of. An excellent course.

This course was a great addition to my busy schedule because the workload was light and enjoyable. I got to practice thinking about art and storytelling in a different way. One thing that I think was unique about this course is that I felt quite connected to the other students in the class; there are often chances to be vulnerable or share personal things about yourself if you so choose, and the overall environment of the classroom was inviting and wonderful.
worse_comment: PLEASE do not take this class. This class was terrible, and I regret taking it. The professor was inconsiderate, was always late to class, and did not provide any structure. Our class was unorganized, and often felt as if we were meeting for no point. The assignments were often unrelated to what our course was supposed to be covering. For a pass/fail creative writing class, I wasn't expecting to have such strong feelings about this course. Most importantly, this class did NOT foster my love of writing. It fostered a hostile environment in which I felt as if I never want to write again.

course_title: Law and Social Change: How Reform Movements Leverage the Law 001
best_comment: I would recommend taking this seminar as an easy supplement to your freshman course load. You learn about the theory of social movements and then get into real–world case studies such as Me Too and Black Lives Matter. The final presentation on the social reform movement of your choice was also pretty fun. Dean Brown–Nagin is one of the smartest professors and legal/historical minds I've met here at Harvard, so you may feel intimidated at first. However, it's a great chance to engage with her and talk about current events and issues in American society. The class gets a lot better once you loosen up a bit and have fun with the discussion at hand. All in all, it was a good part of my Harvard experience, and you can't go wrong taking it.

course_title: Zen and the Art of Living: Making the Ordinary Extraordinary 001
best_comment: I loved this class! For not knowing anything about Zen, I felt like I got a fairly good grasp on the basics by the end. It is fairly history heavy, so keep that in mind. We also got the opportunity to talk with Buddhist nuns, which was an amazing experience!

This course was LIFECHANGING! Professor Reinert is the absolute best; he engages everyone in the class and is a phenomenal professor overall. The HBS cases were all so different but equally interesting; I learnt a ton! Take this class even if you don’t have an interest in pursuing an economics concentration; it will be the best decision you ever make!
subject: Freshman Seminar

best_comment: This course is wonderful for anyone interested in education, social justice, philosophy, and politics. It encourages you to think deeply about the role of education in society and in terms of content, it fulfilled and transcended my expectations. It does a good job of introducing the a very wide breadth of theory on the topic and opening you up to further questioning. As far as freshman seminars go, I would say this is one of the more demanding in terms of work and assignments—a lot of reading, response papers, and presentations, which is something to keep in mind—though all of it is quite fascinating.
subject: Freshman Seminar

course_title: Portraying Activism: Lessons from Social Movement History 001
best_comment: Take this class!!! not only is it an amazing class for people interested in activism or social justice movements in general, but it is an amazing exposure to Harvard's on campus buildings and resources –– especially for future papers and if you are interested in potentially writing a thesis. this class was definitely as great as it was because of Dr. Alemu (but unfortunately I do not think you will get the  privilege of having her because she is moving to another school), but if you do decide to take it, I hope that the next professor will hold true to the intents of this course and regardless, I think this class is surely a great decision.

course_title: Power and Identity in the Middle East 001
best_comment: This is a good class but isn't what I'd call a "gem" necessarily. You get to learn a lot about the Middle East though and Prof. Cammett is clearly super passionate about what she does! There's probably somewhere between 100 and 150 pages of reading each week, but a lot of it is skimmable so it doesn't take too long. The essay assignments aren't too bad and grading seems pretty chill. You also kinda don't need to attend lecture since the essays often only require familiarity with the texts, though of course it can be fun to just sit and listen.
worse_comment: This course covers a lot, which can be good or bad but I would say mostly bad since you don't necessarily grasp too many concrete ideas about the Middle East. It's more concepts that might stick with you. The assignments are kind of weird too. I would be hesitant to say this class will leave you knowing so much more about the Middle East..
best_gem_comment: This is a good class but isn't what I'd call a "gem" necessarily. You get to learn a lot about the Middle East though and Prof. Cammett is clearly super passionate about what she does! There's probably somewhere between 100 and 150 pages of reading each week, but a lot of it is skimmable so it doesn't take too long. The essay assignments aren't too bad and grading seems pretty chill. You also kinda don't need to attend lecture since the essays often only require familiarity with the texts, though of course it can be fun to just sit and listen.

best_comment: The readings in the class are at first very dense, but they get better over time. Professor Pistoja's lectures are interesting but can get boring. He's genuinely passionate about this topic. Michael Mango is a great TF and makes section engaging. The assignments are short and doable; they are either creative assignments or short reflections on the readings. There is a quiz, which was a bit weird but graded leniently. The midterm research paper is not very difficult, and the final project is a creative assignment. The class is overall a good GenEd and would recommend to anyone who's interested in satire.
worse_comment: The class has a substantial amount of work. I did have some key take aways from the class. My biggest complaint is that the class felt very disorganized. Assignments were always emailed to us last minute and the directions for assignments (specifically midterm and final assignments) were sometimes unclear and not centralized. Also I requested to take the class pass/fail and was only told by staff that they weren't allowing students to take it pass fail several days before the final day to drop a class which was very frustrating.
best_gem_comment: This is an incredibly interesting class that explores in depth the social, political, and cultural positioning of satire and satirists. Honestly one of my favorite courses at Harvard, and I wasn't even an English concentrator or even tangentially related to that field. There are so many takeaways in this class for anyone in any concentration, about art, about humor, about how to enact change in the world. And Professor Pistoja is an absolute gem of an instructor –– excellent and passionate lectures, incredibly thoughtful about giving students to engage in the way that best supports their learning. Absolutely recommend.

best_comment: I personally believe this class or something similar should be a requirement for graduation at Harvard. Climate change is assuredly the biggest problem my generation will ever face, and it was really interesting to think about it through the lens of a philosopher. I've never taken any philosophy classes (personally have been a little scared of them), but this class was a really interesting introduction to the discipline. The lectures were really, really interesting and sections were very helpful for thinking about the questions asked in the assignments. Overall, I would highly recommend this class to just about anyone, even if you don't need the GENED req.
worse_comment: This is NOT a philosophy course; it should be called the Economics of Climate Change. Almost all of the readings rehash the same economic arguments that the professor disagrees with. So he presents some economists view and then in class says why he thinks it's wrong. Almost no philosophy is in this course, which I wish I knew before taking it.
best_gem_comment: Seems like a gem but wouldn't go as far as saying that. Unless you have a background in philosophy writing, it takes a lot to do well in this class and even then you still may be getting Bs. Even when meeting with your tf and rewriting drafts, you'll likely remain in the B range. xoxo

best_comment: This is a challenging course, but if you put the time and effort in, it is so, so worth it. The course covers the history of US nation–building projects from the end of the nineteenth century onwards ––– each unit builds on the last and covers material that should be but rarely is acknowledged in standard US history classes. (It was a treat to learn so much about the Philippines in particular!) Lectures were always fascinating, and sections were incredibly engaging and thought–provoking. Get started on readings and papers early ––– they're rigorous, but I learned a great deal from them.
worse_comment: It can be a lot of work. While the week to week is manageable in terms of readings, the few essays you are assigned throughout the semester require lots of time and writing. Probably only take this course if you are really interested in the history of American imperialism and occupations. If not, you are better off spending your time elsewhere. Additionally, there were a few questionable moments in the class that felt a bit colonizer–y.

best_comment: This is a challenging course, but if you put the time and effort in, it is so, so worth it. The course covers the history of US nation–building projects from the end of the nineteenth century onwards ––– each unit builds on the last and covers material that should be but rarely is acknowledged in standard US history classes. (It was a treat to learn so much about the Philippines in particular!) Lectures were always fascinating, and sections were incredibly engaging and thought–provoking. Get started on readings and papers early ––– they're rigorous, but I learned a great deal from them.
worse_comment: It can be a lot of work. While the week to week is manageable in terms of readings, the few essays you are assigned throughout the semester require lots of time and writing. Probably only take this course if you are really interested in the history of American imperialism and occupations. If not, you are better off spending your time elsewhere. Additionally, there were a few questionable moments in the class that felt a bit colonizer–y.

course_title: Pride & Prejudice & P-values: Scientific Critical Thinking 001
best_comment: This is excellent. Don't let the # of assignments scare you. The work load is not heavy AT ALL. You learn a lot doing the short assignments, and I spent at most ~3–4 hours a week outside of class (probably closer to 2 realistically if I was focused). TAKE THIS CLASS. You will not regret it –– Ned and Doug are some of the greatest, funnest, most interactive and caring professors I've ever had.

course_title: Pride & Prejudice & P-values: Scientific Critical Thinking 001
best_comment: This is excellent. Don't let the # of assignments scare you. The work load is not heavy AT ALL. You learn a lot doing the short assignments, and I spent at most ~3–4 hours a week outside of class (probably closer to 2 realistically if I was focused). TAKE THIS CLASS. You will not regret it –– Ned and Doug are some of the greatest, funnest, most interactive and caring professors I've ever had.

At one point professor Rinard mentioned how a colleague said “Research, teaching, and family; pick two.” I’ve heard she’s an accomplished researcher and it’s clear she has strong bonds with her family. I think it’s fair to say her colleague was right. Never in my four years at college have I experienced a lecturer that is so disorganized and difficult to follow. I like to pay attention in all my classes, I tried, fervently, to do that in this class. It was impossible. Rinard begins every lecture well, for the first two minutes or so: That's when the first aside about her son, her obsession with beans, or whatever her husband is writing begins. Every single lecture has been fragmented with these unnecessary asides with information about her personal life. It's not that I'm cruel and don't care about any of the things that make her human, it's that I can't learn if every 2–3 minutes she disrupts the flow by telling us a story that is only marginally related at best. And, even then, maybe I'm giving her too much credit: even when she had a long period without interruption (in this class that would be roughly 8 minutes), it was still difficult to follow what she was saying. It's clear she puts no time into planning her lectures and making them easy to digest. I imagine that her "preparation" for lecture is sitting down for 15 minutes, bulleting down anything that comes to mind when she thinks about the reading, then deciding that she might as well just lecture it in whatever haphazard order she came up with it in.And then, of course, comes the issue of the materials. I read through every single assigned reading, sometimes more than what was assigned. To be frank, the reading list was very interesting and I was constantly intrigued by the ideas put forth. But, I have this inkling that she has not read more than a third of the readings she assigned herself. Throughout lectures, she would make vague counterarguments to the readings that show she clearly has never engaged with some of the readings. I wonder if she looked up book summaries instead. Then, of course, she would often portray the ideas she disagreed with as uncharitably as possible. If it wasn't written by Dan Haybron, it was probably hogwash, and she'll try to convince you of that by shaping the argument to be something it never was. This wouldn't bother me as much if I didn't get so excited to learn more about the readings after reading them. Imagine taking a GenEd thinking you just have to get by, finding yourself intellectually stimulated then wanting to learn more, then having the professor continually prove she does not know what she is talking about and likely knows less than you if you did your reading closely.Overall, do not take this class. If you're interested, I'd recommend skimming the reading list and making use of it yourself. Professor Rinard does not make it an enjoyable learning experience whatsoever.
worse_comment: this course was boring and not related to happiness at all. The professor literally said on the first day, "this course will probably make you more unhappy, at least while you're taking it." Don't do it to yourself.
best_gem_comment: This class is relatively EASY, but BORING! if you want to take a class where the professor talks about her children 25% of the class, then this is the class for you. I think the average mention of kids per lecture is 10. this does not include mentions of other family members, friends, boring stories with no relevance to the subject, or attempts of jokes. The class might be a gem in terms of easy assignments, if you do well on the short papers and put in some effort, it should be an easy A. But is it worth it? the material is not enjoyable and the lectures consists of the professor just talking for an hour and fifteen minutes, once every other lecture she wrote something on the blackboard, but not a single picture, presentation, or anything that made it easy to follow and engaged. I would rather take a more demanding class than Happiness, which did not fulfill my expectations (which was fairly high).
subject: General Education

best_comment: This is a great but non–trivial course to fulfill your science GENED requirement. I actually took it as an elective, and enjoyed it. Nevertheless, there are daily labs, and exams are comprehensive and rather difficult, and graded rather harshly –– you will need to study, and also be quite specific in your answers on exams, as they will dock points even if you have captured the main idea, but do not include a specific term and/or piece of evidence. Aside from exams however, the rest of the course was really quite good. Weekly labs were actually on the interactive side in terms of GENEDs, and lab assignments were generally pretty easy (good to work with others though). Most importantly though, the takeaway concepts I gained from this class were what really made me enjoy this course. One of the fundamental messages this class illustrates is that we've been accustomed as a society to treat the symptoms of diseases that arise from mismatches between what humans have adapted to historically versus the starkly different environment most of us now live in (very sedentary lifestyles, extreme abundance of food, etc.). Crucially it has taught me how effective and vital disease prevention is, and has motivated me to stay active and maintain a healthy, balanced diet even more so than I already had.  Lastly, if you're interested in archaic human species, or the evolution of humans in general, as well as how humans differ from our ape relatives (and why these traits were selected for), this class is certainly a good overview of that.
worse_comment: This course is not treated like a GenEd. The majority of the students are HEB concentrators, and the professor assumes some proficiency with the material before it was even taught. This is explicitly seen in practice exam answers that utilize information that was never discussed in the entire class.
best_gem_comment: This class is very interesting, but is by no means a gem! The labs are graded pretty tough (really depends on your luck with who you get as a TF) but Lieberman is a wonderful lecturer and the class really tells a story of human evolution. It is super interesting and corrects a lot of misconceptions on human evolution! It will also change your outlook on human health.
subject: General Education

best_comment: Really open your ears to hear what your classmates have to say about the texts, some of their views will challenge, reassure, or interest you. Regardless, hearing these different views will always help you grow. Also, use this class as an opportunity to practice joining the conversation. While you could easily skip lecture and nobody would know, you’d be doing great disservice to your enrichment because this class is truly an opportunity to learn how to voice your ideas in a setting where you’re vulnerable to being challenged. Please enjoy it and engage in the readings too – they will give you insight about the human experience which will make many of your daily stressors (GPA, grades, social drama, etc.) seem not so bad. Learning about other human experience definitely humbled me and many of the complaints I had before taking this course.
worse_comment: The lectures aren't the best. You have to do the readings or you will be very bored.
subject: General Education

course_title: Res Publica: A History of Representative Government 001
best_comment: I want to preface that I thought the course was exceptionally interesting, the instructor, and the TFs during OH and section were also excellent and knowledgable. If you are looking for an intense GENED that will improve your critical reading, writing, and general knowledge I would definitely recommend in that regard. However, I will say that for a GENED the workload is very intense, and if you are looking for an easy way to fulfill the H&S requirement there are better alternatives. If the course still has 100 pages of reading a week and three/four papers when you read the syllabus then it will be considerable work. It really depends what your preferences are as a student, if you are academically minded and want to learn new perspectives from the GENED program this is a hard yes. If you want a gem and an easy A I would probably not recommend.
worse_comment: No comment because you ruined the Q Guide
best_gem_comment: I want to preface that I thought the course was exceptionally interesting, the instructor, and the TFs during OH and section were also excellent and knowledgable. If you are looking for an intense GENED that will improve your critical reading, writing, and general knowledge I would definitely recommend in that regard. However, I will say that for a GENED the workload is very intense, and if you are looking for an easy way to fulfill the H&S requirement there are better alternatives. If the course still has 100 pages of reading a week and three/four papers when you read the syllabus then it will be considerable work. It really depends what your preferences are as a student, if you are academically minded and want to learn new perspectives from the GENED program this is a hard yes. If you want a gem and an easy A I would probably not recommend.
subject: General Education
gened: Ethics and Civics; Histories, Societies, Individuals
course_title_2023: Res Publica: A History of Representative Government

best_comment: This was a very fun and relaxed course! The Max and Phil are great and generate a lot of enthusiasm for the subject matter. I would highly recommend!
subject: General Education

course_title: Evolving Morality: From Primordial Soup to Superintelligent Machines 001
best_comment: Definitely take this course! It is basically at the end about affective altruism, but it is not in any way cult–y like what most affective altruist arguments/ communities are. It takes a realistic approach about what we can do for the world and for people and the professor is genuinely curious about how we can approach issues in the world so it feels less like a 'do this do that and you will be doing the correct thing' and more like 'lets try to understand what we can do that is good for people and its okay if you have other ideas' which I think might be the most honest approach tot teaching something like how to help the world. I loved this course and I seriously loved Joshua Greene's teaching he is the best!
worse_comment: Course material is very interesting––just be careful because grading can be very harsh, especially if you don't have a strong background in writing

best_comment: An absolute gem! Some weeks there are two assigned films, so you'll spend 2 hours outside of class watching that. This semester we only needed to attend 6 screenings and write 6 postings (out of ~13 weeks) which was very convenient for midterms/finals period. As such, attend the screenings and do the postings EARLY in the semester because they are EASIER and take LESS TIME. Analytical postings (two required) take <.5–1 hours but creative postings (i.e. video essays, making a film) take much longer (2–5 hours) but are more fun.  I highly recommend doing creative postings as well as a creative final project because you've already written plenty of academic papers and film–making is a great alternative to essays for conveying information.  Shout out to the Bok Center workshops, they are very helpful, have free food, and count towards your screenings! TAKE THIS COURSE IF YOU NEED A LIGHT CLASS BUT ALSO WANT TO LEARN SOMETHING COOL AND NEW! As a STEM concentrator, I thoroughly enjoyed this class.
best_gem_comment: One of those classes that can be a gem if you want but so inspiring to see people putting in so much love into the class! Cool array of films, lectures are excellent, Professor Li is phenomenal, and the creative assignments are so fun to make and watch! Take this class!
subject: General Education

best_comment: This course is a great way to explore race relations in America generally! The class itself is not overbearing and workload, which can make it a good environment to learn about broader topics regarding race in politics. The final project is not particularly difficult, but will require a good group so pick partners wisely to fairly divide the workload. Otherwise — great GenEd intro to politics of race with a splash of genomic science.
worse_comment: Find another GenE to take! I would NOT recommend this course! The teaching staff for a course on RACE should consist of members who have first hand experience with the issues of race (I.e not taught by a white professor and white TF). This is not to sound shallow or crude but rather a critique that I, and many other students in this course, hold about the way this class is instructed. The instructors being people who have not had to experience racial discrimination themselves but attempt to educate others on the topic is problematic and is a prime example of how the history of race in this country is not taught by those who it has affected most but rather by those in positions of power who control the narrative. Harvard, this needs to change! Also, the grading of your essays is very very weird. Even if you follow the rubric exactly, it's very unlikely that you'll receive full credit. HUGE GRADE UNCERTAINTY towards the end of the semester...like it actually gives me anxiety thinking about how I STILL DO NOT KNOW MY GRADE! This is not an "easy" course and be prepared to read and write A LOT. The teaching staff tries, but it's just NOT IT for reasons I mentioned above. Be prepared for awkward sections where no one read the readings and even more awkward one on ones when you receive a horrible essay grade! If you are knowledgable on the racial issues of America and know even basic American history regarding its racist roots, then you don't really need to take the course because you won't learn anything else! There's no emphasis on solutions to our racial disparities, and this course caused me more annoyance than anything else!
subject: General Education

best_comment: The readings are lengthy but are very good content for papers as well as for understanding the course material better

THIS CLASS IS AMAZING – PLEASE TAKE IT. Best Gen Ed I've done for sure (my last one!) The course staff is so kind and wonderful and amazing, readings are amazing, class lecture is amazing (and loved the 2 hour format), and you will be so inspired.
best_gem_comment: This class is a gem! Super easy and exposes you to a lot of beautiful poetry within the interesting theme of borders. I skimmed through the readings and showed up to lecture almost every week and it was a breeze. The assignments are very easy and fast, they took me max 1 hour each. The teaching staff isn't looking for specific interpretations of poems, so I never felt pressure to respond a certain way – any analysis goes, which takes the pressure off. If you like poetry and are looking for an easy gened, this is a fantastic choice.

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! I felt very encouraged and supported in this class the whole time. I LOVED Dr. Goldie and the TFs!! Dr. Goldis is so loving and understanding of everyone's mental and physical health. I felt so safe in the class the whole time! All objectives are very clearly outlined and easily applicable to the world! You do not have to put in much work outside of class time! Only a weekly HW that takes about an hour or two on the weekends. This class taught me how to write a policy brief (like case studies) that has prepared me for Global Health jobs in the future. I feel very confident in my ability to analyze data and find important information in conceptualizing a health problem. This is the best class I've taken because I feel like everything has prepared me for the future. I LOVED this class SO MUCH! TAKE IT!!
worse_comment: Overall, this class is very mediocre. I don't really think I gained anything from taking this class. That being said, you don't have to take any exams, so it is a pretty light workload. Going to section for this class was so annoying because it was useless. I felt like I was in first grade again based on the activities we did in section. WARNING: !!!!Attendance was taken during lecture!!!!
subject: General Education

best_comment: I was intimidated to take this class because of what I heard about the grading but really wanted to engage with this material, and I’m glad I made the decision to take it. Dr. Hyman is a great teacher and has the most possible experience in this field, and even if lectures can feel like they’re droning on for a bit, he’s always able to incorporate a view that we would not know otherwise. The section was the best part. My TF, Dr. Robbee Wedow, was so enthusiastic and engaging. A lot of his work had already been cited for the class, and he was very willing to share his knowledge and always gave the best feedback. An amazing class that makes you look and think more critically about so many mundane things around us. This fits the science or ethics requirement (you get to choose), and I definitely recommend it being one of the geneds you take.
worse_comment: Take this class if you're interested in the material! The essays make you think, and the midterm test isn't the most fun but overall there's not too much work.
subject: General Education
gened: Ethics and Civics; Science and Technology in Society

best_comment: This course is a lot of work. Mainly, there are a lot of readings, although the readings were really interesting. I think the class is interesting and informative—and, in particular, relevant—but it is a time commitment, and I think you should take it pass–fail if you are interested. I had trouble completing all the readings with my STEM schedule, so I was quite often stressed during lectures to be cold–called and section to make a meaningful contribution (attendance and discussions are graded). The Professors and Teaching Staff are knowledgeable and engaging, and I learned a lot from this course on US–China relations as it relates to the current state of affairs, but I would have taken this class pass–fail if I could go back. Also, be prepared to do a lot of public speaking in addition to a lot of reading—this course is heavily discussion–based. The assignments at the end of the course are extremely interesting and meaningful, as I learned a lot from my final essay and debate. But, the work is also concentrated at the end of the semester, so be sure to start early and budget time closer to the end of the semester if you choose to take this course. With that being said, I want to reiterate that the class is interesting, and if you're interested and have some passion or experience in politics, economics, US–China relations, and foreign policy, you should definitely take this class!

Attend the lectures whenever you can! You won't miss that much if you don't, but they are super interesting and Dimitar is a super accomplished astronomer and wonderful person. He's very approachable and makes the class engaging for all the students. Lectures are entertaining and very insightful.

The content of course (i.e. readings) a be a little dry at times, but it's a good way to satisfy the HSI requirement. Prof. McKenna is wonderful and you can tell a lot of care has gone into crafting the syllabus. Most of the activities/assignments are pretty fun, too! (e.g. museum outing, Celtic word project, Celtic artifact project, ethnonym project) I definitely learned a lot
worse_comment: It was a bunch of fun, I learned a lot, no complaints at all.

course_title: Permanent Impermanence: Why Buddhists Build Monuments 001
best_comment: There is a lot of readings so I wouldn't recommend reading through all of them page for page. You can definitely get away writing a response paper by just reading a little bit of each paper. Also, they want less of a summary of the readings and more of your opinion. I will note that they grade the response papers pretty hard (e.g. a 5/5 was said to be extremely rare and so I never got a 5/5 on any of the 13 papers the entire semester). The workload overall is not bad at all, expect when it comes to the quizzes, which you really need to study a lot for. If you're taking other classes that also have 3 midterms throughout the semester, I would rethink taking this class because it can be a lot.
worse_comment: a lot of quizzes and one of the professor is not the best teacher!! (even though it is a good course, one should not have to put this much effort in a gened)
subject: General Education
course_title_2023: Permanent Impermanence: Why Buddhists Build Monuments

course_title: Permanent Impermanence: Why Buddhists Build Monuments 001

course_title_2023: Permanent Impermanence: Why Buddhists Build Monuments

best_comment: Professor Haig is an amazing person. He is super passionate and friendly and caring about his students. This class is easy grade–wise, and you get out of it what you put into it. If youre super interested in the material AND looking to boost your GPA, definitely take this class. Interesting material, easy to get a good grade in. Very little time commitment.
worse_comment: This course could be interesting, but the semester was a bit too unstructured. The lack of readings made for a light workload, but it also made it difficult to understand what you were meant to be learning.
best_gem_comment: Awesome gem
subject: General Education

best_comment: This is a great class for anyone looking to learn more about how the world's economy works and its implications on the environment. I would particularly recommend it to anyone interested in climate policy as it provides a great understanding of what considerations are at play in current energy decisions and will allow you to build a more robust perspective of the challenges at hand.
worse_comment: This was a very insightful class. It is a tough GenEd though. You do need to score 90s on the exams to get an A, and this does require a lot of time to memorise information. It isnt tough work, it is just time consuming work

best_comment: The bi–weekly write–ups may seem like a lot, but they go pretty fast. Professor Asani is one of the sweetest and wisest professors I have had here — so much to learn from. Overall, this is a great course for deepening religious literacy (which in the US, I think we all need) and appreciating different aspects of Islamic practice and expression! I am very glad I took this course, and it sounds like in a normal year there is a dance workshop, and a trip to the MET too, so an added bonus!
worse_comment: I tried hard to like this course but I did not enjoy it going into it with hope for Islamic art & art history content. What you end up getting is theology – dense texts of religious literature and essays on ideology, which I personally hated. This course has ~120 pages of theological readings weekly (but sometimes you need to finish a whole book in a week, lol) for lectures and sections, 3 mandatory 2–hr film screenings that happen at night (or write a long essay for each as penalty), and 2 small assignments due PER WEEK. The same coursework applies for HDS 3627 (its graduate level title), so yup you're doing the graduate level work for a GENED. Also, the art perspective of Islam is kind of this class's false advertisement – lectures will touch on written arts (such as music and poetry), but never fully examines visual art. This course did demystify Islam for me, but I wish I could take half the class, because the other half is too much theology, too much readings and work for a GENED.
best_gem_comment: THIS CLASS IS THE BEST CLASS I HAVE TAKEN AT HARVARD!!!!! not the gemiest gem but the work is pretty light and is geniunely so fun. If only I could have retaken this class every semester.

course_title: The Crusades and the Making of East and West 001
best_comment: This is a good class with a lot of readings. You probably only have to do the readings that have essays (there’s only two of them). For the others you have to write a short discussion post but it’s not that bad. Sections are otherwise quite good. The lectures are interesting and the Professor is obviously very knowledgeable and super nice. You can go to his office hours and he’ll answer any questions you have and is just super nice to talk to.  Definitely consider this class!

course_title: The Border: Race, Politics, and Health in Modern Mexico 001
best_comment: This class is so much more than what seems like a niche topic about the US–Mexico border. Professor Soto Laveaga expands the course to help students better understand what borders are worldwide, how migrants face structural violence, etc. I was initially worried that this course would give me random facts, but it really enlightened me about how the world works. I liked the structure of the course and how we spent time on the history, case studies, and current issues. I was engaged throughout the course and thought Michael Ortiz–Castro's sections were excellent. The assignments are definitely not bad, but this could be because Michael Ortiz–Castro was continually a helpful section leader and generous TF. The course is slightly backloaded with work so don't be fooled! Nevertheless, this class is not too much work, and I would not be intimidated!
worse_comment: The course's material is really interesting, and important to know. But the major weakness of the course is the teaching staff.
best_gem_comment: This class is an absolute gem and its actually interesting

course_title: Pyramid Schemes: What Can Ancient Egyptian Civilization Teach Us? 001
best_comment: Enjoy the ride! It’s very enjoyable if you show up with the right attitude, but can easily become a burden if you adopt the wrong attitude (this is true for most Geneds). Whether you’re a first year taking classes for the first time or a senior that’s going to be graduating and needs a Gened class, or any other student in between, please show up ready to learn. The biggest mistake you could make in this class is just writing it off as “just another Gened” and skipping it or doing other work in class. Invest in your knowledge not for the sake of a GPA or graduation requirement, but for your own edification and development! This course is truly enriching and the field trips remind me about the history and resources we are privileged to have at Harvard. Please show up to class ready to engage with the material. If you just come in to do other work, you’re doing a disservice to yourself and your other classmates who really want to hear from you – plus you’re being super disrespectful to the professor.
worse_comment: Pros: (1) Exams are take home!!!! You still learn a lot and think about history critically without having to memorize trivial stuff. (2) The final project is very fun and light. You can write an essay, make a movie, or make a virtual museum curation about literally any topic you want related to ancient Egypt. I actually learned a lot. (3) Some cool museum field trips where you can see actual artifactsCons: (1) About ~100 pages of reading a week, although not super dense. (2) IMO the lectures and readings were extremely boring but I generally don't like history so that's my problem
best_gem_comment: Would not necessarily call this course a gem, but I still enjoyed learning about ancient Egypt; would have appreciated more support/guidance on the final project
subject: General Education
course_title_2023: Pyramid Schemes: What Can Ancient Egyptian Civilization Teach Us?

course_title: The Two Koreas in the Modern World 001
best_comment: First and foremost, if you are thinking about taking this course, you MUST have a strong interest in Korean history. This is not a class about K–pop or modern Korea, this is fundamentally a Korean history class. As with any history course, this class can be very dry at times, even for a student who is enamored by Korean history. Only a super strong love and appreciation for the class material will get you through the dry periods without hating the course and its busy–work assignments. So, if you have a strong interest in Korean history, then I cannot recommend this class enough. The course is fantastic. The readings are informative and thoughtful, the movies are good to watch, Professor Eckert is a decently good lecturer, and Sungik (the TF) was phenomenal. This class completely changed the way I understand Korean politics and Korean culture, and it changed the way I understand the history of East Asia and the legacy of that history in the region today. As a Korean–American, the class also changed the way I understand my family and the struggles my family went through during the 20th century. It was really an amazing history course. My only critique is that a lot of the assignments felt like busy work, but hopefully they cut down on this in future years.
worse_comment: Make sure to get those response papers done ASAP! Do not wait until the end to get your 6 required papers done because it'll just conflict with other course things so it's much better to get them done and over with. Also it gives out a final paper AND a final exam (which is kind of brutal and everyone disliked that a lot because you really only should assign one or the other)  so if that's going to be too much for your workload (like me with CS20 and CS51 exams/projects due the same week) then I do not recommend taking this course. Otherwise, go all out.
subject: General Education
course_title_2023: The Two Koreas in the Modern World

course_title: Classical Mythology: Myth in Antiquity and Today 001
best_comment: I walked in with minimal background in mythology (pretty much just reading Percy Jackson, and even that I didn't really remember), but the lectures and sections make the myths covered easy to understand even with no background! The course was overall really well structured and taught, and the lectures were probably some of my favorite ones at college so far. The material was super interesting, the lectures were engaging, and I got so much more out of this class than I expected. I highly recommend this course and I feel like if you go to lectures you will definitely get a lot out of it!!
worse_comment: The class is fantastic but many of the narratives in the course are centered around sexual assault. The course staff handles this well, but almost every single week one of the readings will contain deceptions of sexual violence.
best_gem_comment: This class is great and exactly as advertised — a fun, engaging way to learn about myths and learn about how to analyze mythology. It was a fun class and a good way to fulfill the Arts gened requirement. Professor Libby is a gem! Super engaging lectures, very accessible, wants her students to succeed, and full of interesting knowledge about mythology! Workload was minimal.
subject: General Education
course_title_2023: Classical Mythology: Myth in Antiquity and Today

best_comment: You should definitely consider taking this class! Painting takes a long time and requires a lot of work but it is worth it. You don't have to be an experienced artist to take it, so you can use this class to explore something new. Having access to a studio, oil paint, canvasses, and other materials is a great privilege. If you are able to spend a good amount of time painting, definitely take it.
worse_comment: It is fun but time demanding

course_title: Human Trafficking, Slavery and Abolition in the Modern World 001
best_comment: This class has no work aside from studying for the two exams and writing the final paper. I recommend it if you're looking to get an easy A, but if you're genuinely interested in learning about human trafficking, I did not feel that this year's course format was very conducive to that. The lectures from Prof. Patterson were great, but I found the sections a bit of a letdown.  While Patterson's lectures covered human trafficking related topics and incorporated philosophical questions about the nature of trafficking/how we should address it, Ben (my section leader) pretty much only discussed big picture ethical questions. As someone who took the class to learn more about human trafficking, this was disappointing, especially because Ben frequently went on tangents and seemed pretty disorganized overall (he sometimes blatantly blamed delays on exam logistics, etc. on Professor Patterson which was also odd and slightly disrespectful?). We only received section assignments 3–4 weeks in the semester (very late relative to other classes), which forced me to rearrange my work shifts.I was also in an Engaged Section. We did no actual “engaged” work with a nonprofit or human trafficking–related org until very late in the semester (mid–April) when we began working on final projects. Aside from the late start date, I really enjoyed my Engaged Section project (with HEAL Trafficking). It was led by an undergrad who was very organized (especially relative to Ben) and clear about her expectations. I wish we had had more time to work with her and HEAL. TL;DR — This class is an easy A but needs a new teaching staff, as everything outside of lectures felt very disorganized.
worse_comment: TBH don't take this course. I disliked my TF and felt the course drained me more than nourished me. It's easy during the semester, I suppose, but the combination of a final paper and final exam back to back was frustrating.
subject: General Education
gened: Ethics and Civics; Histories, Societies, Individuals
course_title_2023: Human Trafficking, Slavery and Abolition in the Modern World

best_comment: This was a really great course if you are interesting in delving into the details about what happened during the Holocaust, how we think about each of the different groups of people involved, and historical debates over what happened. Professor Madigan and Michael are both incredibly smart and knowledgeable on this topic and I really loved how they got to know everybody in the class so well. This class has a light work load besides the final paper but the readings and movies assigned are great and you should definitely spend the time reading/watching them to get the most out of the class. Overall, if you are interested in history and how we understand the Holocaust in particular I highly recommend this class.
worse_comment: Seek out guidance on your final paper, otherwise very vague

course_title: Law, Politics, and Trade Policy: Lessons from East Asia 001
best_comment: GENED 1119 is one of those GENED courses that is disguised as a general education course but in reality is very much a GOV class. The work associated with this class can be challenging for someone not familiar with political economy or international relations, so know that going in. While Christina Davis is an excellent lecturer and the TF staff did their best, the expectations for this course are higher than where they should be at for a GENED course. I very much enjoyed the course, but I did put in the time to do the reading and the like. The more time you put into this course, the better it comes out. In short, take GENED 1119 if you are interested and passionate about the topic and are willing to do the work; the course is one of the more demanding general education courses on offer.
worse_comment: The readings are extremely extremely extremely lengthy for a GenEd, and it is not clear which readings you are expected to know for section. The TF will ask questions about the readings you didn't know you were expected to read. Also, the lectures are quite dry.

best_comment: The course is a very fulfilling and rewarding course. Especially if you are interested in political and economic structures and theories, this course will introduce you to different perspectives and solutions that people have to tackle economic injustice to reach economic justice. After this course, you will definitely think differently about your circumstances and the circumstances of others. However, the writing component of the course can be fairly difficult. If you have little to no experience with writing in philosophy, I would recommend taking an introductory philosophy class first (though it is not necessary!). I would recommend reaching out to your TF for help with writing if this is a concern for you. Despite the difficulty with the writing aspect of the course, it is an amazing class and I do not regret taking it.
subject: General Education

best_comment: Overall, this class is a gem and is fun and interesting to think about. However, the readings are extremely US–focused and tend not to incorporate much diversity from POC and women, which is my only reservation about the course. Assignments are manageable, and since they walk you through the research project throughout the entire semester, it's really not that much work during finals.I thought this class was going to be interesting and we would talk about the quality of education, but ended up a being a very narrow focused discussion about academic freedom and what freedom specifically professors have in speaking out about modern social issues. This was all very abstract, and to add to it, most readings were solely from white male professors from the 1960s where the most important social issue was the Vietnam War. But most students in the course wanted to learn about today’s issues. The second half of the course gets into case studies which are super interesting (affirmative action, divestment, open admissions, etc). But I wish this part was longer.Halfway through the class, the weekly assignments on the readings are 500–700 word posts based on the readings. I never understood why we had to write so much all of a sudden, and no specific prompt was really given. I don’t see how the course staff can really spend the time to fairly grade these assignments, and from the student perspective, spend an adequate and meaningful amount of time where 500 words is necessary to make a point. I believe a 200 word response would be sufficient.
best_gem_comment: Overall, this class is a gem and is fun and interesting to think about. However, the readings are extremely US–focused and tend not to incorporate much diversity from POC and women, which is my only reservation about the course. Assignments are manageable, and since they walk you through the research project throughout the entire semester, it's really not that much work during finals.I thought this class was going to be interesting and we would talk about the quality of education, but ended up a being a very narrow focused discussion about academic freedom and what freedom specifically professors have in speaking out about modern social issues. But I wish this part was longer.Halfway through the class, the weekly assignments on the readings are 500–700 word posts based on the readings. I never understood why we had to write so much all of a sudden, and no specific prompt was really given. I don’t see how the course staff can really spend the time to fairly grade these assignments, and from the student perspective, spend an adequate and meaningful amount of time where 500 words is necessary to make a point. I believe a 200 word response would be sufficient.

best_comment: This is a great way to get either some AI or neuroscience experience in a chill way. I had not taken any neuroscience courses before and I really wanted to learn a bit of that before I graduated – in that regard the course was great! I think the same would also be true if you wanted a bit of AI exposure – I have taken a lot of very technical AI classes before and this one was able to cover like 80% of the detail in 20% of the work. The guest lectures are truly amazing – interesting topics, very engaging speakers, and some pretty famous people too! Would definitely recommend as a gened or a chill senior elective.
worse_comment: The problem sets are easy/ straight from lecture. As a neuroscience/biology person (and not a CS person), the lectures on machine learning were very hard to follow, but the content that was assessed on the problem sets and midterm was not hard.
best_gem_comment: It is a GEM, low time commitment, and has 4 psets and a project. TFs are wonderful and the professor is good. Take it
subject: General Education

best_comment: Fantastic gened and introduction to the theory and history of race and caste. Professor Subramanian is a brilliant and generous lecturer, and there were many excellent guest lecturers throughout the semester. Readings were varied and deep, and it’s just two papers (20% each) and participation (60%) which is extremely forgiving (though check the syllabus to see if this has changed in later years). Highly recommend to anyone, super relevant and interesting course.
worse_comment: this class was trash but it was still a gem tbh. most painfully boring and annoyingly pedantic gem. like yes, you'll do fine in this class but you will hate every minute of the course. the professor is not the greatest lecturer, she just talks and rambles all the time. never felt like the teaching staff was on the student's side, always just trying to make our lives more difficult. class is cheeks, but you'll get an A

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Professor Richardson is absolutely brilliant, knowledgeable, thoughtful, and dedicated. She is genuinely one of the best, if not the best, professors I have ever had, and I say that as a graduating senior. Her lectures are so eye–opening and accessible to all backgrounds, and at every lecture I was blown away by what I learned. She teaches so eloquently and clearly, and my attention was hooked at every lecture. Please take this class regardless of your background and identity, especially men–– all of the male students thoroughly enjoyed the lectures and information as well and the teaching team is so welcoming and knowledgeable. In fact, I highly recommended this class to all of my male STEM friends because the history of gender and science is very applicable to them as well. The assignments were graded very reasonably and sections were great. Taking this class was honestly the best decision of my senior spring because I got to learn so much about the history of gender and science in a very low–stress, accommodating environment. After taking this class, I now am most likely going to continue studying the social sciences in the future. PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!!
worse_comment: This class was easy, manageable, but the content itself felt outdated, white, and not very engaging.
best_gem_comment: This is a fairly easy class but only if you help yourself. You only have to complete 2 papers and they’re not too difficult but make sure to start on time because there’s a lot of finicky bits you have to include. You’ll have to attend course events which are interesting but somewhat annoying because they take up extra time outside of section and lecture. Because this course also counts for concentration credit, I thought the grading was a little harsher than that of other geneds, so keep that in mind when deciding how much effort to put into your assignments. The final project is a lot of work but the presentation fair makes it all seem worth, super cool to see what everyone comes up with! All around great class to take, especially if you’re a woman concentrating in STEM, but be prepared to do a bit more work than in a gem. Again, this class isn’t that hard, I’m just lazy and so are most people

course_title: The Conduct of Life in Western and Eastern Philosophy 001
best_comment: Really loved this class. Format was a weekly two hour class, where Unger/Puett talked for 60–90min with the rest for Q&A/discussion, along with a weekly section. I loved the more modern take on religion and philosophy, thinking less about God or trolley problems and more about actual philosophy I'd consider meaningful or interesting today.  The readings and classes partly focused on what today's versions of Christianity, Buddhism, Schopenhauer, Emerson, Nietzsche, Confucianism, and Hegel look like, if you take what was truly radical about them in their time (for example, Christianity's love + anti–hierarchy) and try to revise and apply them today. But those were a backdrop to the most interesting part of this class which was trying to synthesize all of these together into two branches of philosophy – "revised self–fashioning" and "maximal connection", as two ways one could approach the conduct of life, and also how they combine into one interesting approach to politics. I don't think the philosophy Unger proposed by the end of the class was completely right, but I think the approach getting there will really stick with me, making it much easier for me to think hard about what matters in life and how I should approach it going forward. I loved the sections although they could be a bit quiet at times, though that changed by the end of the semester as the focus shifted from discussing specific readings to thinking about various problems in life and how we might approach them.
worse_comment: Beware who the TF is. Definitely interesting sometimes, and I learned vocabulary such as "to reconcile life" and "come into the possession of life" from Unger's textbook–esque speeches, but the grading in this class, three papers with odd prompts, was not fun.

best_comment: Not quite a total gem but pretty easy.  It's essentially no work every week (there are readings but it's like any other gened).  If you study hard for the exams it's definitely possible to learn everything the night before after taking no notes all semester. If you're interested in consent definitely take the course.  If you're thinking about it, look at the syllabus and course readings and if they seem interesting, take the course.
best_gem_comment: Not quite a total gem but pretty easy.  It's essentially no work every week (there are readings but it's like any other gened).  If you study hard for the exams it's definitely possible to learn everything the night before after taking no notes all semester. If you're interested in consent definitely take the course.  If you're thinking about it, look at the syllabus and course readings and if they seem interesting, take the course.

best_comment: This class has the potential to be incredibly interesting, but in reality is a bit of a let down. The workload is very manageable; there's not a ton of reading (and in my opinion it's all very fascinating  and you don't have to read every single page) and the assignments are pretty quick and short. However, it did not have the best flow (we jumped around a lot) and if you have a solid background in history and current events, you probably will not actually learn that much new information. There was nothing about this course that was objectively "bad", and there were a lot of good parts (i.e. great guest speakers, visiting the map room, a pretty "gem–y" workload), but if you're looking for a super enlightening course about borders and deep, intellectual discussion, this class––at least in my opinion––is just not it.
worse_comment: This is not a great class because it doesn't teach the material in an organized manner.
best_gem_comment: This class has the potential to be incredibly interesting, but in reality is a bit of a let down. The workload is very manageable; there's not a ton of reading (and in my opinion it's all very fascinating  and you don't have to read every single page) and the assignments are pretty quick and short. However, it did not have the best flow (we jumped around a lot) and if you have a solid background in history and current events, you probably will not actually learn that much new information. There was nothing about this course that was objectively "bad", and there were a lot of good parts (i.e. great guest speakers, visiting the map room, a pretty "gem–y" workload), but if you're looking for a super enlightening course about borders and deep, intellectual discussion, this class––at least in my opinion––is just not it.

best_comment: Definitely take this class! It's a great supplement to any ESPP classes and if you are interested in "dipping your toes" in the environment/climate change world, this is a great stepping stone.
worse_comment: Gem. no questions asked. if you are not into stem and need your stem gened take this class
best_gem_comment: This GenEd is great. Kaighin is a really kind person and knows so much about the water cycle. The class is relatively easy compared to other GenEds, and only has a few assignments plus a discussion post.
