There is a section component, but you don't do a ton of new stuff there, you only review topics. The midterm is fairly simple, and there is no final. It's not a pure "gem" since there is lots of work in the second half of the semester, but it is far better than any other GenEd I've taken here.

best_comment: American Capitalism is an okay Gen Ed. It's easy, but I didn't find it to be the most engaging or stimulating class. I definitely had a lot of high expectations coming into the course after reading some of the previous Q Guides (and given the topic of the course itself), but often left feeling like there was no overarching framework or structure to the course. I personally felt like a lot of the readings weren't the most valuable, and many of the section discussions, which were occasionally interesting, lacked structure. There is a good amount to like about the course, but there is still quite a bit of room for improvement.

THIS IS A REALLY COOL CLASS! Dan and the TF's are great, it's so clear that they care about the students as people, and the material is presented in such an engaging way that even if it's something you never thought you were capable of caring about, you'll find yourself engrossed before long. The best way to experience this class is to let yourself be fascinated by every little thing and just enjoy the ride. He literally said in class that he didn't give a final because he wanted us to come away from this class having learned different things, things we care about, and every project has tons of freedom to let you pursue your own interests. I recommend it wholeheartedly.
worse_comment: Approach this class with caution. If you're looking for an easy gened, this isn't it. I did more work for this class that I did for basically any other class this semester, which is saying something. There is an incredible amount of busywork, and your grade will quickly nosedive if you don't do a single reading or slack on an assignment. The grading system they use is fairly unforgiving –– if you are not actively participating every lecture, your grade will suffer. If you do not go above and beyond on every single assignment, your grade will suffer. Feedback can be vague and once you implement said feedback, it won't actually improve the grade on your final output unless you're willing to put in thesis–levels of research into your projects because that is what they ask of you.The class often felt jumpy and disorganized. You'll be told that this is on purpose, and if you're confused then the super secret teaching method is actually working, but it can often feel frustrating. If you're looking for a linear progression though the middle ages touching on various topics of the middle ages, this class is not for you. If you're looking for a gem, this class is not for you.

course_title: If There Is No God, All Is Permitted: Theism and Moral Reasoning 001
best_comment: Would highly recommend if you're looking for a gened that actually has some substance and doesn't just leave you with "this problem is important!" yet also allows you to deprioritize it when more pressing academic commitments get in the way.This class could change your life if you give it the time to do so. But more likely this class will give you interesting readings to gloss over portions of when you're in the mood, good opportunities to dive into one or two thinkers you find particularly interesting with the papers. You can generally leave feeling like you were able to extract as much meaning/purpose from the class as you had the time for. The structure of the course and its grading is forgiving enough to make that possible, lectures are a really good opportunity to get a broad overview of the work and its most popular academic interpretation as well as answer some of your questions, and sections let you think about how to square the text at hand with your own/others' moral frameworks.
best_gem_comment: This class is superb!!  I recommend with great enthusiasm.  Professor Harris is funny, engaging, and deeply thoughtful, as he leads exploration of complex moral thinkers and questions.  Be warned that the reading load is rather heavy for a Gened, so do not take this class if you want a throwaway gem; DO take this class if you want to make genuine use of your time at Harvard to learn and grow as a human being engaging with the real questions.  You will not find a better class in which to do that.  As someone who has spent most of my time taking highly technical classes in my concentration, this was the first time I really realized what liberal education was supposed to be.

best_comment: I highly recommend this course. One of the best courses I've taken. Prof. McLaughlin is an excellent professor. She gives excellent lectures and has very good organization. Section was also very good. Stress was a problem for me at Harvard, so I am grateful to have new perspectives and tools that will increase my happiness and health.
worse_comment: Aside from the papers, this class is incredibly chill and teaches you a lot about the stress response and how to manage your stress, which is incredibly difficult to do as a college student
best_gem_comment: Definitely recommend. Professor McLaughlin is very understanding and knows how stressful Harvard can be. The assignments are relatively easy and pretty fun to complete. Would definitely consider this class a gem
subject: General Education

best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!!! it has a very doable workload with really nice grading, the lectures are FANTASTIC and the class community is really nice. i really liked my section and found that it was a great way to explore the texts more deeply. there are field trips, guest speakers, movies, and very interesting and short reading each week. it's a gem of a class!
worse_comment: This is a great introduction to Ancient Greek Tragedy and a good demonstration of why it is still important to study Greek tragedy!

best_comment: Discourse is definitely worth taking it for your STSGEN Ed requirement. Not only is the teaching staff over qualified and incredibly engaging, but the course has a clear goal of making the students critical thinkers without getting them and necessary busywork. The assignments are genuinely thought–provoking and oftentimes enjoyable. The final project receives so much support from the staff that so long as you choose a topic you’re  interested in (they’re flexible as long as it’s applicable to the course) — you will probably honestly enjoy it! Def recommend.

Discourse is definitely worth taking it for your STSGEN Ed requirement. Not only is the teaching staff over qualified and incredibly engaging, but the course has a clear goal of making the students critical thinkers without getting them and necessary busywork. The assignments are genuinely thought–provoking and oftentimes enjoyable. The final project receives so much support from the staff that so long as you choose a topic you’re  interested in (they’re flexible as long as it’s applicable to the course) — you will probably honestly enjoy it! Def recommend.

If you are queer, DEFINITELY consider this class. As someone who is STEM, I was cautious with deciding whether or not to enroll in this, but I loved it. The texts are insightful and include a variety of gay, bisexual, lesbian, and transgender experiences. There should be more inclusivity of other identities (asexual, intersex, etc.).Many assignments are based on completion and contribute a large portion to your grade, which is very relieving. Make sure to take advantage of office hours to review papers and drafts.Start reading ASAP because it is easy for one to fall behind.Lectures are a MUST, especially for the first half of the class. The midterm covers specific texts, and the analysis is all provided during lectures. If you take notes during lecture, read (or at least skim) the text, and write it all down in the midterm, you have a guaranteed A.For the second half, you are more flexible with what you can do. Instead of doing a second analysis paper, you can do a creative project, like a memoir, reflection personal essay, short story, etc. and I highly recommend. It is a great chance to talk about your own queer experience and connect it to certain texts.One thing I noticed about the class (though it is not necessarily related to the content but more to the demographics) is that there was a plurality of white students. It is definitely something to consider, but the texts read are also from Black, Latinx, and Asian authors, which is extremely important to include!
worse_comment: The readings are interesting but will take a long time to do. If you are a STEM person, you might struggle with the midterm and final papers – the guidelines are vague and although the course staff said they don't expect everyone to be familiar with close reading analyses, they don't really explain how to do it or give any examples of past papers.
best_gem_comment: Take this class! It is such a gem; you read incredible books, the workload is super manageable, and Professor Schlossberg is a really interesting and knowledgeable lecturer. Truthfully this often didn't even feel like class it was so enjoyable.

best_comment: This course was good! I learned so much about mental health and psychotherapy as a clinical practice and socio–culturally influenced entity. Professor Lunbeck is very passionate about her work and this course, and the head TF Chris was so kind and helpful. He was flexible with office hours and provided very useful insights for assignments and confusing course materials. Some weeks, the readings are pretty heavy, but truthfully you can survive just skimming the sources. Just make sure to write the precis papers on time and contribute during section! The papers/writing assignments aren't too bad either, but I felt like they were a bit long (7–10 pgs) considering this is a GENED. Definitely think the page limit could've been shorter but alas. Just communicate with your TF and get started early on so you don't procrastinate writing. Overall, a good course that I really enjoyed! I recommend!
worse_comment: Only take this class if you have an interest in psychology/psychotherapy. I found it to be a bit boring and repetitive at times.
best_gem_comment: < GEM ALERT >I really enjoyed this class! I thought it was super useful as an introduction into psychotherapy (and for me, generally an introduction into psychology as well). Definitely want to take more histsci or psych classes.Didn't require too much work and I would definitely consider a gem.
subject: General Education

best_comment: A great class, would highly recommend – your grammar will certainly improve, as will your reading and translating ability!
worse_comment: German 61 is a difficult class if you don't have a very strong foundation in German grammar. I think it's a class that works well for people who have been studying German in school for many years but is a more difficult class for someone who learned german by living abroad or primarily by speaking. The exams are quite difficult and I found there wasn't too much explanation of techniques for some of the exercises that repeatedly come up in HW/Exams. Definitely don't take this course lightly.

best_comment: This course is so much fun! It's a unique chance to be involved in a play in German, even if you don't consider yourself an actor. You'll learn about German theatrical traditions while stepping outside your comfort zone with scene work and theater warm–up games. Professor Parkes is great at improving scenes while keeping everyone comfortable. Highly recommend!

course_title: Bargaining with the Devil: the Faust Legend 1
best_comment: This is one of the rare occasions where I enjoyed the course much more than I can express in words. The readings themselves were rich with wisdom and creativity. They were often the lifework of the authors and it's evident that the magnitude of each work goes beyond much of the literature we as students normally read. Each literary work and the connections to one another gave me a much more profound understanding of the world and especially of German culture. I did not expect to learn so much about music theory, religion, etymology, and history but it was a welcomed addition that always elevated our understanding of the texts. Before taking the course, I was only somewhat familiar with the Faust legend. I did not realize how deeply this legend is tied to German identity. It explains Germany's historical journey, and we specifically focus on its connection to WWI and WWII. Moreover, the Faust legend captures something so innately close to our humanity that the questions raised and the works based on it illuminate much about ourselves, our purpose, and how to make sense of humanity's trajectory. I have always loved literature, but this course took it to another level. I felt so transformed by this course and it left me thinking, this is one of those courses you dream of taking. This is a class is the epitome of what makes Harvard an untouchable academic experience. Professor Hamilton is an amazing lecturer –– very humble too –– who can keep you captivated for the two hours we meet each week. Every lecture is like an intricate story that ties together knowledge from all disciplines to explain and analyze the text at a foundational level. It's beautiful to see how literature and the decisions made by the authors evolve from one culture to another, across time periods. I still remember our first class, when Professor Hamilton began by explaining the difference between literature and philosophy. Literature is for you to interpret. It doesn't retain a concrete meaning. It is meant to evolve, and it will connect to each individual uniquely. I have taken philosophy classes before and he is exactly correct. This class embodies an openness to ideas, no matter how unusual or unpopular. Unlike philosophy, literature doesn't have rules nor does it tell you how you should think. The joy and curiosity I thought I would find in philosophy, I actually found in literature.  With every essay, you can feel free to write wherever your connection to the literature takes you and Professor Hamilton is always supportive and encouraging of your interpretations. Sometimes, it felt intimidating to have to write essays after hearing Professor Hamilton's lectures which expertly made connections you can only make with his breadth of knowledge and after spending years ruminating on the literature. I truly was in awe after every class because his revelations about the text and about themes would be things I've never heard or even considered before. Oftentimes, perspectives and interpretations on common motifs are repeated so you hear them in one class and then another. This was completely different, like studying literature for the first time again.Having said this, please view the lectures as an incredible educational experience that should only inspire you to reach to produce your best work in the course. I would encourage you to challenge yourself in finding new connections, still, or ones that weren't touched on much in class. It's not easy, but it will be rewarding when you prove to yourself that there is no ceiling to literature. No matter how much you think you have learned and understand, there's always more to discover. Interestingly, the course structure doesn't appear to be heavy on workload or reading, but the beauty of only assigning work that is necessary is that we have the time to discuss and reflect, reread and do our own research. I spent considerable time outside of class thinking, talking about what I read, and over time that relationship with the text allowed me to make the most of each essay I eventually wrote. The course also isn't a writing course –– it's not meant to nitpick on writing skill/style –– but I felt a natural progression in improving my writing style because the material we wrote about has such gravity to it. I'm left with a greater sense of awareness of who we are and why we do what we do in addition to a deeper connection to humanity of the past and present. This course ultimately made me decide to continue studying literature at Harvard and the lectures and readings are things I will be thinking about, fondly, for years to come. No matter what your background is, if you are curious about humanity, its relationship to nature, and the ever–present balances in life –– if you are willing to dedicate yourself to the readings with care and attention –– I recommend this course with the greatest enthusiasm.
worse_comment: Take this course. Total Gem––engaging and low work.

course_title: German Philhellenism: From Winckelmann to Heidegger 1
best_comment: Take this course. The content is absolutely fascinating, and the professor is incredibly insightful on all things Greek and German. He truly understands the texts with such deep passion that you will also feel that same passion and wisdom.

course_title: Scandinavian Folklore: Trolls, Trolldom and the Uses of Tradition 1
best_comment: I would say to take it! My biggest advice is to just have fun. If you keep in mind how fun it is that we are talking about trolls, culture, witchcraft, spirits, spells, and stories that range thousands of years, you'll feel fortunate that you get to dedicate a semester to this topic with one of the leading experts in the field. I felt so incredibly lucky for this experience. Mindset is important, because you could easily become stressed and overwhelmed if you try to intensely and perfectly keep track of names, places, unfamiliar language, and belief systems.  That being said, take it seriously as Steve expects you to be fully prepared and to work through the materials making connections and thoughtfully exploring them with purpose.  Take risks, make mistakes, and open yourself for seeing things in new ways.
Agnes is a fantastic professor!
subject: Swedish

course_title: The Quality of Health Care in America 001
best_comment: ABSOLUTELY LOVED IT! Please take it if you can! The Professor is phenomenal––super understanding and kind and passionate about what he teaches. This course provides a diversity of perspectives on issues around public health/medicine, and I think that's truly rare and valuable. It allowed me to step out of a kind of echo chamber on issues related to public health, which intersects heavily with politics and thus is a topic on which you might easily find yourself stuck in an echo chamber. Professor Jena himself is also a great public orator, so besides the course materials, public speaking skills are something that I tried to pay attention to/learn. If you are lucky enough to get the lottery, don't feel shy to ask questions during the speaker events. I kind of regret not doing that enough... TFs (Bijan and Annabel) were fabulous. Both are super understanding and always available to support you when you are in need of help. This course comes with my highest recommendation :)!
best_gem_comment: Please take this course!!!! It was incredible; the speakers were amazing, Bapu is an incredible lecturer, and the topics we covered in the class are so genuinely interesting (overview of Medicare/Medicaid, payment systems for physicians, malpractice, specialization, etc). I think this is a wonderful class to take if you're even remotely interested public health, because you get a broad sense of it, especially in America. Also, the assignments and exams are super doable; this was definitely a gem!!
subject: Global Health & Health Policy
course_title_2023: The Quality of Health Care in America

course_title: Global Response to Disasters and Refugee Crises 001
best_comment: Best class I've taken at Harvard. You come away from this class much more open–minded about the messiness of humanitarian situations, and also the importance of crisis response––in everything from disaster evaluation and risk assessment to coupling interventions with longer–term development and facilitating collaboration across sectors. This class pushes you to think like a problem–solver and a leader, and throughout offers opportunities for teamwork, feedback, speaking, and learning generally.  Profs. Kayden and VanRooyen will be among the most eloquent and engaging lecturers you'll ever encounter, and the course material and case studies are very informative and thoughtfully compiled. Sections offer opportunities for interactive discussion and review, and the group assignments truly encourage you to collaborate with your team and learn from each other. You emerge from this class more thoughtful, compassionate, and humbled. A wonderful class; could not recommend it highly enough.
subject: Global Health & Health Policy
course_title_2023: Global Response to Disasters and Refugee Crises

course_title: Global Response to Disasters and Refugee Crises 001
best_comment: Best class I've taken at Harvard. You come away from this class much more open–minded about the messiness of humanitarian situations, and also the importance of crisis response––in everything from disaster evaluation and risk assessment to coupling interventions with longer–term development and facilitating collaboration across sectors. This class pushes you to think like a problem–solver and a leader, and throughout offers opportunities for teamwork, feedback, speaking, and learning generally.  Profs. Kayden and VanRooyen will be among the most eloquent and engaging lecturers you'll ever encounter, and the course material and case studies are very informative and thoughtfully compiled. Sections offer opportunities for interactive discussion and review, and the group assignments truly encourage you to collaborate with your team and learn from each other. You emerge from this class more thoughtful, compassionate, and humbled. A wonderful class; could not recommend it highly enough.
subject: Global Health & Health Policy
course_title_2023: Global Response to Disasters and Refugee Crises

course_title: Research in Global Health and Health Policy 001
best_comment: I think that this course is a really worthwhile space to potentially research and write a piece of work you can be super super proud of. I think that it's really cool that the finished product of this class is a real world policy recommendation based ostensibly off of the best and most recent research on a subject area. I wish that I had been better able to take advantage of this class's framework for putting together a body of work like that.
worse_comment: It's a lot of work in the beginning to brainstorm and craft your proposal. Waiting until the last minute makes things chaotic.
subject: Global Health & Health Policy
course_title_2023: Research in Global Health and Health Policy

course_title: Research in Global Health and Health Policy 002
best_comment: If you're reading this, it's likely because this course is a requirement for you and you probably don't have a choice. This course is good in that it gives you freedom to explore a topic of interest to you, and if you want to you'll learn a lot. However, the weekly section discussions were a complete waste of time (useless topics like, "how do you give a presentation?", "how do you cite?", etc.) which were obviously covered in high school / first year of college.
subject: Global Health & Health Policy
course_title_2023: Research in Global Health and Health Policy

best_comment: GOV 10 is a strong introduction to political theory. If you enjoy considering the moral questions behind different forms of government and different governmental policy decisions, you will probably appreciate this class. It provides a strong overview of class political theory while also pairing those texts with more modern and practical interpretations. Of note, however, is that the reading load if fairly heavy for an intro class, though the foundational texts that make up the bulk of the reading are all fairly well–known and summaries can be found if you're running short on time.Professor Beerbohm is an excellent professor and a wonderful human, and I would absolutely recommending going to his office hours and getting to know him if you can. The TFs were also very solid when I took the class, and I thought the sections were engaging (though they're bolstered if you have classmates also willing to engage with the material).If you are already familiar with political theory, you will probably find this class straightforward; the reading and writing expectations are not meaningfully different from other classes in the field. That being said, the class is still worthwhile for those experienced with political theory for two reasons: 1) You get to engage with Professor Beerbohm, who is fantastic and has done really interesting work on applied political theory; and 2) The course provides a strong overview of many of the most important thinkers and can help fill in some gaps in your knowledge if you've previously taken more specialized political theory classes.
subject: Government

best_comment: Take this class if you are interest in gov/econ!! This was a really fun and interesting course. Professor Chaudoin was super enthusiastic and energetic. He made class really fun and interactive. Honestly, the course was not very demanding. Prof Chaudoin made lectures really easy to understand and section was basically practising the concept and applying more real–world examples to them. This was a very insightful and interesting class. Highly recommend!
worse_comment: If you really don't care about IR and have the patience to spend 75 minutes twice a week browsing the web, take this course. It felt absolutely useless and dreadfully boring. Even reddit couldn't make the lectures bearable. On the plus side, grading is pretty lenient and section can be good depending on the TF. Andi Zhou was absolutely phenomenal.
best_gem_comment: Do not come into this class expecting it to be a gem! You can do well, but it definitely requires a thorough understanding of the course concepts and attention to detail when completing the assignments. The ICAs are also very important to complete, as missing even one can affect your overall grade more than you might think.
subject: Government

best_comment: This course is a mixed bag, but I think it's really useful to take it. On the one hand, you learn a LOT of R. It's a fast, structured progression that will allow you to cover many concepts in coding and statistics within a short amount of time. I think you'll be surprised by how fast you're learning. On the other hand, the PSETs were often pretty confusing, and many of the solutions required outside code/knowledge that no beginner could reasonably come up with on their own without help. A lot of times I didn't feel like the material covered matched the assignment (the probability unit was notorious for this). I would recommend creating a PSET group and going to office hours EVERY week. That will be your best way to survive Gov 50, but when you complete it all you will be impressed with your journey.
worse_comment: Take this course if you want a glimpse of how social science research works. This course is very practical in terms of learning how to navigate R, visualize data trends, compute statistical tests, and run some cool simulations using real–world data. Many of the problem sets were built around replicating the results of actual social science papers, so you get to put yourselves in the shoes of actual social scientists. You do have to put in a bit of work for this class, especially towards the end of the semester. But overall, I found this course to be relatively enjoyable (even though I don't like politics and found out over the course of the semester that I don't like the government department). Also, take my advice with a grain of salt, because your curriculum might be entirely different from mine. This class went through a lot of changes recently; the former long–time professor who taught this course had a history of saying racist stuff, so he was fired and there's been a revolving door of visiting professors who have all brought their own unique approach to teaching this class since then.

best_comment: This is a great class that will teach you a lot and be valuable for you future endeavors. The class is very manageable and has great support from the instructor and the TF. I would definitely take this class if you were considering it!
worse_comment: If you're taking data science within the gov department, I'd try to avoid this class unless there is nothing else to fulfill your requirements. Lectures were more effective than melatonin, and much of what was covered doesn't end up ever being tested on problem sets or exams. I didn't end up learning much more than I did in Gov 50, so other data science electives are probably more worth your time.
subject: Government

best_comment: I would take this class if you care about really learning how to use data science in a concrete useful way that doesn't waste anyone's time with busywork and problem sets. Andrew is a great professor who is truly kind, caring, helpful, and encouraging.

If you are considering writing a thesis, you MUST take this class. It is a great course with a very engaged teaching staff that has endless knowledge to pass on about your projects. At times, this class can be stressful but all the work that you're doing is working towards your own thesis project so it feels meaningful. I cannot imagine going into my senior thesis without having the experience of this class. They break down the process for you and make an extremely stressful and elusive thing, like a thesis, more understandable and possible. Professor Hagopian is a sweetheart and tries to get to know and help all her students with their individual topics. She is available to talk to you and can point you in the direction of more information. If you are lucky enough to get Aaron as a tf, you will have a great support system throughout the semester. He is also incredibly helpful and made the class a great time.
worse_comment: If you don’t already know what you want to write your thesis on, DO NOT take this class. All the assignments are precluded on you having so much figured out already even though you’re only a first or second semester junior. Additionally, you really only learn about how to write a thesis, not about qualitative methods in general. Was really disappointed with the class overall
subject: Government
course_title_2023: Research Design, Qualitative, and Mixed Methods

course_title: Topics and Resources in Political Theory 001
best_comment: GOV 63 is a great, small–sized, engaging seminar that anyone interested in writing a theory/philosophy/social studies thesis should take. You get a broad overview of modern political theory and the relevant debates, and the conversations and readings are quite lively and engaging. Rosen is a wonderful teacher and one of the best at Harvard. A marvelous course – highly recommend it.
worse_comment: Even if you're not sure about your thesis topic or whether your government thesis will be on political theory, this is a class worth taking.
subject: Government
course_title_2023: Topics and Resources in Political Theory

best_comment: This class is one of the best ones here. Dr. Dillon is a brilliant professor that really facilitates conversations, while your peers and course materials will challenge your views and encourage you to think outside of the box. You will really feel like you learned something at the end of the semester, not just like you survived a bunch of readings. I highly recommend this class, the work is very worth it.

course_title: The Governance and International Politics of World Regions 001
best_comment: This class is incredibly interesting and a great way to learn about different regions. The readings are definitely long and can be a little dense, but you will learn a lot if you do them and participate in class. Definitely not a gem, but a worthwhile class to take, especially if you're a gov student interested in learning about different regions. Prof Colton is great: incredibly knowledgable and thoughtful.
Jill is an amazing instructor, and she is so extremely helpful. I wish I could have attended office hours to chat with her, so definitely take advantage of those if you are able!
subject: Government

best_comment: Great class if you like to discuss and think deeply about issues of rights, tradeoffs, law, and design of government and legal systems. Really good stuff, Gabe makes it worth soldiering through some dense readings that are really interesting once you understand them
worse_comment: Gabe isn't an easy grader and you should expect to do work for this class. However, if you take it seriously, you will do well and learn a ton. For anyone considering law school, this is an essential class.
subject: Government

course_title: The Political Science of American Democracy 001
best_comment: This course provided a great exploration of the Federalist Papers and Democracy in America. I would highly recommend this course if you're interested in those texts.
worse_comment: Needless to say, Professor Mansfield is an expert on political philosophy, and particularly on Tocqueville's Democracy in America, which he translated. This is an experience that you can only get at Harvard, so if you have the opportunity, definitely lottery for the class. The readings can be quite long and abstract, but class consists mainly of lecture, during which most (if not all) of the key concepts and arguments will be explained.

course_title: Sino-US Relations in an Era of Rising Chinese Power 001
best_comment: This class is an excellent Gov 94. Professor Johnston was great to learn from — he was super knowledgeable, flexible with assignments, and clearly cared about our learning and development as scholars. The course topics were broad and engaging, and after taking the class, I felt I had a deeper understand of each sides motivations and historical perspectives on the issues that animate the relationship. I also appreciated the fact that the course was a bit more structured than the typical GOV 94; Professor Johnston had slides for each class and made an effort to ensure that we got a representative overview of the topic (unlike some Gov 94s where you only learn about what the loudest voices want to focus on) while still facilitating robust participation in the class.  Professor Johnston's connections also allowed him to bring in some really interesting guests that deepened the learning opportunities.The course assignments were fairly short and all built up to the final paper. This course was an excellent research practice course in addition to the obvious focus on U.S–China relations; I felt like I was a better researcher after taking the class. Though such a long final paper can feel intimidating, Professor Johnston gives a research design assignment due in April that forces you to do significant work on the paper before reading period and finals, and he's always willing to help students along the way.

course_title: Propaganda and Politics: Past and Present 001
best_comment: Definitely take this class. Professor Soroka is truly one of the best in the game. He's an expert lecturer and is super engaging, and he also understands student need. He does a great job making the content interesting and teaching you how to think, not what to think. Exceptional class and teacher.

This class was truly the "what is money and why does it matter" class that Harvard was missing. Professor Krampf was great, but any instructor equally passionate about the topic and equally willing to break down tough finance concepts for students would make this course a big win. I honestly can't imagine having gone through college without taking a course like this: it was truly a great academic experience. The work load was manageable and the style of the final project made it much more fun than most research papers as long as you follow the guidelines closely, really try to ask for and understand the Professor's feedback, and do everything EARLY rather than later.

course_title: Capital, Ideas, and Development in Latin America 001
best_comment: This class is a lot of reading, and the essays will be hard to write and take a while, but it is very rewarding if you put in the work

Professor Skocpol is an icon. Incredibly knowledgeable, gives great feedback on final project deliverables, and invited us over for the last class to have dinner at her house. This class is pretty readings heavy (ranging from 80 to 200 pages of reading in a week), but they're really interesting readings, and I do recommend making the time to actually go through them properly rather than just skimming (though you can likely get away with skimming). I feel so much more informed about American inequality/polarization than before. You have to write four memos throughout the class, but it's nice because the first two memos are front loaded, and that you can choose the weeks in which you write the last two memos. Overall great vibes, strongly recommend this course!

course_title: EJ Safra Undergraduate Ethics Fellowship Seminar 001
best_comment: Take this class if you're the kind of person who likes staying up until 2am talking with friends in the dhall about moral dilemmas. This class is incredibly interesting but you'll only find it engaging if you're interested in ethics. If you aren't interested in ethics, then you'll not enjoy the readings / class discussions. Arthur is one of the smartest human beings on campus – soak in his wisdom. The class is demanding but you won't have to worry about your grade – you should just try to learn as much as possible because this is such a unique opportunity. Try to do as much of the readings as possible, but there will be some weeks where you'll only have the chance to do 1 reading and skim the others (and that'll be okay because Arthur is pretty understanding).
subject: Government
course_title_2023: EJ Safra Undergraduate Ethics Fellowship Seminar

course_title: A Dream Deferred: The politics, promises, and pitfalls of American Education 001
best_comment: This class was fantastic! Sarah guided a lot of really interesting discussions about American education and its endless complexities. She also did a wonderful job of building a community among the students; I felt super comfortable with the group by the end of the semester. Sarah is also so helpful in guiding your development as a student as a writer; she gives great feedback and is super accessible!

By all means take the class! You will learn a great deal, not just about countries you're familiar with but also about a range of others. Inequality and the politics behind it are both very rich areas, and Prof. Remington does a great job at guiding students into them.
subject: Government

best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE. You should definitely have at least some interest in the topic of course, but Sparsha is hands down the best professor I've met at Harvard. She knows her stuff and really REALLY cares about her students. The readings are interesting and well–curated, the assignments make you think but aren't too hard/time–consuming compared to some other courses, and the people are really lovely.

TAKE THIS CLASS. I cannot speak more highly of Professor Ayee. She is nice, enthusiastic, supportive, super knowledgable about the content. The readings are long, but honestly as long as you get the gist of them, you can participate in class. This was my favorite class of the semester, please take it.

This is a great seminar.  Professor Wang is awesome and always leads a very interesting discussion.  His expertise is impressive but he is still super approachable which is really nice.  The readings are really interesting and not overly dense or long.

This is a really strong option for a GOV 94. Professor Ziblatt is great; he's very knowledgeable about a wide range of democracies (especially in Europe, his focus area) and makes a really effort to get to know students. The course approaches democracy from  many different perspectives; there are weeks focusing on political theory approaches, comparative approaches, and different case studies of democratic challenges pulled from different (though mostly European) locations going all the way back to the beginnings of modern democracy. The final paper is pretty standard for a GOV94, and Professor Ziblatt works with each student (including multiple meetings in office hours) to craft a project that is achievable during the semester and aligned with her interests. He also used scaffolding assignments to ensure we all were making progress well before finals period. Finally, a cool feature of this class was the research presentations at the end, where you got to present your research to your classmates and hear about what everyone else was working on for their final paper. All in all, I would definitely recommend.

This class is required for Gov so you kind of just have to take it, but I recommend Technocracy in China. It's a good class with a great preceptor. Honestly, the saving grace of my section was Josh Freedman. He's a wonderful teacher and person and made the long and dull papers worth reading, at least just a bit.
worse_comment: kinda a crap shoot given that the entire course is one essay but more a product of the gov 97 structure than any individual section
subject: Government

best_comment: Take this class. Don't think twice. It is challenging enough to make you think and question the world around you but its objective is to make you learn, not suffer trying to keep up. I genuinely left the final happy because I had fun taking the test, as crazy as this seems. Peter is an amazing professor and all should try their best to get to know him.
best_gem_comment: GEM of a class, very little work, a lot of interesting topics
subject: Government

best_comment: If you have a background in ArcGIS and know a bit of programming, take this class. It's very low–stress, but very informative. There's a perfect balance between hand–holding and self–exploration (digging through APIs and the ESRI forums). And Jill is an incredible teacher – very patient, funny, and a strong communicator.
subject: Government

course_title: Abraham Lincoln: The Statesman in Thought and Action 001
best_comment: If you have the opportunity to take this class, you absolutely should, regardless of concentration. It is quite accessible, requiring fairly small amounts of reading per class, yet helps explore the best of American democratic thought from its greatest statesman. Professor Schaub is truly an expert in his thought and work, and does a great job encouraging and directing discussion in class.

course_title: The History of Modern Political Philosophy 001
best_comment: The GOV1060 &1061 series is one of the most valuable Harvard offerings. This course is comprehensive and holds its enrollees to high expectations. Take advantage of this opportunity to truly learn the foundations of political philosophy, read great works, and engage in strong discussion sections. I would encourage anyone with an interest in politics and philosophy to take this course!
worse_comment: This text might have made me a philosophy concentrator. This was the last year Mansfield taught this course. That's a shame. But even when he doesn't, I think it's a phenomenal introduction to political thought. It is rigorous, consuming, and thought–provoking: the sort of course you come to Harvard to take.
subject: Government
course_title_2023: The History of Modern Political Philosophy

best_comment: Professor Unger is an extremely knowledgeable person and you have a lot to learn from his class. That said, you should be prepared to spend a few hours per week grappling with texts, and I would recommend going to every class so you can ask questions when necessary (this is a class where you really have to pay attention – if I tried to multitask I got behind). You have to be ready for a relatively impersonal and strict learning experience, but there’s a lot to gain if you engage with the content thoroughly.
subject: Government

best_comment: Definitely take this class! Professor Nelson is an amazing lecturer– the syllabus for this class is great and you will learn a lot about Judaism.
Professor Iversen is great, super knowledgeable and a great teacher. This class was really interesting and changed the way I think about government and institutions!

I HIGHLY recommend this course! It is rooted in fascinating historical cases, so I never felt bored or bogged down by abstract political theories. The readings are interesting, the work load is manageable, and lectures are very straightforward. Professor Ziblatt is an exciting lecturer who spreads enthusiasm for the topic, evident in the eagerness of people to bombard him with questions at the end of class.

course_title: Identities, State Building, and Political Change in Eurasia (with a focus on Caucasia) 001
best_comment: If you are interested in the region, want to travel/work there, or want to learn more about post–Soviet transformations, this is a course I would recommend.  Professor Jones also provides excellent feedback on assignments, that helps you improve throughout the course. Given the number of assignments, it might be good to consider how you can balance the workload considering other courses you are taking. Overall, I am delighted that I took this course.

course_title: Negotiating Post-Soviet Conflict: The Geopolitics of Eastern Europe and the Caucasus 001
best_comment: This is a fantastic and very practice–oriented course. What I really liked about the course was its focus on skill–building: The theoretical constructs from the readings (especially those on negotiation practices) can be directly applied to the negotiation exercises. The course helped me a lot to understand and work on my own weaknesses when negotiating. The guest lectures were interesting and some of the content actually really useful from a negotiation perspective (especially the talks by Alexander Hug and Danny Stoian).  The memos help to actively reflect on one's negotiation strategy and to integrate (and thereby better remember) the main take–aways from the readings. Through the negotiation sessions, you also get to know your classmates much better than in other courses. The readings are very helpful and def worth reading, but I often had the impression that it was fine skimming some of it since they are not the main predictor of doing a good job in the negotiation sessions. Arvid knows how to make the class interesting and entertaining, and Alex did a fantastic job when organizing the negotiation sessions. Both of them, and also the guest lecturers, are genuinely helpful with any questions you might have and keen to help you improve your skills. Overall, I feel like I learned a lot and met super interesting people.
subject: Government
course_title_2023: Negotiating Post-Soviet Conflict: The Geopolitics of Eastern Europe and the Caucasus

best_comment: Hummel is a super organized and effective instructor.  This person is like really on her shit.  Everything is built very logically and clearly from the syllabus down through the lectures (with the impeccably organized slides and activities) to the study guides down through to the assignments.  You know what the point of the two units are.  It's nice that she doesn't swamp you in readings (although you end up reading a lot of the recommended theories on your own time for the final paper which I think is preferable to giving 100 pages per lecture).  The participation component is really excellent.  She really goes the extra mile.  As someone who took this class as a jaded senior, I think this would be a great class for an eager freshman just out of GOV 20.  People clearly like the participation activities which are done very well with all the variety (she does poll everywheres, a couple of excellent role play ones, competitions in class for xtra cred, among other things).  You directly and indirectly would be learning the skills needed to take higher level gov classes like how to write, what parts of the readings are the parts that you have to read, how to have discussions, how to connect the different concepts.  Section is rather meh, however.  Hopefully that will be fixed.
worse_comment: Do not take this course. It could be a gem if you get a TF who grades you easily, but you can also regret the decision to take the course if you do not have that.
best_gem_comment: The class was excellent. As a gov senior who has taken numerous gov classes, I would say this one was one of my favorites. Professor Hummel is truly a gem in the gov department. The assignments are  very manageable and fun if you like researching authoritarian regimes. The class is also graded fairly.

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. Professor Levitsky is a phenomenal lecturer and you will learn a lot about politics which is not just applicable to Latin America. Make use of office hours and talk to Professor Levitsky, he has some very interesting stories to tell and is always happy to talk to his students. The readings can seem like a lot but they are truly amazing and you will gain a much better understanding of the theories if you commit a couple of hours each week to them.
worse_comment: So much reading. My TF was great, but quite literally NO ONE can complete all of the readings unless this is your only class.
subject: Government

best_comment: A great space to think about race while also feeling safe in your ability to participate or just listen. Also has great readings about race in film.
worse_comment: I was really excited about the subject material of this class, but was disappointed by the execution. Although I learned a lot from the readings and assigned films –– and now watch movies with a more more critical and analytical eye, which I think is really helpful –– lectures often felt very surface–level and repetitious, and didn't usually give me a deeper understanding of the course content. The work level is very manageable.

course_title: Tech Science to Save the World 001
best_comment: The value you get out of the class really depends on what you make of it. This may be true for education in general, but I think it applies to this class more than to any other class I have taken at Harvard. In many of the classes we had I felt that the input I got from the class itself was scarce. Where I learned the most was when collaborating with other students on some of the assignments. (You can work on most assignments on your own or in groups of up to three people). For one of them, I worked with an experienced consultant who took the HKS version of the class. Seeing how differently he approached the problem at hand was a great experience. For the other class, I worked with a college student with a CS background, whose R–skills added incredible value to our final project and clearly showed me where I (with my Econ major) need to improve. Apparently, the grading is harder if you work in groups but I would say (though I don't know my final grade yet) that this is totally worth it, especially if you work in groups of two.Prof. Sweeney also has interesting ideas for research during the summer – do make use of this opportunity if you can and if you like the topic of the class.I think the class has huge potential. The hybrid HKS–college structure is a fantastic idea. Prof. Sweeney, as I mentioned earlier, is very inspiring. Also with the current structure of the class, you do get something out of the class, if you make an effort and take the assignments seriously. If they do improve the structure and increase the "content–load" for this class, this could actually become an excellent class one day.
subject: Government
course_title_2023: Tech Science to Save the World

course_title: Bureaucratic Politics: Government, Economic, Social and Military Organizations 001
best_comment: I liked this class. Readings were sometimes tough and dense, but I definitely got a lot out of it. Professor Carpenter is extremely well–educated on the subject matter and shows great enthusiasm and passion. You better hope Gwen is still TFing! She's great.

course_title: Politics of the Environment and Climate Change 001
best_comment: I LOVED this class. I wouldn't call it a gem since you do have to put in some work into the policy memos to get an A, but otherwise the class is pretty easy (and if you do the bare minimum work you'll get an A). Dustin Tingley is super funny so you'll be super entertained. The course lectures are also super interesting so you're bound to learn a ton if you're interested in climate change.
worse_comment: Do not take this class. Unbearably boring, the Boston project was completely useless. The memos are terribly worded, unreasonably difficult, and graded on a bizarre rubric. Lectures were so boring and painfully obvious. The ultimate issue with this class is that everyone wants to learn about climate change, but lectures will say things like "international cooperation is hard" but then does not go on to say why it is hard, or what ways we can overcome these challenges. Also reviews concepts like prisoners dilemma, trolley cart problem. what laws are, things that everyone should know going into the course. Devoting so much time to these simple concepts, especially when they assign brutally hard readings which they proceeded to never talk about. Horrible horrible class
best_gem_comment: I LOVED this class. I wouldn't call it a gem since you do have to put in some work into the policy memos to get an A, but otherwise the class is pretty easy (and if you do the bare minimum work you'll get an A). Dustin Tingley is super funny so you'll be super entertained. The course lectures are also super interesting so you're bound to learn a ton if you're interested in climate change.
subject: Government
course_title_2023: Politics of the Environment and Climate Change

course_title: Politics of the Environment and Climate Change 001
best_comment: I LOVED this class. I wouldn't call it a gem since you do have to put in some work into the policy memos to get an A, but otherwise the class is pretty easy (and if you do the bare minimum work you'll get an A). Dustin Tingley is super funny so you'll be super entertained. The course lectures are also super interesting so you're bound to learn a ton if you're interested in climate change.
worse_comment: Do not take this class. Unbearably boring, the Boston project was completely useless. The memos are terribly worded, unreasonably difficult, and graded on a bizarre rubric. Lectures were so boring and painfully obvious. The ultimate issue with this class is that everyone wants to learn about climate change, but lectures will say things like "international cooperation is hard" but then does not go on to say why it is hard, or what ways we can overcome these challenges. Also reviews concepts like prisoners dilemma, trolley cart problem. what laws are, things that everyone should know going into the course. Devoting so much time to these simple concepts, especially when they assign brutally hard readings which they proceeded to never talk about. Horrible horrible class
best_gem_comment: I LOVED this class. I wouldn't call it a gem since you do have to put in some work into the policy memos to get an A, but otherwise the class is pretty easy (and if you do the bare minimum work you'll get an A). Dustin Tingley is super funny so you'll be super entertained. The course lectures are also super interesting so you're bound to learn a ton if you're interested in climate change.
subject: Government
course_title_2023: Politics of the Environment and Climate Change

course_title: Evaluating the Impacts of Public Policies: How to Design and Implement Randomized Controlled Trials 001
best_comment: Truly a gem! Take this class! Not only do you learn a lot of helpful material about experimental design and methods, but you learn about super cool studies across a wide array of disciplines. The class is a super fun experience and not overly challenging. You don't need any statistical background, which is great for keeping the course open to students of all levels.
best_gem_comment: Truly a gem! Take this class! Not only do you learn a lot of helpful material about experimental design and methods, but you learn about super cool studies across a wide array of disciplines. The class is a super fun experience and not overly challenging. You don't need any statistical background, which is great for keeping the course open to students of all levels.
subject: Government
course_title_2023: Evaluating the Impacts of Public Policies: How to Design and Implement Randomized Controlled Trials

course_title: Behavioral Insights and Public Policy: Nudging for Good 001
best_comment: This course is fascinating. It gives you the theoretical foundation to understand how behavioral economic insights (cognitive psychology insights) are and can be used to craft public policy. And you learn how it is done empirically in practice, not just by giving policy opinions, but by actually running experiments (RCTs) to find the effects of interventions. The professor is great, and very kind. The second half of the course, when you start reading the articles on different interventions, was basically just seeing other students present their projects, so it felt like the professor stopped teaching at that point. But before that, it was great fun to listen to him. In terms of work, I would call this class a gem. In the sense that if you want to do the readings (as I did) then it is a (little) bit of work, but if you don't then you could essentially not do anything and still be able to get a good grade in the course. That doesn't mean you should take it just to get a good grade; I don't think that's a good idea. But it is good to know that you could take this as a 5th class if you are interested in the material but worried about time commitment.
worse_comment: This class is the definition of a gem––there's no work week–to–week, there were only three graded assignments the whole semester, each of which took only a few hours to prepare for, and the grading was extremely lenient.  Not super happy I took the class though, as the whole second half of the course was in–class presentations during lecture.
best_gem_comment: THIS CLASS IS A GEM! Really love the material (even though the second half is all student presentations which we watch on Zoom) and found it very interesting. Prof Hiscox is also a great teacher and generally a great person who really cares. Definitely recommend taking it!
subject: Government
course_title_2023: Behavioral Insights and Public Policy: Nudging for Good

best_comment: Take this class. Peter offers a thoughtful overview of different types of methods, providing you with the knowledge it's often assumed you should have, but isn't offered elsewhere. While that part of the class is great, what's truly invaluable is all of the great insights he offers about research and the field of political science. And even more valuable is the incredibly thoughtful feedback Peter offers. He takes your work seriously and really thinks about how it can be improved.

This was a very fun, low–pressure introduction to machine learning that covers a good deal of Hastie, Tibshirani, and Friedman's "Elements of Statistical Learning" along with some more modern additions from text and network analysis. Adeline and Sooahn are fantastic instructors and people. I would recommend the course!

This class is hard work, but is very illuminating and well worth the effort. Carefully designed pedagogically, Professor Perry is an amazing professor who will really help illuminate your knowledge of comparative politics in China. It has helped me gain a deeper appreciation for China as a site for studying comparative politics, and opened up a broader range of new research ideas to explore.
subject: Government

best_comment: This was a nice introduction to international relations. Iain is a fantastic and extremely kind professor with an extensive knowledge of the field. The assignments and reading load are very reasonable. The topics overviewed are a bit scattered, but this likely reflects the overall structure of the field. Iain's mini–lectures and slides on select aspects, subfields, and histories of IR were particularly useful. Overall, I would highly recommend taking this course with Iain to fulfill the Government Ph.D.'s new field seminar requirement or if you are interested in conducting research as a scholar of IR.
worse_comment: I highly recommend taking this course, especially if Iain is teaching it. As a PhD student from outside IR, I was not sure how much I would learn from the course or how difficult it would be, but I found that the workload was manageable and that I had a lot to learn from the theories and models in IR for my research on domestic politics.

best_comment: Challenging but an essential one for students wanting to do academic research in IPE.

The class lasts two hours, which can be too much for a lecture. I would recommend you bring a little snack, coffee, or tea and take one or two breaks to go to the restroom or grab some candies or chocolates from the bowls outside Collen's and Debbie's office. This might clear your mind for a few minutes, and you can come again to the class with some energy reserves.
subject: Health Policy

course_title: The Great Divergence and Convergence: Disparity in the Global Economy, 1500-Present 01
best_comment: This course was a great look at economic history, and dealt lots with historiography, which I found really interesting — thinking about how historians have interpreted economic changes through history. Dr. O'Sullivan is also an excellent instructor; he brings passion, enthusiasm, and a really incredible dedication to helping students develop their ideas and writing capacities. I'd recommend this course to anyone interested in economics, history, or both!
best_gem_comment: Dr.O'Sullivan is a gem, as is this class! One of the best–run seminars I've taken at Harvard, and one of the best instructors I've had. If you have any interest in comparative global history or economic history and are willing to do the readings (it's worth it), 100% take this class

best_comment: This is a great course! Professor Penslar is wonderful – he is super knowledgeable and intelligent and also cares about his students and their learning experience. He is also quite funny. He is super available outside of class. Our TF Erin was also amazing. Definitely take this class if you are thinking about it!
If you are even just remotely interested in U.S. Latinx history, take it! Best class I took this semester.
worse_comment: Writing essays with little time to do them is not the best move.

course_title: Biography and Autobiography in Renaissance Italy 01
best_comment: Professor Hankins is great and you should take a class with him if you can! He is incredibly knowledgeable and is great at explaining things and asking questions that allow us to get deep into the texts.

course_title: The Social Life of Science in East Asia 01
best_comment: This is a phenomenal class! The readings are salient and interesting, and the people in the class are fantastic. The discussions can be a little dragged out sometimes, but the open–ended nature also leads to some really interesting points. Ian and Hwei–Ru are wonderful and so supportive as well.

course_title: The History of American Conservatism from William F. Buckley, Jr., to Donald Trump 01
best_comment: Take this class! Aaron is the best, and he does a great job of interrogating conservatism through a fascinating historical lens without spending too much time on Trump or the current Republican Party (though the class does touch on the present a bit). Still, if you're interested in politics or American History, I really can't suggest a better class or instructor than Aaron.
subject: History
course_title_2023: The History of American Conservatism from William F. Buckley, Jr., to Donald Trump

course_title: St. Louis from Lewis and Clark to Michael Brown 01
best_comment: This course led to some of the best discussions I've ever had about what we can do as young activists. You learn a lot about socialism, communism, and how it applies in the United States, and you just grow a lot as a thinker and being. Prof. Johnson is an incredible speaker (it's like the best of both worlds— small class + powerful lecturer = great discussions), and he really tries to create a tight–knit community within the classroom. The final project is awesome— really meaningful to do work for a class that actually has a real–life, beyond–the–classroom impact.

This class is very interesting and is very fun to take. Professor Weld is always available to talk to you about the History of Mexico and always keeps the conversation going. The readings are kind of long but they are fascinating. Despite two hour long class, time would fly by. The subject is interesting and the content was as well.

course_title: The Challenge of Making America Modern 01
best_comment: If you're interested in social history and/or the 20th century US, this class is for you. It's a good bit of work, but it's entirely worth it; both Prof. Cohen and Ken are amazing course leaders, and you'll engage with issues of immediate importance to today's moment with a nuance and historical depth I haven't found anywhere else at Harvard. Along the way, you'll become a better historical writer, and get to engage in rich discussions with your peers. It's much fun!

This is a HARD class !!! But as hard as it is, it will truly make you a MUCH better writer, reader, and historian. And for that, I think it is definitely worth it. It is a very well structured course, that has obviously been developed over generations of students and their feedback. There is a LOT of readings (do them and PARTICIPATE in class!) especially at the first half of the semester but it cools down in the second half where the focus is on writing the final paper. You will do a LOT of writing but it will make you a much better writer. History97 has much more rigorous methdological training than many other equivalent concentration sophomore tutorials in social sciences and humanities. Get started on a final paper topic ASAP – feels scary to decide so early on but it will be enormously helpful. I think the best thing to do is build off an idea from a previous history class you took or a book you've read or some topic of interest/expertise that you are deeply interested in. It will inevitably shift and develop over time but it is good to have a somewhat clear general idea from the very beginning.Prof Blair is incredible! Despite being the Chair of the History Dept and being super busy, she dedicated so much time and effort into teaching us. Her weekly emails, her lunch out at the end of the semester, her generous office hours, her prompt email replies – I don't know how she has the time but you feel that she really cares for you. Her attention and care to the students is almost unmatched from my experience.

Based on what I heard from friends and others in the other HIST 97 tutorials, this seems like one of the best ones. The content was really interesting and Professor Cohen is great. It's a good amount of writing assignments which can be a lot but it's totally doable because they're spaced out and it's super useful because they all build up and contribute to your final paper. Ione was an amazing TF and also made tutorial so great.
it is a pretty challenging course that requires a lot of care and work. however, it was super rewarding and facilitated a stronger foundation for me as a history concentrator

This class is hard. It will make you work for it. But it is so worth it. I grew so much as a writer this semester and I am very grateful to the TF and the professor for all their help. Definitely recommend it, but be ready to work.
subject: History

best_comment: This class is a lot of work but will be very rewarding. I recommend military history with Dr. Penslar if you are interested in this subject. Make sure to keep on top of the deadlines because you will likely have an essay due almost every week and you do not want to get behind.

The thesis process was the highlight of my college career. It was the most difficult, most rewarding, and most transformative experience in my time as an undergraduate. Having a clear idea of your topic or argument at the outset is unimportant; rather, desire to think critically and become expertly acquainted with some general area of interest are the only requisites. If you keep these in mind, you will not regret writing the thesis. The seminar is extremely supportive and useful as you progress, and the instructors will answer any and all questions. The History Department puts its full weight behind your enterprise, including providing resources and flexibility to focus on the thesis, in order to ensure your success. I would highly recommend this class to any student that feels serious about some academic interest and wishes to experience the full rigor and richness of academia.
worse_comment: you should do it. though there is no need for more theses, yours should be written.
subject: History

course_title: The Making of the Modern Middle East 01
best_comment: This is a really great class! Take it to learn way more about the Middle East than you probably know now and dispel the conventional narratives you've been taught about the region. I've learned so much about the region and now feel like I have a much better understanding for various aspects of the modern Middle East. Pay attention in lecture because Prof. Bsheer goes very fast, but you'll learn a lot. Go to office hours with both Prof. Bsheer and your TF!! You'll learn so much because they both have so much knowledge that they just don't have time to share in lecture/section. Be prepared –– the class has considerable assigned readings (usually 120 pages/week). You can get away with not doing some of them, but it's definitely in your best interest to do them (and you'll learn much more by doing them). Other than readings, the course isn't too bad assignment–wise –– I had to spend a lot of time studying for the midterm and final, as well as for preparing a section presentation, but other than that, my only work for the class was reading. Also don't feel intimidated if you've never taken a history course before –– the course is structured so that no prior knowledge is needed, and even though we were in class with grad students, I never felt out of my depth.

course_title: Coffee and the Nighttime: History and Politics, 1400-2020 01
best_comment: If you drink coffee and/or stay up at night working, this course will change how you perceive your own habits (in a very good way). You will also get to explore some fascinating, niche aspects of history (such as coffeehouses, vampirism, and sleep habits) you probably won't encounter in other classes. I always looked forward to this class and enjoyed lectures, readings, and assignments (which are fun and not stressful!). Professor Kafadar is so passionate and knowledgeable––it is obvious that he really cares about this topic and wants to spread that enthusiasm to his students.
worse_comment: Definitely take this if you're looking to learn something completely different and new but don't want to grind too hard.

best_comment: It is a great introductory course for people interested in studying history. The subject matter was specific enough that somebody with a genuine curiosity in the subject would find all lectures really engaging and would appreciate Professor Cratty's enthusiasm in the subject and willingness to answer questions. The essays/projects of the class were also genuinely fun to complete as they were not simply conventional essays.
subject: History

best_comment: Savor every moment in this class! Professor Bose & TFS are truly unique, compassionate, intentional, and understanding. They have a passion for history, particularly emphasizing the visibility of SEA on a global scale, such a pleasure and an opportunity to have learned from them.
worse_comment: It's very boring and not relevant.
subject: History

course_title: First Empires: Power and Propaganda in the Ancient World 01
best_comment: This class was a highlight of my college experience. The material is generally interesting, although given that so much material is covered, everyone will have some parts that they like more than others. The papers are also really fun to write, and the final paper is particularly fun given that you can choose any topic that you want as long as it's somewhat related to the course material. Gabe is a fantastic lecturer, and he clearly put a lot of effort into the slides. He was also extremely accessible, and was always willing to meet and discuss things. Sama, the TF, was also a highlight. She was always incredibly helpful, and more than willing to meet and help with assignments. In other classes, I've always found section to be a waste of time, but I actually looked forward to section in this class every week –– it was by far the best section I've had in any class. Overall, take this class if you want an interesting, relatively chill elective with a dedicated professor.  My one hesitation in recommending it is that not everyone is as interested in the ancient near east as I am, but I still think that many of the lessons of this course (how states develop, how propaganda is used, imperial ideology, etc.) are universal.

course_title: An Introduction to the History of Economics 01
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! One of my favorite classes I've taken. Dr. Kumekawa is the best lecturer I've had at Harvard – his passion and knowledge of the topic shines through. Salmaan is a really good TF. You will learn so much in every single lecture – this class covers a lot of material in a really engaging way. Readings are concise and to the point. Assignments are all fair and will let you apply what you've learned in class. Take this class if you have any interest in how economic concepts have developed over time. IMO, this should be a required class for all Econ concentrators.

course_title: U.S. Foreign Policy in a Global Age 01
best_comment: This class is a good overview of events in American foreign policy, but that understanding is going to come from you doing the readings. Professor Logevall lectures for about half the class and then facilitates a discussion (frequently on a philosophical level or counterfactuals). Because the class was cross–registered with the Kennedy school, this was interesting, but I didn't feel like I got a great understanding of the events we were supposed to be describing. Also, I received very minimal feedback in the class, to the point that I have no idea what grade I might get. We completed two simulations — one was well–planned and had clear guidelines, the other did not — but I've heard back on neither. The entire directions for the final paper could be found on the syllabus. I would have appreciated more guidance as to what to do in this course, but it was certainly an interesting experience.

This is a really interesting class! The lectures and course materials are all great and you can learn a lot about the history of Germany after WWII. There's not very much background information necessary to take the class, so definitely sign up if you're interested!

course_title: The American Century?: A History of the United States since World War II 01
best_comment: This class is absolutely amazing. It fills in many gaps that may not have been covered during high school American history and is extremely enjoyable. The readings are all useful and interesting and they will not feel like a waste of time. The papers are also helpful and there are not many of them. Professor Bekemeyer is so engaging and intelligent, you will learn so much from him. Everybody in the course staff is extremely helpful and will always make time to meet/discuss materials.
worse_comment: Good survey course of U.S. history – does exactly what it tells you it will do on the syllabus. Aaron is an excellent lecturer. Thomas is a good TF, but section might suffer if no one does the readings. The course is very manageable, just make sure to skim the readings again before the midterm and exam.

course_title: Western Intellectual History: The Prehistory of Modern Thought 01
best_comment: For the philosophically–inclined, this course is a great way to spend a semester. Professor Hankins offers lectures to provide grounding in the topic, while Konrad's sections always provide the opportunity to probe deeper on difficult questions. The midterms, quizzes, and finals are all fair and test your understanding of the material. However, getting through the readings is a challenge if you put them off for too long.

course_title: West Africa from 1800 to the Present 01
best_comment: This class was very well organized and well taught.  You learn the major themes and developments in West Africa in a systematic and clear way. Professor Akyeampong is great and very knowledgable, and Ifeosa if she is still TF is great as well. Slightly heavier than history courses on average in terms of courseload but manageable and worth if if you want to learn about West Africa.

This was the most incredible history seminar I've taken at Harvard — a shame that it had to be in my senior year but a treat that it helped conclude my time here! I adored this class and Professor Frank Johnson. Professor Frank Johnson creates something special in the seminar: beyond just learning about Vienna (and believe me, there's plenty of fascinating things to learn!), she creates a space where we can all discuss serious topics with no judgment, with good humor, and with real joy. She is an amazing professor, seminar leader, and comedian and really cares about her students and the curriculum that she crafts for the course. The curriculum is intentional and well thought through; by the end of the class you'll want to hop on the next plane to Vienna! I don't think it's an overstatement to say that this course was my favorite I've taken at Harvard and Professor Frank Johnson is my favorite professor here. From the unexpected class trip to get coffees in the square to discuss Viennese coffeehouse culture to the discussions on postwar spy thrillers , urban planning, and the Cold War (to name just a few topics), I looked forward to this class every week.It is exactly courses like these that I think make college special. I can't recommend this course (or any with Prof. Frank Johnson) enough.

This class is a terrific opportunity to delve into Civil War studies with a professor who is easily one of the most accomplished and respected academic authorities on the subject. It was truly a pleasure engaging with Professor Faust, the fellow students, and the diverse course material.

course_title: The History of Law in Europe 01
best_comment: This course is incredibly engaging and will be valuable to students with an interest in history, law, or both. Professor Herzog is someone you can learn a great deal from, and she fosters a very positive classroom environment that appreciates your questions and perspectives. You will be tested in your ability to make connections, question the material you read, and form your own opinion on prominent debates, but you are certain to become a better reader and thinker because of it. Do not let your lack of experience with the subject or the fact that you may share a space with Law School students intimidate you––there is a wealth of knowledge here that is yours for the taking.
