worse_comment: It is strange to have a mix of law students and undergrads. The classroom environment is significantly impacted.

course_title: The Imperial Map: Geographic Information in the Age of Empire 01
best_comment: This course is delivered in an engaging and interesting way. The instructor is very enthusiastic about the material and very approachable. The syllabus can be quite fast paced though, and sometimes it's hard to keep track of what we are doing with an array of assignments and readings. That said, the class is not overwhelming.

Take this class! If you have any interest in the concept of wilderness, landscape history, GIS mapping, or nature more generally, you will enjoy this class. I had absolutely no experience (or interest really) in GIS mapping before taking this course, so don't be intimidated or turned off from that aspect. Prof. Chaplin is wonderful. She is extremely thoughtful and wants this course to be rewarding for her students. She's very willing to make amendments to the syllabus or assignments if it will benefit the students. This class, while extremely rewarding, is not at all stressful. Assignments are more than manageable. Readings can be hefty, but you surely don't have to read everything every week (though they are super interesting). Class can be a bit long, especially if you aren't interested in the topics. This class does have a lot of group work, but at least from my experience, everyone in the class is really interested in what we're working on, so working in groups was very pleasant. If you are on the fence about taking this class, I really do recommend it. Plus, it's incredible to have a true impact on the Harvard community. I can't wait until our little mound is planted, and we get to see our work in action. It was also a really cool experience to work with representatives from the Business School –– it was a window into what real life is like and what presenting pitches is like. Highly, highly recommend!!
best_gem_comment: Definitely a gem. Readings are super digestable (1.5hrs to read, max), the writing assignments are spread out and fairly straightforward, and Professor Chaplin is fantastic!

course_title: Understanding Political Economy: The View from the Middle East, and South Asia: Seminar 01
best_comment: Quite literally the best class I've ever taken at Harvard. The other students were fantastic, really interested and incisive in their analysis, and clearly did the work every week. Prof. Bsheer is brilliant – she pushes students to be as good as they can be while also being a very kind and genuine person. I really, really loved this class, even as someone without very much background in Middle East/South Asia studies, and could not more highly recommend it.

Professor Armitage is exceptionally dedicated to training and supporting graduate students. If you consider yourself an intellectual historian in some capacity or other, taking this class is a no–brainer.

course_title: Topics in Ottoman Social and Cultural History: Seminar 01
best_comment: Cemal is always the highlight of these seminars. Don't go into them with any prior expectations about how it's going to turn out because the course develops organically according to interests and the overall feel of the seminar members.

Great course for a first–year unsure about concentration but knowing they enjoy arts and humanities or the social sciences. Manageable work load and Phil is AWESOME. It's clear that he loves this class and cares a TON about the students in his class. As an older student, I can tell you that this is a very special opportunity to learn from a super brilliant professor at the top of his field who is also a great human being and teacher. On the course, it's not super structured, so you have to be willing to be creative, come up with your own topics, and take time to develop your own ideas. This is a unique course in that sense. You've got to be willing to do this or else you won't enjoy the course. However, it's also a really great course to explore different studies in different areas of the arts and humanities and social sciences.
subject: History & Literature

best_comment: Take this class if you're quite interested in the Red Scare and learning about its different causes and impacts. You will likely have to be prepared to read about 100 pages a week, sometimes more, but the experience will be rewarding if this is a topic you're interested in. Both Lauren and Steve are wonderful professors who are incredibly helpful and knowledgeable and are great at guiding discussions. If you're thinking of potentially concentrating in History and Literature, this is a great seminar to choose.
worse_comment: Very repetitive
best_gem_comment: This course is a gem!!! If you have any interest in concentrating in History and Literature you MUST take this course. It is brilliant!

best_comment: Take this class if you're quite interested in the Red Scare and learning about its different causes and impacts. You will likely have to be prepared to read about 100 pages a week, sometimes more, but the experience will be rewarding if this is a topic you're interested in. Both Lauren and Steve are wonderful professors who are incredibly helpful and knowledgeable and are great at guiding discussions. If you're thinking of potentially concentrating in History and Literature, this is a great seminar to choose.
worse_comment: Very repetitive
best_gem_comment: This course is a gem!!! If you have any interest in concentrating in History and Literature you MUST take this course. It is brilliant!

course_title: Too Soon? Comedy in Europe’s Tragic Twentieth Century 001
best_comment: I would say, take it! It's a really interesting subject matter and you learn a lot about how to approach comedy. However, make sure to set aside a good chunk of time per week for the readings and films. There is a lot! Also don't blow off the weekly assignments because Dr. Brackney really appreciates and notes when you put time into them.
worse_comment: Do not take this class. Professor Brackney is a tough grader. I know people who genuinely tried in this class and were still receiving low grades on their essays. This class seems like a gem because you just watch movies, but it actually ended up being the hardest class I took this semester because of the hard grading. I put in 50+ hours into my final essay, and I still feel like I won't get a good grade :(

course_title: Witchcraft and Magic in the Atlantic World 001
best_comment: thoroughly enjoyed this class. The readings were interesting, prof. urus was great, and I learned a lot. really enjoyed learning more about the idea of “ways of knowing” and how that applies to our modern conception of science and religion. super fascinating content.

I would definitely recommend this class, especially as a good way to fulfill the humanities divisional distribution requirement. It's a great intro course for students who don't know much about architecture. Also, if you go to class (and you'll be in the minority if you do), the class will be a breeze. The exams do require a decent amount of memorization, but the essays are very relaxed and fun. I do wish that the course staff/structure were more accommodating – they automatically sort you into sections without asking what section time you would prefer, and tell you that you're not allowed to switch. I found that to be both presumptuous and unrealistic (plot twist: Harvard students have commitments outside of their classes and can't go to section at whatever random time you assign). They also only provided the recorded lectures to students who reached out with reasons they missed class, and the recording link expired after a week or so. Ultimately, that stuff wasn't that big of an issue and a lot of the lectures were genuinely interesting. There is a wide range in how good the lecturers are from week to week, but some were great.
worse_comment: I was overall disappointed with this course. Grading was very uneven between TFs. No paper rubrics, very vague assignment guidelines, and no prior practice exams were given. Nevertheless, "participation" is such a large grading component that you can still do  well in this course even if grading is very harsh on everything else. Some so–called "landmarks" are very obscure, and some were never even built (!). Some lecturers were very bad and boring (a few were also outstanding). Most people never bothered showing up to lecture. The readings were entirely unnecessary.
best_gem_comment: This class is a gem from the standpoint that it has little work week–to–week but that doesn't mean it is easy to succeed. The class doesn't set you up for success because a lot of the lectures are so incredibly dry that it is hard to pay attention and the assignments are poorly written.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

course_title: Genghis Khan and his Successors: Art in the Wake of the Mongol Conquests 001
best_comment: I loved this class. Professor Roxburgh and Sarah are both great –– very interesting subject matter as an elective (and I'd imagine as an HAA student as well). Cool to learn about Genghis Khan and his successors and look closely at the art as well. The Harvard Art Museum component was a pleasant surprise as well. Professor Roxburgh is hilarious and smart, would highly recommend it as a leisurely 4th, as the work isn't too strenuous (while still being interesting and engaging).

This is an easy course like many will say. However, to humanists with personal interest and commitment, looking for an engaging and fun way to broaden their exposure to the discipline, this is an excellent choice. I found the course curated, with a clear and engaged narrative, and consistent. Professor Lambert–Beatty truly is an excellent educator with thoughtfulness and curation inspiring to see.

Fantastic HAA course. One of my favorites as a concentrator. Very manageable workload, very interesting course content. Professor Hamburger and the TF Ale are wonderful and very engaging, and really make an effort to get to know each student which is often underlooked. Take this course 100%, even if youre not a concentrator this is a great course to take for the humanities distribution requirement as well since you don't need any background whatsoever for this course.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: Take this class! It is by far one of the best academic experiences you'll get at Harvard. The class is super interesting. You'll acquire a strong background knowledge in the history of money and the information will stay with you forever because this class makes the learning experience super enjoyable. Professor Georganteli and the teaching staff are phenomenal; they care about each and every single student and they always keep us engaged with the material. I am grateful for this experience and I hope everyone especially those interested in finance and economics beyond theory take the class.
worse_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. Professor Georganteli is an angel and academic weapon. You will learn so much and be so so enriched.
best_gem_comment: Money Matters is a course that truly deepened my understanding of numismatics by utilizing coins and artifacts as vehicles to understand history, socio–economic practices, and art. I recommend all students take this course!! Definitely a gem!!! The professor (Professor Georganteli is the sweetest!!!!!!) and teaching staff are amazing! What other class lets you handle/hold artifacts, particularly coins, from thousands of years ago? If you have any interest in exploring the philosophy of economic/monetary systems, coin designs, the value of money from coins to NFTs, or anything that has to do with money, take this course!!!
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: Awesome. Takes a ton of time, but you get to engage creatively with materials in such an exciting, supportive environment.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU HAVE ANY INTEREST IN ARCHITECTURE (EVEN IF IT'S NOT YOUR MAJOR). This was the best class I've taken at Harvard –– there's no other class like it. Every week or two you have a project, where you gradually build your technical skills and experiment with different materials and fabrication techniques; each project iterates off the former one. This is an extremely time–intensive class: I probably spent 10–15 hours/week working on a project, but for the final around 30–40 hours. No one slept before the final project was due lol. That being said,  I spent this much time in the class because I loved it, and this class really is what you make of it. Because the class is super small, you get to know the other students really well and get a lot of time with the instructor and TA's. Everyone in the GSD is also so genuinely nice and will gladly help you when you have no idea what you're doing because you're an undergrad. Most of this class is spent on building models and is very hands–on, but you also get lots of experience in Rhino and Illustrator. The class is very abstract though, and doesn't really get to building anything in the "real world" until the final project, and even then the project was still slightly abstract. However, the abstract models are still very structured and not just doing whatever you want, which I liked. I was not an architecture major before this class, but now I'm seriously considering going to architecture grad school because I loved it so much.  If you were like me and didn't know if you liked architecture, YOU NEED TO TAKE THIS CLASS!
worse_comment: I highly highly recommend taking this class, even if you aren't an HAA concentrator. If you have time in your schedule and are interested in building with your hands or design, a studio course designed for undergrads at Harvard but taught by grad school faculty is a unique experience that can teach you a lot about your interests, especially if you're undecided. You get as much as you put in so this isn't really an easy course if you're taking other time–consuming classes.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: Take this class! It is an amazing introduction to Art History, and it's still helpful even if you already know a fair bit.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: Make sure to find advisors who really care a lot about you and your work – it makes a huge difference!
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: Engage with the material as much as possible to get the most out of this course, and choose works for your final project that you genuinely find interesting.
worse_comment: Ask early on as many questions as you can about the presentation. It is essentially how you are graded in this class and legitimately for the entire semester I was completely lost on what they wanted. Ended up not doing very well because when they did give you the expectations for the presentation it was the end of the quarter and all the work you I had chosen didn't really fit into a brief.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: Engage with the material as much as possible to get the most out of this course, and choose works for your final project that you genuinely find interesting.
worse_comment: Ask early on as many questions as you can about the presentation. It is essentially how you are graded in this class and legitimately for the entire semester I was completely lost on what they wanted. Ended up not doing very well because when they did give you the expectations for the presentation it was the end of the quarter and all the work you I had chosen didn't really fit into a brief.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

course_title: The Court of Constantinople: Imperial Art and Ceremonies 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS because it will be one of your all time best decisions at Harvard and you will experience a once in a lifetime trip to Dumbarton Oaks, the largest collection of Byzantine art in America/the world!

This class was an amazing opportunity to breach into the field of art history. I was very nervous about taking the class at first because I had never taken any art or art history class, but I found both my peers in the class and Professor Koerner to be very welcoming and accepting of someone with little knowledge on art history. The class itself was amazing and incredibly interesting while not being super intensive on the work side. Every assignment had a meaningful purpose and achieved its goal of encouraging intellectual growth; there were no useless assignments. 10/10 would recommend to anybody even somewhat interested in Hieronymus Bosch or art history.
TAKE THIS CLASS. IT WILL BE THE BEST CLASS YOU TAKE AT HARVARD AND YOU WONT STOP ENROLLING IN PEREDA'S COURSES. This is your sign to enroll immediately. You will not regret it.
worse_comment: You get out of the class exactly how much you put in –– there are only 2 assignments, so extra reading, thinking, and exploring is left totally up to you. If you are not going to invest time in reading alongside the course and generating ideas alongside Pereda, it may not be worth it.

best_comment: You will learn a lot of interesting, and surprising, material in this course if you're willing to put in the time for readings.

course_title: Artisanal Modernism & the Labor of Women 001
best_comment: Wonderful seminar in which you not only get to travel to NYC to see some amazing exhibits for free, but also have the chance to improve your writing and close looking skills dramatically while discussing some incredible and underappreciated artworks and artists. Professor Gough seems intimidating but is lovely and supportive. Her passion for the work is palpable.
subject: History of Art & Architecture
course_title_2023: Artisanal Modernism & the Labor of Women

best_comment: Try your best and don't be afraid to ask for help. The material can be pretty intimidating, but it is so fun to tackle and the art is absolutely incredible. Professor Kim is there to support you and loves to do so, so ask her for help if you need it!

course_title: A Connected Architectural and Urban History of Early Modern Empire: The Ottomans, Safavids & Mughals 001
best_comment: This is an excellent course! You get as much as you put in, so make sure to do with readings so you can keep up with the lectures.
worse_comment: It's just a really long seminar. You should be really passionate about the subject to take it. But the course requirements are not too much of a burden.

course_title: Mysticism and the Limits of Representation, from the Middle Ages to the Baroque 001
best_comment: This is an amazing course! Profs. Hamburger and Pereda are engaging, charismatic educators with a consistently awe–inspiring knowledge of and passion for this material. The material is endlessly interesting and challenging. Easily the best course I've taken at Harvard.

course_title: Mysticism and the Limits of Representation, from the Middle Ages to the Baroque 001
best_comment: This is an amazing course! Profs. Hamburger and Pereda are engaging, charismatic educators with a consistently awe–inspiring knowledge of and passion for this material. The material is endlessly interesting and challenging. Easily the best course I've taken at Harvard.
This course will give you a strong, deep, and experiential understanding of early soviet avant–garde movements, balancing practice and theory.

course_title: The Object in the Art Museum 001
best_comment: Definitely take this course if you are interested in curation or museums as an institution as a whole. The knowledge and expertise that Makeda and Mary brought to this course was so special and I learned to expand my thinking beyond just art in a theoretical or academic sense and dive into the museum as an institution.
worse_comment: Take it! If you're at all interested in a museum career or in curation, this course will provide some seriously invaluable hands on experience that no other course at Harvard offers.
subject: History of Art & Architecture
course_title_2023: The Object in the Art Museum

course_title: The Object in the Art Museum 001
best_comment: Definitely take this course if you are interested in curation or museums as an institution as a whole. The knowledge and expertise that Makeda and Mary brought to this course was so special and I learned to expand my thinking beyond just art in a theoretical or academic sense and dive into the museum as an institution.
worse_comment: Take it! If you're at all interested in a museum career or in curation, this course will provide some seriously invaluable hands on experience that no other course at Harvard offers.
subject: History of Art & Architecture
course_title_2023: The Object in the Art Museum

best_comment: If you want to learn how to learn and be involved in a highly enthusiastic and passionate class community, this is a wonderful course to take! All work is self/peer–directed, and students are encouraged to truly think outside the box in creative ways you rarely find at Harvard. That said, this is a somewhat time–intensive course given the amount of reading/hypothesizing needed to produce new theories and conclusions.
worse_comment: It is really student–driven, so in that sense, it gives you the power to shape your own learning experience, which is great. But that also means that you have more responsibility, so if you fall behind, it's hard to catch up. It also might get chaotic and uncertain throughout the semester, but it ended up tying together really nicely.

best_comment: This class is an excellent survey of Afro–Latin American histories and a good discussion space to workshop ideas about those histories.
This class is an excellent survey of Afro–Latin American histories and a good discussion space to workshop ideas about those histories.

This is a fantastic introduction to History of Science, both in the sort of work scholars in the field conduct as well as the actual technical nitty–gritty involved in engaging in critical research processes. Prof. Harrington really cares about the sophomores, is such a cool person herself, and has really figured out how to make this class great. The rest of the teaching staff as well was excellent and they were all always willing to answer any questions about the course or the department more generally.
worse_comment: I had to take this class, but I hated it until half way through the semester. In the end I loved it though,
subject: History of Science

best_comment: this class is a great opportunity to gain a more enriched understanding of histsci methods and, if you haven't already taken another histsci class, shows you how to take a research interest or curiosity and turn it into a full–fledged project. in addition, through section and through the sharing sessions, you will leave this class with a wonderful community of histsci peers, so don't be afraid to make friends (with other students as well as with professor harrington and the other amazing tfs)!
subject: History of Science

best_comment: Writing a thesis was super rewarding and I highly recommend it!!! It also requires a bunch of self discipline, so make sure you set reasonable deadlines for yourself and stick to them.
worse_comment: The last few weeks of the thesis can be rough– a lot of things are coming together which is satisfying, but one is so tired and there is always more to be done. Find yourself a thesis writing buddy to lighten the mood while writing and to hold you accountable.
subject: History of Science

best_comment: this was an incredible course! I am an upperclassman and took it as an elective for Histsci but it would also be accessible to first–years or underclassmen interested in exploring the field. readings and assignments are very interesting and engaging and you receive a lot of guidance on them. Professor Alam is kind, thoughtful about how she teaches the course, is extremely well–organized, and very good at facilitating discussion/engagement during lecture.
worse_comment: This course was more difficult than expected in terms of grading. It felt difficult to get an A on assignments since they are very particular about getting small things correct.

best_comment: This is an incredible course! It pushed me out of my comfort zone in terms of reading/writing/discussion but it was a small and supportive environment for engaging with complex histsci issues and was not an intimidating environment. Professor Abi–Rached is passionate, incredibly intelligent, and thoughtful about how to approach the readings and writing/research we did in this course. I really enjoyed the readings and appreciated the chance to pursue research independently as well.
subject: History of Science

course_title: Mental Health in Crisis: From War Neurosis to Covid-19 001
best_comment: This course was great! This class really broadened my worldview and taught me so much about mental health and trauma in the context of crises and disasters. I love how the course syllabi broke down the different weekly topics (i.e. violence of the state, violence of capitalism, etc.). Professor Abi–Rached was a great lecturer, and it's clear she's passionate about the course. I loved the addition of documentaries and guest speakers/lecturers! Molly was an exceptional TF that made sure everything ran smoothly; between her flexibility/accommodation and feedback on assignments, she made sure everyone was in a good position to succeed in this class. Course material was interesting, but Perusall was a slight nuisance at times. I think the requirement for Perusall engagement should be lowered in the future! That way students aren't stressed about a comment limit and can engage with the sources as normal. The written assignments and final project were unique and allowed for students to tap into their creativity. I appreciate that. A rubric would be even more helpful since there was a lot of confusion for me when approaching the change over time essay and final project. Nevertheless, I enjoyed HISTSCI 1472 and would recommend to my peers!
worse_comment: Do the readings early! They are long and sometimes not as easy to read due to the antiquated language. While this class may not be super intense, remember that you get what you put in. You can really learn to speak eloquently about these topics and learn something invaluable if you put in the effort.
subject: History of Science
course_title_2023: Mental Health in Crisis: From War Neurosis to Covid-19

best_comment: This is a small discussion class with about 16 students; as such, your time in the class will depend very heavily on *who* is choosing to take the class at the same time. I really recommend that you take the class with a friend so that at least you can ensure that someone is on the same page as you. In any case, if you're looking for a gem, this is it, but it can actually be a super rigorous class if you want that to be your goal.Professor Csizar is actually one of the kindest, sweetest, most wonderful professors you could ever imagine. He creates excellent materials for class and puts a lot of thought and care into the curriculum. Unfortunately, I think he is a bit too nice sometimes to moderate the discussion in a way that keeps it most productive / interesting for everyone in the class (the class is sometimes a bit prone to hijacking by "section kids.")The assignments are great — 600, 1000, and 1500 word papers that are graded more so for your thoughts on the topic than any type of specific topical knowledge. In that way, you can pursue something really interesting even if the class discussions are a bit subpar. I've heard that these vary from year to year, so just get a vibe check on your first session!
best_gem_comment: This is a small discussion class with about 16 students; as such, your time in the class will depend very heavily on *who* is choosing to take the class at the same time. I really recommend that you take the class with a friend so that at least you can ensure that someone is on the same page as you. In any case, if you're looking for a gem, this is it, but it can actually be a super rigorous class if you want that to be your goal.Professor Csizar is actually one of the kindest, sweetest, most wonderful professors you could ever imagine. He creates excellent materials for class and puts a lot of thought and care into the curriculum. Unfortunately, I think he is a bit too nice sometimes to moderate the discussion in a way that keeps it most productive / interesting for everyone in the class (the class is sometimes a bit prone to hijacking by "section kids.")The assignments are great — 600, 1000, and 1500 word papers that are graded more so for your thoughts on the topic than any type of specific topical knowledge. In that way, you can pursue something really interesting even if the class discussions are a bit subpar. I've heard that these vary from year to year, so just get a vibe check on your first session!

course_title: Co-ops, Commons, and Communes: The Technology of Cooperation 001
best_comment: This class is very focused on Co–ops and Commons, and feels scattered at times. The 2 hours and 45 minute session is very lengthy and it's very focused on discussions. Feels like it is made for a small group, but instead was 50 people. I think there are much more engaging and interesting courses in the HistSci department, though this one is very easy.
best_gem_comment: Dave is really cool, and his courses are too! In my experience, students treated this course like a gem and as such we didn't get as much out of it (collectively) as we could have. Do the readings and find the (few) other people who do, too. Engage as deeply as possible, especially with the modules, and you'll get something out of this course.

best_comment: This is a great course with a kind and unexpectedly brilliant professor ('unexpectedly,' because he doesn't rub it in your face.) Take this course if you are interested in how the modern era was shaped by Cold War intellectuals.

course_title: The Changing Concept of Race in Science and Medicine in the U.S.: From Jefferson to Genomics 001
best_comment: Save yourself, take another grad seminar, literally any other one. Hammonds is extremely intelligent and well–read but just does not want to be there. Be ready to never get your emails responded to and to just take a guess if she has read your reflection paper or not. Just save yourself the frustration honestly.
worse_comment: The course material is really interesting, so you should definitely do the readings. But you'll have to be self–driven, since you can also easily slide by without truly engaging with the material. We never received any feedback on any of our submitted work. Even though it's a weekly seminar, the structure of our class on a weekly basis was a hefty lecture delivered by Professor Hammonds and then we would go down the line and present what we wrote about in our weekly response paper. We never truly had a full group discussion or addressed each other's points in class.

course_title: Science and the Conquest of the Tropics 001
best_comment: I would absolutely recommend this class! The readings are fascinating and Professor Soto Laveaga is an amazing instructor
worse_comment: This is a challenging course, both in the actual course material and in the way you must analyze and think about it critically. It is incredibly rewarding if you put the proper amount of time into it, but because of that it's also very difficult to keep up if you have a couple off–weeks as I did.

course_title: Bioethics, Law, and the Life Sciences 001
best_comment: For me, Professor Jasanoff's have been grounding and eye–opening in the best possible ways. The readings are super fun and insightful and it's the only class I've taken at Harvard that feels like every reading and every minute is essential not to just get a "grade" but to become a better person and citizen of the world. The STS modes of analysis explored in the class will likely change how you view science and technology, possible futures, and your place in the world. A whirlwhind and tour de force of an experience I recommend to everyone.

course_title: Agnotology: The History of Knowledge and Ignorance 001
best_comment: Come prepared to engage in rich discussions that go beyond academic walls. If you have an interest in public debate and the role of media in science communication (and disinformation), this is the course for you

course_title: Sophomore Tutorial in Human Evolutionary Biology 001
best_comment: This class is a great introduction to HEB, and sets a great foundation for the ideas and themes you will use again and again. It is also a small class with great discussion, so you feel comfortable sharing your thoughts and asking questions while talking through the weekly readings.
worse_comment: I found the strategy of 75% research and planning 25% actual writing and drafting to be the most efficient way to attack the essays
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology
course_title_2023: Sophomore Tutorial in Human Evolutionary Biology

course_title: Research in Human Biomechanics and Physiology 001
best_comment: I had an amazing experience in this course. Wonderful and dedicated course staff that care about their lab experiments, so great to learn with them for a semester. Was nice to break up other work with experimental work. Take it!
worse_comment: HEB 1210 gave me a unique experience to work closely with post docs on their own research projects. This was a new and difficult experience, but I learned a lot and it is very fulfilling.
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology
course_title_2023: Research in Human Biomechanics and Physiology

course_title: Research in Human Biomechanics and Physiology 001
best_comment: I had an amazing experience in this course. Wonderful and dedicated course staff that care about their lab experiments, so great to learn with them for a semester. Was nice to break up other work with experimental work. Take it!
worse_comment: HEB 1210 gave me a unique experience to work closely with post docs on their own research projects. This was a new and difficult experience, but I learned a lot and it is very fulfilling.
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology
course_title_2023: Research in Human Biomechanics and Physiology

best_comment: I don't think this class is being taught anymore, but it is a great course. What makes it great is Professor Hooven, who lets us learn about what we want to know more about. She gets people excited and interested, and has fostered a class dynamic that allows everyone to feel comfortable and open to sharing our own personal experiences with various topics that we are learning about.

course_title: Ancient DNA as a Window Into the Human Past 001
best_comment: I cannot recommend this course highly enough. Because my remarks elsewhere in this evaluation comprise what I would tell future students about the class, I am providing sections of those responses below, as my response to this question: This course has too many strengths to enumerate all of them.  Professor Reich has done an excellent job in structuring the course in terms of the broad division between the lecture and discussion formats.  Professor Reich's enthusiasm for the material was infectious, and at the same time. Professor Reich was also a very clear lecturer, explained ideas as well, and also made clear early on that the course would be technically challenging (more on this later). Professor Reich also took great care to acknowledge and discuss the fraught ethical and political landscapes into which ancient DNA studies are injected. In addition to these, Professor Reich was very responsive to student communications throughout the semester. He was very receptive to student questions in class. Importantly, he introduced students to the difficult and often tortuous landscape of science research and the enormous amount of effort that underpins the movement of research from an initial idea to a published result. Professor Reich will help students learn not only about ancient DNA but also about how science is done.  The class covered diverse temporal and geographic scales, and did an excellent job of demonstrating the role of genes in understanding "deep" history and how genetics can contribute to problems of social science (i.e., this is not only a genetics class but both a genetics class and a history class, capturing the core themes and goals of HEB).  The opportunity to work with ancient DNA datasets under the mentorship of highly skilled and committed mentors is extremely valuable and will ensure that students leave the course with a strong appreciation of the rigors and wonders of the role of human genes in elucidating the human story.

course_title: Coexistence in Crisis: How Animals Made Us Human 001
best_comment: This is a really hard class to put into words; my best suggestion to decide if it's a good fit for you is to spend a few hours looking through a few readings. Also, even if you find them challenging (not challenging to read but challenging in principle), stick with them! This class, like all truly meaningful classes, is meant to open your mind and that involves asking hard questions. Also, Christine makes a remarkably supportive learning environment, so you won't /feel/ challenged when it comes down to it. I'm a better person for having taken it for sure, so I can only recommend it.

course_title: The Human Brain in the Animal Kingdom 001
best_comment: Take this class! It is truly focused on your learning, not on how well you can memorize. Erin makes it interesting and fun, and it is a refreshing perspective on the human brain and neuroanatomy and physiology. You also bond with your classmates in a way that doesn't usually happen in stem classes. I loved this class!!
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology
course_title_2023: The Human Brain in the Animal Kingdom

course_title: Explaining Beauty: The Hidden Functions Behind Aesthetics 001
best_comment: This is a perspective–shifting, engaging course that is also very manageable! Bethany is extremely compassionate and engaging, and the topics covered within this course are all very interesting. Sometimes, assignment instructions are slightly unclear, but none of them are too difficult and are pretty fun to complete, so it really isn't a problem. I wished we had gone more in–depth into most of the topics covered, but it was great as a survey course / intro to a whole new way of thinking. Overall, this is such a unique course that you should definitely take if you get the chance.
best_gem_comment: This class is absolutely a gem, would recommend!

best_comment: This course is incredibly helpful if you plan to go to medical school. The information and pacing matches closely the experience of a medical school anatomy course. The addition of the cadaver labs makes this even more practical and real. However, this course is really hard and has a lot of information. I would not take this course with a heavy course load but it is good to take when you can focus on it! Good luck and go to office hours!
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology

course_title: Evolutionary Genetics of Complex Human Traits 001
best_comment: I recommend this class with enthusiasm and suggest that any student interested in the genetic origins of human biology and the human mind should take it. The final project will give you a valuable opportunity to understand a complex trait of your choice. Professor Ruvolo will ensure that you learn a great many new things in an exciting and rewarding manner.

course_title: A Humanities Colloquium: From Ralph Ellison to Homer 001
best_comment: I will not be concentrating in the humanities, so take that as you will. The following is a little bit (too?) unfiltered, but I hope it doesn't get filtered out of the displayed comments (sorry in advance for the length; i'm still recovering from the final; for a tl;dr read the end i think).I have a lot of mixed opinions about Hum 10  — and a lot of my friends are tired of hearing me talk about my mixed feelings for Hum 10, so I'm excited to put some of them to words here. I think that Hum 10 is a really interesting class in general, and the vision for Hum 10 that is projected during info sessions and in group chats is certainly appealing; after all, a yearlong transformative experience through great texts seems to be the quintessential Harvard course, and the hype that is built up around it (not to mention the prestige it holds) makes it seem like a great and distinguished privilege to take the course.The course itself is not bad by any means, but I think that it is slightly different than the experience that I had originally expected. The work it takes to keep up with the breakneck pace at which you are expected to read books is not inherently a good reason to dislike the course; after all, there are giant warnings throughout the application process and in the general culture/buzz surrounding Hum 10 that it is "a book a week" and "only for humanities kids who would like to marry a book one day." But, the pace at which the course runs through texts can make the texts (and conversations about them) far less meaningful. I often found myself reading these great texts with the express goal of finishing them before lecture, even though I had looked forward to reading many of them for a long time; in the end, I feel like I never got to really enjoy or savor what makes these texts so great: their cultural background, their language, their stories, their influence. A better and richer understanding of the texts felt restricted by time, and I often found myself wishing that we had another week to discuss them, which sounds cheesy and corny and cringy but is ultimately true. All that being said, Hum 10 does expose you to a ginormous selection of texts, and for someone who came into Hum 10 without reading most of the texts on the syllabus, I do appreciate being familiar with these texts that are referenced so often.Seminar can be a little hit or miss I think. I liked my seminar both semesters, and the people in them are some of my close friends on campus, but I also think that Hum 10 is a class that encourages speaking in seminar for the sake of speaking and that punishes just listening to the insights that others have on texts. There's a broader problem, I feel, with the participation grade that is worth 25% of your grade each semester: we are never told our participation grade and are only given a vague overview of what goes into it ("eh it's like if you participate in seminar and writing lab and turn your stuff in on time and attend lecture"), which leads a lot of people to perhaps over–participate? I think that I sometimes found myself making a comment in seminar not because I was really dying to make the point but because I didn't want to say nothing for the entire seminar, and I was slightly concerned that someone would make the point before me.Writing lab does not teach you writing. I think this is one of the reasons that I still feel a little iffy about my decision to take Hum 10 over Expos 20; I am far from being a good writer, and I've heard that Expos (at least certain sections) are really good at teaching you how to write. I can say confidently that Hum 10 did not really teach me how to write, and I'm not sure if my writing has improved much over the course of this year. Maybe that's just me though. On a related note, essay grading can feel a little arbitrary; I'll say that I never received a grade that was wildly out of my expectation, but there was always a 3 grade range in which I had no idea where I would land. Feedback can also feel a little arbitrary and detached from the grade you receive. I'm also not sure if writing labs are standardized, but there definitely are some concerns with some writing labs having a TON of really great writers and the effect that might have on the grades you receive. This is complete hearsay though.The finals are brutal, mentally. They are eight hour finals during which you write two 1000–word essays, each of which must discuss two texts from the semester. We don't get written feedback on them, and, like above, the grading can feel a little arbitrary.I think this is my second–to–last but main substantive paragraph. The people (yes, cheesy) are honestly what makes me feel better about taking Hum 10. As someone who is not likely to take many humanities classes in the future, I'm really, really glad that I had the opportunity to meet all of the incredible people in Hum 10: professors are all incredible people and academics, TFs are wonderful and smart and insightful, and the students are super helpful and genuine and sweet. If you do take this class, don't be the person who doesn't talk to other people; suffer in company and talk to your fellow Hum 10ers. Truly some of the smartest and most genuine and deepest people I've had the privilege of meeting.If you're still deciding whether or not to take Hum 10, ask yourself why you want to take it, try reading one of the texts in a week, and think about whether you really have the time to devote to Hum 10. From personal experience and from comments I've heard, do not take the course a) if you don't feel super confident already in your writing ability, b) if you don't think you'll have the time/stamina to read a book a week earnestly, or c) if you are only/mostly taking the course for the prestige. Also consider whether a) you have read a lot in the past and b) your experience before college has prepared you to talk with lots of kids who went to prep schools (something I genuinely wish someone had talked to me about). Talk to lots (lots!) of people who have taken the course because almost everyone I know has a slightly different take. Best of luck if you do take the course. <3
worse_comment: Hum10 teaches you so much more than the basics of the humanities. It teaches you to think critically about history, life, death and the things we take for granted.
subject: Humanities
course_title_2023: A Humanities Colloquium: From Joyce to Homer

Also consider whether a) you have read a lot in the past and b) your experience before college has prepared you to talk with lots of kids who went to prep schools (something I genuinely wish someone had talked to me about). Truly some of the smartest and most genuine and deepest people I've had the privilege of meeting.If you're still deciding whether or not to take Hum 10, ask yourself why you want to take it, try reading one of the texts in a week, and think about whether you really have the time to devote to Hum 10. From personal experience and from comments I've heard, do not take the course a) if you don't feel super confident already in your writing ability, b) if you don't think you'll have the time/stamina to read a book a week earnestly, or c) if you are only/mostly taking the course for the prestige. Also consider whether a) you have read a lot in the past and b) your experience before college has prepared you to talk with lots of kids who went to prep schools (something I genuinely wish someone had talked to me about). Talk to lots (lots!) of people who have taken the course because almost everyone I know has a slightly different take. Best of luck if you do take the course. <3
worse_comment: Hum10 teaches you so much more than the basics of the humanities. It teaches you to think critically about history, life, death and the things we take for granted.

course_title: A Humanities Colloquium: From Ralph Ellison to Homer 001
best_comment: I will not be concentrating in the humanities, so take that as you will. The following is a little bit (too?) unfiltered, but I hope it doesn't get filtered out of the displayed comments (sorry in advance for the length; i'm still recovering from the final; for a tl;dr read the end i think).I have a lot of mixed opinions about Hum 10  — and a lot of my friends are tired of hearing me talk about my mixed feelings for Hum 10, so I'm excited to put some of them to words here. I think that Hum 10 is a really interesting class in general, and the vision for Hum 10 that is projected during info sessions and in group chats is certainly appealing; after all, a yearlong transformative experience through great texts seems to be the quintessential Harvard course, and the hype that is built up around it (not to mention the prestige it holds) makes it seem like a great and distinguished privilege to take the course.The course itself is not bad by any means, but I think that it is slightly different than the experience that I had originally expected. The work it takes to keep up with the breakneck pace at which you are expected to read books is not inherently a good reason to dislike the course; after all, there are giant warnings throughout the application process and in the general culture/buzz surrounding Hum 10 that it is "a book a week" and "only for humanities kids who would like to marry a book one day." But, the pace at which the course runs through texts can make the texts (and conversations about them) far less meaningful. I often found myself reading these great texts with the express goal of finishing them before lecture, even though I had looked forward to reading many of them for a long time; in the end, I feel like I never got to really enjoy or savor what makes these texts so great: their cultural background, their language, their stories, their influence. A better and richer understanding of the texts felt restricted by time, and I often found myself wishing that we had another week to discuss them, which sounds cheesy and corny and cringy but is ultimately true. All that being said, Hum 10 does expose you to a ginormous selection of texts, and for someone who came into Hum 10 without reading most of the texts on the syllabus, I do appreciate being familiar with these texts that are referenced so often.Seminar can be a little hit or miss I think. I liked my seminar both semesters, and the people in them are some of my close friends on campus, but I also think that Hum 10 is a class that encourages speaking in seminar for the sake of speaking and that punishes just listening to the insights that others have on texts. There's a broader problem, I feel, with the participation grade that is worth 25% of your grade each semester: we are never told our participation grade and are only given a vague overview of what goes into it ("eh it's like if you participate in seminar and writing lab and turn your stuff in on time and attend lecture"), which leads a lot of people to perhaps over–participate? I think that I sometimes found myself making a comment in seminar not because I was really dying to make the point but because I didn't want to say nothing for the entire seminar, and I was slightly concerned that someone would make the point before me.Writing lab does not teach you writing. I think this is one of the reasons that I still feel a little iffy about my decision to take Hum 10 over Expos 20; I am far from being a good writer, and I've heard that Expos (at least certain sections) are really good at teaching you how to write. I can say confidently that Hum 10 did not really teach me how to write, and I'm not sure if my writing has improved much over the course of this year. Maybe that's just me though. On a related note, essay grading can feel a little arbitrary; I'll say that I never received a grade that was wildly out of my expectation, but there was always a 3 grade range in which I had no idea where I would land. Feedback can also feel a little arbitrary and detached from the grade you receive. I'm also not sure if writing labs are standardized, but there definitely are some concerns with some writing labs having a TON of really great writers and the effect that might have on the grades you receive. This is complete hearsay though.The finals are brutal, mentally. They are eight hour finals during which you write two 1000–word essays, each of which must discuss two texts from the semester. We don't get written feedback on them, and, like above, the grading can feel a little arbitrary.I think this is my second–to–last but main substantive paragraph. The people (yes, cheesy) are honestly what makes me feel better about taking Hum 10. As someone who is not likely to take many humanities classes in the future, I'm really, really glad that I had the opportunity to meet all of the incredible people in Hum 10: professors are all incredible people and academics, TFs are wonderful and smart and insightful, and the students are super helpful and genuine and sweet. If you do take this class, don't be the person who doesn't talk to other people; suffer in company and talk to your fellow Hum 10ers. Truly some of the smartest and most genuine and deepest people I've had the privilege of meeting.If you're still deciding whether or not to take Hum 10, ask yourself why you want to take it, try reading one of the texts in a week, and think about whether you really have the time to devote to Hum 10. From personal experience and from comments I've heard, do not take the course a) if you don't feel super confident already in your writing ability, b) if you don't think you'll have the time/stamina to read a book a week earnestly, or c) if you are only/mostly taking the course for the prestige. Also consider whether a) you have read a lot in the past and b) your experience before college has prepared you to talk with lots of kids who went to prep schools (something I genuinely wish someone had talked to me about). Talk to lots (lots!) of people who have taken the course because almost everyone I know has a slightly different take. Best of luck if you do take the course. <3
worse_comment: Hum10 teaches you so much more than the basics of the humanities. It teaches you to think critically about history, life, death and the things we take for granted.

course_title: Place and Planet: Mahindra Scholars Lab 001
best_comment: Take all comments with a grain of caution as this is the course's first iteration. I came into Hum93 excited to continue on the fantastic experience I enjoyed in Hum90; unfortunately, not only did the course connect poorly with its predecessor but it also did not appear as a fully formed course. While many of the weeks were enjoyable and taught valuable lessons in how to look at the world in novel ways, the course did not have an arch with central take aways. The assignments were vague and rarely did we receive feedback.  Engaging with the other students is the best component. I hope that the next cohort receives a more complete course.
worse_comment: The course was well–intentioned but often felt like it had no direction or overarching theme (we were supposed to be studying phenology but never properly learned what that meant). The assignments were graded FAR too harshly though, especially given that we had very little direction on them and got virtually no feedback.

best_comment: I loved learning ASL with Anbo. I enjoy it much more than the other foreign language classes I have taken and feel I have gained a lot by learning some ASL.
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: Go to office hours. They are super fun and super helpful. The best way to practice is to do a little bit every day.
worse_comment: Do not take this class. While you will learn something, this semester is significantly slower than the last. The disorganization is enough stress in and of itself and the work that has to be done outside the classroom (essentially constantly playing catchup) is exhausting and wasteful.
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: This course was fantastic and almost too easy. The material is fascinating and the professor was engaging and dedicated as a teacher. I say too easy because we only had five problem sets, no section, and at times that made me feel like I would've understood some of the material better if we'd had a little more resources / work on it. But I really appreciated the way Prof. Singerman tailored the material to the group and our interests, even in such a large class. Overall such a wonderful gem. This is the type of class that very concretely changed my understanding of the world, the type I would bring up fun facts from in conversation.
worse_comment: This class was an interesting introduction into linguistics that had a relatively low workload. Most of the concepts were pretty straightforward, but sometimes the coursework was a bit dull.
best_gem_comment: This course was fantastic and almost too easy. The material is fascinating and the professor was engaging and dedicated as a teacher. I say too easy because we only had five problem sets, no section, and at times that made me feel like I would've understood some of the material better if we'd had a little more resources / work on it. But I really appreciated the way Prof. Singerman tailored the material to the group and our interests, even in such a large class. Overall such a wonderful gem. This is the type of class that very concretely changed my understanding of the world, the type I would bring up fun facts from in conversation.
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: It’s really a hit or a miss. The first half of the course made me want to bang my head against a wall, but the second half was great. The first half taught me a valuable lesson: don’t try to design a curriculum around a passion project that does not appeal to a wide audience. (So I guess that is to say, don’t design a course around a passion project.) The department tried to do this with writing systems, and consequently, eleven people were bored silly. I will say, though, it opened my eyes to just how many layers there are to writing systems, and I enjoyed designing a writing system of my own (which was like doing a fun puzzle). And the TF put a lot of effort into the course. The homework was also fun.But the second half was indeed great. Learning how to use Excel was valuable, and I loved writing a critical review. Learning to read papers carefully and thoughtfully is crucial to succeeding in linguistics, and the TF did a wonderful job of teaching us how to do this. Also, OT is very cool. I had fun doing the OT problems the TF gave us. Lots of effort on her part as well.
worse_comment: I would tell them not to take it. They should wait for the junior tutorial if they can so that they can develop more in their linguistics knowledge. The course was boring and uninteresting in the second semester so I would avoid it especially if it was taught by the same tf.
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: This class was okay. One of those cases of a terrific professor’s being assigned to a fairly dull curriculum but making the most of it. The material was a bit dry at times, but this truly wasn’t her fault. Having Professor Wurmbrand for LING 102 was like eating a meal cooked by a world–class chef but made using somewhat lousy ingredients.The pedagogy was so powerful and well thought out. The homework was very useful to do and drew upon everything we learned, brought it all together — very well designed. I definitely liked the assignments from  the first half a bit better, but that’s just because I didn’t enjoy the material from the second half of the course. Again, not the professor’s fault. Additionally, the exams were really interesting. A challenge, in the best way possible.Talk to the DUS about using morphology for this core requirement, but if you definitely have to take this class, take it with Professor Wurmbrand. She’s amazing! Gave us a real glimpse into how scientists build models, find flaws in those models, and then improve them. Also, she and the TF were transparent with us about the flaws in the models we were learning, about how the field is very much a work in progress, which I loved. So the course was really as good as a syntax course was going to get. Again, if you’re going to take syntax, try to take it with Professor Wurmbrand. She’s so good!
worse_comment: Take this course if you are already interested in syntax. Otherwise, don't take it at all. Will not foster a love for the subject, more of an apathy. Made me not want to pursue Linguistics as  a concentration at all!!

best_comment: I would highly recommend this class, especially if you can take it with Professor Sag! She is extremely smart and cares a lot about student feedback, which makes her a fantastic professor. The assignments for this course are very fair and do a good job of helping to make sure that no one falls behind in the class over the course of the semester, even as you engage with more challenging topics. This course was great in the sense that I genuinely learned a lot from it while also feeling like it had a very manageable workload. Overall, this was an excellent course!
worse_comment: This is a great course! The concepts can be challenging, but the problem sets are very manageable.
best_gem_comment: A chill and fantastic intro to semantics, from someone who did not have a linguistics background. The course is accessible, fun, and has deep connections to concepts in CS/math/logic. The instructor is also super sweet and helpful, truly a gem!

best_comment: If you are interested at all in how linguistics is done practically, take this course. Even if your interests are in theory or (for example) in historical linguistics, which might seem unrelated to fieldwork, learning about a language from the ground up is fun, exciting, and valuable, and I would not pass up the opportunity.
If you have a strong background in semantics, you can get a lot out of this class!
If you have a strong background in semantics, you can get a lot out of this class!
To be honest, the course seems like a miscellaneous assortment of topics, put together to make a second semester phonology course for grad students.
subject: Linguistics

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 001
best_comment: Honestly this class is very time consuming. 3 psets a week on top of all your other classes is a drag. If this class is a requirement, you just sort of have to get through it. The TFs and CAs are great. But the way the course is designed is a little harsh. I would recommend going to office hours instead of MQC if you can. MQC gets so crowded and you spend hours in there..while office hours is more 1 on 1 with the TFs which is nice. The TFs are extremely nice and want you to succeed which is a huge plus!
worse_comment: Take this class if you feel like high school calculus wasn't that great for you, or if you never took calculus before. The community is great, the TFs are great, and the friends you will make are great! Just because you take this course doesn't mean you'll be behind, you will realize that you are not alone in your journey.

course_title: Quantitative Analysis for Economics and the Social Sciences II 001
best_comment: This is a fantastic course to take, and I highly recommend this course if you are looking for an introductory mathematics course. The course can be challenging, but there is plenty of support available and willing to help you through any difficulties you encounter. One of the course's advantages is that it blends mathematics with real–world situations like climate change and planning for retirement, into activities and projects that are both engaging and informative. I am very glad I took this course!
worse_comment: My experience in this course has been invaluable. This course has forever shifted the way I think about everyday problems. I now am able to approach a problem with a quantitative lens and break it down in order to piece together an analysis of the problem and potential ways to move forward. Through projects and teamwork, we have learned mathematics through the application of real–world problems rather than imaginary word problems from a textbook. I have already seen how useful the skills I have learned in this class truly are as they have helped me on other assignments and in my internship/jobs.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Quantitative Analysis for Economics and the Social Sciences II

best_comment: The grading model for this amazing, as it emphasizes a learning–based approach. It extremely motivating  that you can work on learning objectives throughout the semester and re–test your skills when you make errors on the last course. This method of test–taking, paired the with completion/effort–based pset grading made the focus of the course much less about the stress of perfect arithmetic, and much more about the calculus at hand. I learned just as much if not more than I would have in a course that had standard grading and test taking model. TAKE THIS COURSE. Professor Nathanson is incredible, and I strongly disliked calculus in high school and LOVED it this past semester. Amazing opportunity for growth and is low stress if you put the work in!
worse_comment: A lot of people will need to take this course for various requirements. It's fine and the mastery–based grading helps kids succeed, but the overall teaching quality is somewhat poor. It can be especially confusing/problematic if you didn't have a great high school math background.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: I loved the way this course was structured this semester! I had a lot of people warn me against taking this class at all costs, but they were referring to the class having 2 midterms and a cumulative final. This semester was different with 5 lower stakes exams and a non–cumulative final only covering the newer topics seen since assessment 5. I enjoyed having the assessments every two weeks which covered less material and it allowed for me to study each topic with greater depth rather than breadth. This allowed me to feel very prepared for each and every exam with very low stress levels which was great. I also appreciated the learning goal system since it allowed for more opportunities to retest to achieve mastery in each topic. Hakim and all the TFs were super accessible during office hours and I was never left with any doubts. I also really appreciated the help I received at the Math Question Center. I enjoyed having the Problems of the Week which were fun ways that challenged my problem solving skills while getting extra credit added to my final grade! I highly recommend taking this. I had been placed in math 1a coming into Harvard, but I decided to jump into math 1b having only taken AP Calc AB and I was able to do very well!
worse_comment: Do not get behind on the weekly pset. Try not to do it on the day it is due, big mistake.

best_comment: This class is a great one, albeit will take you a lot of time — Dusty and Brendan are incredible professors and so kind as well. Make sure you keep on top of your PSETs and assignments, and find a good PSET group! That will make all the difference.
worse_comment: There are way too many problem sets. But plan out time to go to office hours since there's no MQC for this course. The take–home exams relieves so much stress, but psets are just way too much work. My semester has been consumed by this class just because the amount of time I spend on 4 psets a week.

best_comment: 21A is a great course! The overall structure and course policies are generally pretty favorable. Exams aren't too bad; in my experience they're decently lenient with the grading. You also get to retest objectives that you missed, which is nice. Section is not mandatory, but you should definitely go if you want to be successful in the class. The CAs are super helpful both in section and outside of it. PSets are usually not that hard but can be pretty long and tedious. You do get 3 free late days and can earn more throughout the semester though. Overall I really enjoyed the class!
worse_comment: The learning targets are a source of unessecary stress, and the fact that you can only miss one or two to get an a is really stressful.
subject: Mathematics

subject: Mathematics

best_comment: PLEASE TAKE THIS CLASS. The sense of fulfillment it will bring you is exceedingly difficult to find, and taking this class is a beautiful experience. I came into this class after having taken math classes earlier in college and struggling to the point where I became disenchanted with them. If you’re in these shoes as well, I beg you to take this class. You will fall back in love with math. It might even change the path you take in college. It’s changed mine.I’d heard linear algebra was useful and widely applicable, but I had no idea just how much that was the case. And I can safely say that there were many moments where I sat in class and simply marveled at just how powerful the material I was learning was. Is this class hard? Yes. But you will have so much support from so many exceedingly patient and helpful CAs and TFs, and you will have so many resources at your disposal. If the textbook doesn’t help you understand something, lecture will. If lecture doesn’t, the videos posted on Canvas will. If the videos don’t, the course staff will. So on and so forth. There are so many office hours as well. You’ll never need to worry about not having enough in–person office hours to attend. And come finals, you’ll have review sessions to attend. Janet (the course head) even sent out articles on how to overcome nerves around taking tests, how to answer true–false questions, etc. YOU WILL HAVE SO MANY RESOURCES AT YOUR DISPOSAL. The course staff sets students up to succeed.Also, Janet basically designed a system where we could benefit from learning. For example, we got a pset drop for every three quiz sessions we attended. (By the way, at quiz sessions, students take NON–GRADED quizzes and talk through them with CAs as a full group. Very helpful!) And we were given another option re: to how to weigh the midterm grades if we filled out a survey where we assessed how we could learn the material more effectively. So you’ll be encouraged to learn and to learn to learn effectively. In fact, you’ll be rewarded for it.And the problem sets set students up to learn effectively. They tie everything together so nicely and always have a clear purpose. Also, they are REALLY fun. There are even extra credit problems for those who wish to gain a deeper understanding of certain material just because.Do yourself a favor — whether you like math or just want to become a better student and thinker, PLEASE TAKE THIS CLASS.
worse_comment: If there was any way to possibly avoid this class I would highly suggest you take it. This course is unlike any other math class at Harvard. If you're coming from 21a and have becoming accustomed to group work and collaboration on the worksheets, be ready to sit and work through all your issues alone. Be ready for daily problem sets that can take anywhere form 3–6 hours each, and occur three times a week. Be ready to read the textbook after your p–set as well, because the next class will inevitably jump right into material — a completely unnecessary form of teaching in my opinion, especially given how long my TF would let us struggle individually with a problem. Then, you get to struggle with 3 exams that are worth the vast majority of your grade and graded unbelievable harshly. This course is the complete opposite of 21a where I also found some difficulty, but always felt supported and allowed to make mistakes. In 21b, you'll lose points for not simplifying on an exam, getting the right answer, but making one mistake in your explanation and the whole question might be marked wrong. Don't take this course. It's not worth it.,
