course_title: Vector Calculus and Linear Algebra II 001
best_comment: This course felt a little chaotic and disorganized, but the content was interesting. Oliver is a great teacher who makes time to meet with students one–on–one and in small groups, and the CAs were very helpful! Make sure to go to office hours outside of class to ask clarifying questions, and know that you spend a fair amount of time reviewing linear algebra at the beginning of the semester before starting the vector calculus aspect of the course (so if you are in a physics course concurrently, you might need to self–study a little to keep up. I did this, and it was manageable). If Dusty is teaching next year, I imagine it would be much more similar to 22a, which was a fantastic course, and I would recommend checking out the Q Report for 22a from 2021 to get a better idea of what the course would be like. Either way, I would recommend this course.
worse_comment: Don't take this class. It's just not fun. I love math, and it's not fun.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Vector Calculus and Linear Algebra II

course_title: Theoretical Linear Algebra and Real Analysis II 001
best_comment: Math 25b with Wes is a wonderful class. The material is so insanely well taught. Wes's strength is in analysis so he motivates examples and provides intuition really well. The lectures are very good, and he answers all questions during the lectures. However, this results in the fact that most classes end around five minutes over time, and additional videos may be posted if the material isn't completely covered. Also, this class was a 9AM three times a week (with no recordings), so just make sure you're prepared for this. The community is really great, and many students in this class actually did not come from a high school math background but were more so interested in fields that require knowledge of real analysis. Because of this, a collaborative environment was fostered. I think it's really important to find people to pset with, if not the most important. Definitely definitely attend Wes's office hours. He is an amazing professor but also such a kind person, and it's very nice to get to know him! He can also clarify gaps in your knowledge about lecture material. For psets, I think it's more helpful to go to the CAs office hours since you can collaborate with students, but Wes gives great intuition behind how to solve the problems. This class is extremely rewarding, in my opinion, if you put in the time. Because the psets are not graded harshly, it felt that a lot of my energy was spent truly learning the material instead of perfecting pset solutions like in some other classes. Overall, this class is tough but rewarding. Make sure you're interested in this class for some reason, make sure you allocate enough time for the class and think about what you want to gain from this class before taking it!
worse_comment: Start your problem sets early, do them with a friend, and go to office hours. Ask questions in class. Math is hard to understand. There's no point in pretending to understand when you don't.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Theoretical Linear Algebra and Real Analysis II

course_title: Studies in Real and Complex analysis 001
best_comment: Math 55B was a very interesting course. First of all, Prof. Auroux is wonderful. He's incredibly accessible and cares about making sure people are doing well. He is going to be in France next year, but I'm sure whoever is teaching 55 in 2022–2023 will be great! The material is really beautiful (although you can certainly have more of a taste for certain things than others), and it feels ever–so–slightly more chill than 55A.The material is honestly quite interesting. Topology – and especially algebraic topology – is a fundamental discipline to basically anything, and Auroux's presentation of complex analysis is very good for getting you to appreciate just how beautiful of a subject it is. Full disclosure, I am not the biggest analysis fan – I liked alg top far more – and I didn't have any experience with real analysis. Yet, often during the two weeks we talked about real analysis, there was a general sentiment of "yeah this is all stuff we should know." The point being: this class is technically an introduction to all these fields, but unless you're ready and willing to make it the center of your spring semester, it won't be a very comfortable introduction.The psets were also generally fun. There were some questions that definitely should have been marked as challenge problems that were simply not, but beyond that they were good. Do start psets early, or at least look at them early – it takes time for things to sit and be mulled over in your head! The exams can be a big source of stress, but I think they were generally easier than in 55A – analysis at this level is often "done on autopilot," in that there's only so many tricks you can try before something ends up working. Overall, try to stay on top of the material – it is much harder than you expect to catch up if you fall behind, speaking from experience.On the other hand, the class environment in 55B is... less than stellar. Your best hope is to find a good group of people to pset with that aren't magnets for drama, but in my case, there was so much drama going on that I didn't go to lecture for a very long time. 55 attracts a very specific kind of person – generally, people who enjoy suffering, or enjoy watching other suffer around them, and people who, as mathematicians, haven't quite mellowed out from the cutthroat, competitive, and prestige–centric attitude that high school math things breed. If I could have taken the class entirely remotely, I probably would have.So, should you take 55B? First, I don't think 55A is a strict prerequisite, but definitely a soft one – the familiarity with group theory is essential for alg top. And as my experience goes, I think there's basically no barrier to entry, save for how much time you're ready to put into it. If you want math to be the center of your spring semester, then go for it. If not, then take 25B or 22B, or whatever is best for you (you'll quickly realize that if prestige is what you're shooting for, your mental and physical wellbeing are high costs to pay for it). In any case, good luck with your decision and whatever you choose to do!
worse_comment: Auroux's version of this course is significantly harder than his version of 55a. Work through MIT OCW 18.02 (multivar, the number might be wrong) through winter break or at some point before taking this course because while this course has no "formal prerequisites" multivar is essentially a must. Also prepare yourself for weeks 8 and 9 where everything goes insanely fast.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Studies in Real and Complex analysis

course_title: Reading Course for Senior Honors Candidates 001
best_comment: It's a great way to free up time for your thesis, but its up to you to actually use that extra time for thesis work.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Reading Course for Senior Honors Candidates

best_comment: Math 101 is extremely accessible to anyone with calc BC knowledge, and no proof–writing experience is necessary. It is a great place to start if you are considering a math or math–related concentration. Professor Mavraki does a terrific job of introducing students to the material while also honing their proof–writing and abstract thinking skills. Also, the material overall is very interesting, and can completely change the way one thinks about mathematics. Great course, 10/10 recommend to anyone with an interest in math or even just a curiosity about abstract thinking or theory.
worse_comment: You can get through this course if you want to, but you'll work pretty hard. If you've never written any proofs (as I hadn't), the first 3 to 4 lectures will be hell. After that, each lecture will be hell for everyone anyway so you'll be level with everyone else. The content is super interesting though, and looking back, I learned more in this course than any other course I've ever taken.

best_comment: Overall, this is a great class –– if you are at all interested in theoretical math and especially if it is still being taught by Dr. Balibanu, definitely take it. This class is accessible to a fairly wide range of math backgrounds, has a good balance of definitions and interesting results (i.e. not too many of the former and plenty of the latter), and the problem solving on the PSets and exams is mostly satisfying. I'll now get into more detail about what I felt were this class' pros and cons.Pros:– Lectures. Dr. Balibanu does an amazing job explaining difficult concepts so that everyone can understand them. Coming from a limited math background (only previous math courses were 21a/b, with some proof–writing experience), I was somewhat apprehensive about my level of preparation for the class. The most out of place I ever felt was occasionally when she would ask, "who here has at least heard of concept X," to which most of the class excluding me raised their hands. However, she would go on to then clearly explain the concept and how it related to the material at hand. Despite my minimal prior math experience, I found the lectures very clear and easy to follow. This was especially evident when trying to self–teach myself the concepts from textbooks –– the lectures were significantly easier to learn from.– Course content. Obviously this is very subjective, but complex analysis lies at the intersection of many areas of math wherein many interesting results are fairly easily accessible, without needing to get bogged down in too many definitions. The class is at face value an extension of multivariable calculus to the complex numbers, and it provides very nice ways to think about otherwise difficult problems such as the fundamental theorem of algebra, certain real–valued integrals and infinite sums, and the Riemann zeta function. It is clear that the concepts of complex analysis are very useful for future areas in math, but even if you're not planning on continuing to study math, they are also pretty fun to learn/think about in and of themselves.– Course staff. As previously mentioned, Dr. Balibanu is a great lecturer. She is also generally very accessible in office hours and in Slack, and the TFs are similarly helpful, especially in the resources and review sessions they have before tests.– Grading. The grading for this course is half PSets and half exams. The PSets can be tricky and occasionally take a while, but office hours are great in helping to get through them, and they are graded leniently. The exams are very fair –– the problems are often easier versions of those from the PSets, and lots of points are given just for remembering definitions (btw –– when studying, make sure to know all the results, especially those with names).Cons:– Course materials. Outside of lecture, the only real supplementary course resource is the textbook which, as I previously mentioned, can be difficult to learn from. This is fine if you go to all the lectures and take good notes, but there are no lecture notes/recordings to help catch you up to speed if you don't (though this was Dr. Balibanu's first iteration of the course, so maybe this will change).– Feedback. The only feedback given is the PSet and exam grades. The exams were graded pretty quickly, which was appreciated. However, the PSets often took many weeks to be returned, which especially mattered given that there were (generally) no PSet solutions available other than by going to TFs during office hours and asking for explanations.– Computational homework problems. The PSets were a mix of conceptual and computational problems. While the conceptual problems were generally good concept review, the computational problems sometimes became tedious and felt like busywork.
worse_comment: This class is fairly difficult and Ana does not offer practice exams or answers to pset problems, so it is hard to study for exams.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This was Laurent Cote's first time teaching, so there were a small but nontrivial number of typos in assignments and exams were not very well written. That said, I think he is a good instructor and that the course is good. I have full confidence that in a second iteration of the course, these details will be ironed out and the course will be much better.One recommendation I have (especially if the course is offered at 9 am again) is to attend lecture! This course is not so hard, but it is not one which can be learned just by reading notes online (which can be a bit hard to read). If you have trouble waking up or just generally do not attend lecture, I would advise you choose a different course. But the course is very good and different from just about any other math course at Harvard. It is an excellent way to fulfill the Math requirement for those who want something a bit harder than Math 112 but probably not quite as hard as Math 114.
worse_comment: Laurent is great! Only complaint would be that I wasted a decent number of hours in my life due to mistakes in the problem statements in the homeworks.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This class is much more proof–based than something like Math 21b, and I would recommend having 21b under your belt beforehand, because without it, material in proof format can seem much more confusing. Dylan was great and super helpful, though not sure what this class under another professor would be like.
worse_comment: This is a very difficult class that is very chill if you want it to be. ONLY take this class if you really want to learn math AND are VERY self–guided.

course_title: Algebra II: Theory of Rings and Fields 001
best_comment: A fairly standard math course covering quadratic number fields and Galois theory – covers roughly chapters 13 and 16 of Artin. It wasn't quite my cup of tea, but the assignments were fair and Mark was a very good professor.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Algebra II: Theory of Rings and Fields

best_comment: Professor Mazur is great! You should take a class with him if you have the chance — he really focuses on the main ideas, letting the textbook and homework fill in some of the details. I thought his style of teaching gave me a better overall understanding of the course material without sacrificing any precision. He supplements the lectures with great lecture notes, which come in handy when reviewing for the final. They're very clear, and much less dense than Marcus (the textbook). Also, don't be worried about the in–person final — I actually think it's better than a take–home exam. It forces you to review the whole course without being super stressful, and as a result I think I learned the material a lot better!
worse_comment: By the end of this course I came to realize that many of the theorems learned are very interesting and deep and that algebraic number theory is fascinating. However, this Math 129 was badly structured and that prevented the course from being enjoyable at all. First, we were assigned weekly reading from Marcus' "Number Fields" textbook. I don't have anything against reading some pages every week, but the fact that lectures covered the same material as the readings did (sometimes slightly less, professor Mazur often skipped details, focused on irrelevant concepts, or just presented too slowly) made going to lecture basically useless. It also didn't help that Marcus was an EXTREMELY BORING read. I believe that the course could have been structured in a way that avoided the reading assignments and instead present in class only the key results without going into all of the boring details. Second, homework was badly designed: everybody complained about the length of it and I found many exercises to be there just for the sake of maintaining the assignments at a certain length. On the bright side, the presentation part of the course was not bad: I learned some very interesting applications of algebraic number theory while doing research for my presentation. Overall, I would recommend the course for its material, but I would avoid taking it with professor Mazur, unless he changes the course structure. It was a shame that the course wasn't on par with Mazur's expertise in the field.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This class was very time–consuming between homework, flipped classroom self–teaching, preparing math presentations for the class, preparing Greek translations for the class, and projects. And there wasn't much of a break from work –– often, I would be at dinner and I'd get an email telling me I had to give a presentation on a new topic the next morning. I appreciate Paul's enthusiasm for (and knowledge of) the material, but I did not enjoy Math 130.And to this day, I don't understand why such a big part of the class was learning Ancient Greek. It was not at all essential for learning the math. But if you like Ancient Greek, you will love this class...
worse_comment: Avoid this course. There is no focus on concepts, and you will spend every week stressing out over the undecipherable homework problems, lecture notes, and other materials. Moreover, Bamberg assumes a base knowledge of Greek morphology and R coding, which are not listed as requirements– no time will be spent actually teaching you either of these, but you will be heavily graded on your ability to utilize them on the frequent in–class presentations (for the Greek) and homework problems. The geometries being studied are presented without any motivation, there is no structure presented for studying these geometries– most students were stressed out every week because we had no idea what was going on, and had to rely heavily on the CA to help us figure exactly what was being asked. The questions on the homework were almost always easy, but never provided deeper insight or understanding into the concepts being discussed.  This class was the biggest waste of time of my Harvard career.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Differential topology is amazing, and if you want to get into the more geometric fields of mathematics at a high level, a solid background in differential topology is a must.
worse_comment: Overall I think this is a great course that I learned a lot from. If you are interested in the subject and have a LOT of time to sprae you should take it. This is the most I've learned from a math course at Harvard. Gaitsgory has a reputation of being a student–eater that doesn't care at all about students, but he's actually a nice guy and does really care that you understand the material. The psets are difficult, but you learn so much from them as they are more fundamental questions about the subject. We did cover a lot of material, and if you're expecting the courseload to be reasonable you shouldn't take this course since the psets regularly take more than 20 hours to complete.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This is a nice class, good intro to classical algebraic geometry. Expect a lot of algebra, and less geometry. More algebra than something like algebraic topology. While it's not a prerequisite, I would say it would be helpful to be confident in the fruits and veggies of Math 131 Topology and basic algebra stuff about rings / fields.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This is not a commonly taught topic as far as math classes go, so I'm sure you will learn a lot and have fun too! Would be helpful to have some combinatorics background, in particular graph theory, game theory, and Ramsey theory. There will also be references made to classical results in algebra, such as properties of the natural numbers, vector spaces, and group theory.

Be wary with this course— especially if Professor Bamberg is teaching. The psets were given out on Thursdays—if not later— then they were due the following Tuesday. You will have to teach yourself just about everything in this course, and the workload is much larger than you would expect(expect a pset during reading week). It is definitely an interesting course that being said and if you are interested in math, CS, or have an advanced algebra requirement I would recommend this course so long as you are not taking a crazy courseload otherwise.
worse_comment: Would recommend taking CS20 instead of this. The class was poorly run, section was run in an unconventional and confusing manner, some topics were strange/not applicable,  and the apps used in the class are frustrating and unhelpful.  The one source of help/clarity was our TF who was fantastic, but not sure if she will be around next year/in future iterations of the course.

best_comment: This class provides a great mathematical foundation for probability theory, however that's not why most people take this course. Most people take this course because they don't wish to take Stat110, for fear that it is too hard, or at least harder than this course. If this is your worry, I highly encourage you to think twice about taking this course. Though on paper this course may be less of a time commitment than Stat110, there are other negatives to it that Stat110 doesn't have. For instance, there are very, very few people who take this course, so chances are you're PSETting and studying on your own. This class has only one TF while Stat110 has much more and all who are very committed to the class. Foremostly, Stat110 prepares you to take more Stat classes at Harvard and leaves the door open for doing a Stats concentration. Math154 course doesn't count towards Stats requirements. As a disclaimer, however, I've never taken Stat110 – this is just what I've heard and seen from friends and people around me. But in summary: Math154 is a good course, but I suggest you take Stat110.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Take this course!!!! (Or any course with Piotr! He’s an amazing teacher). This course is a great excuse to casually learn about cool math twice a week and I think anyone who takes it will really love it.

Take this class! It's a bunch of fun math problems. The homework are challenging enough so that it's not boring, but not too challenging where it seems impossible when you look at it. Sasha is the best, and the whole course staff is very nice. Going to office hours is very useful. Would highly recommend.
worse_comment: You get exposed to a lot of topics in math that other classes don't teach, and the environment is really chill, so I ended up learning a lot
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: H.T. Yau is incredibly knowledgeable and a great lecturer. Work load is manageable.
worse_comment: I would say that Prof. (HT) Yau's teaching has some pluses and minuses: on the plus side, he tells you a lot of useful things about what theorems and proof techniques are important and a lot of things about how he thinks about math in general, but on the minus side, the homeworks are not posted regularly and vary a lot in length and difficulty (the first one was trivial, but they get harder), and the final homework in particular seemed like kind of a mess (in the end all the issues were sorted out, but up until a few days before it was due, there was a problem that was beyond the scope of the class that eventually got removed, a lot of typos, some missing assumptions, two problems that were slightly changed, etc.)
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Fabian's 229 was amazing. He didn't follow any text, but despite that, the class was really well designed!! The material flowed really intuitively, he structures his lectures in subparts and numbers everything, so your notes are always really organized and easy to look back at. He's really enthusiastic, and the topic is really interesting. This is one of the few analysis classes at Harvard, but the quality doesn't suffer at all from the deficit.

This class was the highlight of my semester, and I highly recommend taking it, especially if Puskar is teaching. It was never too stressful, but I learned a ton and it greatly supplemented the other GR material that I had seen. I can's sing praises for this class or for Puskar enough, but it truly was a great experience.

This was a wonderful course!! Prof. Hopkins is an incredible lecturer, and I highly recommend going to the lectures (no matter who teaches it next semester). Even though is is really busy (being the head of the math dept.), he makes time for his 231 students and his office hours are very fun! Also, Sanath Devalapurkar, our CA, is great; he's super helpful, accessible, and does a good job complementing Prof. Hopkins' perspectives.The material in this class is very beautiful... if abstract homotopy theory is your thing. I'd recommend having a working knowledge of category theory (i.e. going through Riehl's Category Theory in Context ch. 1–4 would be slightly overkill, but the definitions in those chapters shouldn't be unfamiliar), and a good familiarity with the computations of (co)homology.  The material definitely starts off deceptively slow, but by the time we got to spectral sequences, things were moving at a good pace. Just be prepared to be doing algebra and not geometry – that's what Paul Seidel's 18.906 is for (so I've heard). There are tons of typos in the lecture notes/psets, but as a class, we put the lecture notes on overleaf, so we would all go through and correct things – some students even added substantial exposition of things they found confusing or interesting, which was super helpful! The psets are really interesting though, and aren't a lot of work – I wouldn't get started the day they're due, because it can take some time to think about, but they're not bad at all.Overall, this class has a lot of community, very cool material, and teaches you some useful life skills (like how to use the Serre spectral sequence and the basics of ∞–categories, which are objectively useful life skills in math). Definitely take it!
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This is a great course to take! Don't be scared of the high course number –– it is quite friendly for varying levels of math prowess. Depending on what you want to do for your final project, some subset of probability and statistics, programming (ability to run computer simulations and code up algorithms), and techniques for mathematical proofs/analytical derivations is helpful to know. This is definitely a course where what you put into it is what you get out of it.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This class was fantastic!

This is a very exciting course that will teach you many things about algebraic curves specifically, but also many other topics in algebraic geometry in general, as well as important techniques that you can apply to various aspects of math.Definitely take this course if offered, or any other class with Professor Harris. He is a spectacular, very charismatic lecturer with an unparalleled understanding of the material, including its conception and valuable insights into its application.

course_title: Qualitative and Quantitative Analysis of the Biological Literature 001
best_comment: Although the class if Pass/Fail, take course seriously as it truly is what you put into it. You can become a much better researcher by taking the class with some seriousness and learn a lot of experimental set–up and design. Also, the faculty are truly incredible and do your best to get valuable information from them.
worse_comment: Participate in class. The worst thing is when people don't participate and you have the same 1 or 2 people talking. Maybe you're wrong, that's okay, I guarantee you it won't be the last time you're wrong in the PhD process. Your peers won't judge you, some of them probably have the same interpretation and could learn from you.

course_title: Qualitative and Quantitative Analysis of the Biological Literature 001

You can become a much better researcher by taking the class with some seriousness and learn a lot of experimental set–up and design. Your peers won't judge you, some of them probably have the same interpretation and could learn from you.

You can become a much better researcher by taking the class with some seriousness and learn a lot of experimental set–up and design. Also, the faculty are truly incredible and do your best to get valuable information from them.

best_comment: Great class in terms of depth and breadth of metabolism––you will learn plenty and be exposed to a variety of pathology–related metabolism research (from that on obesity to cancer to immunomodulation, e.g.). BUT be prepared to be a very active student in and outside of class––be ready to commit 3–6 hours weekly outside of class to truly internalize the material (whether studying the material or working on a case response, which have often required extensive literature searches), to frequently discuss in–class activities every day of class (which will shape 35% of your final grade), and to spend 2–3 weeks learning about a metabolic pathway of your choice for your student presentation. If you do not do these things, the class can easily be a GPA dropper. So, the class is both fascinating and effortful––important to keep in mind as you maximize your learning opportunities as a student, balance this class with others, and strive to protect/maintain a particular GPA.
worse_comment: I would tell them that this class has interesting content, but the management of the course and treatment of students is extremely frustrating.
subject: Biolog Chem & Molecular Pharm

course_title: Molecular Biology of the Bacterial Cell 001
best_comment: If you're joining a bacterial lab or just interested in bacteriology fundamentals, take this course. I really appreciated the dedication and time that the professors put into the course, making it challenging yet do–able, and I felt so much more knowledgeable and confident after having taken this course. I actually ended up loving the class format, since it made me comfortable with talking through experiments and ideas out loud with others. The classroom environment was encouraging, creative, and rigorous. I cannot recommend this course enough and I will really miss taking this course.

best_comment: I wanted to love this class but didn't. The patient presentations and guest lectures were extremely interesting and insightful but everything else felt very chaotic– there were only two assignments (a presentation and take–home final). The presentation was pretty straightforward, although we got zero feedback on it (no grade, comments, etc). The final exam was supposed to take three hours but took me far longer than that as I had no idea what the expectations were in terms of length/specificity/etc. It felt like the course instructors were putting in minimal effort to the course (makes sense since they are all very accomplished). Would not recommend to college students for course credit as it caused more stress than it was worth. If anything, I wish I had audited on the patient days and not taken for credit. Keep in mind that the trip to Longwood can be long, especially on the 9:30pm ending nights.

best_comment: While the topics of this course are undoubtedly interesting, this is unfortunately the most disorganized course I have taken at Harvard, and perhaps the most disorganized course I have heard of. While the course syllabus said to no prior experience with coding ML is necessary (and we were told “we will teach you all the ML you need” in the very first lecture), the two short tutorials we had on ML in which we very loosely went over already written code was not helpful at all in grasping the skills that we would inevitably need for the projects. The first two assignments had less to do with ML and more to do with debugging long and unintelligible code. The project topics were already set and limited, but for some reason we were not allowed to work in groups (which to me feels very counter to the collaborative nature of true research), so we ended up in this weird situation where many people would be working on effectively the same project, but independently, which made the project feel more like a problem set rather than original research. However, unlike an actual problem set, the prompt and the requirements were much more up in the air and little help was provided. The feedback we received for proposals/midterm reports was minimal and in all honesty not that helpful. A lot of the times our slack messages would remain unanswered, and the ony TF of the class only had OH one hour per week (for a class with 75+ people!) so you couldn’t really get to speak with him for more than 5 minutes, and the OHs on the last two weeks before the project deadline (which is probably the time period during which we needed the most help!) were canceled. I know from discussions from my classmates that for both them and me, often times working on the project became borderline depressing since we had no idea what to do, which resources to use, and where to even start. Overall, I really enjoyed the topics covered by the lectures and also the readings I did for the project, but I really felt discouraged while working on it and didn’t really learn much due to the lack of resources and guidance. This course has great potential (the setup of it is really perfect for a computational neuro course), but it needs a serious reorganization if students are going to get anything out of it. More OH (and maybe more TFs?), allowing group work, and actual help on coding in ML rather than a pair of tutorials that are undeniably impossible to understand w/o prior ML knowledge would be a good start.
worse_comment: Take this class if you are self–motivated to learn. This class will not hold your hand
best_gem_comment: Gem of a class! You create your own project with AI and you self teach yourself for the semester! I learned a lot about neural networks and how to navigate the tons of resources online, and while having fun in the meantime.
subject: Neurobiology - Graduate

best_comment: Great class—huge exposure to a variety of manuscripts, amazing sessions in Houghton, meet a bunch of interesting medievalists. Sean Gilsdorf is fantastic and cares so much about the material and the students. The best way I can describe it is that you come away from this class feeling as though you've learned a superpower. Latin definitely required.

The course is split into two sections: anatomy and cases/project presentations. Anatomy consists of Dr. Milberg giving slideshow presentations on various structures/functions of the brain, sometimes using a human brain or a model. It can be easy to get a bit lost in this part of the course, so don't be afraid to ask questions. You'll also learn the most if you buy the workbook he recommends and actually use it. The anatomy section is tested with a relatively easy midterm. The second segment is group presentations on famous cases of abnormal cognition — think Phineas Gage, HM, ect. — that build on some anatomy knowledge but are generally interesting to work on & listen to. The take–home final was based on these cases. Our seminar was also offered an opportunity during reading period to do one last "cutting" of the brain to access some of the structures we weren't able to physically see earlier in the class. Overall, I'd highly recommend the course — it's a 'gem' in it's low required workload (again, you get the most if you do work outside of class that's not required) BUT it is also extremely interesting. Dr. Milberg is a gem of an instructor. He is incredibly knowledgable, friendly, accessible, and has a lot of interesting personal stories about cases he's seen throughout his career. This is a low–stakes way to learn brain anatomy (which is surprisingly lacking in the College's neuroscience department) because the workload is very low and Milberg is very willing to entertain questions. Even if anatomy is not the most interesting subject for you (as it wasn't for me), examining a real human brain is a unique opportunity that is hard to come by. The cases were also very interesting with a good mix of diversity. I didn't think I had retained that much from the anatomy section but I was surprised at how much I actually remembered when we came to the cases.
best_gem_comment: The course is split into two sections: anatomy and cases/project presentations. Anatomy consists of Dr. Milberg giving slideshow presentations on various structures/functions of the brain, sometimes using a human brain or a model. It can be easy to get a bit lost in this part of the course, so don't be afraid to ask questions. You'll also learn the most if you buy the workbook he recommends and actually use it. The anatomy section is tested with a relatively easy midterm. The second segment is group presentations on famous cases of abnormal cognition — think Phineas Gage, HM, ect. — that build on some anatomy knowledge but are generally interesting to work on & listen to. The take–home final was based on these cases. Our seminar was also offered an opportunity during reading period to do one last "cutting" of the brain to access some of the structures we weren't able to physically see earlier in the class. Overall, I'd highly recommend the course — it's a 'gem' in it's low required workload (again, you get the most if you do work outside of class that's not required) BUT it is also extremely interesting. Even if anatomy is not the most interesting subject for you (as it wasn't for me), examining a real human brain is a unique opportunity that is hard to come by. The cases were also very interesting with a good mix of diversity. I didn't think I had retained that much from the anatomy section but I was surprised at how much I actually remembered when we came to the cases.
subject: Mind, Brain & Behavior

course_title: Functional Neuroimaging of Psychiatric Disorders: Insights into the Human Brain-Mind 001
best_comment: This is a wonderful class with a wonderful instructor!!! You don't need any background in this area (or in related STEM fields, for that matter) –– all the necessary context will be provided to you and you can learn as you go via the readings and class discussions. Moreover, it is a low pressure environment that encourages everyone to share perspectives and ask questions. Not only did I come away from this course with more knowledge about neuropsychiatry and neuroimaging techniques, I am also more excited about medicine and mental health in general. This was my top choice for the MBB seminar lottery and I am so, so glad that I got in. My one piece of advice would be to definitely stay on top of the readings and take the weekly response paper assignments seriously. It will help you get more out of the course and also give you an advantage when deciding on what to write for your final paper!
worse_comment: Take this class! It covers fascinating material and is relatively low stress.
subject: Mind, Brain & Behavior
course_title_2023: Functional Neuroimaging of Psychiatric Disorders: Insights into the Human Brain-Mind

best_comment: This course is an amazing empirical investigation of the impacts of mindfulness meditation. Dr. Ferguson is more than happy to discuss tangential fields as well such as spirituality, mysticism, psychedelics, and more. This course is great for anyone who has a personal or professional interest in mindfulness' impact on the mind and is searching for an intimate classroom setting that emphasizes vibrant discussion. Dr. Ferguson is truly an amazing professor and I would highly recommend the course.

Dr. Ferguson is truly an amazing professor and I would highly recommend the course.

course_title: Neuroimaging and Big Data in Connectomics: Advances in Understanding the Wiring of the Brain 1
best_comment: This is a great MBB seminar to take. The concepts can be a little advanced at times, but Dr. Nickerson really takes the time to break them down and make sure you understand everything. Also, the assignments are always related to what we are learning and Dr. Nickerson has ample office hours to help provide any feedback. She is always open to meeting and talking more, which was especially helpful when completing the final project. Overall, very great class and the material is interesting and rewarding. You can definitely do well if you take the time and talk with Dr. Nickerson.
subject: Mind, Brain & Behavior
course_title_2023: Neuroimaging and Big Data in Connectomics: Advances in Understanding the Wiring of the Brain

course_title: An Integrated Introduction to the Life Sciences: Genetics, Genomics, and Evolution 001
best_comment: Personally I enjoyed LS1a more than LS1b. However, the class was very entertaining.Berry was my favorite lecturer. The material may feel sometimes redundant, though. Make sure to study hard for PIE 2 (it went bad for most people). Berry is super sweet and enthusiastic. His material is interesting, and you can tell that he really cares about what he talks.Hopi's material is the most dense. It is all new material and concepts I had never learned before. She is a fun lecturer, but be prepared to study hard for those PIEs.Pardis's material is the most mathematical. There will be many calculations made (Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium, GWAS, LOD Score, KA/KS, inbreeding coefficient), and memorizing the steps to take will save you.There are four different types of questions where chi–squared is used, so make sure to know how to get the expected values, the correct p–value, the null hypothesis, and more for each one.Section is very helpful. labs sometimes feel pointless, but they're fun. There are two write–ups to do for labs, which are hell, but they are easy to get through. Make sure to dedicate time for each of them (my mistake was starting last minute, and I mean LAST minute, like with a few hours left the day it was due).Keep track of assignment deadlines. Most are at 9 pm. Make sure not to confuse them for midnight!
worse_comment: LS1B is an intro course that is required by many concentrations, unfortunately. I walked into this course expecting it to be quite a bit of busywork and nontrivially hand–holdy (due to it being an intro course). But what I did not expect was to spend 10–20 hours a week doing useless busywork. Besides that, the grading is very messed up due to the following reasons:1. PIEs are almost half of your grade in the course. They are online and open–note, but there is rampant cheating. This bumps up the cutoffs for grades, making it very difficult to do well in the course, even if you make a few silly mistakes here and there.2. Everything you turn in, other than the exams, is graded by your TF. Thus, your grade is entirely in the TF's hands. Certain TFs may be very kind and lenient with grading while other TFs count off just because they want to (or on a whim, depending on whether they like you or not). If you have a particularly strict or mean TF, you are already put at a significant disadvantage. Additionally, your experience in the course is dictated entirely by your 3 hour section (which includes discussion and lab) led by your TF. Otherwise, you do not interact with the course staff at all. If your TF is not good or does not know the material, your experience in the class will be absolutely awful, as was mine.I have not taken a class that I dislike more than I dislike LS1B. I've never spent more time doing useless busywork, and I've never had such an awful experience with a member of the course staff.
subject: Life Sciences
course_title_2023: An Integrated Introduction to the Life Sciences: Genetics, Genomics, and Evolution

subject: Life Sciences
course_title_2023: An Integrated Introduction to the Life Sciences: Genetics, Genomics, and Evolution

best_comment: LS50 WILL BE THE DEFINING PART OF YOUR FRESHMAN YEAR if you decide to take this course. This is simply fact. You will find a great community of students and really welcoming teaching faculty who will assist you in every way they can. Some people might describe this class as scarring yourself with knowledge such that you build scar tissue to protect you from the trauma of future classes at Harvard and beyond, but it is important to remember that this metaphorical scar is composed of learning the most wide array of topics possible for an introductory course and that in and of itself is valuable.  It can help narrow down what you are interested in studying or fill in the gaps of a subject you may have felt initially weak in.  Another benefit is that the speed of learning and organization of this class will likely prepare you for rigorous courses that have plentiful resources and study aids down the line since LS50 is much more amorphous in the material it covers. Regardless, you will have to be dedicated to the pursuit of learning and thinking like a researcher over worrying over the granularity of your grades. If you focus on the minutiae of points, this is not the class for you and you will likely feel that the outcome of this class is not worth the work entailed. The perception of difficulty and  challenge within this course is only natural and there are many points throughout the course where no student has a detailed background in what is being taught, creating a more even playing field. Personally, the second semester has been exponentially easier than the first in terms of psets and exams although it's not a complete pushover.  Given that LS50 restricts 5 out of the 8 courses you take within your freshman year, I believe the second semester's lowered difficulty will allow you to take on an additional 1 or even 2 courses. With all that said, this class is definitely not for everyone. If you are not interested in exploring the integration of mathematical and physics based components into biology or chemistry, immediately walk away and run in the other direction. Ls1B and LS1A are much better fits for people interested in pure bio and chem. If you are somewhere wavering in between and wondering why this inclusion of math in biology is important or even remotely interesting, it allows you to dive deep into the mechanics of cells and life that are often taken for granted in typical life science courses and presents a useful paradigm for research questions and modeling of biological systems. Personally, I entered this course much more interested in medicine than research but in exiting, I have grown to appreciate research more in tandem with medicine. Deciding to take this course is a pretty huge decision and one that should not be left up to your ego. It's important to level your expectations by consulting with a previous student or some members of the teaching faculty but even in cases where expectations were not necessarily aligned with the reality of the course, there is a general consensus of feeling extremely rewarded by all this class has to offer.

With all that said, this class is definitely not for everyone. If you are not interested in exploring the integration of mathematical and physics based components into biology or chemistry, immediately walk away and run in the other direction. Ls1B and LS1A are much better fits for people interested in pure bio and chem. If you are somewhere wavering in between and wondering why this inclusion of math in biology is important or even remotely interesting, it allows you to dive deep into the mechanics of cells and life that are often taken for granted in typical life science courses and presents a useful paradigm for research questions and modeling of biological systems. Personally, I entered this course much more interested in medicine than research but in exiting, I have grown to appreciate research more in tandem with medicine. Deciding to take this course is a pretty huge decision and one that should not be left up to your ego. It's important to level your expectations by consulting with a previous student or some members of the teaching faculty but even in cases where expectations were not necessarily aligned with the reality of the course, there is a general consensus of feeling extremely rewarded by all this class has to offer.
subject: Life Sciences

course_title: Experimental Research in the Life Sciences 001
best_comment: A great way to get neuro honours. It was really helpful being given a selection of labs and easily being placed into one rather than finding your own. It also ensures that you learn a lot and have a good teaching experience, rather than just doing busy work in a lab.

This class is an interesting, chill, intermediate biology class that emphasizes the connection between science and society. It is not policy–focused enough to be a public policy course, yet it is not technical enough (biological/chemical content) to feel like an intermediate bio course (MCB64 or other). Take this course if you want to fulfill a requirement or otherwise explore biology (for non–bio people! this course is not hard! it is in fact fun and exciting, low–workload!) See the syllabus for course topics, they are not typical to bio courses. If they interest you, you could probably take this as a 5th class or to fulfill a req. Have fun! :)
worse_comment: This class is very doable, fair grading, light workload.  The quizzes are a little tricky but do not count much towards the grade.  The lectures are more discussions and this was not too effective at times because we would waste time in small group discussing one figure and then not have enough time to discuss the whole paper together.  A lot of times I left class wondering what I was supposed to take away.

best_comment: This course is hard and there are a lot of components to juggle, but the content is really interesting and the course staff are amazing! If you keep up with the course materials and ask questions when you need help, it's totally manageable.
worse_comment: Go to office hours for the LPS assignments. Seriously. Do it. Also, don't wait until the day before the lab report is due to put it altogether. Seriously.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: This course is hard and there are a lot of components to juggle, but the content is really interesting and the course staff are amazing! If you keep up with the course materials and ask questions when you need help, it's totally manageable.
worse_comment: Go to office hours for the LPS assignments. Seriously. Do it. Also, don't wait until the day before the lab report is due to put it altogether. Seriously.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: This is a great class, pretty easy and you learn a lot about how to use microscopes and how to get better images with them. I knew nothing about microscopes prior to this class and I was totally fine. You put in what you get out, so if you put a lot of effort and try to do more innovative techniques with the projects you will definitely get more out of it. I wish I had had more time to spend on this class honestly.
worse_comment: This class is not that difficult and probably less work than other premed bio classes, but it is so extremely frustrating. Biology lectures were so boring and disorganized. Why are they entirely given in analogy? Just describe the cell directly. Microscopy lectures were a little more interesting. Quizzes were not helpful for learning and unrelated to the lectures sometimes. Expectations for lab reports and independent studies were extremely unclear and they took an insane amount of time with no guidance from the course staff. They gave us no information on how to prepare samples or take the images and we guessed based on online guides incorrectly and had to spend many hours doing it again. You probably will learn very little as most of the lectures are just on actin and very boring. Also, there is nothing to check if you recall them at all. The lectures are unrelated to the lab work and the quizzes can be Googled. Overall, super disorganized and irritating, but still relatively easy.

course_title: Research for Credit in Molecular and Cellular Biology 001
best_comment: I absolutely loved this course because I had a great mentor. A persons experience in lab is very dependent on the people surrounding and supporting them. I was fortunate to have amazing people, which is not something I have had in previous lab work.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology
course_title_2023: Research for Credit in Molecular and Cellular Biology

best_comment: Definitely write a thesis! It was a great experience and I felt supported throughout.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: Definitely write a thesis! It was a great experience and I felt supported throughout.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

course_title: Experimental Research in Molecular and Cellular Biology 001
best_comment: Take this class! It’s a great way to learn what being in a wet lab is like, and it’s nice to get practice working in a research group. You will be in the lab a lot, and will need to coordinate with your group members, so this class helps you develop communication and teamwork skills
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology
course_title_2023: Experimental Research in Molecular and Cellular Biology

best_comment: This course was absolutely phenomenal. Professor Dulac is not only an exceptional scientist, but a fantastic teacher and mentor with a great sense of humor at that. I have never felt so inspired and genuinely fascinated by lectures in my life. The teaching staff adjusted the course such that there were no exams and only problem sets, which was truly wonderful for someone who chose to take the class as an elective for purely intellectual enjoyment. I do not have much of a biology background, but the staff and my peers in the course were very helpful/always willing to explain certain concepts.  The problem sets were also rewarding in the sense that they required us to carry out our own research/analysis but always with the support of the teaching staff. Overall, would absolutely recommend this course to ANYONE who even remotely has an interest in neuroscience or biology.
worse_comment: It is a chill class but not always  very interesting
best_gem_comment: This class is definitely a gem in terms of assignments. It is truly so boring though. Lectures are quite dry and hard to follow but you can still do really well without attending as it is all problem set based.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

course_title: Experience-Based Brain Development: Causes and Consequences 001
best_comment: Definitely a super cool course that teaches you so much about how much experience truly impacts brain development! If you are interested in this area, or even just a little bit curious, take this course! Also get started on your final grant proposal early! Don't be afraid to ask for help and ask questions to finalize your aims.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology
course_title_2023: Experience-Based Brain Development: Causes and Consequences

course_title: Interplay between Viruses and their Hosts 001
best_comment: You should totally take this class! It's a really great way to learn a lot of cool new things about viruses and their replication cycle and how they interact with the host without too much effort. Only work is just reading one paper a week and writing a 500 word summary and then participating a couple of times in section, and the final project is super chill and is done before reading week. Victoria's lectures are also engaging and interesting. Highly recommend if you are CPB/MCB/other bio or bio–adjacent concentration and you are looking to fulfill an upper level class requirement, or if you're just looking for a chill class where you can learn some interesting and important things about viruses.
worse_comment: Low workload but the grading can be kinda sketch
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology
course_title_2023: Interplay between Viruses and their Hosts

best_comment: The class really gives you a lot of freedom to choose your topics and to present papers that are interesting to you. Considering the bulk of the workload is mainly based off of these presentations you give every 1–2 weeks, it is definitely a very reasonable workload.
worse_comment: In general, I would not recommend this course unless you know you have a strong interest in chromosomes. The class was disorganized, had unclear expectations, and did not really inspire interest in chromosomes for me. There is no one better (in this world) to teach about chromosomes than Prof. Kleckner – however, I personally did not find my learning style to be very compatible with her teaching style. She is blunt and straightforward, which in itself is not what I found off–putting, but I felt that this did contribute to a fear of being wrong or naive in the class, which was hard to deal with as an undergraduate with little exposure to chromosome biology.

best_comment: This is an advanced class to learn how to communicate science effectively. If you take this class, be prepared to be thoroughly critiqued about every detail of your presentation, including things like fonts and text placement. The professors also often don't agree on what is effective or not, making it difficult to receive good feedback. It's a decent time commitment and can be hit–or–miss on what you get out of it.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

course_title: Introduction to the Principles and Practice of Macromolecular Crystallography 001
best_comment: Take this course! It's an interesting introduction to a fascinating and historically important technique to the study of molecular biology. The course material does get into the nitty–gritty of this technique, but it is important to recognize that this technique has been in development for more than 60 years with respect to macromolecules and can reveal protein structural information at the subatomic level! The course staff are wonderful!

course_title: Current Topics in Molecular, Cellular and Organismal Biology 001
best_comment: This class is very helpful for practicing public speaking, but not in the common mediums. This would be great for someone preparing a job talk.

course_title_2023: Current Topics in Molecular, Cellular and Organismal Biology

best_comment: Sorry to say it but this is one of your Sisyphus classes–– it's just another rock to push up a hill until the blessed end of the semester. Maybe they'll change things for you all, I really hope so. If not, I hope you make it through like the rest of us. They probably won't even publish this response for you all to see.

best_comment: Although I was required to take this course for my program, I feel the instructors cared very much about our comfort with the material and were very helpful. The course layout was thoughtfully planned and math, physics, coding, and protein modeling skills were emphasized.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: Although I was required to take this course for my program, I feel the instructors cared very much about our comfort with the material and were very helpful. The course layout was thoughtfully planned and math, physics, coding, and protein modeling skills were emphasized.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

course_title: Introduction to Western Music, from Bach to Beyoncé 001
best_comment: This is, quite simply, the BEST course I've taken at Harvard. Let's break down why.1. MUSIC LISTENING: The music we listen to in this course is sooooo good, and learning to listen to it analytically is honestly super fun and rewarding. I developed a bigger appreciation for classical music but also became able to think about more modern music in a completely new light.2. IT'S NOT MUCH WORK AND NOT STRESSFUL AT ALL: A true gem. INCREDIBLY interesting lectures and course material, great assignments, also a SUPER polished and organized course. And truly, this course is not very difficult or stressful. Still, I was motivated to do well because the teaching staff is so great, which brings me to...3. THE COURSE STAFF: Oh. my. god. I LOVED my TF in this class (Cana McGhee, she's a gem), but the other ones were also SICK. Section was such a joy, had amazing convos, great music listening, and always walked out having Shazam'd at least 2 new songs.4. MICHAEL UY: This man right here, is just, *chef's kiss*. Never have I had a professor so eloquent, enthusiastic, personable, funny, polished, relatable, and SO INTELLIGENT at the same time. Every lecture, every moment of this course was made so enjoyable because of Michael. He also knew everyone's name (I'm talking like 120 people) after the second week. The man cares more than anyone I've ever met.TAKE THIS COURSE. Do it, or else I'll be disappointed in you.
worse_comment: not a gem. tests were difficult and ambitious. lectures were very engaging though, but this class is difficult if you have no musical background.

subject: Music
course_title_2023: Introduction to Western Music, from Bach to Beyoncé

best_comment: Take it! You seriously don’t need any background. MUSIC 2 is remarkable in that it takes people who don’t know how to read music and turns them into arrangers.As an instrumentalist, I found the beginning of the course to be quite slow, as it teaches students to read music. But I got a TON out of learning about harmony. Also, the homework is generally pleasant to do (though tedious on occasion) and very rarely feels like busy work.The projects are GREAT. They tie all of the material together so nicely and are a challenge in the best way possible. Such a joy to do and something I genuinely learned from. I loved all the creative liberty we got as well.The problems on the final were difficult but very interesting. Section was super dry, but lectures were great. Dr. Jakubowski taught us a lot of theory and exposed us to lots of great, new music. And he always made sure to tie in concepts we were learning with real–world examples (i.e., songs). He not only showed us a new lens with which to look at the world, but looked through it right in front of us.Would recommend for musicians and non–musicians alike.
worse_comment: Don't fall behind on the workbook assignments. They don't look like much since they are like a bunch of basic drills but all together it can become very time consuming if you have like 20 sections to get through
best_gem_comment: Take this class if you are actually interested in learning music theory. If you are, this class will teach you A LOT in a very short amount of time. You see the connections between many different genres of music; it is definitely not just classical. That being said, it can be tedious and boring at times, but that is how music theory is. If you just like listening to music and even playing a little of it sometimes, that might not be enough. You will be learning all of the fundamentals. They are fascinating, but they also require memorizing and practicing things which can get quite annoying after a while. The professor is great, the TFs are very helpful, and the projects fun. Does not require a lot of time. Probably no more than 2 hours per week to complete the simple, repetitive workbook exercises. In that sense, this is like a gem. You do have to work for the projects, but they are very fun, and likely more creative than difficult.
subject: Music

best_comment: I love HRO! It's not just an orchestra, but a family of incredibly talented musicians who enjoy playing incredible music together. Fed is quite ambitious with the repertoire selection, so the actual experience of playing in the ensemble is fun and rewarding. If you want to play in the largest and highest–quality ensemble (in terms of musical excellence) on campus, join HRO. There's no other opportunity like it to make serious orchestral music.

Take Collegium for credit! It gives us access to more resources as the college views us as more legitimate if we make the organization be perceived as more of an academic institution. And the work we do is a crazy time commitment and is certainly an academic endeavor, so you deserve to be rewarded for that.
Join the Glee Club! This was by far the best choice that I've made at Harvard. There is nowhere on campus that the ratio of great community to time investment required is as high as it is here.
worse_comment: take this class, there is literally no reason not to.

best_comment: The community in RCS is very warm and welcoming, but you do need to put in some effort to get to know people through social events. Otherwise, it can be very nice in itself to have a focused time for music–making with other people. Meg and Liz are truly the greatest – spend some time in office hours or just during rehearsal to talk to them. It is truly a gift that we have their care. If Andy Clark is conducting, however, note that the experience is not pleasant. When Andy is around, you should have some experience in choir – he is so confusing and scattered as a teacher that it is not beginner–friendly. In general, knowing how to read music is important.

It's a great band, lots of great players. The community is alright, a bunch of cool people individually, but there hasn't been an environment made for most players to feel comfortable with each other. Awesome featured artists. Very rare opportunities to solo in rehearsal or jam with other students. If you're pressed for time and want to continue playing, consider JCI, but jazz band is also solid. Rehearsals can drag on fairly recently (wednesday 1–hours often become 2–hours)

TAKE THIS CLASS! Lectures are really interesting, and Prof Abbate always plays clips from the Met Opera. The operas are dramatic and fun! It's like taking a class on fairytales – the stories and the characters are super fun to pick apart and learn from. This class isn't a crazy amount of work at all, and you don't need a music theory background. Class is actually really enjoyable and assignments correlate exactly to what is taught in class.
subject: Music

best_comment: Please take this class!!! If you're remotely interested in taking a music theory class, TAKE 51B. Landon is AMAZING and he really engages every single student. His enthusiasm and attitude toward certain topics are just wonderfully contagious. Kate, the TF, is brilliant and truly cares about every single student. Yes, this course is a bit of work, you'll spend time stuck on assignments or confused on certain topics, but it's super rewarding when you finally get it. Practically everyone in the class seems to do well grade–wise (A/A– range), so it was nice to just focus on the actual learning instead of being preoccupied with fighting for a grade. The teaching staff definitely makes sure you succeed!
subject: Music

best_comment: If you're a music concentrator, you'll be required to take this course–– but don't fret! This is hands–on class that allows a lot of flexibility for the student to process the information how they want to (creative projects, essays, etc.). Prof. Rehding is a great lecturer and a caring person!

This is a really great class I would highly recommend to anyone. Obviously it works perfectly and best for someone preparing a thesis before senior year, but even if you aren't writing a thesis, the chance to get paired with a mentor one–on–one to do something that YOU like, anything you like, in such an open and flexible way, is unparalleled in any of the other departments I'm familiar with.
subject: Music

best_comment: You do not have to have conducting experience. Seriously, genuinely, you can take this class without having ever held a baton before, so long as you are willing to put time and effort into learning the basic beat patterns and such. Do not be intimidated by a lack of experience!What you will need is a very strong background in classical music, in whichever instrument you play or in opera. I think this class probably had the highest concentration of Harvard/NEC or Harvard/Berklee people out of any class at Harvard... and you will be expected to play the repertoire when you are not conducting (for pianists, this means the piano reduction). You will likely be stressed a LOT for this class. On average, we were assigned one symphony a week + 2/3 arias, and the expectation was we should know the piece well. Fed will call you out for faking it/not preparing enough before a class! I really wish I took this class with more time in my schedule to prepare each week; I tried to compensate for my dearth of score study time with listening to the rep as much as possible, but it definitely showed.With all this said, I don't regret taking this at all. Maybe some of it is the masochistic classical musician energy, but for all its intensity and stress, I feel like I came away with a lot of knowledge on how to get better in the future (though I am unsure of how much I have actually improved in one semester). I would suggest, if you are on the fence about it, to try taking this as a 5th class, and stay or drop in the first 5 weeks after you have a better sense of what its like. In fact, I really, really strongly suggest this instead of going in based on expectations of previous years, as the class changed quite a lot to accommodate this year's group and I'm sure will do so again, and also because there are a number of factors people of different backgrounds may experience differently. It really is not for everyone, but honestly if you're still considering it after reading this you're probably the type that should try it.
subject: Music

best_comment: This is a wonderful class that changes the way you think about music, and it allows you to compose the kind of music that you like but encourages you to incorporate different elements and themes learned from the class, which will definitely make your style of music composing evolve over the course of the semester through the exercises.
worse_comment: This course is very low pressure, I feel like the only thing that felt rushed was the final project portion of the course; but I felt relatively okay to tackle this portion. I think the only comment that I was I knew coming into this course is that you won’t learn a lot of music notation in the course, if you don’t have some sort of prior knowledge of music as either a musician (from playing instruments or making electronic mashes), previous composition experience, or just time to learn more about music, this might be a timesink. If not, it’ll be a pretty low pressure class.
subject: Music

best_comment: BEST CLASS EVER !! Honestly this class is just so unique that I don't even know where to start but basically you write songs every few weeks and share/perform them with your community cohort. The songs are based on a whole variety of spiritual and psychological needs that the class brainstorms and it's super cool to see how we can use the creative and emotional aspects of music and songwriting to address them. This is powerful stuff that will change your perspective on music forever! And you get to meet super cool people and just jam what more do I even need to say ,,,,,

Honestly, the experience from taking this course can be a coin flip. Depending on your chamber group, you may have to end up spending several more hours rehearsing compared to other groups. There will always be pre–made dual degree musician chamber groups that will always sound amazing, but if you just want to enjoy chamber music as a regular Harvard student, it may feel like you're having to catch up. Not that the actual level of performance matters that much towards your grade though. The teachers/coaches are very helpful and insightful, and getting to hear other groups play can be interesting.
subject: Music
