subject: Music

course_title: The Sacred Sounds of Black Folk: The Black Choral Tradition 001
best_comment: Definitely, definitely, definitely take this class if it's offered again — it's amazing!

Music 194R was a rewarding class – enjoyed exploring and reflecting upon current frontiers in music cognition research. Dr. Jakubowski is wonderful – highly passionate about course material, and super caring towards students. Would recommend this course to anyone even remotely interested in the way cognitive science and music interact – you don't need background in either music or neuroscience to learn a lot from this class!

It's a very learn–by–doing course, but the professor gives really good feedback and sets up a friendly environment for you to share your work and improve. I definitely learned a lot and overcame (to some extent) my fear in sharing my creativity.
worse_comment: This course is very hectic and is very demanding

course_title: Theory and Analysis of Music in Visual Multimedia 001
best_comment: Professor Lehman is one of the best teachers I've ever had, in my entire life. He is probably the most qualified person on Earth to teach this class, and he clearly cares very deeply about his students. He's one of those teachers who is genuinely excited to hear new ideas in every class discussion, and it was always exciting to start a new topic. The assignments never felt like a hardship to me – they were usually just an opportunity to explore the new things we were learning and go a bit deeper than the readings. I highly recommend this class to anyone who is interested (with the caveat that students should have taken at least a feel year of college music theory – or the equivalent – before enrolling).

This class is absolutely incredible! I learned so much about the discipline of music philosophy; however, the class is not for everyone if you're not deeply interested in fundamental questions about epistemology, efficacy, ontology, music praxis, and other aspects of what makes music so powerful.

course_title: Food and Identity in Ancient Israel 001
best_comment: This was the first year this course was taught. It was clearly very well done and I think she did a great job facilitating discussion. I do think there were times when the course could have been better which was in the middle of the semester. Rather than having 1 paper worth 40% of the grade, I think 2 papers of 20% that were half the length would have been great because we could check our learning along the way.

This course is challenging but it is worth every drop of effort that you put in. The homework will eat up hours of your day and the tests will be challenging but, at least in my opinion, it is worth it. It is worth it when you are watching a tv show in Arabic and can understand it. It is worth it when a tourist asks you a question about Harvard in Arabic and you are able to help them. If you want to truly transformative foreign language experience this is the class for you.

Be prepared to learn a lot of vocabulary, but eventually –– rather quickly actually –– you will be introduced to ways (methods/patterns) that make vocabulary acquisition really interesting and much easier. Be prepared for daily homework and make sure to study your verb conjugations! I found it very helpful to repeat things back (say them out loud) whenever I did al–kitaab drills online. Doing that made my ear and pronunciation much better. Ustaadh Richard is awesome and you would be lucky to have him as your Professor.

If you're interested in learning Arabic, take Elementary Arabic with Ustaad Richard! He is such a king and is incredibly knowledgeable about Arab culture and Arabic.  If you tend to be an oversleeper, take his later sections because he likes to begin classes very promptly! You can tell that he has a lot of respect for the Arab world, and I wouldn't have wanted any other preceptor to guide me through the beginning of my Arabic journey at Harvard! As long as you approach the course with an open mind and are willing to put the work in, you'll definitely succeed. Good luck!!! :)

Take Ustaadh Adnan's course! One of the best teachers I've had, and he really cares about his students. Teaches effectively and genuinely generates a love for the language. Very thorough in his knowledge and is able to answer all kinds of questions. Helps students learn new material while also ensures students remember and engage with the old.

This course is awesome! Definitely recommend taking it (especially with Ustaadh Greg and Phoebe). There is a lot of work––but it is all necessary. Arabic is a hard language with lots of nuances, and you will spend time on the assignments, however it is so rewarding! You will learn and progress so much!

You should definitely take this course! I had been off cycle in the Arabic department when I entered and definitely felt that Professor Madi was exceptionally good at addressing my level of Arabic specifically relative to the course. Moreover, he is an exceptionally welcoming and attentive professor; of all the courses that I took to complete my citation, this one was *truly* the most rewarding and fun! If you're debating continuing because you're not sure of your experience with the first two years of Arabic using Kitaab al–Kitaab, this course –– especially with Professor Madi heading it –– is a refreshing departure that really will boost your confidence and ability tremendously.
subject: Arabic

best_comment: You definitely need to be prepared to devote a lot of time to this course, because the workload is heavy, but if you're struggling Ustadh Amr is very understanding and flexible and he will work with you to make sure you stay on top of it. It really is a wonderful course, and the transition to reading real literature and consuming media not made specifically for an Arabic learner is a huge step forward and a confident boost. Highly recommend, but only if you have the time.
subject: Arabic

course_title: Advanced Modern Arabic Bridge: Language, Literature, and Culture II 001
best_comment: A great class! It's work but definitely worth it – your Arabic will improve a lot. Students choose the topics for the various units at the beginning of the semester so the course material is super interesting and can be made relevant to your interests.
subject: Arabic
course_title_2023: Advanced Modern Arabic Bridge: Language, Literature, and Culture II

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Absolutely amazing! You will have a great time!!

course_title: Transforming Tradition: Islamic Education in the Modern Muslim World 001
best_comment: I loved this course! Super cool topic and the professor is really knowledgeable. If you're at all interested in education in the Middle East take the course!
subject: Islamic Civilizations
course_title_2023: Transforming Tradition: Islamic Education in the Modern Muslim World

best_comment: This class was probably my favorite at Harvard. Irit is the kindest and most caring professor, and trust me it is worth it to get to know her well. The course is always so interesting and you become good friends with those in your class. Irit is extremely supportive, and she understands that everyone learns at a different pace in their Hebrew journey. She gets to know all of her students well and wants everyone to find enjoyment in the language and culture. The TFs were also great and brought so much enthusiasm to the course and were supportive when I needed extra help. Irit also made so much time for office hours. I cannot recommend this course enough!
subject: Modern Hebrew

best_comment: Take this class!! The teaching staff is amazing and you will really learn Hebrew and all the patterns that underly the language!
subject: Modern Hebrew

best_comment: This is a wonderful course! You will learn a lot about yourself and tactically improve many of your Hebrew skills all around which is very impactful! I think you will grow as an indivuidual and learn a lot about Israel as a whole and just history. The course staff is wonderful and there is a wonderful relationship that you will build with other students in the class! Overall, a wonderful time!
best_gem_comment: Good class if looking for a gem or to fulfill a language req
subject: Modern Hebrew

course_title: Historical Background to the Contemporary Middle East: Religion, Literature and Politics 001
best_comment: Near Eastern Studies is a fascinating discipline that lets you engage with real people and their real issues better than perhaps any other concentration!
subject: Near Eastern Civilizations
course_title_2023: Historical Background to the Contemporary Middle East: Religion, Literature and Politics

course_title: The History of the Book: Using Harvard's Greatest Treasures to Study the Material Text 001
best_comment: Do you want to turn the pages of the Gutenberg Bible? Do you want to look at (and touch!) some of the most consequential books in history? Then take this class!! The History of the Book is seriously the best class I've taken at Harvard. No other course singularly makes use of the resources here.The workload is relatively light, too. You should expect to spend at least 2–3 hours on it outside of the (once–weekly) class meeting. Each week there is a group assignment in Houghton, which takes usually 1–2 hours, plus readings that you don't strictly need to do since they will often be covered in class.Professor Stern is an amazing teacher – knowledgeable, enthusiastic about the subject, and incredibly kind. If the books and the light workload weren't enough to convince you, it's worth taking this class for him. I really cannot repeat myself enough – this is an AMAZING class!!

The class goes at a great pace. You learn quickly, but it is not stressful, especially as the instructors are very helpful in class and eager to help outside of class if needed. The regularity of the class is great for cementing skills in the language.
worse_comment: Do not take this course. You will regret it. It is so boring and homework/quiz content is never clear. In fact, if you are passionate about Persian as a language, that is even more reason not to take it because it will take away your enthusiasm entirely.
subject: Persian

best_comment: THIS CLASS IS AWESOME! Please please take this class, you will absolutely LOVE it! The professor is THE BEST, she is always willing to help, offers advice, and makes sure no one is confused in class!!! She is very understanding and her teaching style is the best! The homework helps you a lot in your exams and prepares you well for the oral and final exams! Make sure to put in the effort and you will earn a great grade! I love Professor Meryem!! She is SO enthusiastic about Turkish and she is willing to help you every step of the way and ensures you are walking out of her class with everything clear and understood! I cannot recommend you enough to take this class! : )
subject: Turkish

best_comment: This class is challenging and requires dedication but you can learn a lot.
subject: Turkish

best_comment: This course is probably the best way to complete then foundational neuro requirement. Lectures were very enjoyable, and I found the section papers quite interesting as well. As there is a lot of material, and some of it can either overlap or be relevant to a particular topic, making  very clear subsections/divisions in my notes was very helpful for studying. Don't fall behind on studying! The material itself is not difficult to understand. It's still quite a lot to keep fresh, and you don't want to be memorizing the particular details of that one example you are still not comfortable with the night before the exam. Investing time in the rough draft of the written assignments is probably the best strategy. Peer reviews are not always helpful, and giving yourself that extra time to discuss something in your draft with your TF can make the final draft just a one–hour improvement session.
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

best_comment: This course is probably the best way to complete then foundational neuro requirement. Lectures were very enjoyable, and I found the section papers quite interesting as well. best_comment: Neuro 91 is great since it provides you with course credit thereby freeing up some time in your schedule to really dive into your research! There's only one assignment the entire semester, which is your final report, which is super short and easy to write since at that point you've done so much throughout the semester. Would highly recommend taking this and trying our research in any lab you're interested in!
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

best_comment: Neuro 91 is great since it provides you with course credit thereby freeing up some time in your schedule to really dive into your research! There's only one assignment the entire semester, which is your final report, which is super short and easy to write since at that point you've done so much throughout the semester. Would highly recommend taking this and trying our research in any lab you're interested in!
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

best_comment: If you are taking this course, it is because you are in the final stages of a neuro thesis. Congratulations! The finish line is ahead. Writing a thesis is harder than it seems, but don't let that discourage you. This course is a great way to space out that work and get the help of the neuro advisors and neuro head tutor. Definitely take this course!
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

best_comment: If you are taking this course, it is because you are in the final stages of a neuro thesis. Congratulations! The finish line is ahead. Writing a thesis is harder than it seems, but don't let that discourage you. This course is a great way to space out that work and get the help of the neuro advisors and neuro head tutor. Definitely take this course!
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

best_comment: overall, i loved this class. florian is great, lectures are informative but he also makes them fun with jokes etc. tfs are both excellent. grading is pretty lenient which allows you to take in the information without being overly stressed. the whole staff stresses that it is about the overall learning experience and that you should not be too stressed about grades. the one HUGE downfall is that the psets are basically impossible, at least for someone who has not coded (at least i though so). definitely find people to work with or u will be screwed. also do not wait till the last minute like i did
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

best_comment: take this class! Ryan is a great teacher and so is Katie. If you do take this class, the psets are really helpful to understand the material and they can be a little confusing but if you go to office hours they provide so much help and you can get the grade you desire. It was a moderate amount of work compared to other biology courses I have taken at Harvard. I wish there was a part 2 of this class because I liked it so much. Definitely take it for your foundational neuro course if you like more micro or quantitative perspectives on science topics.
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

best_comment: take this class! Ryan is a great teacher and so is Katie. If you do take this class, the psets are really helpful to understand the material and they can be a little confusing but if you go to office hours they provide so much help and you can get the grade you desire. Definitely take it for your foundational neuro course if you like more micro or quantitative perspectives on science topics.
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

best_comment: This course was absolutely phenomenal. Professor Dulac is not only an exceptional scientist, but a fantastic teacher and mentor with a great sense of humor at that. I have never felt so inspired and genuinely fascinated by lectures in my life. The teaching staff adjusted the course such that there were no exams and only problem sets, which was truly wonderful for someone who chose to take the class as an elective for purely intellectual enjoyment. I do not have much of a biology background, but the staff and my peers in the course were very helpful/always willing to explain certain concepts.  The problem sets were also rewarding in the sense that they required us to carry out our own research/analysis but always with the support of the teaching staff. Overall, would absolutely recommend this course to ANYONE who even remotely has an interest in neuroscience or biology.
worse_comment: It is a chill class but not always  very interesting
best_gem_comment: This class is definitely a gem in terms of assignments. It is truly so boring though. Lectures are quite dry and hard to follow but you can still do really well without attending as it is all problem set based.
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

best_comment: While the topics of this course are undoubtedly interesting, this is unfortunately the most disorganized course I have taken at Harvard, and perhaps the most disorganized course I have heard of. While the course syllabus said to no prior experience with coding ML is necessary (and we were told “we will teach you all the ML you need” in the very first lecture), the two short tutorials we had on ML in which we very loosely went over already written code was not helpful at all in grasping the skills that we would inevitably need for the projects. The first two assignments had less to do with ML and more to do with debugging long and unintelligible code. The project topics were already set and limited, but for some reason we were not allowed to work in groups (which to me feels very counter to the collaborative nature of true research), so we ended up in this weird situation where many people would be working on effectively the same project, but independently, which made the project feel more like a problem set rather than original research. However, unlike an actual problem set, the prompt and the requirements were much more up in the air and little help was provided. The feedback we received for proposals/midterm reports was minimal and in all honesty not that helpful. A lot of the times our slack messages would remain unanswered, and the ony TF of the class only had OH one hour per week (for a class with 75+ people!) so you couldn’t really get to speak with him for more than 5 minutes, and the OHs on the last two weeks before the project deadline (which is probably the time period during which we needed the most help!) were canceled. I know from discussions from my classmates that for both them and me, often times working on the project became borderline depressing since we had no idea what to do, which resources to use, and where to even start. Overall, I really enjoyed the topics covered by the lectures and also the readings I did for the project, but I really felt discouraged while working on it and didn’t really learn much due to the lack of resources and guidance. This course has great potential (the setup of it is really perfect for a computational neuro course), but it needs a serious reorganization if students are going to get anything out of it. More OH (and maybe more TFs?), allowing group work, and actual help on coding in ML rather than a pair of tutorials that are undeniably impossible to understand w/o prior ML knowledge would be a good start.
worse_comment: Take this class if you are self–motivated to learn. This class will not hold your hand
best_gem_comment: Gem of a class! You create your own project with AI and you self teach yourself for the semester! I learned a lot about neural networks and how to navigate the tons of resources online, and while having fun in the meantime.
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! I absolutely loved it! Professor Sanes is one of the kindest professors that I got to know, and he structured the course such that you get out a lot without having to worry a lot about big deadlines and workload. As long as you are interested in the topic of the course, you should be able to get a lot of fun and insights out of it! The lectures are delivered very coherently and eloquently and have both breadth and depth, so there's something for everyone, whether you are neuroscience concentrators or not. There was a nice balance of lectures by Professor and presentations by students, and I liked how this format gave you the opportunity to both get to know topics that you weren't familiar with and go into a discussion with your classmates in a fairly open and flexible setting, where you are welcome to toss out comments and questions as they arise. The reading selection is also great, some nice review articles that get right to the relevant points and some very interesting papers with fascinating/pretty clean experiments! Also, Professor Sanes really makes himself available to get to know you and answer your questions. The TF (Aboozar) has also been amazing, willing to help students whenever they are in need of support! I am a senior and this really has been a wonderful experience, and I can't recommend enough!!
worse_comment: This is the perfect class. Period. And I'm a little sad that other classes won't be like this. From the beginning, Josh set expectations that this was not going to be a class of harsh grading or pop quizzes or tough exams, or anything like that – you get out of it what you want. Basically, it's a participation based course that actually makes you want to learn by eliminating stress in any form. I wish every single class was like this.

course_title: Experience-Based Brain Development: Causes and Consequences 001
best_comment: Definitely a super cool course that teaches you so much about how much experience truly impacts brain development! If you are interested in this area, or even just a little bit curious, take this course! Also get started on your final grant proposal early! Don't be afraid to ask for help and ask questions to finalize your aims.
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate
course_title_2023: Experience-Based Brain Development: Causes and Consequences

course_title: Brain Invaders: Building and Breaking Barriers in the Nervous System 001
best_comment: For all neuroscience concentrators, I highly recommend taking this course. It's not easy, but all grading is fair and assignments/tests manageable, and I've not only learned so much brain/CNS diseases, but I also understand many neuroscientific concepts more deeply. This is a really great advanced neuro requirement, and the structure of the course is very conducive for learning the material and understanding outside reading extremely effectively. During the lecture before, you learn the background info needed to understand the paper for the week, which you then have to write a 1 page discussion on (instructions vary week–to–week). I can honestly say that I've never gained as much from outside readings as I have from this course, nor have I felt as prepared for discussions coming into class. The tests are tough but fair, and the presentation is also a lot of work, but also fair. The material is also SO interesting and Laura is AWESOME. Take this course!

I enjoyed this course, but it was certainly challenging. Working with partners on the psets is a huge help, and ask for extensions if you need them. The course staff were super accommodating throughout the semester.

course_title: Computational Cognitive Neuroscience: Building Models of the Brain 001
best_comment: Sam is an absolute beast in terms of raw neuro knowledge; lectures pack a ton of info and offer a great survey. Overall chill class and you learn a ton about neuroscience (that is not just bashing matrix calculus in the same way Neuro 231 might be). The hands–on aspect of the class is also very nice; similar to real research, you read papers and reimplement them (i.e. code up the results).
worse_comment: Would definitely recommend it if you have some interest in learning to think more quantitatively about the brain! Very chill in terms of grading, definitely a very weird class structure that I didn't think was super conducive to learning—for example, we were given a paper or two to read before most classes, but we never discussed our own thoughts on the papers or even discussed the papers at all. The lectures all felt quite disjointed, and the projects were only slightly related to the readings. As for the projects, the directions and expectations are incredibly unclear—was super stressful at first, but then got the hang of it—but they were great experiences to become a better programmer communicator of science.

best_comment: This course was really fun!! I got a big–picture understating of evolutionary adaptations that plants innovated over time, and an understanding of the beauty of plant architecture and function; it’s a fascinating alternative form of existence compared to animals/mammals. I loved how this course wasn’t nitty gritty about molecular function, i.e. “mitochondria is the powerhouse of the cell” AP Bio flashbacks—instead, precise topics were touched upon as was critically relevant. I found it fascinating to learn about an approach to existence and life that is distinctly separate from animals. Plants are constantly works in progress, and have developed and changed their life cycles over evolutionary time in a brilliant manner. This course is a gem, the labs are really fun because they encourage a “good old, hands–on” observational approach to studying plants, using high–powered optical microscopes and lab journal–keeping/drawing . This class was really fun. The professors, Elena and Missy, are very inspiring and fun people, and the field trips are super cool! This class is wonderful for those inspired by a pure love of learning.
worse_comment: This is not the easiest class ever, and if that's your expectation, I think you'll be disappointed. I think if you want to engage, though/spend time, the course staff will make it so that you can do incredibly well, like if you care about the class, then I think it probably becomes the easiest class ever. The teaching staff is just really available/understanding/welcoming and wants to make the class work for you. If you want to take an interesting science class, then you should lean into this class and you'll learn and it'll be fun, but if you're trying to avoid spending any time on this class, then that will probably get annoying because you do need to spend some time on this class.

best_comment: This is a great class to take if you are looking for a STEM class to pick up as a non STEM student, you learn a ton in one semester, it's not an easy A but its not terribly difficult, the work is back loaded so just keep an eye on that but otherwise a pretty light workload, objectively one of the most fun ways to fill a STEM requirement and the field trips were super fun
worse_comment: Solid class. Work load not bad. But I think it's getting revamped so ignore this comment.

best_comment: This is a great class to take if you are looking for a STEM class to pick up as a non STEM student, you learn a ton in one semester, it's not an easy A but its not terribly difficult, the work is back loaded so just keep an eye on that but otherwise a pretty light workload, objectively one of the most fun ways to fill a STEM requirement and the field trips were super fun

Take this course! It is a totally manageable workload but you learn so much about marine biology. Prof. Hartmann is an excellent teacher, and assembled a great course staff. For a course as fun as this one, you walk away with a lot of knowledge. Highly, highly recommend.
worse_comment: If you know nothing about marine biology or want the easiest/lowest workload class you will ever take, take this course.  However, be warned that it is VERY surface level so if you already have a background in marine bio you'll probably be bored/not learn anything new. The lectures are super dry/boring and the activities in class felt like a chaotic waste of time, which was frustrating.  That being said, I've never taken a class with this low of a workload or that was graded this easily ever, so that is a plus.
best_gem_comment: DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU ACTUALLY WANT TO LEARN ANYTHING ABOUT MARINE BIOLOGY! This course was a near–complete waste of my time. I learned almost nothing. The lecture content was as basic as it gets –– I think that this course would have been easily accessible to middle schoolers or even 5th graders. I was really disappointed because I am an OEB concentrator with a significant interest in marine biology and especially corals. I was really looking forward to learning from Dr Hartmann since his specialty aligns very closely with my interests. Looking at the syllabus, I imagined that the course would be taught like some other upper level OEB courses –– I understood that there wasn't a lot of work involved, but I thought that meant the lectures would be really engaging and scientifically oriented, and that we would read and discuss papers, or get into the specific dynamics of various ecosystems. Instead, we spent multiple lectures on ocean zones and far too many lectures on the boggle activities. There were a bunch of random activities which don't contribute to learning at all. The only things I learned during this class came from the guest lectures and reading the textbook. I'm guessing that most of the people who took this course probably are going to give it great feedback because it was a complete Gem of a class –– essentially that there was no work and it was an easy A. If you are looking for this then great, take this class. But you will be bored out of your mind, even if you don't know anything about marine biology.
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

best_comment: This is an incredible class and if you are interested at all in ecology, botany, field research, or just want a fun, experiential class you should take it. It is not an easy class, but the reward is indescribable. The labs and spring break trip are a hands–on and far more engaging method of learning that traditional classes and Chuck and Jacob have such a wide breadth of expertise and experiences that enhanced our learning and fun. I cannot emphasize how much I enjoyed this class and wish I had more opportunities in college to take more courses taught in this style. Even the lectures were engaging and lively, with frequent activities and a very clear roadmap of what we were learning. Compared to other taxonomy–based classes I've taken, the organization of this one set students up for the most success. Overall this is an amazing class and I feel grateful that it was offered this semester.

course_title: The Mouse in Science and Society 001
best_comment: This class is a treasure!!!  As a humanities student who cannot do math and was freaking out about what I would do senior spring for my science distribution requirement, this class probably is the reason I can graduate.  Incredibly low stakes but incredibly engaging.  This class was exactly what the distribution requirement should be: no crazy assignments, loads of homework, tests or quizzes, but instead a really engaging change to learn about something way outside your own field of specialty.  I will never think about science, research, (or mice!!) the same way again.  It was fascinating to make the connection between best practices of animal welfare and the best scientific results: the two go hand in hand.  Dr. Pritchett–Corning is absolutely superb!!!!  Kind, thoughtful, funny, wicked smart, empathetic, and really, really knowledgeable and passionate about what she teaches.
best_gem_comment: Take this class if you're looking for an easy, science–based gem! The professor is supportive and the final project has the potential to be very interesting.

best_comment: Great for anyone with any interest in the environment, opens your eyes to new career fields as well

course_title: Arthropod biology: Arachnids and myriapods, their biology and evolution 001
best_comment: This is an awesome course!!! It's super super low stress (one of the chillest classes I've taken), but you'll learn a lot.  Gonzalo and Shoyo are both great, and create a welcoming, casual environment where anyone feels welcome, regardless of biology background.  If you're at all curious about invertebrates, you should take this, and you should ESPECIALLY take it if you're at all apprehensive about Biology of Invertebrates or Biology of Insects, both of which are more intense than this course.  You'll also get to go on a fun field trip where the students all get much closer to one another, and you'll get to learn about arachnids and myriapods hands–on.  All in all, 10/10 must take if you think this stuff is even remotely interesting! and you get to learn about all aspects of their biology, so it's really comprehensive.

course_title: The Developmental Basis for Evolutionary Change 001
The Developmental Basis for Evolutionary Change 001
The Developmental Basis for Evolutionary Change 001

best_comment: PLEASE TAKE THIS COURSE. Peter is amazing, and the TFs give amazing feedback. The deep sea is really fascinating, and Peter does a great job–making lecture interesting.  Even though there are only 4 essays throughout the course, because of the feedback from each essay I became a better scientific writer. If you aren't familiar with the sciences, Peter does a good job of covering the basics and making sure anyone of any background can succeed in this course. If I could take it again, I would.

course_title: From Darwin to Derrida: The Evolution of Meaning and Purpose SEM
best_comment: This is a wonderful class! Professor Haig is a truly phenomenal Professor: so kind, so accessible, deeply enthusiastic about his work/the space, and committed to creating the best learning experience for his students. His book, From Darwin to Derrida, is a fascinating foray into the philosophy of biology and debates about meaning/purpose in biology; even if you don't have a background in biology, you will learn so much –– there are a multitude of connections between his work and other fields, including communications and CS. It's also a small, intimate class (about ~15 this semester, I believe), so you'll get to know everyone/feel a sense of community. And the coursework is manageable/the class is not about grading: it's about learning and critically engaging with the material. I highly recommend this class!
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol
course_title_2023: From Darwin to Derrida: The Evolution of Meaning and Purpose

best_comment: The course presented a wide survey of different biomechanics concepts, covering everything from intro to engineering concepts around locomotion, stresses and strains, fractures, scaling, fluids and flight to the biological organism examples and inspiration that exhibit the concepts within the natural world. The course this year featured hands on lab components working with force plates, actual specimens for dissection, and freedom to construct/design interesting questions to explore of student interest. Lectures were always well prepared and introduced interesting concepts, paper discussions and projects provided opportunities to dive in and engage further, and course staff were always open to and had interesting insights on questions that arose. A great class for exploring a wide variety of topics, getting to dialogue with course staff in smaller setting, and meeting students from across different disciplines.

This course is super interesting, but I would only recommend it if you’re super interested in birds. The course material and lab material can be quite overwhelming and there is quite a bit of outside of class time you need to dedicate to the class, so only take the course if you’re genuinely super interested in birds, otherwise this course may be overwhelming rather than enjoyable.

course_title: The Fishy Aspects of the Human Body 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!!! awesome lectures, cool labs, and you get to roast Neil Shubin weekly. Amazing teaching team, so kind and competent
Fantastic course highly recommend for anyone interested in ecosystems, design, and long–term projects
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

best_comment: You will definitely learn something in this class that you will remember long after this class is over. You will have a much better idea of the common tools and methods used in neuroscience and how to ask interesting, answerable research questions.
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

best_comment: John is an amazing facilitator, and such an incredible resource to have if you are interested in population genetics. However, you will get out of this class what you put in. The more extensively you read the paper before each session, the better questions you'll have and more you'll learn! But take it take it !!!! if you want a relaxed but exciting investigation into interesting evo pop gen topics
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

course_title: Microbial Sciences: Chemistry, Ecology and Evolution 001
best_comment: This is an excellent class if you are interested in the microbial world, and particularly if you are interested in getting involved with microbiology research.
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol
course_title_2023: Microbial Sciences: Chemistry, Ecology and Evolution

best_comment: This class is not difficult and definitely gives wisdom throughout. I liked learning about philosophies from around the world, thought this structure means you will only learn a bit about each global ethical framework. The assignments are not bad at all, and Professor Robertson is very kind. My only reservation is that this course's breadth sometimes led to not really understanding any topic in depth . I took this as an elective (and my fourth class) and thought I learned interesting facts about world philosophy and how to live a good life. However, since this was a survey class, I felt like I was a bit of a jack of all trades yet master of none by the end of the course. A background in philosophy is definitely not needed – do not be intimidated! If you are looking for a course that in depth teaches Kant, Rawls, etc., this is not it. However, I would recommend this if you need a fourth class, especially if you are interested about what ancient (and current) thinkers have taught about being a good person. I am unsure if this course would be good for someone very interested in concentrating in philosophy.
worse_comment: interesting class that is low pressure environment
best_gem_comment: Gem of a class, but also super interesting if you apply yourself! It turned out that section was non–mandatory (not in the grade according to the syllabus). Assignments were super light, 4 1–page papers, take–home midterm and final exams with study guides provided (so you already knew all the questions ahead of time), and a final 4–5 page paper!
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: Seth is great! I would try to at least skim some of the readings – they're interesting. Don't expect to have a full thesis plan at the end per se, but it can be helpful to be reminded to think about the thesis every week.
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: Prof Goldfarb loves telling anecdotes and they are a highlight :) Doug is a great TF and makes pretty helpful comments :)
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: This class will best serve students with a moderate or strong background in analytic philosophy (a background in classical philosophy is helpful but you can get by without it). Without a grounding in both the content of analytic philosophy, and the form in which it is written and conducted, Doyle's methodology and the ensuing class discussions may strike you as pedantic or opaque. They are neither but a solid background in philosophy and a good amount of work is required to get at the valuable experiences this class offers (a detailed and unique reading of a particular Platonic dialogue and a sound overview of the nature of Platonic dialogue itself).

Zhuangzi and Xunzi are my favorites; go back and read more passages from the ones that interest you most; have fun with the midterm and the class as a whole! Seth wants you to succeed, and does a great job at structuring the class for you to have a fun time and learn a lot at the same time

course_title: Frege, Russell, and the Early Wittgenstein 001
best_comment: If you have any interest in logic or the development of analytic philosophy, then this course is for you. Professor Goldfarb is truly an expert on the subject and every lecture is lucid and enlightening. I was initially drawn in by Wittgenstein's name and though his section of the course was interesting, it was Goldfarb's comprehensive treatment of Frege that was the unexpected highlight.

On a high level, this course teaches fascinating, mind–bending material. The notes provided are thorough and very well–written, although I recommend re–reading them a couple of times to fully grasp what they say. I found the problem sets to be (unnecessarily) hard to do on your own, although they did succeed in improving my grasp of the material. Doug, the TF, was very helpful, and Goldfarb himself is extremely enthusiastic about the material, and an expert in the area. The exams were hard, though, and I wonder if I would have appreciated the course more had I taken it P/F so as to be able to focus on (and enjoy even more) some of the bigger ideas without getting caught up in the weeds of understanding every single thing in the notes so as to not lose points on a problem set or exam. Overall, though, I have few regrets about taking this course –– it expanded my mind and is very cool material. If you're at all interested in the philosophy of Math, take it.

This is a great intermediate–advanced philosophy course that covers a wide range of interesting topics. It's taught very well, all the readings & assignments are useful and very manageable, and I found that as a Neuro / Philosophy joint concentrator I enjoyed being able to integrate concepts from this class into my other courses and research.
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: This class was all–around exceptional. I looked forward to the class each week and two hours always went by quickly. – Professor Siegel is an outstanding professor, now one of my top favorites at Harvard, who enriched our learnings with excellent readings while moderating rich conversations in class. I feel fortunate to have been Professor Siegel's student, a top researcher in her field, and a phenomenal teacher with a rare mix of compassion and benevolence of presence for her students. – Professor Siegel generously prepared helpful handouts for us for most classes. The readings to do before class also allowed us to focus on engaging in class and actively learn from it. – Every student in the class has been detrimental to my learning: our discussions were always very lively, and each contribution was significant.The class was an excellent mix of learning from academic papers and from my classmates, who all had insightful comments in class. It was never boring!
worse_comment: I hoped that this course would be an interesting intersection of three passions of mine: philosophy, psychology, and political science. Unfortunately, it was elementary and disorganized musings about political emotions, completely uninformed by any expert scholarship in either of the three fields. Lectures were disorganized and difficult to follow. Sometimes handouts were provided, and if they were, they were just the text that the professor was saying, which was helpful when you inevitably lose track of Professor Siegel's very fast and difficult–to–follow talking. Even though there were very few assignments, I received absolutely no feedback on any of them (I'm writing this 2 days before the end of classes). So that was frustrating. If you're looking at this class, I suggest you just take a philosophy class, a government class, or a psychology class. You'll actually learn something substantive there.

best_comment: Think very carefully about whether you actually are interested in the course content before taking this course. I liked philosophy going into this course and thought that I wanted to take it because epistemology seems very relevant to the real world and it seemed important to investigate how people come to know/ justify knowledge. However, this class successfully convinced my that most parts of  philosophy are obscenely detached from reality. The course itself is probably great if you enjoy engaging with questions and theories (about whether you are not dreaming all the time/ are justified in believing that things are colors/form beliefs about sensory input etc) that are extremely technical and have absurd totally infeasible counterexamples. The professor and tf are  enthusiastic and care a lot about the subject and are also very very very smart and clearly think about these questions a lot. However, the course itself kinda just felt like pointlessly plowing through content. On paper, it's a great course, but think very carefully if you want to spend a semester thinking about the content even if you think you really like philosophy. I thought I loved philosophy and technical arguments etc going into this course as well –– I no longer feel this way. If you are interested in taking it I would recommend shopping it for the first few weeks or taking it as a 5th class and just dropping it if you realize by week 4 that it is not for you. (I wish I had done this). I would recommend this EVEN if you like philosophy.

If Emilio Mora is teaching any class, TAKE IT. He is an absolute gem of the Philosophy department and of Harvard in general. This class was another excellent one and helped me think more deeply about minority group rights in relation to liberal political theory. In a political climate with so many heated arguments, this class was a breath of fresh air, helping us to think about these issues calmly, rationally, and critically. Outside of class, readings and response papers do not take a lot of time (2 hrs. per week just readings, 3–4 hrs. per week if writing a response paper as well as doing readings), and the flexibility in the assignments is incredibly helpful. Anyone can take this class, no background required. However, some writing experience may be useful because there's not a ton of formal scaffolding around how to write the response papers (however, going to office hours or talking to Emilio would surely help if you find yourself needing guidance). Take this class if you want to engage in interesting discussion, receive extensive feedback on your writing, and grow as a thinker and scholar.

course_title: Justice and the Politics of Cultural Memory and Representation 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! Professor Mora is a great teacher. He knows so much about the issues we discuss and is very passionate about the subject matter. You can tell he genuinely cares about the education of his students and he is always available to work with after class if you want to talk further. The class discussions were so interesting and I learned so much from this course. Makes me want to do a secondary in philosophy. Also the grading is not too hard so the class is not too stressful.

If you have any interest in Buddhist philosophy, no matter what you think that means, I would recommend this class. The readings can be hard, but the goal of the class is to understand something, not everything. Parimal is great at giving lectures that each everyone something, no matter what their backgrounds are. He'll also make sure that you care about the class if you put in the time to engage with it.
worse_comment: Be ready to analyze difficult readings. The philosophies/ideas are less difficult than the texts themselves.
subject: Philosophy

course_title: Special Topics in Post-Kantian European Philosophy 001
best_comment: It's best to have a few themes from one or both thinkers that you'd like to trace to bring into the course. This will help with what can be an otherwise very overwhelming (because comprehensive) analysis of western philosophy's most important transitions, developments, and thinkers.
worse_comment: no
subject: Philosophy
course_title_2023: Special Topics in Post-Kantian European Philosophy

course_title: Electromagnetism, Circuits, Waves, Optics, and Imaging 001
best_comment: If you're taking PS 3, you probably have to for your concentration or premed requirements. I did too, so take all of this with a grain of salt. The other option is AP 50b, which I've heard good things about. That is usually more work week–to–week since it is project–based, with no exams, whereas PS 3 is usually less work week–to–week but does have exams (which aren't too bad)On balance, PS 3 is an okay course. I liked PS 2 much better – it was more approachable, but that may be a function of easier material or just because it was better taught. PS 3 was not as good as PS 2, but it wasn't as painful as a required physics class could be. The lectures were pretty confusing, especially at the beginning of the semester, but section and section videos helped clear things up. The course staff also solicited feedback on how to improve things when they saw how much everyone was struggling. Office hours are a must if you want to do well – go there with your pset, and you will finish it much quicker and learn much more. Exams were not too bad, and the course has friendly grading policies, which is definitely a strength.
worse_comment: This was the most difficult premed course for me personally–– worse than orgo, far worse than PS2. I felt that lectures were so ineffective. Maybe they just didn't fit with my learning style, but I found it surprising and unsatisfactory how infrequently lectures defined key concepts, terms, equations, etc. and instead went straight into applications and demonstrations. I essentially had to teach myself everything later from section videos and office hours, which was very time consuming and frustrating. That being said, with the work I put in (ie, a ton of work), I was doing very well for most of the course until the extremely difficult final exam. It was my last exam of college and the only one I have ever cried after. Only take this class if you need to for premed. Stay on top of everything and study earlier than you think if physics isn't your thing.
subject: Physical Sciences
course_title_2023: Electromagnetism, Circuits, Waves, Optics, and Imaging

course_title_2023: Electromagnetism, Circuits, Waves, Optics, and Imaging

course_title: Mechanics and Statistical Physics from an Analytic, Numerical and Experimental Perspective 001
best_comment: If you’re deciding between the physics 12/15 track and aren’t as confident in your abilities, I highly recommend taking this class. The pacing of the course was perfect for me, and the assignments were challenging but still very doable (especially if you attend office hours and/or work with others). The teaching staff is so friendly and genuinely passionate about the subject matter. I also really enjoyed the lab component and formatting; if you want to learn coding in Python but don’t want to take CS50, this is honestly a pretty good way to gain some experience.
worse_comment: I think this class is a good alternative to one of the more difficult, upper level physics classes if you are not going to concentrate in physics. It was great to get practice with coding, but the analytical problems could be hard/annoying and the psets overall took a fair amount of time especially after the first few weeks. Lectures were not super engaging although I liked the professor; the material was just kind of boring to me.
subject: Physical Sciences
course_title_2023: Mechanics and Statistical Physics from an Analytic, Numerical and Experimental Perspective

course_title: Mechanics and Statistical Physics from an Analytic, Numerical and Experimental Perspective 001

subject: Physical Sciences
course_title_2023: Mechanics and Statistical Physics from an Analytic, Numerical and Experimental Perspective

best_comment: I would recommend this class to students interested in making things involving both digital objects and materials! There are definitely elements of both digital and non–digital objects, so I think an interest in both would be a great reason to take this course! I certainly found that the class was a lot of work at times—I'd recommend starting the assignments early and attending office hours—but the teaching staff is incredibly helpful with completing those, which is really nice.
subject: Physical Sciences

best_comment: This is an extremely well–taught class. It’s rigorous, and hard, and the psets will take time, but this is physics taught the right way—it ameliorated an AP physics 1 trauma that was introduced in high school, and was a very satisfying course. As a first calculus–based physics course, I can’t recommend it enough if you’re wondering whether you would enjoy physics as a discipline. I developed a strong mathematical  intuition for physical laws to complement and clarify the physical intuition I’ve developed throughout my young life and this was incredibly enjoyable; also, the demonstrations are great.  Physics night is SUPER fun, even if you’re in for hell because you started the pset when you got there (seriously, start before, or at least look at the problems before sitting down in Jefferson at 7pm), but the TFs and CAs are very helpful and wonderful to talk with.  Mundy is a wonderful professor, and I would advise taking this class in the spring because Mundy’s exams are not timed and this makes a massive difference.  Definitely my favorite class from this semester.
worse_comment: The problem sets have kind of a steep learning curve as you get used to the type of problems they present. However, there is always enough help to get through it.
subject: Physics

best_comment: This is an extremely well–taught class. subject: Physics

best_comment: This class is very difficult (especially if like me you take multivariable concurrently), but it is very fascinating and rewarding. The demonstrations in each class period are also very cool, and the demo guy was a great storyteller (if you have him). Main advice: 1. find a pset group, 2. go to section. Even if you can do the psets by yourself, checking with other people and making sure you can explain why you did what you did is crucial. Section is also where I actually learned most of the material, because in class you "learn" it but just from that it's often hard to apply. I guess instead of section you could do the textbook readings, but I much preferred attending section. The exams are difficult, but having them as take home was great (though you should manage your time well if you want to have a weekend). The final was very difficult but it was actually interesting and fun because of the types of problems given, and it also shows you how much you've actually learned even when it feels like you know nothing. (But we really all do know nothing. Physics is crazy!) If you're interested in physics (or if you like to see a shower of sparks at the end of class) I do believe you will enjoy this course! And make some great friends! Good luck!!
worse_comment: 15b is the hardest of the Physics 15s, but that does mean that it is terribly difficult. There won't be many concepts that are very difficult to grasp; rather, the difficulty is that the class moves very fast with concepts that build on one another. Don't be scared to take this class, but just be prepared to be on top of your work.
subject: Physics

best_comment: This class is very difficult (especially if like me you take multivariable concurrently), but it is very fascinating and rewarding. subject: Physics

best_comment: You're probably taking this because it's required anyways... It has the least hand–holding of all of the 15's, but wasn't too hard. In my opinion it was easier than 15b but harder than 15a. I wouldn't take it as an elective – the exams were difficult, even the take–home final! Huth is a good professor, and pretty flexible, too. His demos are great and keep it fun. Otherwise I feel pretty neutral about this class, it didn't cause stress but I definitely couldn't slack off.
worse_comment: This course is unnecessarily difficult, and the material frankly isn't interesting enough to justify the headache. Once you understand a topic or concept, it's usually actually super simple. The only reason this class is difficult is because of the way it's taught. I found it very difficult to learn the course material. Lectures move fast and often breeze through difficult or confusing concepts, and there isn't a good textbook. The lecture notes are not enough to understand the class. Every week, I'd spend hours on the internet trying to learn the necessary material for the course using other sources.
subject: Physics

subject: Physics

best_comment: This is a great introductory electronics course for physicists looking to understand laboratory instruments for experimental measurements.  For those who want to take Physics 123A/B in the future, but feel like they may need more preparation before taking a the more challenging course,  I would highly recommend this class.   While this is a newer course, Prof. Morii and Kathryn were great at making the learning material engaging and fun; this class is very much hands–on learning, and you will get much more enjoyment and reward from really trying to understand the concepts discussed and apply them to your own projects.
worse_comment: Make a serious effort to fully understand each lab and answer all of the lab questions.
subject: Physics

best_comment: This is a great introductory electronics course for physicists looking to understand laboratory instruments for experimental measurements.  For those who want to take Physics 123A/B in the future, but feel like they may need more preparation before taking a the more challenging course,  I would highly recommend this class.   While this is a newer course, Prof. Morii and Kathryn were great at making the learning material engaging and fun; this class is very much hands–on learning, and you will get much more enjoyment and reward from really trying to understand the concepts discussed and apply them to your own projects.

subject: Physics

best_comment: If you want to properly learn how to make circuits, please take this class. I enjoyed the breakdown of the class being half lecture and half lab; David Abrams is a good instructor, though he will not hesitate to go very in detail regarding specific topics  in class and office hours. Pedro was an amazing TF, and he helped me a lot in making sure that I was comfortable with the material, and was getting through the labs. Be aware though, this class takes up a lot of time: on top of the two four hour sessions, pre–class readings took me about an hour if I wanted to properly go through the material before section (when I was able to go through it, they were sometimes helpful). Even though David estimated 2–3 hours per homework during the week, normally it would take me double that amount of time, if I wanted to do the homework well.  TL;DR, this class was hard and time–consuming, but if you're interested in electronics it's definitely worth it!
subject: Physics

best_comment: Take this class! Pretty chill – just two exams. The material is really fun and honestly seems really informational in terms of just being a citizen of the world (i.e., subjects like planes, human energy, global warming), in that it gives you a lot to talk about. Morin is fantastic as a lecturer – covers topics in a clear way. All the homeworks are honestly really fun. Exams are fair. Soumya (the TF) is awesome – extremely nice and knowledgeable, really cares about the students.

Very good class on energy and future of renewable energies. Professor Hau is very good, very knowledgeable and willing to help students. She cares a lot and will even hold extra office hours to help if you need it.
worse_comment: This class goes into a lot of depth for semiconductors and photosynthesis. The first half mostly focuses on semiconductors, which is the more interesting half, however, the lectures can be dry. There's not much work that needs to be done outside of class because psets are assigned approximately every 2 weeks. The final project is a bit of a pain to do because you need to deliver a 30 minute presentation during reading period, and write a 6 page single spaced paper as well. Overall, it's not too much work, but it can be a boring class

best_comment: I'm in a superposition of feelings about this course.  And if you ask me in the morning and then ask again later, you might get a different answer.  First: Barandes is extremely dedicated, enthusiastic, and accommodating.  Second: the TAs were incredible, too.  The course content, though, left me wanting.  I wasn't always able to draw ties from one piece of material to the next.  It felt like each class we would walk out having heard, "now you have the tools to begin doing quantum mechanics," but we never hit the punchline.  I know it's a foundations course, so just expect that going in.  The philosophy aspects are on you to weave into the course.  It's there and ready to grab!  But I do think the application (seeing particle in a box and other canonical experiments) should motivate the material, too—not just the mathematical beauty and evolution of the field.In all, calibrate what you're looking for.  This course does a good job of most things, but know for sure that it is what you want!
subject: Physics

best_comment: Take this course, especially if it's with Professor Louis!! Professor Louis has such an illustrious career in practically every field in physics, and he's done physics education research and it shows! Professor Louis prioritizes student learning over everything else, and he is incredibly accessible and approachable, and will answer any questions you have during lecture or office hours (and will NEVER make you feel dumb). I think the pace and structure of this course is very well thought–out, and because of that, I think that I will retain the knowledge from this course for years to come. In addition, the support in this course is just amazing– there were office hours EVERY DAY, so no matter which day you started the pset on, you could count on getting support that day. The sections were above and beyond in quality – my TF Spencer was able to clarify, explain, and expand upon content covered in lecture, and I always felt prepared for the pset after his section. While the material is complex and difficult to understand (it's quantum mechanics), the course staff do everything in their power to help you. The psets can be quite difficult and time–consuming, but again, with the support from the teaching staff and from your classmates (highly recommend working with others!), they are doable and are very enlightening and satisfying to finish. Exams are similar in style – challenging, but not impossible, and certainly worth it. Don't feel intimidated by quantum mechanics; this class makes it very fun and gratifying to learn!
worse_comment: Get a pset group to avoid individual misunderstandings and errors.
subject: Physics

best_comment: Overall, I really enjoyed this course, and I would definitely recommend the course in general and especially if you like math computations. Professor Kim and the teaching fellow Henry are both incredibly helpful individuals and will take the time to answer your questions. The class follows the content within the Griffiths textbook closely, but the PSETS are challenging, worthwhile, (and pretty fun). Exams are tough, so study psets and lecture examples carefully. The course material might seem to go fast at times (especially towards the end of the semester), but it can always be understood with the help of the textbook. Office hours are extremely helpful and worth your time. At least try the course out, I think you’ll like it! :)
worse_comment: Professor Kim goes through many examples during class. I would recommend studying those examples and putting them on your cheat sheet when studying for exams. Also the final exam was very similar to the final review that Professor Kim did.
subject: Physics

best_comment: I think the best way to describe this course is that it is the most glorious way to get academic trauma. This course was hard, definitely one of the top 3 hardest courses I've ever taken (this is coming from someone who's taken courses like CS124 and physics143a with Doyle, so use that for comparison). It is also somewhat disorganized. At first, PSETs were due on Mondays, with TF office hours and section being held on Wednesday and Friday, so basically the only time we could get help was during Friday section (by Wednesday we hadn't even learned all of the material needed for the PSET so barely anyone had actually started the PSET). Then PSETs became due on Wednesdays after some complaints, but that made it even worse because in order for OHs to be useful, you either had to start the PSET the minute it came out or use an extension. The midterm was take–home, but it was the hardest take–home midterm I've ever taken and I definitely spent 25+ hours on it. After the midterm, the material also starts becoming disorganized since you jump between random topics like implementation of quantum computers, error correction, quantum complexity, etc., which are very interesting but you go through it so fast that you end up understanding maybe 10% of it all. There was also one week when prof. Lukin said the PSET would be short and sweet––and then it turned out to be harder than all of the previous PSETs, which I had spent an average of 15 hrs/week on.So yeah I definitely got traumatized by this course. But there is glory: Lukin is a great lecturer and is lowkey very humorous and cool, plus he's very big in the field of quantum info. The final project in this course can also be pretty cool: you basically get to use Qiskit and experiment with real quantum devices from IBM, which are a refreshing break from all of the tedious math and theory on most of the PSETs. You also get mentored by grad students from Lukin's group, which was super super helpful (if you get Nishad as your mentor, he will save your life in the class). As a result, I enjoyed this final project the most out of all final projects I've done in any course. Overall, if you are considering this course, you want to make sure you have quantum background and that you remember a lot of your linear algebra. And prepare for some trauma. But otherwise, this course is very rewarding.

course_title: Laser Physics and Modern Optical Physics 001
best_comment: Take this class if you're thinking of using lasers in (physics) research or if you're just interested in laser technologies, and you want to understand the underlying physics. You can also choose to just read Saleh & Teich instead, but I think the class experience is not bad, even though a good number of lectures were not delivered so clearly. There are good homeworks and Markus (professor) and Anant (TF) are incredibly nice and supportive (they even got ice cream for us at the end)!
subject: Physics
course_title_2023: Laser Physics and Modern Optical Physics

best_comment: Pretty standard physics course in terms of workload, exams, etc., but the material is super cool! The first few lectures are slow, but by the end of the course things start to get really interesting. Statistical mechanics explains a huge number of observable phenomena (Bose–Einstein condensate, semiconductors, stars, to name a few), so if you want to learn about real world systems this class is a must. The lecture notes are great, but the lectures ended up following them very closely, and at times it felt redundant.
worse_comment: Not my favorite. Neat demos.
subject: Physics

best_comment: Unless you're excited about this course ahead of time, RUN AWAY. There are alternative ways to fulfill the requirement, and your best option is to go for those. This class has been one of my least favorite in four years here, and definitely the worst within the Physics department. Everything breaks when you touch it, or even if you don't, and at most one person will know how to fix it. When that person is busy fixing everything for everyone else, good luck waiting around. Perhaps someone else will try their hand at a repair, and will end up making it way worse. The expectations for assignments, and therefore the justification of your grades, will be opaque (that is, if you even get a grade on your assignment). Raising any concerns will result in the staff expressing their empathy, along with making exactly zero changes. Take this nightmare of a class, and you will end up reconsidering your choice of concentration.

This is a great course for thinking about data analysis from an experimental (physicist) point of view. I learned what I needed to learn in order to think about my own data, error, and models better. I wish I had taken the course earlier in my PhD! I wouldn't necessarily recommend it in the first 2 years since you really want to have had lab experience collecting and trying to fit some data. Plus, Vinny is just great all around.
subject: Physics

best_comment: This is a really worthwhile class if you're willing to put in the time and effort. It's a lot of work, as it requires getting accustomed to a whole new notation. The lectures were often difficult to follow, but they didn't end up being super necessary for the class (though it would have been nice for them to be a bit more comprehensible).  This is a very cool class that opens the door to a really interesting and important field, and I recommend it even though it has a few weaknesses.
subject: Physics

best_comment: It's a really good class where you'll learn a lot
subject: Physics

I enjoyed the breakdown of the class being half lecture and half lab; David Abrams is a good instructor, though he will not hesitate to go very in detail regarding specific topics  in class and office hours. subject: Physics

best_comment: I enjoyed this course, but it was certainly challenging. Working with partners on the psets is a huge help, and ask for extensions if you need them. The course staff were super accommodating throughout the semester.

worse_comment: The course material is solid and the class notes are fantastic. But the lecture may be weirdly paced at times.
subject: Physics

best_comment: good class, matt reece is a pretty good lecturer, QI section was fun
subject: Physics

best_comment: This class was a lot of fun, and covered a wide range of material that is useful for modern particle physics. There were frequent connections to experiment, which was nice for grounding the theory, and the selected topics were very interesting. The final project was a great way to dive deep into a particular topic of interest and really apply the material that had been seen throughout the two semester of QFT I had taken.
worse_comment: Don't listen when Matt says this class is "more chill" than 253a. It is in the sense that there are no exams. It is not in the sense of workload.
subject: Physics

course_title: Renormalization Group Methods in Condensed Matter Physics 001
best_comment: This class is a great choice once you have a good understanding of the basics of condensed matter theory. Since it's not as standardized as, say, the 295 a/b series, the exact form of the class will depend a lot on the professor teaching it, and the topics they choose to talk about. David Nelson's lectures were very clear and accessible, and the topics captivating and surprisingly subtle. Assignments aren't always very easy, but if you start them on time and put in some effort, they will work out. Overall, great experience.

This course from Professor Vishwanath is amazingly well–taught (both in terms of problem sets and lectures) in my opinion. However, depending on your interest and passion in this subject, you may feel that the course is progressing in a bit slow manner. I personally read the recommended readings that Professor suggested, and this was very helpful for learning the important materials covered in the lecture more concretely. I highly recommend to read the textbook or suggested reading materials while taking this course in Professor Vishwanath's version.
subject: Physics

course_title: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers 001
best_comment: Honestly, I think this should be a required course for everyone. Learning how to write is so important in both academia and industry, and this course is a really great low stress way to learn how to write well. In particular Suzanne is really dedicated to the students and put together an amazing and diverse group of guest speakers and readings. I am so glad I got to take this course and only wish I had taken it earlier in my studies to produce better papers.
subject: Physics
course_title_2023: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers

course_title_2023: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers

course_title: Quantitative Research Methods in Population Health Sciences II 001
best_comment: Overall, a useful (required) course that covers a lot of topics in causal inference. Great course materials that I'll definitely find myself returning to. Some sub–topics in causal inference (e.g., non–linearity) are not really touched on, however.
subject: Population Health Sciences
course_title_2023: Quantitative Research Methods in Population Health Sciences II

best_comment: Take this course. This is probably my favorite class I have taken at Harvard (I took it with Mitchell my junior spring). The material is SO interesting, even if you are not a psych major. Not only that, but it is so so well taught. Mitchell is amazing––I enjoyed being in class and remembered the material just because of how well he taught it. Doing the reading is definitely a good idea for tests––if you listen in class and do the reading they are really not that bad. Making flashcards (he recommends that) is a really helpful way to study.  Best class!!!!!!
worse_comment: This course needs to be trashed and recreated. I understand that PSY 1 used to fill a genEd requirement. It no longer does so, yet the course structure and design remains the same. It is a terrible introduction to psychological science, built to trap students and provide them with completely outdated and unnecessary information. In no way, shape, or form is this class fitting to be an introduction to a science. If you take this course, you'll find your opinion is unwelcome, your complaints are unheard, and the professor has a weird bent on forcing attendance. This course made me lose most of the respect I had for psychology as an academic subject. DO NOT TAKE!
best_gem_comment: This class is fascinating! A very easy low commitment and low work–load gem. Take this class P/F for fun if you're remotely interested in psychology.
subject: Psychology

best_comment: Take this course. This is probably my favorite class I have taken at Harvard (I took it with Mitchell my junior spring). The material is SO interesting, even if you are not a psych major. Not only that, but it is so so well taught. Mitchell is amazing––I enjoyed being in class and remembered the material just because of how well he taught it.
