subject: Psychology

best_comment: Don't take this class unless you are really, really interested in the topic. The content is pretty dense and the workload is too high, especially for a sophomore level course. You are expected to memorize so much material, a lot of which is only mentioned once or twice in lecture and not clearly explained. Also, this class expects you to read over 200 pages of textbook per week. If you are truly passionate about developmental psych, then you could maybe enjoy this class. But if you're just looking to fulfill a foundational course requirement, I'd highly recommend taking either PSY15 or 18 instead. It'll save you so much time and stress, trust me.
worse_comment: I would not recommend taking this course. It is a lot of wok and not well organized. It is not well structured and caused me a lot of frustration.
best_gem_comment: This class is super interesting! You get to learn a lot about cool research related to children and it really gives you a lot of insight/ perspective on childhood. The lectures and really well done, and the class is easy and not that much work. Definitely a gem!
subject: Psychology

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!! It is super interesting and gives you a great foundation of understanding psychopathology. Dr. Shingleton is awesome and really cares about her students and takes feedback and their experiences really seriously in the best way. She brings in her clinical experience into lecture which adds a whole other interesting layer to the class. Really not super time consuming and the assignments do not take long to complete/are really straightforward. Exams are also really straightforward and directly relate to lecture material. If you are at ALL interested in psychiatry, psychopathology, neuroscience, or psychology, I highly HIGHLY recommend this course.
worse_comment: This class presents mental illness in a humanizing way that provides a fuller understanding of the individual.
best_gem_comment: Gem, very easy, a must–take. Recommend for everyone, equally for psych and non–psych concentrators. Work is extremely light, exams are easy, lectures are very fun and insightful.

course_title: Contemporary Issues in Psychology: Intensive Cross-level Analyses 001
best_comment: Obviously this is required for concentrators, and I know you are probably intimidated as I was at the start. I will tell you that I actually loved this course. Make sure you take on a lighter courseload otherwise because it is VERY demanding of your time and energy (mostly just writing–intensive), but this course will help to illuminate for you whether you are truly interested in psych, and if you are the work won't feel so bad because you'll be passionate about your sophomore research topic. I would think this class would be very dependent on your "section" leader, but Brandon was absolutely amazing. The class environment felt super supportive, more so than other classes I've taken at Harvard, and it was never intimidating. I got such helpful, individualized, and timely feedback on every assignment, which is sooo useful.
worse_comment: Prepare to have a bad experience.
subject: Psychology
course_title_2023: Contemporary Issues in Psychology: Intensive Cross-level Analyses

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!! This is one of the most important classes you will ever take at Harvard and in your life. All of the topics are incredibly pertinent to everyday life and your perspective on gender and the world will change so much. Every week I felt myself growing more and more as a student and as a citizen hoping to make a change in the world. Dr. Noll is the most intelligent, knowledgeable, introspective, and eloquent professor I have ever had, and listening to her during class discussions is such an invaluable experience because I gained so much knowledge. The assignments reinforced important themes and concepts and made me contemplate about how they show up in real life. Male–identifying students should feel very comfortable taking this class too. I highly recommended this class to all of my male friends because of how relevant this class is to everyone’s life, so if you are a male–identifying student, PLEASE consider taking this class!!! You will not regret it! Overall, this class was the best class I have ever taken in college because of the fascinating concepts and the brilliant Dr. Noll!
subject: Psychology

course_title: Nature Can Nurture: Fostering an Ecological Worldview 001
best_comment: This was a great class! Super interesting and chill. Loved the different components like the local environment presentation, the nature journal, and even the final paper was a good experience because it was pretty open–ended and Jacob gave a lot of really valuable feedback at multiple steps of the process. Great class !!!

course_title: The Science and Psychology of Music 001
best_comment: Super light workload and super sweet/passionate course staff! A little disorganized at times (instructions on assignments were unclear) but the content was pretty interesting. Mayron and Deborah were so sweet and supportive, and genuinely care about their students. Would recommend if you're looking for a gem! I bet this class will be even better next year since this was the first semester it was offered.
best_gem_comment: Super light workload and super sweet/passionate course staff! A little disorganized at times (instructions on assignments were unclear) but the content was pretty interesting. Mayron and Deborah were so sweet and supportive, and genuinely care about their students. Would recommend if you're looking for a gem! I bet this class will be even better next year since this was the first semester it was offered.

course_title: Precision Cognitive Neuroscience: Opportunities Afforded by Deep, Intensive Study Within Individuals 001
best_comment: Awesome course! A great way to reshape thinking on what is meaningful research, learning from a knowledgable and helpful professor.

course_title: Decisions Big and Small: The Cognitive Science of Making Up Your Mind 001
best_comment: This class is really great! You makes countless decisions in your everyday life, and this class will give you the frameworks and models necessary to understand those decisions better. Prof. Ullman is an extremely great lecturer who truly cares about his students and every lecture keeps you on your toes. The class is not much work (~2 hours a week) and I really enjoyed this class and would highly recommend.
subject: Psychology
course_title_2023: Decisions Big and Small: The Cognitive Science of Making Up Your Mind

best_comment: This is a wonderful course with applicable topics, ideas, and explorations. A relatively low workload with interesting material results in the ability of students to engage with topics fully and effectively. Dr. Phelps is lovely and incredibly knowledgeable on the topic of neuroscience of emotions. Loved this course and would highly recommend!

course_title: Computational Cognitive Neuroscience: Building Models of the Brain 001
best_comment: Sam is an absolute beast in terms of raw neuro knowledge; lectures pack a ton of info and offer a great survey. Overall chill class and you learn a ton about neuroscience (that is not just bashing matrix calculus in the same way Neuro 231 might be). The hands–on aspect of the class is also very nice; similar to real research, you read papers and reimplement them (i.e. code up the results).
worse_comment: Would definitely recommend it if you have some interest in learning to think more quantitatively about the brain! Very chill in terms of grading, definitely a very weird class structure that I didn't think was super conducive to learning—for example, we were given a paper or two to read before most classes, but we never discussed our own thoughts on the papers or even discussed the papers at all. The lectures all felt quite disjointed, and the projects were only slightly related to the readings. As for the projects, the directions and expectations are incredibly unclear—was super stressful at first, but then got the hang of it—but they were great experiences to become a better programmer communicator of science.

course_title: Biological and Artificial Visual Systems: How Humans and Machines Represent the Visual World 001
best_comment: Take this class! It is fun, interesting, and some of the readings will blow your mind. Prof. Alvarez is so passionate about the topic that it's contagious. I wish I could take it again and continue learning about biological and computer vision. The format is engaging, with take–home recorded lectures and dynamic classroom discussions. It attracts a multi–disciplinary audience so everyone is learning something new.
subject: Psychology
course_title_2023: Biological and Artificial Visual Systems: How Humans and Machines Represent the Visual World

best_comment: Holly is so sweet, and the course content is genuinely so interesting. That being said, this course is very much you get what you put in. You can definitely skate by without attending lectures/doing the readings and be okay, but that is kind of doing yourself a disfavor because you won't learn much. It's easy to not prioritize this class because it's so chill and the teaching staff is so nice, but I would really recommend taking it when you can devote some time to it (and by that I mean just like 3–4 hours a week)! I learned a lot and had a great time.
best_gem_comment: Gem! You get to learn super interesting and relevant info concerning close relationships. A lot of the class is about you reflecting on your own close relationships and how you can better them and apply what you learn in class. Writing assignments and presentations are manageable. The teaching staff is super understanding.
subject: Psychology

course_title: Is Persistence a Panacea? Contextualizing Human Motivation 001
best_comment: Fantastic course! You should absolutely take it. Tim is a tremendous teacher and great person –– super friendly, accessible, helpful, and intelligent. You'll learn a great deal about goals, stuff you never would have even thought of before. One of my favorite courses I've taken at Harvard. You definitely need to take at least one class with Tim! (See my write–up about Tim as a teacher for more info!)
subject: Psychology
course_title_2023: Is Persistence a Panacea? Contextualizing Human Motivation

course_title: Power and Society in Romantic Relationships 001
best_comment: This is truly a phenomenal course. It is enjoyable, educational, and genuinely rewarding.  It is clear that Professor Valshtein cares more about you learning as opposed to testing your knowledge. Consequently, it fostered an environment where, as a student, you don't need to worry about anything except engaging with the course material as the course intended. Outside of the classroom, I quoted material I learned from this class regularly in my everyday conversations with my friends. I think it is representative of truly how valuable and applicable the knowledge from this course is.With that said, it is one of the rare courses at Harvard where you get out what you put in. Not intended to bad mouth other classes that aren't as rewarding, but truly in Psych 1527, it does a phenomenal job of offering lots of value if you engage with the course material and every discussion. If you come into class with a good attitude and a curious mind, it won't take long until you can appreciate this classes's beauty.

course_title: Blindspot: Hidden Biases of Good People 001
best_comment: This class is definitely challenging, but super rewarding! You will learn a lot about implicit bias, and Dr. Banaji is an incredible professor. The readings are engaging and the workload is very manageable!
subject: Psychology
course_title_2023: Blindspot: Hidden Biases of Good People

course_title: Psychology of Social Connection and Belonging 001
best_comment: This course is absolutely fantastic. Dr. Perry is not just one of the friendliest teachers, but one of the friendliest people in all of Harvard. She makes this class so fun, and it contains such interesting subject matter. You'll learn so much about human connection and you'll have a great time doing it. I can't recommend this class highly enough! One of the best classes I ever took at Harvard :)

course_title: Family, School, and Society: Shaping the Developing Child 001
best_comment: Take this class!! Whether you're interested in psychology, education, policy, law, healthcare, becoming a parent one day, or even something else, this course will benefit you. The course load is quite light, and the discussions lead by Dr. Lewin–Bizan alone are enough to make this class worthwhile. Such a fun, engaging, and interesting lecture, lead by such a wonderful professor!!
best_gem_comment: Great class. A gem for sure. All of the assignments were feasible and relative to course content. You always get good feedback, and discussions were interesting. A lot of flexibility and independence in terms of assignment deadlines, and every assignment was straightforward.
subject: Psychology
course_title_2023: Family, School, and Society: Shaping the Developing Child

best_comment: great way to dedicate course credit to research!
subject: Psychology

best_comment: Please take this class! The concepts are so important in everyday life! You are able to observe class concepts in yourself and others, which in turn allow you to analyze class concepts in such an interesting way. Also, Dr. Somerville is so wonderful and encourages you think critically about the current research and ways it can be improved. She is also just an overall wonderful person!

Pretty standard psych elective, in that it was not overly time consuming but very interesting! Add in reasonable (and even fun!) assignments, a caring professor, and neat readings, and overall I would definitely recommend. (though keep in mind it is a pretty general course! in case you're looking for something a little more focused)
worse_comment: Do not – under any circumstances – take this courseIts boring, more complicated than it looks, and its one of the worst (if not the worst) classes I have taken at Harvard.There is nothing good about this course: the content is boring and not well–structured, there is no section component to discuss what you learned in lecture (have fun only having powerpoint slides to study for a very complicated set of "quizzes" which are essentially midterms), and you never meet the person who grades your coursework.
best_gem_comment: It's a huge gem
subject: Psychology

best_comment: If you have an anxiety disorder, know someone with an anxiety disorder, or are interested in learning more about anxiety disorders, definitely take this class. Workload is light and exams are reasonable, and Dr. McNally's lectures are very engaging and interesting.
worse_comment: The tests are hard!

best_comment: this course is AMAZING!!! and i recommend it with much enthusiasm. mayron is such a kind hearted and knowledgeable professor.  i am so lucky to have been a student in his class. he is patient and understanding, flexible with deadlines, and cares a lot about his students. he is truly incredible. the assignments are easy and this class is LIGHT work. you can literally take it as a fifth class and get an A.
worse_comment: The class is heavy with group work. If you are an independent learner, this is not your class. You have to write a paper with a partner, and then produce a podcast with the same partner. The danger is if your partner is bad, you're screwed.
subject: Psychology

best_comment: Absolutely take this course! This is the most rewarding course that I have taken, and I am a senior.  Professor Hatzenbuehler is really an eminence in his field of research, and it's such a precious opportunity to get to learn about stigma directly from him. He is also super well–spoken and the nicest person in the world, and the teaching staff is amazing, which mean you will most likely have a very positive experience. The issue of stigma as it relates to health has more recently come to attention, and it's perhaps a lot more complex than how it is simplified in popular media. There are so many different motives and processes that can underlie stigma, and if we don't understand them well, well–intended interventions could only backfire. This course will teach you the complexities of stigma processes, and ultimately give you hope that things can change. If you want to contribute to that change, or are curious in any way, this is certainly the course for you to take.
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! Not only is it a gem but it really truly teaches you about the importance, relevance, and implications of stigma that will change the way  you view discrimination and stigmatic interactions.  If you are a person interested in solidifying the reasons for why people may stigmatize,/discriminate even unintentionally and the potential solutions and health implications, this class is a definite must. The material itself is really interesting and the class is engaging. The professor is extremely understanding and the class itself does not actively try to make sure students don't get an A. Note that you will have to actively participate in the class every time and will likely have to be present for every lecture to receive full points for the participation.

best_comment: This is a great class if you want to learn about self–injury and the existing literature regarding suicide. It's really discussion–based meaning you can focus on really any aspect of the literature you find curious (terminology, theories, prevention etc). The assignments fit really well with the content and don't feel overwhelming because prof nock gives you a lot of resources and is very transparent!
worse_comment: This class is about suicide and non–suicidal self–injury and both are clearly serious topics, but Professor Nock is a world leader and expert in suicide research and is able to foster navigate discussions in a way that feels effective and safe.  I looked forward to this class every week because I felt like it was a comprehensive overview of not only suicide research but also gaps in the mental health industry.

course_title: Introduction to Statistics for the Behavioral Sciences 001
best_comment: Take this class! I had horrible experiences in math courses at Harvard and was therefore nervous going into this course, but the course staff is so helpful and makes sure that you feel comfortable learning and making mistakes. Grace is a fantastic professor! Everyone in the teaching staff was super approachable and massively helpful.
worse_comment: Not the worst, but also completely miserable.
best_gem_comment: This class is a GEM, it's a very light workload and an amazing alternative to stat110/102/104. The teaching staff genuinely wants you to do well and get an A. The material is presented clearly and there's a lot of support. It's a good introduction to R if you're looking to start coding!

best_comment: Your experience in this class will likely depend a lot on your previous experience with, aptitude for, and interest in psychology research. I came into this class with experience from other courses in creating and running psych experiments, so this class was basically a review. On the one hand, it was pretty easy; on the other hand, it felt like a waste of my time. I don't think many students really loved this course, but depending on your previous experience, you might like this course more or less. The positive of this course is that you'll receive a lot of specific feedback on your work, which you won't necessarily find in upper level classes.
worse_comment: I found this class quite time–consuming and difficult, and although the content was interesting at times, it wasn't enjoyable due to how stressful it was. Grading was also quite harsh. I felt there was also little guidance in terms of assignments.
subject: Psychology

best_comment: This is one of the best graduate course I have taken or heard of. It is remarkably useful and geared towards exactly what any grad student needs– there is no reason to not take the course.
subject: Psychology

course_title: Research Methods in Child & Adolescent Clinical Psychology 001
best_comment: If you're looking for a lab to join and an opportunity to get hands–on research experience, enroll in this course. And especially if you've taken another class with Dr. Weisz and are in search of more time with him, definitely enroll in this course. Assignments are flexible and geared towards the interests of the student, and everyone in the Weisz Lab is downright awesome. Such a wonderful and friendly group of people to encourage learning about the wonderfully relevant world of youth clinical psychology!
subject: Psychology
course_title_2023: Research Methods in Child & Adolescent Clinical Psychology

best_comment: Yes I definitely will, I felt it was really interesting and really enjoyed discussions!
worse_comment: More work than CBB prosem after the edits made by Fiery.

best_comment: This is a great class if you want to gain research experience is a close–knit setting.
subject: Psychology

best_comment: This course is perfect for people curious about how religion works in life and society. The readings are very interesting, but long. I struggled to finish them, but skimmed the best I could. Even so, I was still able to contribute what I knew and make connections. Work hard on the midterm! Pedro is a great resource for making sure that your understanding of course concepts is accurate. I enjoyed doing my creative project and would highly recommend that instead of the final since I was able to talk about the course topics that were most interesting to me, the ones that I paid the most attention to over the semester.
subject: Religion

best_comment: This class has been top 2 for me of 3 years worth of classes.  Recommend it to the highest degree to students who are Christian and battle with how their faith should be a lens and a lighthouse when thinking and discussing hotly debated topics.  This class was so fun and everyone was entirely invested.  I never thought about how much the reading was (which is not too much) because I was so genuinely interested in the material.  Class discussion is the best; this was the only class where I really felt able to say anything relevant without having to worry about being judged or discriminated.  I wish there was more class time per week.  Professor Lockwood is spectacular and gives very useful background information so you also come away learning concrete material.  He has wonderful input and always facilitates the best discussions.
subject: Religion

course_title: Topics in Religion and Literature: Narratives of Religious Conversion in American Literatures 01
best_comment: This class is amazing! Professor Lamberth creates the most lovely, warm seminar environment and is such a brilliant and kind person. The readings are incredible, and the other students in my class were wonderful. This is the best class I've taken at Harvard.
Take this! Even if you're only casually considering religion. it's wonderful!
worse_comment: This class is a good introduction to religion and the topics are fairly interesting, but I did not feel totally supported as growing as a writer in the class and the long class times made the last hour of discussion feel long and a little painful to get through.
subject: Religion

best_comment: The people it attracts are, without fail, interesting and fun. And the texts are great!

course_title: Beginning French I: Cross-Cultural Encounters in French 001
best_comment: I definitely recommend this class if you're interested in learning French! Madame Mills is awesome and it was very fun without being too much work.
subject: French
course_title_2023: Beginning French I: Cross-Cultural Encounters in French

course_title: Advanced French I: The Contemporary Francophone World Through Cinema 001
best_comment: would highly recommend!! Madame Brisson is wonderful and the classes are so enjoyable. Super accessible class, just make sure to put time aside to watch the films!
subject: French
course_title_2023: Advanced French I: The Contemporary Francophone World Through Cinema

course_title: Advanced French I: The Contemporary Francophone World Through Cinema 002
best_comment: This course is a great step in the French path. It is interesting and the films are great. Be aware, the film Laurence Anyways is great but it is 3hrs, so just don't procrastinate it. Be sure to discuss in class or else the class will be awkward. The workload is not very heavy! Dre Brisson is so great and kind.
subject: French
course_title_2023: Advanced French I: The Contemporary Francophone World Through Cinema

course_title: Advanced French II: Écrivons droit(s)/ Writing Right(s): Justice, Equity, Rights, and Writing 002
best_comment: I think this is a very good course to take. I would recommend making sure you start the assignments in the dossier with ample time (not that they're insanely long, but it's just nice to have them all done by class time). I also really appreciated how clear our assignments were and enjoyed speaking with other students during class. It's probably my favorite French class I've taken at Harvard! I'd recommend it!
subject: French
course_title_2023: Advanced French II: Justice, Equity, Rights, and Language

best_comment: I would tell future students that this class has a lot of reading but that it's very interesting and you will definitely learn and be able to practice your French.
worse_comment: There is a decent amount of reading for this class, so if you struggle with comprehension, it might not be the class for you.

best_comment: Take this class! Especially if you are a photographer, this is the class for you. The class is perfectly structured, with engaging readings, well–spaced essays, smaller "pastiche" writing assignments, and a few really cool museum visits. The class discussions are superb, and M Rodriguez does a fantastic job of lightly facilitating them but leaving a lot of space for students to talk about what they want. This has been one of my favorite classes at Harvard. I think one of the key reasons is that it wasn't so much a french class as it was a class taught in french. It's a fantastic class at the core, and the ability to take it in french only makes it better.

This class is a true breath of fresh air—it is wonderful and engaging. Proust must be read with care, but if you are willing to commit the time, it is truly worth it. His novels are beautiful, and the class truly treats them as such, analyzing and discussion intricate choices. The seminar size makes for very interesting conversation and connections to peers, and Professor Greene and Émile were always encouraging and kind. The course develops critical thinking, discussion, and writing skills.

This class is really helpful in improving your French and interesting if you put in the work and take it seriously. Taking the time to engage with the texts is difficult to balance at times but the books are really good. I also really appreciated looking more critically at France and its imperialism. Learning French through Francophone literature around the world was more enjoyable than just reading books by French authors

course_title: Beginning Italian II - Parliamo Italiano! The Art & Craft of Italy 003
best_comment: Italian 11 is quite fast, but if you pay attention in the course and do what the professor tells you, you'll be fine by the end. Professor Tragni is such a kind soul, and she truly wants you to succeed in the class. I had several instances in which my medical or personal issues stood in the way of completing my assignments/taking my exams, but she was understanding and helped me out when I was struggling; that kind of support is rare and something I'll remember in my four years here. Italian is not an easy language, especially when you get to the more complex grammatical structures, but if you keep practicing, pay attention, and do your work, you will be successful. Highly recommend Italian 11—great course, great environment, and great professor!
subject: Italian
course_title_2023: Beginning Italian II - Parliamo Italiano! The Art & Craft of Italy

course_title: Upper-Level Italian: Italiano in Verde: Sustainability Issues in the Italian Classroom 001
best_comment: This is a wonderful class in which you learn about several aspects of Italian culture and sustainable living while having fun and meeting great people. Since the sections are generally small, you get very close to the people in them and it is much easier to study something when you are in a friendly environment rather than in a large classroom. Additionally, the course had a great structure for learning grammar and vocabulary, making for a smooth and enjoyable process.
worse_comment: This class is excellent. It not only improved my knowledge of the Italian language, but also opened my eyes to issues of sustainability in Italy and beyond. We covered a range of topics, from sustainable fashion to the migrant crisis in Europe. At the same time, the coursework and small group discussions helped me grow as a writer and a speaker. I highly recommend this class!
subject: Italian
course_title_2023: Upper-Level Italian: Italiano in Verde: Sustainability Issues in the Italian Classroom

course_title: Preparing the Revolution: Machiavelli, Gramsci, and the People 001
best_comment: This is an excellent course, hands down. This is a true humanities course that expands one's horizons and challenges one to think differently.

course_title: The Ego in things: fashion as a moral laboratory 001
best_comment: This class was VERY INTERESTING. If it's offered next year or in the future, I highly recommend taking it just to learn about something interesting in a low commitment class. Coccia was a wonderful lecturer and a very fun guy. Go to his office hours and chat with him, he's very interesting! The course materials are definitely eurocentric, though, so if that might bother you, I would not recommend. It does focus on heavily white authors

Loved this class! I genuinely had so much fun and at times forgot that this was an academic course for credit. It felt so much more like just chatting with friends! The assignments are not insanely difficult and the classes and homework leave you well prepared!
subject: Spanish

best_comment: this class was great! jorge is an awesome teacher and he made the class super enjoyable and interesting.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Advanced Spanish Language I: Viewing the Hispanic World 004
best_comment: This course does cold–call, but the professors are excellent and the structure of the class really allowed me to practice speaking spontaneously. This was my first Spanish class since taking AP Spanish in high school (it had been 2.5 years since my last course) and this was a great reintroduction. Grading is very low pressure and there are opportunities to fix all of your mistakes in writing assignments. Movies were sometimes hard to keep up with every weekend, especially without Spanish subtitles (this would be really helpful for future iterations of the course), but they are all great picks.
worse_comment: Watch the moviessss – at least the critical parts and speed through some others if you have to – we discuss all aspects of the film – if you didn't watch it, Wikipedia alone won't prepare you
subject: Spanish
course_title_2023: Advanced Spanish Language I: Viewing the Hispanic World

course_title: Spanish for Latino Students II: Connecting with Communities 001
best_comment: Take this class!!! This was one of my favorite classes this semester. We got to have a lot of important, fun, and interesting discussions while practicing our Spanish during class. Profesora Parra–Velasco is lovely and really encourages you to critically think about the language and the meaning of "proper" Spanish. You will also get to work with the Latinx community in Boston through an organization.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2023: Spanish for Latino Students II: Connecting with Communities

best_comment: This is an amazing class!!!! Profe is really caring, enthusiastic, and passionate about this course. The readings and materials are all very interesting. & worth the read! This class is also a very nice way to balance a tougher work load. Very low–stress class. I definitely recommend!
subject: Spanish

course_title: Tales of Two Spains: A Survey of Spanish Modern Literature and Culture (18th to 21st centuries) 001
best_comment: I would tell future students to make sure they have a clear understanding of the readings so that they feel confident in class discussions and to stay engaged in the lectures/discussion as more as possible. The more you stay engaged (both in and out of class) the more you'll be interested in the literature/topics and a 2 hour period won't feel so long.
Take this class! Its a great opportunity to read interesting texts, improve your grammar, and translate.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Migration and Border-Crossing in Film and Photography 001
best_comment: This is a really great class to gain a breadth of knowledge on migration and get a different way to approach it. Each class conversation was very thought provoking and even as someone who has taken a couple of classes in migration, I walked out of each class having learned something new or with a different perspective on things I thought I already knew. Additionally, Professor Vega–Durán is a phenomenal instructor who is very generous with her time and also extremely knowledgeable on the topic of migration and does a great job at keeping the course engaged while also being flexible to talk about specific topics you may be interested in covering.

course_title: Thinking Beyond the Human: Persons, Things and the Environment in Latin American Culture 001
best_comment: Take this course! It is   a time commitment, the course readings can be long, but Mauro and Profe Sorensen create a great class environment and really help every student on their journey.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2023: Thinking Beyond the Human: Persons, Things and the Environment in Latin American Culture

best_comment: This is hands down one of the best classes I've taken at H (and I'm a spring semester senior). I came in knowing nothing about Barcelona and the Catalan culture and came put really appreciate the city and its people. It gave me a bigger understanding of the culture and origin and also allowed me to understand the debate that exists in Spain better!  Now, I want to go visit the city and not just be a tourist, but really go and appreciate the history and beauty of Barcelona.  The professor is super kind, understanding, helpful, and caring and is very VERY knowledgeable about the topic and super helpful in the final project. The workload is a perfect amount and you can truly enjoy the class and not worry about your grade.
subject: Spanish

course_title: AIDS, Aesthetics, & Politics in Latin America 001
best_comment: The professor is very nice about it if you aren't confident in your Spanish.
Don't stress about it! The course is designed to help you make progress and work through the normal problems that arise in the course of any long–term research project.
subject: Russia, E Europe & Cntrl Asia

best_comment: The emotional payoff of writing a thesis you are proud of is worth a lot, put in the effort. Put in the effort early as well; don't subject yourself to the pain of last–minute work and extensions, however justified it may seem at the time.
subject: Russia, E Europe & Cntrl Asia

course_title: Intermediate Bosnian, Croatian, and Serbian II 001
best_comment: Take BCS! Prof. Kuzmic is fantastic and this is a great opportunity to learn something new. Non–heritage speakers need not be afraid of throwing their hats in the ring. It's a very welcoming and encouraging environment.
subject: Bosnian, Croatian & Serbian
course_title_2023: Intermediate Bosnian, Croatian, and Serbian II

best_comment: I found it to be a lot easier than Russian AA, as I felt way more comfortable with reading, writing, and speaking at this point. There's a lot more grammar pushed onto you this semester, so its really important to stay on top of that. You will improve greatly though, your proficiency skyrockets at this point.
subject: Russian

best_comment: I found it to be a lot easier than Russian AA, as I felt way more comfortable with reading, writing, and speaking at this point. There's a lot more grammar pushed onto you this semester, so its really important to stay on top of that. You will improve greatly though, your proficiency skyrockets at this point.
subject: Russian

best_comment: This is a great class and I recommend anyone interested in Russian to take it. You will learn so much in a short amount of time, and the Russian language department is very supportive of all the students. I really appreciated the tight–knit section group and we had a lot of fun in class.
subject: Russian

best_comment: This is a great class and I recommend anyone interested in Russian to take it. You will learn so much in a short amount of time, and the Russian language department is very supportive of all the students. I really appreciated the tight–knit section group and we had a lot of fun in class.
subject: Russian

best_comment: Take this class if you are strong in russian already. Preferably, if you did will in intensive or really well in elementary. The best students in this class all lived in russia, had a connection to russia, took russian in hs, or were russian. If you don't fit these categories, it will be hard. Five times meeting a week is also a lot of time
subject: Russian

best_comment: This course is a continuation of Russian Ha. The two course series has been a unique opportunity to fill in many of the gaps in my Russian language knowledge. I now have the vocabulary to speak about grammar, I have learned the major grammatical concepts, including all cases, and I can write in Russian with some confidence that there are minimal errors. I don't know where else I would have gotten the opportunity to  do this, and highly recommend this course to anyone who want to take their home–grown Russian to the next level.
subject: Russian

course_title: Advanced Russian II: Reading, Composition, and Conversation 001
best_comment: This course is great. You will learn Russian while reading works by some great authors like Chekhov and Dostoevsky. I've long heard of Dostoevsky, but I've never read any work by him. Of course, it wasn't easy, but I really liked the reading. The reading by Chekhov was also very interesting. The film is good too. Something that we didn't have in Russian 101 was that in Russian 103 each student was partnered with a Russian student and we had five calls throughout the semester, which were very helpful for practicing the language and learning about the life of Russian people nowadays.
subject: Russian

best_comment: This is a wonderful class (if Svitlana Malykhina is teaching) that I can't recommend highly enough! It's so engaging and guides you to consider aspects of media (graffiti, contemporary music, photography) that are often overlooked and how they interact with Russian culture. Svitlana is an incredible professor and is so dedicated to supporting her students in their learning
subject: Russian
course_title_2023: Fourth-Year Russian: Russian Media and Popular Culture

course_title: Hacking Russia: Technological Dreams and Nightmares of Russian Culture 001
best_comment: Easy and enjoyable class on a fascinating subject matter. Prof. Skakov has an interesting perspective and a fantastic network (i.e. he knows many of the authors/ artists personally).

course_title: Russia’s Golden Age: Literature, Arts, and Culture 001
best_comment: This course is an absolute treasure (not an easy gem, but a truly great course that you won't regret taking). It does require some work, but it's totally worth it to read some of the best literature in the world. Prof Buckler is incredible, don't miss the chance to take a class with her. The overall classroom environment was incredibly welcoming and fun. It's great to know the names of all your classmates, and Prof Buckler and Brett really facilitated a positive classroom energy. Fantastic readings and course materials, including film, opera, and ballet. I learned so much! One of my all–time favorite classes at Harvard and one that I know I'll look back on positively for years to come.
best_gem_comment: This course is an absolute treasure (not an easy gem, but a truly great course that you won't regret taking). It does require some work, but it's totally worth it to read some of the best literature in the world. Prof Buckler is incredible, don't miss the chance to take a class with her. The overall classroom environment was incredibly welcoming and fun. It's great to know the names of all your classmates, and Prof Buckler and Brett really facilitated a positive classroom energy. Fantastic readings and course materials, including film, opera, and ballet. I learned so much! One of my all–time favorite classes at Harvard and one that I know I'll look back on positively for years to come.
subject: Slavic
course_title_2023: Russia’s Golden Age: Literature, Arts, and Culture

best_comment: This is a fantastic class, and I am so glad that it took it. It was wonderful to be in a class with Iaroslava, and I hope I have more opportunities to work with her!

10b is by far the best course I have taken at Harvard and the type of course I wanted to take/imagined taking here. It is definitely intellectually challenging and requires a lot of time, but I think that level of rigor is necessary for a class to be life–changing like 10b was. 10b is western social theory, but it's also not just that. The texts are diverse and more applicable to the modern world than you'd think, and I often find myself mentally referencing concepts or thinkers we read in 10b when I'm just listening to the news or having conversations with my friends. I have also definitely become a better writer after slogging through six fat essays. Overall, would highly recommend — Social Studies 10a and b make you think, like really think. Even if you think you don't like theory (like I did), I would say it's worth giving it a shot because it has made me smarter, more critical, and more open all at the same time.
worse_comment: This course is difficult but these texts can be seriously life–changing if you take them seriously and apply them to your own life. Try to do as much of the readings as possible and stay on top of your work — things can pile up quickly if you don't.
subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies

best_comment: 10b is by far the best course I have taken at Harvard and the type of course I wanted to take/imagined taking here. It is definitely intellectually challenging and requires a lot of time, but I think that level of rigor is necessary for a class to be life–changing like 10b was. 10b is western social theory, but it's also not just that. The texts are diverse and more applicable to the modern world than you'd think, and I often find myself mentally referencing concepts or thinkers we read in 10b when I'm just listening to the news or having conversations with my friends. I have also definitely become a better writer after slogging through six fat essays. Overall, would highly recommend — Social Studies 10a and b make you think, like really think. Even if you think you don't like theory (like I did), I would say it's worth giving it a shot because it has made me smarter, more critical, and more open all at the same time.
worse_comment: This course is difficult but these texts can be seriously life–changing if you take them seriously and apply them to your own life. Try to do as much of the readings as possible and stay on top of your work — things can pile up quickly if you don't.
subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies

best_comment: This is a really great methods course that actually helps you get ready for your thesis! The teaching staff is great and the topics covered are super varied, they don't just cover the typical things, so also super interesting! This course did actually make me change up my plans for what methods to use, as I was exposed to new methods and found different ones fit my thesis! Would definitely recommend!
worse_comment: If you've taken a Social Studies Junior Tutorial or another class where you had to write a research paper and think critically about methods, this class was very repetitive and intuitive.

best_comment: This class has a phenomenal reading list, but could have been organized better. Terry would assign us excellent readings, but then allow students to fully direct the flow of the conversation for the full two hours. The pacing often suffered because of this. There were times when we would read a really interesting book or paper, but never discuss it in class because the conversation never came around to it. Often we’d have five/six readings but only discuss one or two of them—making it hard to motivate myself to finish all the readings. It also felt like we often spent lots of time on minor details, so that the core ideas of a reading were never discussed.We got weekly emails with our reading assignments, but they were sometimes confusing or poorly worded.On the other hand, Terry is an amazingly thoughtful, committed teacher who really cares about his students and has a deep knowledge of the subject matter. The go–with–the–flow design of the class did allow us students a lot of chances to discuss and debate with one another, which is always fun.
worse_comment: very difficult
subject: Social Studies

course_title: Art, Political Culture, and Civic Life 001
best_comment: This class singlehandedly changed the course of my thesis and inspired me to focus on the topics I love and am passionate about. By far it is the best tutorial/small discussion based course I have ever been in. The professor (as well as every classmate) was ready to have amazing and deep discussions on topics, and always provided helpful feedback and suggestions for our papers. After giving my presentation on my final paper, I truly believe the feedback I received from both students and the professor helped me put together a better paper. Words can't express how amazing this class was. Not to give myself away, but is one of the few classes where I always made sure to do EVERY readings, because that's how interesting the topics were. It was two hours long, but the pace of discussion and the enthusiasm of my classmates never made it feel like that. One of the few (if not only) classes were a five minute break halfway through; there was always something else to talk about. Take this course if you want to truly learn how to have freedom and creativity with your thesis. With Professor Adatto, every topic is possible!
subject: Social Studies
course_title_2023: Art, Political Culture, and Civic Life

best_comment: This is a great class; Prof. Rosen has so much to offer and the subject matter is so relevant to everything in life.
Do a 92r! Find a mentor who shares your research interests and go research! It is a great experience that I recommend everyone does before they graduate.
subject: Sociology

best_comment: Definitely recommend. Professor Meyer is an incredibly kind, enthusiastic, and knowledgeable professor, so this class is definitely a worthwhile way to fulfill the sociology junior tutorial.
subject: Sociology

best_comment: This course is a pretty easy introduction to the various methods of Sociology. Paul Chang is an amazing and engaging lecturer, even on Zoom. I also think he does a good job to pick really good readings for the syllabus. It is honestly worth while to read as much as you can.  The assignments were a bit boring since you could not pick the topics, but they were overall easy to do. The course mainly focuses on the pros and cons of each method rather than the in–depth intricacies. This maybe a good course if you are still trying to figure out which methods to use for a thesis. However, if you already know what methods you want to use, maybe other in–depth courses would be better.
worse_comment: Be prepared for a lot of new vocabulary and ways to apply new methods to your sociological thinking. It comes at you a lot at once and very quickly but if you stay organized and pay attention you can handle it.

best_comment: This class is so great! The concepts are super interesting and the workload is actually manageable. I've learned a lot from this class. Not only is the actual concepts interesting but the teaching staff are amazing! Danilo Mandic is an amazing professor who makes lecture so interesting. The TFs are also super wonderful! I would recommend that you take this class if you are interested in sociology, politics, or how the world works!
worse_comment: Should be titled, Danillo Mandic aka The Goat, spits facts about pop culture and the nature of reality for 2 hours a week. Hated missing class.

best_comment: This is an absolutely amazing course and I enthusiastically recommend it. Professor Viterna is brilliant, funny, and extremely clever. The lectures are hugely engaging and the material is so fundamental and important to know. Section always has very interesting discussion and both Professor Viterna and the TFs are very available and supportive.

Professor Dromi is one of my favorite professors and I would highly recommend the course if you're at all interested in humanitarian aid. The assignments were creative, interesting, and fun to do, and the course staff were super helpful and were very accessible.
worse_comment: Shai is a very smart guy, but for a host of reasons the class was miserable. Most evident in weeks 1 & 2 having a classroom packed with students, with the rest of the semester being  a ghost town. Readings were overbearing/uninteresting, silly busy work assignments with rules that no one has time for... take this if you're an overambitious freshman/sophomore with no job and/or a great interest in humanitarian activism.
best_gem_comment: This course is definitely a gem. The readings are interesting and there were a few discussions that truly changed how I viewed the humanitarian world. But, overall, you can succeed in this course relatively easily.

best_comment: The content of the course is super interesting and very important. Sections are also SUPER fantastic!! Lecture could definitely be more engaging, though. Also, sometimes the instructions of the assignments are a bit unclear and then you get a lot of points taken off for things you weren't expecting. This could be a good course, though, if you are interested in the intersections of public health and environmental injustice.
worse_comment: I would say take this class if you have never been exposed to environmental injustice work. For people who are very involved, you might not get as much out of this class.
subject: Sociology

course_title: The Internet, Social Media, and Society 001
best_comment: This is a great class for anyone interested in the course topic. To get the most out of this course, you need to be willing to share personal experiences, engage with the texts, and connect with classmates. The class almost takes on a seminar form so participation is crucial. The work is very manageable – not something to stress about. Greg is the best if you get to know him. It is worth it to make the effort and will make the class even more enjoyable! A great class for someone who is interested in social media effects, likes to discuss with classmates, and is willing to wake up for a 9am (participation is big!)
subject: Sociology
course_title_2023: The Internet, Social Media, and Society

course_title: Sociology in the Age of Big Data 001
best_comment: This is an amazing class!! Pretty light but definitely so so informative. Would highly recommend if you have any interest in sociology research or big data's applications in today's society. It can be boring for some though, so make sure you actually are interested. The instructors for this course are all great! The professor is super nice and generally approachable! Definitely would recommend making use of his office hours, he's very helpful during them and will essentially give you the answers to the lab if you're checking over your answers with him. My TF was also so so amazing and really helpful. I didn't talk to him as much, but he always made himself available for discussion after section and would crack jokes. Overall, an AMAZING class!!
best_gem_comment: Gem: Interesting topic, grading is generous.

course_title: Student Leadership and Service in Higher Education 001
best_comment: I would highly recommend Sociology 1130, especially if you've enjoyed other interactive classes like Expos 40 and freshman seminars. Manja and Catherine as a teaching team provide the most welcoming, helpful, and kind environment I have found in a Harvard class. Just as importantly, the group of students is incredibly inspiring, and the class allows you to learn from them throughout. This class really pushed me to reflect more on myself as a leader, my experiences at Harvard, and my goals for the future.
subject: Sociology
course_title_2023: Student Leadership and Service in Higher Education

best_comment: This class is absolutely incredible: it will challenge you, it will keep you thinking, and it will ease you into economics and sociology in a meaningful way. At the helm is someone who cares about your well–being, is incredibly understanding, and illustrates concepts in some of the most inventive ways I have ever experienced. Dr. Leah's classroom presence is unmatched, and it was a joy to experience her course in person because she is full of this contagious energy and passion. The course is an opportunity to grow and be exposed to some very timely discussions: about corruption, competition, brokers, and the functionality of networks. I took just as much away from this course conceptually as I did practically, and I loved every moment of it!
worse_comment: If you like economics, but always felt that there was something missing, this is the course for you. Economic sociology dives into all of the complexities of humans in society that economics alone ignores and you will enjoy learning from Dr. Leah about it.
subject: Sociology

course_title: Race and Ethnicity in Global and Comparative Perspective 001
best_comment: This is a great way to learn about race! It's a chill and interesting introduction to an important topic. Take this class, regardless of how much you think you know about race and ethnicity.

course_title: Public Opinion Formation and Change in the United States and Abroad 001
best_comment: Take this class if you're at all interested in public opinion! Yuval is chill but incredibly knowledgeable on the topic, and every assignment was a group assignment, which seems daunting at first but is very manageable. Bi–weekly presentations and two extremely short essays are all that is required in this course, and the readings actually capture a great overview of the mode of public opinion formation that is being concentrated on that week. A fun but rewarding class that I actually took something away from.

course_title: Online Dating and the Transformation of Intimacy 001
best_comment: this class just needs to be a bit better organized but other than that it's a wonderful fun easy class where you discuss things that are extremely relevant to you and learn a lot about a topic that should be discussed more––relationships and why they are so crucial and how they affect different communities! the semesterlong research project is a great way to study an app or concept about dating that interests you and it can seem daunting but everyone's projects turned out great.

This course focuses on a lot of conflicts within the context of cities; if you want to understand cities better, take this course. I would only recommend this course to concentrators in sociology or a related social science field.

Definitely a lot of work, strict grading at the start of the year, need to do readings to stay on top of class –– but overall one of my favorite classes. really pushes you to think critically about issues within Black communities, and is a great overview of the major historical points of Black history. Rivers is a really great professor, will help you grow as a thinker, and really cares about her students
worse_comment: This class was extremely engaging and provided a survey of the sociology of Black America, commencing with slavery all the way up to the Black Lives Matter Movement.

course_title: Climate Change, Power, and Global Inequality 001
best_comment: Ben is a really great professor and does an excellent job spreading out conversation and classroom discussion among the students there.

course_title: Culture and Inclusion in a More Unequal America 001
best_comment: Not all of the greatest scholars are the greatest teachers. This class is compelling on some ways: the readings are great (though perhaps too academic), the ideas themselves thought–provoking, and your peers will likely help you work through and discuss the concepts. However, the structure of the class means it isn't great; it is both too academic and disjointed to be an effective intro class, but also too surface–level to be great for those with a strong background as well. As for Lamont, she improved in teaching over the course of the semester, but it's clear she is used to teaching grad students and the main class never really felt like it got there; lectures in particular did not do a great job explaining concepts in clear terms with helpful examples, but rather felt like a list of different related ideas and the books about those ideas. Lamont is also very experienced in the academic institution, which means that certain topics and ideas (there was a lot of backlash towards her handling of the Comaroff letter and her teaching style in general) may cause tension.
Take it! Definitely take it. Professor Garza is great and you will improve your own work and ways of dealing with digital methods.

course_title: Analysis of Longitudinal Data: Seminar SEM
best_comment: This is a very tough course, but worth it if you can put in the time and effort.  It requires a lot of self study to digest very dense material, but the teaching team are incredibly kind and supportive.  It’s also a wonderful chance to work on independent research in a supportive environment and received very detailed feedback.  Overall, I’d recommend this course as long as your schedule permits the long hours.
worse_comment: Take this course!! Sasha is an incredible teacher and you will leave with a whole new understanding of regression + model assumptions.

course_title: Inequality at Work: Contemporary Problems and Policy Solutions 001
best_comment: This class covers a variety of topics of workplace arrangements and is super rich in content.

Literally the greatest class at Harvard. Unquestionably my favorite class. Being in class is fun and ENTERTAINING. You will laugh everyday because Richard Ji is hilarious and never fails to keep everyone engaged. If you are deciding between this and another language class, TAKE HINDI! Best decision of my Harvard career so far. Richard Delacy is the GOAT of GOATs. Stop wasting time reading this review, just enroll already. Do it. Trust me.
subject: Hindi-Urdu

best_comment: Richard ji is the funniest, eccentric professor with a great depth of knowledge of the language and culture. It's truly a treat to learn with him and I am consistently encouraged to continue through, even when I feel like I'm at a dead end. All he cares about is our learning in the most authentic of ways.
subject: Hindi-Urdu

best_comment: Sanskrit 101B does an amazing job building off the concepts from 101A. At the end of the class you look back and go "woah!" The amount of hard and soft concepts I learned in Sanskrit  was honestly very impressive. I could never imagine that I could go from not knowing a single bit of Sanskrit or Devanagari (the script) to reading and comprehending passages/short stories and writing my very own story/poem! Definitely take Sanskrit! As always, Nell did an amazing job this semester, and could not imagine the class being taught without her. Her expertise, enthusiasm, and flexibility made the class such an enjoyable time.
subject: Sanskrit

best_comment: Overall, I thought this tutorial was a great course to begin thinking about how to communicate the statistical concepts we've learned so far. The professors are so helpful, approachable, and kind, and made the course such a wonderful learning environment. There are three main assignments that help you develop your writing, presenting, and simulation skills. There are plenty of collaborative sessions throughout the semester for students to read each other's work and give constructive feedback. The only downsides were that sometimes the grading would be unclear/harsh and cause stress among the students. I was also under the impression that the tutorial would also help you find a thesis topic/advisor, which didn't turn out to be true. You do get to know the professors quite well though, giving you more opportunity to ask them about writing a thesis (if that's what you're interested in).
subject: Statistics

best_comment: Overall, I thought this tutorial was a great course to begin thinking about how to communicate the statistical concepts we've learned so far. The professors are so helpful, approachable, and kind, and made the course such a wonderful learning environment. There are three main assignments that help you develop your writing, presenting, and simulation skills. There are plenty of collaborative sessions throughout the semester for students to read each other's work and give constructive feedback. The only downsides were that sometimes the grading would be unclear/harsh and cause stress among the students. I was also under the impression that the tutorial would also help you find a thesis topic/advisor, which didn't turn out to be true. You do get to know the professors quite well though, giving you more opportunity to ask them about writing a thesis (if that's what you're interested in).
subject: Statistics

course_title: Introduction to Statistics and Data Science 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! I CANNOT SAY THIS ENOUGH, BUT AN AMAZING CLASS! I learnt more in this class than any other. Loved this course! Probably my favorite class in the college yet. The psets are easy, and the midterm is basically the same as the PSETS. Kelly is an AMAZING professor and person– she teaches really well and really cares about you and your progress. There were probably over 200 people in the class and she made an effort to learn every single one of our names. You don't need any experience with coding or statistics– I had none and ended up learning A LOT.  She takes the class slow and explains everything.
worse_comment: Second half of course is much more difficult. It's also the type of class where you're gonna wanna turn up to class/watch lectures to really know what's going on, otherwise you may just get lost.
subject: Statistics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Statistics and Data Science

course_title: Introduction to Statistics for Life Sciences 001
best_comment: I would highly recommend this class – it is a good idea to go to both lecture and section – because helps to make the material a lot easier to understand. Also, study break is the best and I highly recommend it!
worse_comment: I don't think it is as bad as the other stat classes...
subject: Statistics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Statistics for Life Sciences

course_title: Introduction to Statistics for Life Sciences 001
best_comment: I would highly recommend this class – it is a good idea to go to both lecture and section – because helps to make the material a lot easier to understand. Also, study break is the best and I highly recommend it!
worse_comment: I don't think it is as bad as the other stat classes...
subject: Statistics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Statistics for Life Sciences

course_title: Introduction to Quantitative Methods for Economics 001
best_comment: This class is a decent amount of work, but there are plenty of resources available to help you with it. If you put in the time, you will see results. Make sure to always do the practice tests for the exams, since those give you a very good idea of what to expect on the actual exam.
worse_comment: if you take this course, be prepared to spend a lotttttttt of time on it. it is very difficult but you can make do if you have the time and energy to commit to it. I took it as a sociology concentrator who's not that into statistics/math, but it turned out to be fine. reach out to course instructors or the ARC if you're having trouble (and reach out sooner rather than later!) I had the most difficult time when I would skip lecture
subject: Statistics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Quantitative Methods for Economics

best_comment: Hot take: I liked Stat 111 more than Stat 110. I didn't dislike 110, in fact, I really enjoyed it, but I felt like there was something missing. Stat 111 was the missing piece and made taking 110 completely worth it. This course is similarly structured super well like Stat 110, with organized lectures, tons of great sections, office hours, wonderful TFs, a GREAT textbook that's only getting better, and assignments that neither feel too tedious nor too easy. Felt like the right level of difficulty, which is definitely REALLY hard, don't get me wrong, but I think if you put the time and energy into this course you can definitely succeed. It's not a weed–out class like CS 124, nor is it an easy–ish intro class like CS 50. This class is the real deal, but it's definitely worth taking. I think statistics is perhaps the single most useful quantitative subject to learn as it applied to EVERYTHING and really changes how you think about the world, like for real. Also, I thought Neil was a great professor. Definitely a slow lecturer, but he is SO nice, super communicative, and listens to students' concerns, and adjusts the course on the fly accordingly. I wanted to drop the course after the first week because I thought it would be too hard, but was convinced to stay in it, and I'm so glad I did. First three weeks (outside of the midterm and final, which were hard but very reasonable tbh) were definitely the most difficult, but then it stays at a constant difficulty level. Second half of the course is also even more interesting than the first, so stick with it! Also, don't be scared of the R portion of the class, it's really not that bad—lowkey the R questions were the easiest and most fun, I really looked forward to them by the end.TLDR: take this course, it's sick, go to section, go to OH, read the textbook, and ball tf out. You got this champ
worse_comment: I just took the final for this class. Right after I finished this final, I immediately started drinking. I'm not sober as I'm filling this out. The fact that I am drinking has a lot to do with the stress of this class. I'm drunk in my room by myself filling out the q guide because of Stat 111. Be prepared to be confused a lot.
subject: Statistics

best_comment: This class is amazing! Professor Parmigiani really cares about his students and wants them to have engaging discussion around the course material. There is also lots of support for assignments, and there is not really any super high pressure to be perfect. The structure of the course forms a community. Participating in the class regularly is very rewarding, and I felt myself learning a lot of practical knowledge about how to operate in this field with biomarkers. I wish I could take a course like this every year, I think it was one of my favorite ones at Harvard that I've ever taken. The main message: excellent professor and TF, not super high stress assignments, and you still learn a lot.
worse_comment: I took this class because I had heard good things about it in previous years, but the quality has drastically decreased this year. If Xiang is your TF, STAY AWAY. The content is not inherently difficult to grasp, but somehow the TF made it more confusing than necessary and would refuse to answer questions about the problem sets during office hours. He also had very arbitrary grading, which turned this stat "gem" into a bit of a stresser class. I think if there's a new TF, it would be worth giving this class another shot, but I had a terrible experience in this class.
subject: Statistics

course_title: Data Science 2: Advanced Topics in Data Science 001
best_comment: Honestly, this is a fantastic course. I know people may have qualms about the last few problem sets, but the topics were extremely topical and relevant to modern machine learning/data science literature. Topics like GANs, Word2Vec, BERT (transformers),  and hierarchical linear models are invaluable in my repertoire of skills and tools. While the psets could definitely be strengthened, I can't be mad at one of the few courses at Harvard that actually touch the edge of state of the art techniques. This class was a much needed breather from the vast amount of tiring classes that still cover support vector machines (and call it modern machine learning) and require pages of mathematical proofs. CS109b/AC209b gave me a ton of practice in just programming machine learning algorithms in Tensorflow and Pymc3, reading documentation, and doing cool projects on topics that are still being actively researched. After this class, I can go to any job or task and feel confident in applying these skills, while learning more on the way.
worse_comment: This class was quite a mess. The questions/ instructions on the assignments are incredibly unclear, so you usually waste so much time trying to figure out what you're supposed to do. This would be somewhat okay if the course staff would clarify questions quickly, but they were very nonresponsive on Ed and would not respond to any questions over the weekend. They were also incredibly selective in which Ed posts they would answer, which made me feel like members of the course staff didn't even know what was going on. It felt like the students were shouting at a brick wall when trying to get help.Several of the homework assignment toward the end of the class were ridiculously difficult and in some cases impossible –– I wasted ~20 hours once because the code the course staff provided to us was literally impossible to run and would not work. I often feel like students complain too much, but I think it was very warranted for this class. It was incredibly frustrating to spend over 40 hours on a homework assignment simply because students didn't know what the problem was actually asking them to do. Not to mention, there were so many typos in the homeworks. The undergrad TFs didn't seem super familiar with the assignments, but they did try to help when they could.Poor Chris Gumb needs a raise because he carried the class, and whoever wrote the assignments that made the experience so difficult for him should take him out to lunch
