best_comment: Stat 123 is challenging but incredibly rewarding. The course's content is extremely interesting, and you will come away from this course with a fresh perspective on probability, finance, trading, and (at least in my case) life! Stat 123 is easily one of the best courses that I've taken so far, and I have no doubt that it will remain a defining experience of my  Harvard journey. Above all else (and I cannot emphasize this enough): Professor Blyth is amazing. He takes great care in ensuring that the material is delivered in a way that fosters true learning, but I have also learned from him so much that surpasses the boundaries of course content. Though this is the last offering of Stat 123 at Harvard,  I hope this review will serve as one of many testaments to the immensely positive impact that Professor Blyth has on his students.  He also brings chocolate to class :)
worse_comment: This class was super sick, shame y'all won't get to take it/take it with Blyth

best_comment: This class is very fair, very important, and all around manageable and useful! I would recommend.
worse_comment: it was kind of a real mess this year so youll probably want to shop this course first to see if it's still lacking
subject: Statistics

best_comment: STAT149 is an excellent class, and I would highly recommend you take it. Professor Glickman is an amazing teacher: he explains concepts very clearly, he responds to emails/questions promptly,  his slides/notes were helpful, and he clearly cares a lot about the course.  Grades/feedback on assignments were always released quickly, and I thought the marking was strict but fair. The course involves quite a bit of work, but I always felt like there was more than enough time to get the assignments done as they were well spaced out: problem sets were only due every two weeks and Professor Glickman would always release them early, plus there was ample time to prepare for exams and complete the project. However, the biggest pro of this course is that its content is extremely useful. We covered so many different types of models, which is refreshing after most of the mandatory stat classes up until this point have focused on linear regression.
subject: Statistics

best_comment: This is an incredibly interesting course! The material is really beautiful (at times), and if you have the bandwidth for it, you should definitely consider it!I took this as a fifth class (not the biggest mistake but whatever), and didn't really go to lecture. Subha is a wonderful professor and a kind person, but most of the lectures feel like they come straight from the textbook (a notable exception being the ones on Markov Chain Monte Carlo). This isn't really the worst thing – the textbook is wonderful in my opinion – but it makes the value proposition of a 9am lecture not great. Similarly for sections. That being said, I went to CA office hours regularly (shoutout to David and Christine) and found a ton of support and camaraderie in the class.The psets are a good mix too. I personally like the probability side of the class (i.e. Poisson processes, Brownian motion, Ito calculus) far more than the computational side (Markov chains, Metropolis–Hastings, etc.), so I enjoyed the latter half of the class exponentially more than the front half. The first couple psets are quite bashy, and the fourth pset on MCMC is literally all in R (you should be ready to learn R, because you'll be using it liberally), but the rest are generally fine, and often quite elegant.Finally, the exams are hard, and they're a big chunk of your grade. If I had known how hard, I would have seriously considered not taking the class – unlike the psets, which are almost entirely textbook questions, the exams are hard because you have to apply course concepts in ways that were really never explained or described in lecture/section. If you're not used to that (for ref., lots of people in the course took stat 210 before this or are upperclassmen stats concentrators), the exams will be hard – I'm a potential math concentrator who took three other math/stat classes, and they definitely were my hardest exams. Even having them be open–book exams was not nearly as much help as you'd think. If you're down to learn the material, don't let the exams discourage you. Just be warned.
worse_comment: I liked that I learned a lot of abstract concepts for the many stochastic processes that were covered, but I didn't like how abstract it was since I felt like I would not easily be able to apply or use the things I learned. I think the professor is really nice and genuinely cares for students, but I despised the fact that this class is graded based on 75% tests (2 midterms and a final). Given that tests are a huge portion of your grade, I feel like this course did not help me improve my problem solving skills at all. I felt like the support for actually solving problems related to the processes was lacking. Lectures were nice and organized and helped me understand 'big ideas', but there was a huge jump between understanding the concepts and solving the problems on problem sets and homeworks. The problem sets are really long at the beginning of the course, and the types of problems on the homeworks and the exams are so different. I joined this class right after taking STAT110 and felt like most people in this class were very experienced in math and stats, so I felt like a lot of skills were assumed. There weren't any practice exams for the tests and I just generally felt very lost in how to do well on the exams.
subject: Statistics

best_comment: I loved this course! I learned the theory and application of causal inference rigorously. I found the textbook to be clearly written, lecture was helping in building on the textbook material, and homework was concise (a management amount) and a good balance of conceptual questions, simulations, and proofs. Professor Murphy is enthusiastic and shares insights and examples from the research world (health, economics, social sciences, etc.) during lecture. I also really appreciated the homework group structure; I made some new friends and felt comfortable having collaborators on each homework; in–class discussions were interesting.

This course focuses on the statistical side of ML, which means you focus on considering the characteristics of datasets and how different ML methods would perform on them, and learning lots of theorems and doing lots of math.  If you took MIT 6.036 (which I did), this course is almost nothing like it. 195 also basically just follows the textbook. If you're really interested in theoretical ML topics but can't motivate yourself to learn it on your own, this course may be for you. But otherwise, it'll probably fall short of your expectations. Pretty much the only part of the course I found quite interesting were the no free lunch problems on the PSETs where you run simulations to basically find different scenarios in which certain ML methods outperform another and try to explain why.  Otherwise, PSETs were tedious math and not that related to stuff from lecture. Sections mainly covered topics that weren't covered in lecture, so you don't get a chance to review and thoroughly understand the topics. Lastly, the literature review component of the course does expose you to ML research, but the key word is expose––tbh I understood <5% of the different papers that everyone presented and am still not sure what types of ML research are most interesting to me or how the stuff we learned can be applied to my own ML research. Overall, not a bad course (grading is lenient if that's something that matters to you), but the material can feel pretty disorganized and disconnected.
worse_comment: This course was truly awful, one of the worst I've taken at Harvard. I enjoyed CS 181 and so I was excited to continue learning about machine learning by taking this course. I fully regret the decision to take it. Here are the reasons why:– Pragya just lectures from the textbook (Elements of Statistical Learning), but she is less clear than the textbook.  You're better off just reading the textbook on your own – The problem sets are a complete waste of time. Instead of allow us to practice using concepts or methods from the course, Pragya's problem sets basically just asked us to try to come up with pathological corner cases that contradict common sense that applies to 99.9% of real world cases. These problems appeared on every single problem set and it was such a headache to try to come up with some stupid counterexample that provided zero insight about machine learning. Then when I saw the problem solutions, there would be absolutely nothing insightful about the solution. It was just simply about whether you were clever enough to come up with some stupid pathological distribution and function that happened to break common sense. It made me so angry to have to slave away for 10 hours to try to come up with these pathological counterexamples and these problems appeared on EVERY PROBLEM SET. And these problems were instead of actually practicing the course material. It just felt like Pragya was so tickled by these mathematical curios and wanted to force every student to be tickled by the same things, when theoretical corner cases are usually NOT what people want to learn about machine learning– The two projects are also a waste of time. Every group gets assigned a theory paper and presents it. The presentations are all completely comprehensible because everyone is trying to explain an academic paper's worth of math that is too high level for the class in only 10 minutes. I learned absolutely nothing from anyone's presentation. I'm sure there are some geniuses in the class who probably did learn something, and so if you're one of those geniuses, by all means, take this class.

best_comment: if you really like probability and like it for the theory, take it. but if you are like me (more limited math background) be prepared to do a lot of extra work. by that i just mean outside of hw and lecture. hw is biweekly which is dangerous because you don't spend as much time as you should on the class. prof austern is extremely helpful and cares quite a bit + is available to help!
worse_comment: The problem sets were very manageable, but the material presented in lecture is difficult. Expect to spend time outside of class reviewing lecture notes to understand what was going on. The midterm and final were also difficult.
subject: Statistics

best_comment: Good continuation to Stat 211. Helps bridge you to modern research topics.  Strong mathematical preparation in measure theory, real analysis and linear algebra is recommended
worse_comment: Stat 213 is a very rigorous and mathematical treatment of statistical inference –– it is far more mathematically intensive and detail–oriented than 211. To me, the topics didn't feel super interesting or important, although I appreciate that they are foundational. There are also no course notes or recordings, so keeping up with lectures is important.
subject: Statistics

best_comment: The pre–class quizzes were a strange experience – a month into the term, I (and many others) were doing the readings during the quizzes, instead of before them. I definitely did poorly on some later quizzes (especially the math–oriented ones), but most were conceptually oriented and straightforward. Based on this course, I now believe that RL is a fairly repetitive field, and probably not for me.The classes themselves were pretty entertaining. Professor Murphy is really dynamic and clearly loves the content, and makes the class very conversational. Breakout sessions are much less intimidating than they sound, and just involve talking to the people around you about a short, conceptual question (though it may still be very difficult). Sometimes, people from the Murphy group would come and present to get feedback, which was again very cool, though it would often be  Professor Murphy and the TFs turning it into a pseudo–lab meeting.The project is basically the entire grade. I would definitely suggest putting substantial work into it early and making something you're proud of, since this defines your experience in the class. There is support from the course staff to help you along the way. The poster session and writeup are just opportunities for you to show off the work you've done.
subject: Biostatistics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Data Structures and Algorithms

course_title: Design of Experimental and Non-experimental Studies 001
best_comment: Stat 293 is a great course. The teaching staff, led by Jose and Larry, are fantastic – they take great care to walk through the difficult material and are very patient and supportive. The set of papers is very interesting and fundamental for a strong understanding of research and applications of causal inference and experimental design methods. The course itself is also quite flexible in terms of assignments, which were all helpful in building understanding of the material. I would strongly recommend the course!
subject: Statistics
course_title_2023: Design of Experimental and Non-experimental Studies

course_title: Building a Human Body: From Gene to Cell to Organism 001
best_comment: omg please take this class!!! literally my favorite class that I've taken at harvard so far. the teaching staff might be the most wonderful people at this college and the labs are interesting. there aren't any exams either!! the 4 take home module assessments are pretty difficult, but you get to work with others and the office hours are SO HELPFUL! definitely try to go to as many as you can for the assessments. again the teaching staff are amazing and really make this course so wonderful. again my favorite class I love it so much.
worse_comment: Not my favorite class

course_title_2023: Building a Human Body: From Gene to Cell to Organism

best_comment: This course is awesome. Kara cares so much about the students taking the class and she really wants to make sure that everyone is understanding what is going on. This course focuses not only on reproductive biology, but it also gives you tools to become better at designing experiments and hypotheses. Overall, even if reproductive biology isn't something you are super interested in, you come away having learned so much. That all being said, the content is super cool. You learn so much that isn't taught in other classes at Harvard. This class does a great job at tying together both the scientific side of science as well as the ethical side of science. Overall, this was an amazing class, and I strongly recommend taking it.
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol

course_title: From Cells to Tissues, in Sickness and in Health 001
best_comment: Take this class!!!! It was so much fun, I feel like I really learned a lot, and Professor Hsu was amazing. She has so much energy, explains things super clearly, and it shows how much she cares about her students. The content was really interesting and spanned a lot of different areas of cell bio (such as the circadian rhythm and how it relates to tissue regeneration). We also had 6 paper discussions throughout the semester, and while they're dense, as any publication is, they're really helpful for thinking more critically about science and not always taking conclusions at face value. Overall, I would recommend this course with enthusiasm!

course_title: Epigenetics and Gene Regulation of Human Development and Disease 01
best_comment: This class provided a fantastic foundation in the world of epigenetics and gave me an exciting glimpse into the diverse field of epigenetic research! The p–sets pushed me to apply the concepts we learned in class in new and different ways, and the computational project at the end gave me a taste of the exciting world of research within the epigenetic community. Jason is an awesome professor, who makes you so excited about the cool content and is so patient with questions after class; Caroline and Andrew (our TFs) are the coolest and kindest TFs I've had in my time at Harvard. If you're looking for a challenging and enriching dive into epigenetics, please 1000% take this class!!

course_title: A World of RNA: An RNA-centric view of life 01
best_comment: Take this class!!! Professor Flynn is so knowledgeable about RNA biology and you will learn a lot from him. This class is especially helpful if you have any interest in RNA research, since much of the course focuses on the methods which enabled novel discoveries in RNA biology. After this course, I feel much more confident in designing my own experiments and reading the literature. The week–to–week workload is minimal, so it's a good class to balance out a busy semester. There are two problem sets and a final proposal, which each took a decent amount of work, but besides that, all you need to do each week is read a paper and come to class. Overall, a great course with a great professor. I would definitely recommend it.
worse_comment: This class is very interesting but beware. The grading sucks. The problem sets were way too hard, harshly graded on random details, and the proposal was also graded very harshly. Participation scores they gave were so bad. The professor I think wants to give everyone As but the grading is so unfair.
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol
course_title_2023: A World of RNA: An RNA-centric view of life

course_title: Stem Cell Therapeutics: Exploring the science and the patient experience 01
best_comment: This is a very one–of–a–kind course that is only possible at a place like Harvard, where we are so grateful to have so many opportunities and resources. When else can you have world–class researchers and physicians giving rotating talks and interviewing patients (bringing in patients who are so excited to talk to the class... and having the chance to ask any questions you would like to all the speakers)? Add onto this already amazing experience the opportunity to write a grant and learn how to do this from leading experts in the fields (and also be able to ask any mentoring–related questions.)
worse_comment: This class is worth it but the grading makes the class more stressful than it needs to be
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol
course_title_2023: Stem Cell Therapeutics: Exploring the science and the patient experience

best_comment: This class has been my favorite class I have taken in college so far. It was super helpful and very enjoyable.

course_title: How To Make My Fantasies Come True or Making a Show Where No One Stoops and None Are Conquered 001
best_comment: This class is really dependent on whoever the guest artist is. This year we had a great teaching staff, but I cannot say that I enjoyed the actual course material, nor can I say that I felt artistically fulfilled or stretched by this play. Regardless if you have a lead role or 2 lines in the show, it's going to be a HUGE time commitment so plan to not do any other shows that semester.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media
course_title_2023: Bodies and the Metaverse: Performing "The Singularity Play"

best_comment: If you are even considering the course, take it. LROD is by far the best instructor I have had in 4 years at Harvard and she (and Jessi and the other students) make this course so worthwhile. Be prepared to work hard in the studio and plan ahead for tech week/performances because they are time consuming, but this is an experience that you will not get anywhere else at Harvard or even outside of Harvard. This was a highlight of my 4 years of college and I wish I could go back in time and take it every year. A kind, supportive community—so much stronger than I expected going in. I made friends through this class while also learning from people, which rarely happens in academics here. I can't even begin to express how happy I am that I took this class. I grew as a dancer and personally, met amazing people, and know that anyone who takes the class will grow from whatever their starting point is.
worse_comment: If you danced heavily in high school and miss learning and performing choreo from choreographers, take this class. You will find a community in It.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

best_comment: This is an AMAZING class. If you have no acting experience, don't worry –– this class is so accessible, and Marcus and Ashleigh are incredibly supportive, kind, and there to help you succeed. This class definitely requires work: be prepared to memorize, think critically about the best roles for you, etc. –– but it is so rewarding. You will gain a better sense of who you are, what motivates/drives the world around you, and what acting is really about: acting from yourself/your life experiences. The class is small and intimate, and everyone becomes friends. I'm so glad I took this class before I graduated.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

best_comment: Take this class! If you have any interest in performing and auditioning during or after college this class will set you up for success. Remo is incredibly passionate about teaching, and he creates the most supportive environment for this kind of solo acting work.

Definitely take this class.  Erika is just so kind and approachable and has really good advice.  Every time i asked her a question she made sure that the answer was thorough and applicable.  Also the material is just really good
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! (1) the class is enjoyable and engaging and the instructor & TF are wonderful; (2) the assignments are fun and the course material is really interesting and exciting; (3) this class will be very very challenging, intellectually, creatively, and in terms of time management, but don't worry, you will definitely get a good grade if you put in the work; (4) be prepared to not really know what or when the assignments are until like a couple of weeks before; (5) overall you will learn a lot and have a great time doing it! NOTE: the final assignment performance is like the second day of reading week instead of during finals... there is barely enough time to prepare. good luck! (Seriously, though, it's a great class and you should take it!)
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

best_comment: This class is super fun and very rewarding! You will move your body in a way that feels good to you and make genuine connections with your classmates. This class is super special and one of my favorite parts of Harvard so far.

course_title: Embodied Intelligences: Koteba, Lindy Hop, Hip Hop, Philosophies & Culture 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! this class is amazing, it's challenging in the beginning but you learn so much. Jeffrey is an amazing teacher and super nice. Definitely don't miss this one
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

course_title: Performing Culture: Exploring Identity and Power Through Hip Hop Dance 001
best_comment: You HAVE TO take this class during your Harvard Career. It is such a different type of environment and course than any other course at Harvard. You actually get to dance and feel and learn more about your body. You also become best friends with everyone in your class. I never really danced before this class but after taking this class, I fell in love with dance and hip hop, and will definitely continue taking classes. Further, if you are interested in hip hop and learning about its culture and roots, this is the class with you. Regardless of gender, experience, etc. you will feel at home and safe. It is such an easy, chill, welcoming class, YOU HAVE TO TAKE IT

course_title: Directorial Concepts and Set Design of the 20th and 21st Centuries 001
best_comment: This class is great and super chill. One design presentation based on a play, one really short and chill presentation in the Harvard Art Museums about an artist or artistic movement, and the final design presentation at the end of the semester.  We also took a day trip to NYC to see two shows which was really fun!

This is definitely not a class to miss, take it if you have any interest! Prof. Howze is truly a wonderful artist and teacher who cares so much about everyone he teaches. While there wasn't too much in terms of feedback, I felt that this was a really important and worthwhile experience for me as an artist. If you have any interest, even if it'd just be for fun, you should take this class!
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

best_comment: If you want to learn looping –– take this class! I feel like I not only expanded my musicianship, met new people, tried new things, etc. I really did come out of this class feeling comfortable with a totally new skill/"instrument", which feels really applicable to all of my other art. It's as intense as you make it, which at least for me, is a great structure, and gave me a lot of freedom week to week (some weeks more time, others less, the teacher is understanding) –– Brian is so cool and chill and also super talented and supportive. We need more classes with this energy at Harvard!

course_title: The Power and Relevance of the American Musical: 1776 and Other Musicals 001
best_comment: It's a fun, low–stress class if you're passionate about musicals. Diane is a great resource but is not always present in class. The assignments are fun but there isn't enough time to present them properly. It was great seeing the evolution of 1776 through the director's eyes and see it on stage as well.

course_title: The Power and Relevance of the American Musical: 1776 and Other Musicals 001
best_comment: It's a fun, low–stress class if you're passionate about musicals. Diane is a great resource but is not always present in class. The assignments are fun but there isn't enough time to present them properly. It was great seeing the evolution of 1776 through the director's eyes and see it on stage as well.

A great foundational course to seminal (and emerging!) authors in WGS. Manifestos, prose, theory, poetry–– a great variety and interesting syllabus for sure.
subject: Women, Gender & Sexuality

course_title: Tutorial - Junior Year: Research and Methods 001
best_comment: This is a great course to prepare you for senior thesising and a great opportunity to spend a semester working on a project you are passionate about. I felt so supported, personally and academically, in this class and was given the tools to create a project I cared about and was really proud of.
subject: Women, Gender & Sexuality
course_title_2023: Tutorial - Junior Year: Research and Methods

best_comment: I enjoyed this course a lot! I loved being able to discuss new afrofuturist literature each week and having an amazing discussion about theories in race and sexuality that were relevant to the books. However, I will add that it sometimes is hard to keep up with the amount you must read per week. Each book is over 300 pages, so I would not take this course unless you have ample time (10+ hours per week) to digest these lengthy books as I believe this course deserves full attention. I loved the professor and hope to keep in contact with him after this course ends!

course_title: Leaning In, Hooking Up: Visions of Feminism and Femininity in the 21st Century 001
best_comment: This is a good course to take if you think of yourself as a feminist but don't yet feel well–versed in intersectional feminism. I would recommend this course to anyone looking for an introduction to the field, but don't expect to come out of it as an expert. That being said, it is definitely worth taking a course with Professor Thompson, who is incredibly eloquent, thoughtful, thought–provoking, and inspirational to say the least. I know that most of my peers would say that this class is not to be missed. I would say the assignments are pretty reasonable.
worse_comment: This class provides very intersectional insight into how our society functions from small interactions to large systems. Learning about feminism can shed more light on more aspects of life in America (consumerism, the workplace, violence, politics, etc.) than I could have imagined. Take it!
subject: Women, Gender & Sexuality
course_title_2023: Leaning In, Hooking Up: Visions of Feminism and Femininity in the 21st Century

course_title: Gender, Race, and Poverty in the United States 001
best_comment: I have wanted to take this class since freshman year, and I was not disappointed. This class was phenomenal and I highly recommend it to anyone interested. The course material was disturbing but extremely interesting; the readings were long but engaging, and the teaching staff was the best I have ever had here. The weekly reflection posts and final project allowed you to talk about whatever you wanted as long as it related to the course material, which was a great way to get us to think more about what we had learned. The class also was super interesting in general, and we had cool guest speakers to help us research for our final paper. I truly loved this class; it's probably among my favorites ever here.
best_gem_comment: This class is a gem! You will not regret taking this course at all. Professor Mtshali, and TF's Naohito and Chandra are brilliant teachers with genuine enthusiasm in this field that make the learning experience very enjoyable.
subject: Women, Gender & Sexuality
course_title_2023: Gender, Race, and Poverty in the United States

course_title: Indigenous Feminisms: Environmental Justice and Resistance 001
best_comment: This course was incredible! Every week we looked at a different recent feminist Indigenous environmental justice movement. The material was manageable— Professor Hogue assigned amazing readings, as well as a broad and exciting array of music videos, art, poetry, short films, etc. Throughout the class, we were attentive to the categories of gender and sexuality, which I really appreciated. Professor Hogue did such a beautiful job creating a space in which people felt safe enough to have rigorous, risky, and deep conversations each week. We also got to hear from many absolutely incredible guest speakers— Indigenous women activists, artists, thinkers; settler allies supporting essential decolonial work.  Everybody should take this class, particularly those with commitments to environmental justice, decolonization, thinking beyond white feminisms, building beyond racial/carceral capitalism/settler colonialism (which are commitments everyone should have!).

I wish more people could take it! This class gave me a new lens to look at the world through. In other WGS classes, I've been frustrated with the high–level theory and lack of obvious applicability, but this class mixed both! I was taking Ec10B at the same time as this class and I'm so glad I was exposed to these alternative economic ideas. We take so much for granted about the economy and the world around us, I really really liked the diverse economies approach.
worse_comment: It can be difficult to get an A on assignments, and the later half of the course is a bit of a book club since we read through the entire textbook of "Take Back the Economy." It was also cool to read work that J.K. Gibson–Graham wrote, but it also meant we did not learn a lot of other perspectives.
